Recommended
114.0 hrs on record
Posted: 19 November, 2017
After several days of heavy playing and finally finishing the whole story, I'm bringing myself back here to write my very first game review. I started playing the AC series from AC2 which is an epic game. Besides the rises and falls of public opinion toward this brand name, I've always liked the past AC games (yes, even the Unity which everybody â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ on). Game makers are trying very hard to continue the story, and I truly appreciate their efforts.

Some of the best things about ACO that I really like:

1. Architecture. This is the best thing about AC games. For me, it's since I first "ran" across Venice Rooftops. I could just sit at the top of the Pyramid of Giza and stare at this fabulous world all day long.

2. Combat. Alright, I have complex feelings about this one. Combat is really hard compared to previous AC games, where you could basically just do counters and take down as many guards as there possibly are. Being surrounded would be a nightmare in ACO when you're not well-equipped enough. Luckily boss battles are not hell because you mostly only need to deal with one, and then you can truly analyze their attacking patterns and fight accordingly. BTW, I started using long-ranged predator bows to assassinate most of the normal guards. Super fun controlling the arrow in air and headshotting around the corner, and helps you avoid so much conflict.

3. Resource gathering. I think this is where the game makers really gave some thoughts. You never have excess money or resources, but you never lack a whole lot of them either. You won't have to spend a lot of time to gather some key resources for one or two important upgrade that might get you through one major quest. Super equipments are not hard to get either, Reda the You Also Grow Too Fast kid sells this chest in which legendary ranked stuff are not scarce. All these make the balance just about right between going through the main story and doing random training and gathering to leveling up.

4. Photo mode. Haha this one is just SUPER! This could keep some people playing for a long while. Now those beautiful sceneries would never be wasted again. And you have a bunch of options to play with to make your favorite photo. Also, you can see other amazing photos taken by other players as well in the map tab. Also, those photos might contain information about the location as well, sometimes useful.

5. Senu. She is the Origin of the Eagle Vision and she is the BEST so far. This system helps you locate objects, treasures, animals, enermies and even entrances, but you do have to manually scan the map to pin them all. Again, I think it's just about right in terms of balance.


That being said, some other not too positive thougts too.
6. Level system. This kind of started since Syndicate where the ability points system is introduced. But... you have to upgrade hidden blade damage, or otherwise you can't even do half hp damage to a high level captain or commander when "assassinating" from behind? That just feels weird. Thankfully leveling up and collecting material to upgrade, say your hidden blade (at least to a "usable" degree for your current mission) would not be too much of a hassle, otherwise this system would be really annoying.

7. Story.
7.1 I really liked Bayek's story, but I don't see why... alright I'm not turning myself into a spoiler. Anyways, I see others complaining that every AC game gives a new definition of the Creed, but I kinda disagree with that. Nobody said that game makers advocated what they where conveying through the characters. We see that in AC3 where the game itself spoke for Haythem's Templar logic and criticized Conner's brute work to some extent. The debate between ideologies never stopped, and as a game series, I think AC is still handling itself okay in this context. I believe that if you have played AC3 before, you would probably feel as I do that Bayek is not much better than Conner when Conner started his journey. But the idea Bayek and Aya put forward toward the end of ACO did make sense and was a good explanation for the Origin of the brotherhood. But besides from that, I still find the story lacking the impact I had when playing AC2, Revelations, Black Flag or Rogue.
7.2 In addition, the modern timeline didn't progress much either... I'm really not interested in picking up all the novels and stuff, and I know none of the characters in ACO except for William Miles (whom I only know as much as that he is Desmond's father). I'll just wait for the next AC game and see if the modern timeline could make any sense. I hope it does. Well, you could actually find clues in ACO but... Again, I'm not gonna be a spoiler.

8. Music. It's nowhere near bad. Actually I think it's good and immersive. But Venice Rooftops and Ezio's Family just couldn't be beaten.

To the end of this pile of rubbish I just talked, I like this game very much. But I guess that nobody actually cares, lol. Those who are not interested will probably still not buy this game after reading all those positive reviews, and those who are interested already bought and shot the sh*t out of Anubis haha. Good luck hunting hippos everybody!

Performance issues:

If you just bought the game recently at the time i'm writing this and you have performance issues on Nvdia cards, Know that it is an issue with the latest gpu driver (451.67). Download the older one from Nvidia's Website (446.14) and it will be solved. Unusual problem that can really ruin your experience specially if you just bought it so here is the fix.

Posted: 23 December, 2020
Finally, Ubisoft realized that it was ancientry that conceals the very Â«AssassinÂ» entourage of the first parts.

The tense political situation, unusual cultural flavor and aspects of Egyptian life literally saturated with mysterious religiosity made Origins one of the best events in the series from the time of first parts....
However, Origins is an amazing encyclopedia of culture in itself. And whoever says anything about Assassin's Creed, anyone will agree that only Ubisoft is engaged in such a thorough visualization of the era. And this time, the developers have outdone themselves.

It is impossible to express in a couple of paragraphs the delight that you experience when you rush through the bare desert on a camel, pass the villages teeming with life, visit the temples of Osiris and Set. When you get to Alexandria, and there you can go to the still unburnt library with thousands of manuscripts... Each region, each settlement, be it Memphis or Siwa, has its own artistic flavor, the diversity of which is amazing.

A Screenshot of Assassin's Creed Origins
By: fr0sent <3

The developers have endowed the Egyptians with many patterns of situational behavior. You enter the morgue, and the embalming bodies of the hard workers tell you about all the details of this procedure. In temples, people pray - in each in its own way, because the Egyptians, Greeks and Romans have gathered here. The guard, seeing the body of a colleague, will pick up the body and carry it somewhere. Random events are happening everywhere.

The game card is huge, but more importantly, it really feels like that. Constantly switching between Bayek and Seine and learning that there are people going about their business kilometers away from us, we find ourselves in the context of a really functioning, whole world. And it fully corresponds to our naive ideas about Ancient Egypt.
Each Â«towerÂ» offers stunning views, the territory of which seems limitless. But the most attractive thing about this is the horizon. After all, there are new cities, new landscapes and, most importantly, new adventures. This is exactly what we lacked in the last parts of Assassin's Creed.

Recommended
235.9 hrs on record
Posted: 12 January, 2020
My overall thoughts
Assassinâ€™s Creed Origins is an attempt to bring in new ideas by taking cues from the recent RPGs while trying to retain the soul of the series. To that attempt, I say it has succeeded. The vast expanse of Egypt is breathtaking. The new style of combat is amazing and the narrative has you dig deep into the origins of the Creed, the handbook of the worldâ€™s most spiritual killers. Iâ€™ve been always been an Assassinâ€™s creed apologist and even when playing unity and syndicate, I found many redeemable qualities.

However, the franchiseâ€™s lethargy soon rubbed off on me I was finally going to give up. I mean come on, I liked Unity but Syndicate came off nothing more than an attempt to rectify Unityâ€™s mistake. It made me want to assassinate the franchise. But that all changed with AC Origins, a game that I couldnâ€™t stop playing and finally made me fall in love with the Franchise again.

Plot

You follow Bayek of Siwa, an Egyptian badass and the last Medjay of Egypt. He is on the quest to avenge the death (I know) of his young son by the hands of â€œmasked onesâ€ â€“ an order of proto templars who you chase around all through Egypt. Along the way, you will meet characters such as the brotherly Phanos, the cowardly Ptolemy, the seductress Cleopatra and the conniving Julius Ceasar. The story is weaved in long and drawn-out quests whose pay off makes it almost worth it.

As you can guess, I like the story. While itâ€™s the same my-family-got-murdered-and-I-gotta-murder-the-murderer-too feel of the old games, I like the fact that here, the main character is a father. You see several layers of Bayek. He comes off as kind and playful to help-seekers and rage-filled god of death to the killers. The storytelling is fairly linear but that grips you from start to finish, with you hoping that in the end, Bayek finds some happiness.

Presentation
The vast expanse of Egypt is breath-taking. From the populated cities to depilated caves, from the mysterious pyramids to the historic Alexandria, every inch of recreated Egypt oozes care and detail. Itâ€™s further complemented by the game excellent lighting system, where you can feel the dizzying warmth of the sun as you run or cart over the land of this new playground. The water physics were the best of 2017 and 18, and even 20.

Gameplay

Combat

Combat has been completely overhauled in this game. The counter kill manoeuvres of the previous titles has been replaced by a hitbox mechanic. The combat is complemented by different classes of weapons including Staves, spears, regular sword, khopesh, dual daggers, maces and heavy swords. Each weapon has a unique weight behind it and provides a different way of playstyle.

Another major change in combat is the addition of ranged combat. You now have a bow and not just of a single kind. There is a multi-arrow-spitting warrior bow, a precise-hitting hunter bow, a scope-wielding predator bow and a fast and magnificent light bow. While predator and hunter bows are helpful in stealth, warrior and light bows scream style in combat sections.
The game allows you to equip to melee and two range weapons. Strategize, choose and switch them as per your playstyle anytime as you face challenges from enemies, both man and beasts.

Stealth

Continuing the â€œinnovationâ€ of a dedicated crouch button in Unity, AC origins gives you the ability to crouch behind your enemy as you stab him with your pre-assassin hidden blade. The addition of many ranged weapon options has you meticulously pick off your enemies from a distance. Stealth is satisfying â€“ giving you a rising feeling as you clear out a camp of Roman soldiers without even a single soul screaming.

Exploration

Egypt is vast, and I mean ridiculously vast. You can travel across horseback, camelback or chariot on the road for a faster traversal. On the river, you have boats. The seriesâ€™ staple parkour mechanics are back. However, they donâ€™t give the same feeling as in the previous games. One can say the parkour has been put on the back burner to make room new ways to explore the desert wonder. And boy there is a lot to explore. There are caves, bandit camps, underwater treasure bellies and more.

None of the exploration options is without rewards. Other than being a completionistâ€™s wet dream of checklist gaming, it also provides you with ample of side quests. There are over 100 side quests and all of them have something to add to either the character or the narrative of the game.

RPG elements

In the seriesâ€™ first, traditional RPG elements are weaved into the game with three classes of abilities to develop: Warrior, Hunter and seeker. As you complete quests and explore the world, you gain experience points that you can to put in either one or all of those classes. The quality of abilities you get range from effective to mediocre to obtuse. Although the addition is appreciated, you can see that this is just Ubiâ€™s attempt to see how the new elements work out.

Online Elements

AC Origins is one of the victims of mobile-gaming models that have slithered their ways in Single Player Games. There are events and daily missions, giving you a chance to take a bite of that legendary loot you've been eyeing for so long. Daily missions give you two types of quests: fetch and assassinations. However, the events contain climatic and challenging boss battles that are rewarding quite on their own. 

However, the rate of loot drops is painfully low, forcing a grind that while enjoyable, is still a grind. And it doesn't help that the in-your-face microtransaction model that Ubi has been peddling to compensate for the rarity of loot drops is quite pathetic. That being said, it won't affect your gameplay experience, and you, like me can get quite a lot of loot without spending one penny. Just be ready to invest a lot of time in the desert. 

How well it plays?

The game is demanding. While I wasnâ€™t expecting for a potato to run it, I was hoping for some levity for mid-level machines. While desert regions can help you maintain constant 60, prepare to drop 10 29 in populated cities.

Is it worth it?

Assassinâ€™s Creed Origins is borne out of the passion of its developers. The narrative main quests, the engaging side quests, the amazing gameplay can entertain you for hours. However, make sure that your machine has enough juice to experience it all. You can get lost in its details and even after 150 hours of gameplay, Iâ€™ve yet to see everything the game has to offer. However, the microtransactions donâ€™t bode well for the direction the series is taking.

On that note, I give this game an 8 out of 10.

Assassin's Creed Origins symbolizes the change on the AC series.

I've been playing all the AC games in order for the past year, and while the series has had its ups and downs, it always stands up again. Origins may be more RPG than AC game, but that same feeling and the good ol' hidden blade make it a really good AC game, and it has a beautiful Egypt map with tons of areas to explore.

Great game, historically accurate and a nice new kind of Assassin's Creed.

Posted: 18 August, 2018
I have followed the Assassins Creed series religiously since the days of AltaÃ¯r. Like everyone else, I have experienced a rollercoaster of feelings during the ongoing releases of the AC series; I adored the original game as well as AC2 and ACB, I enjoyed revelations, I lost all hope during AC3, re-gained hope during Black Flag and every game until now left me with no hope and a lot of hate.

Origins has re-ignited my love for the AC series: this game could not possibly deliver anything more 'Assassins Creedy'.
The story is brilliant and draws you in, the characters are so three dimensional and even though almost all controls have changed- the parkour, exploration and system of fighting still feels just like the 'good old days' (AC, AC2, ACB).
The game is stunning, I am yet to play a game with a better appearance and feel. The sound is incredible, the music is beautiful with hints of the previous games soundtracks entwined within; the sound effects within the game are so detailed, nothing has not been thought through.
The game itself is massive and there are an endless amount of things to do: stories to experience, enemies to conquer, lands to explore. I love the levelling up system, I love the weapons and upgrades- everything that is new or unlike the traditional AC games has been incorporated in a seamless way.

I understand everyoneâ€™s fear of buying and playing any new AC games due to their previous failures- but this is a game that is not worth missing. This is the game that brings everything back home.

139.0 hrs on record
Posted: December 8, 2020
125 hours is the time it took me to do everything there is to do in the game and its DLCs. I'm talking about exploring the entire map and completing every landmark, crafting every upgrade, unlocking every skill and getting some of them passive bonuses, acquiring every cosmetic item the shops offer, finishing the story, every sidequest and getting all the achievements. I even went through every tour instance and listened to them. Did I enjoy wasting 5 days of my life on a single videogame? Every single second.

I am not saying you need to spend 125 hours on this. I must admit, a part of me enjoyed this game simply because of its Egyptian theme. I spent a lot of time exploring the land and just looking at the breathtaking surroundings this game offers. This, The Witcher 3 and recently Assassin's Creed Valhalla are the only games where I was able to just... walk around the world.

Now let's look at the price. 60â‚¬ for a game like this sounds like a lot. I myself bought it on a sale, because I was unsure if I would enjoy it that much. Now that I know what the game offers, I would not mind paying the full price. If you do not like looking at the game as a work of art and would rather just do quests and get that fat loot, then you're missing out on a good chunk of content, and this game would simply be boring or not worth its price.

Recommended
90.6 hrs on record
Posted: April 10, 2020
So full disclosure- I never really got into the AC games. I've only played some of the first and second games and decided they weren't really for me. I've avoided every AC game since then.

The main reason I bought this game was because I was itching for another an open-world game after finishing The Witcher 3, which blew me away. While the missions and story here dont have the same branching out like W3 does, this is still a fantastic game.

Starting off with the protagonist- Bayek is awesome. He's strong, loyal, kind, agile and fierce. He's well written and the voice actor did an excellent job. If Ubi made another AC game with Bayek I'd probably buy it. Many of the supporting cast is fantastic as well. The main story is great and The Hidden Ones expansion tops it off perfectly in my opinion. The Curse of the Pharaohs was a lot of fun as well. I did them in that order.

I really like how much there is to explore and find in this game. I felt compelled to discover every fast travel location, completed every enemy camp and animal lair, found every treasure, completed all the side quests and of course all the main missions. I did everything. It was just fun to see what was out there in the world, get XP and level up to get better weapons and gear and make Bayek an ultimate badass and meet new and interesting NPCs.

I love how if you find a weapon you really like you can take it to a blacksmith and upgrade it to your level to increase its damage. I must have carried the same weapon for at least 50 hours and i probably leveled it up a million times to max level 55. Thats a really cool option I think.

And thankfully, at least for me- there isnt a "Vision" mode here like tons of other games, (where you hit a button and it shows/tags items, enemies, points of interest (poi) etc but the graphics go to â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥). Instead in this game you hit a button and it puts little colored diamonds above loot, poi, etc without disrupting the graphics. And what I thought was an awesome addition was your eagle named Seru. He's always flying above you and you can instantly switch to him to hover around enemy camps to tag enemies, check terrain layouts, discover underground entrances, hidden treasures, and even harass enemies if you want! And the camera always zooms out to him and then zooms back to you without any fade outs or loading, very cool!

The only things I wish were different are the armor, level caps and horses. All weapons in the game have better/worse stats depending on what level they are of course, but armor is purely cosmetic. I get why Ubi did this so that people find a look they like and stick with it (or find something cooler), but I wish there were defense stats on them. And i wish you could do the same thing like with the weapons and upgrade them as you please. Being able to increase health, melee/ranged/tool damage but not defense seems a little baffling, but maybe its a balancing issue or something. Horses too dont have stats like at least how fast they can run, which was a little disappointing but not a huge deal.

Moving on the level caps...the main game caps at level 40, and I hit that just exploring the world discovering locations and doing mostly everything except the main story. With The Hidden Ones expansion your level cap increases to 45, and the Pharaohs expansions tops it out at 55. Even if you max out you still earn Ability Points for every level though, which can be applied to anything in the skill tree, and if you have all those learned already you can add 1% extra damage for either melee, ranged, or tool damage to no end. I just wish there were a higher level cap than 55 with better weapons available. To put some of this in perspective- during my 90 hours with the game+expansions, I hit level 55 with an extra 31 ability points distributed to the previously mentioned melee/ranged/tool categories. I did not learn about 5 or 6 abilities though because i wasnt particularly interested in those. This game could easily increase the cap to 75 or even higher for nuts like me. And theres New Game+ as well which im not going to do but if its there i would think the level cap would go even higher but I understand there has to be a ceiling somewhere.

Overall though I loved just about every aspect of this game. Areas didnt feel crowded and there always seemed to be a way through instead of having to go all around or up a cliff just to get to where you need to go. Mission markers were clear, NPC's didnt get it the way and they dont die during escort missions either which is great. Theres just a ton of stuff the game does right and well.

AC Odyssey is much the same although with a different protagonist (that ive read isnt nowhere near as great as Bayek though) and a somewhat bloated map, but I'll still check it out because you can Spartan kick enemies off ledges which seems comically fun at the very least.

I bought the main game first on sale and held off on the expansions until I felt that I liked the game enough and wanted more of it. All in all, I think I paid like $4 more buying everything separately instead of getting the Gold edition from the start on sale. But overall I enjoyed just about every minute of it. Highly recommended!!!!

OVERVIEW â†´
Assassin's Creed Origins is an amazing action-adventure stealth game experience for a single player set in Ancient Egypt near the end of the Ptolemaic period (49â€“44 BC), and recounts the secret but fictional history of once a proud kingdom, now a divided region. We take on a role of a Medjay named Bayek of Siwa, who works to protect the people of the Ptolemaic Kingdom during a time of widespread upheaval between Ptolemy XIII, Cleopatra and Julius Caesar fighting for control... and explore the origins of the centuries long conflict between the Hidden Ones (the Brotherhood of Assassins), and The Order of the Ancients (the Templar Order) which was responsible for the death of Bayek's son, Khemu, that leads our main protagonist into exile to seek vengeance.

GRAPHICS AND AUDIO â†´
I feel like Origins can easily join ranks amongst those games with an outstanding qualities and nearly perfect beautiful design. The vast expanse of the region we get to play in is breath-taking and definitely one of the most amazing environments I've seen. I'm not kidding when I say that everywhere you look you can see the jawdropping details of graphics and physics that are making this game almost ageless. And it's even futher complemented by things like an authentic feeling of this very fascinating time period of civil war the game is set but also an excellent lighting system, which actually makes you feel the dizzying heat of the sun as you explore each district with it's own unique and mysterious sights from the populated cities to hidden cavern passages to even underwater plains full of interesting treasures. And all of this is accompanied by a great score (could listen to the main theme for the rest of my life) and nicely done sound design that works well with the visuals of the game to immerse you into an amazing and intriguing atmosphere of Ancient Egypt. (Ps. Photo mode for the win!)

GAMEPLAY â†´
Compared to the previous games combat in AC Origins has been completley revamped. While the old system of an enemies was heavily based on them attacking you one at a time which made you capable of simply countering all their moves in a never-ending cycle, the new one is more of an RPG style that is significantly harder but also considerably more satisfying. One-on-one attacks are no longer applied but instead a variety of enemies with different attacks, from melee to long-ranged one, can start a fight with you more than two or even three at a time from every possible angle. Before you where getting an easy wins with pressing the counter symbol at a right time, however now to win combat scenarios it's essential for you to level up and have a good gear/weapons equipped (which we can have our pick of since the game offers us different classes of weapons and each one has its unique weight/stats that can provide usvwith a bit of a different way of playstyle). This gives the combat attacks quite the variety as the enemies will definitely not wait in line for their chance to take a hit at you anymore. I think this a great change in the system since now you can feel more like an assassin workin in the shadows to outsmart his foes and this is where we're getting a pretty huge emphasis on stealth and stategic thinking... simply analyzing the patterns, planing your attacks and all that or even finding a quick route of escape since it's no longer so easy to rush in to a fort, due to it being harder than it was before. And let me tell you that clearing out a whole camp of soldiers without even a single soul screaming out for alarm - satisfying as hell. I mean, sure, you can still try charging in there without planing anything out but don't be surprised if you fail miserably at killing your target and you end up as an avenge quest for other players to find. Â¯\_(ãƒ„)_/Â¯

STORY â†´
When we start the game, the Assassin order does not even exist. Instead we learn a story of a Medjay, Bayek of Siwa at a time where the words "I am a Medjay. I am a feather in the eagle's wing... a living dagger, plunged from the sky into the heart of chaos. I am a truth unknown... a scabbard unfilled... a son of the Nile... and a defender of the people. You cannot kill me, for I walk among the dead. Come forth by day, and I will guide you home." are getting a new meaning after he suffers a great lost at the hands of a mysterious figures standing behind the Order of the Ancients which drastically changes his point of view and making him become Medjay to no pharaoh, a hidden one, a protector not only for the people of his region but the whole realm. And this where our journey begins...

PERFORMANCE, BUGS AND GLITCHES â†´
Ehh... there were a some lil' bugs and glitches but mostly the hilarious kind of ones. For example, the ship flying in the sky and then doing it's own re-edition of sinking Titanic, and like c'mon, that flying horse/camel doing cartwheel, anyone? I bet there are few more out there but I didn't encounter anything game-breaking.

CONCLUSION â†´
Origins left me deeply impressed not only with it's unique and breathtaking landscape that stretched for what felt like an eternity but also with the attention to detail for the main story set in Ancient Egypt as well as all the small but gripping story lines that painted an interesting picture for the player. It actually made me feel like every single minute was worth playing and this game without a doubt surpassed my expectations. I cannot find a single thing (except being forced to play as Aya) that I didn't enjoy in this insane world that's a completionistâ€™s wet dream. Seriously, it was a joy to get lost in exploring. That's why I think it's a must have for adventure enthusiasts like me and all those who complain about this game being a walking simulator don't have a real appreciation for a masterpiece this game truly is. For me this entry in Assassin's Creed series is one of the best in the franchise as a whole and it's gonna be very hard to change my mind about that. My bff already tried, didn't worked at all.

Posted: March 1, 2018
Summary:

In 2016, no Assassin's Creed games were announced or released as Ubisoft took a year off to polish their next AC game and boy have they delivered. Assassin's Creed Origins is a awesome comeback for the series and while it still has those core AC elements we know and love, the game has taken a different approach from it's predecessors. It now follows an RPG style game, where you level up and can customise your character with all sorts of loot. The minimap has been ditched in favour of The Witcher 3 compass style navigation and it makes exploring the world much more interesting and fun. Combat has also been revamped and no longer follows the old system of counter and kill.

Game world:

Ptolemaic Egypt is massive and each location is filled with mini objectives that you do to complete the area, for example killing the captain and/or looting all the treasure. Each district in Egypt offers hours of content and are all unique in apperance. Due to the absence of the minimap, locations are now marked with a ? icon and similar to The Witcher 3 they can be discovered upon while wandering the massive world. This is the biggest AC open world to date and it certainly delivers an authentic feeling of the time period the game is set in. There is so much side content in the world that you end up getting distracted and straying away from the main quest very easily. Each side quest is unique and offers different stories which means that it does not become repetitive quickly.

Narrative:

The game's narrative differs from the previous games as it is not about the fight between the Templars and Assassins. When you start the game in AC Origins, the Assassin order does not even exist. As you play through the game you will find out about the people and ideas that ultimatley lead to the Assassin order being created. Each main quest I played was interesting and it gave me little bits of information about the beggining of the Assassin order. We all have grown tired of the same old "Assassins vs Templars" and I think AC Origins story is a nice refreshment from all that stuff.

Combat:

Combat in Assassin's Creed Origins has been completley revamped. If you remember the old system of an enemy attacking you one at a time and you countering all their moves over and over, you can be glad that this is no longer how combat works. Because the game is RPG style the combat is signnificantly harder. Enemies no longer attack one at a time but instead two or three would have a go at you at the same time. Before you could win fights just by countering when the symbol came up, however now to win combat scenarios you're going to have to be the same or a higher level than your enemis and also have strong weapons and gear equipped. This gives comabt in AC Origins variety as the enemies wouldn't wait one at a time. This combat change was greatly needed and I no longer rush in to a fort, due to it being harder than it was before.

Problems:

Assassin's Creed Origin's does not have much negatives however a major issue of this game is it's poor optimization. I have a GTX 970 4gb graphics card and I should be able to run the game at a solid 60 FPS due to me being able to run much more demanding games. I would always have around 45 FPS when playing but sometimes it would drop as low as 25 and it killed some of the enjoyment for me. Assassin's Creed on PC has generally had a bad history of optimization but I never really had it as bad as this. It stutters and lags at some intense moments but I'm glad I can at least mantain a playable FPS 90% of the time. The game eats up a lot of your CPU and Ram so if you have a less powerful CPU or less Ram you may encounter long loadings, stutter, textures not rendering quickly etc. These sort of ruin the experience and I wish Ubisoft would do better with AC on PC.

Conclusion:

You may ask "Should I get Assassin's Creed Origins?" the answer is yes. This game won't disappoint you it is filled with content and I am certain you will be spending hours trying to 100% this game. Assassin's Creed Origins has revived the series for many people and I believe that taking one year off has helped Ubisoft create an awesome AC game. If you're reluctant to give this game a go due to it's previous mistakes I would suggest you come back. This game deserves a chance it has in a way reinvented the series and I hope future releases can follow Origin's example.

Verdict:

9/10 Fantastic game!.

Posted: November 9, 2020
I've picked up and played at least 2-3 hours of every AC game except Odyssey and I've only liked Black Flag (completed ~ 70%) and Brotherhood (100%). I think I enjoyed Origins so much because it is greatly inspired by and features elements of exactly those 2 titles.

What I enjoyed most:
- The world is huge and filled with things to explore - cities, fortresses, temples, bandit camps, animal lairs, tombs etc. just like in Black Flag except this time the seas are filled with sand instead. Each region is unique in it's flora, inhabitants (greeks, romans, egyptians) and cities. Everything looks authentic and it's obvious that the designers did their research.
- The DLCs are really good. The hidden ones focuses more on classic assassinations and Curse of the pharaohs on mythology. If you have the coin, I strongly suggest purchasing the Gold edition while on sale.
- Since the game's release, it has received a lot of quality of life and content updates- discovery tour, Anubis boss fights and Animus control panel, which allows you to modify parameters of the game, like making your hidden blade instantly kill enemies.
- The main character, Bayek, resembles Ezzio a lot. He's charismatic, drops a joke or a pun here and there, has a deep sense of honor and justice despite the fact that his own life was messed up. Plus the voice actor did a tremendous job.

What bothered me:
- Unfortunately I can't say the same for the rest of the voice actors- the Romans and Cleo have British accents, the side quest voice actors (except in Curse of the pharaohs DLC) were simply horrible. I had to skip dialog cause I simply couldn't listen to their tirades.
- The side quest range from annoying fetch missions (go to point X, kill bandits/corrupt soldiers/wild animals>collect item>return to quest giver) to really immersive quests about ancient Egyptian traditions and daily life. Of course you don't know what the quality of the quest will be before you start it. I think I managed to pick up most of the good side quests and skipped some of the filler content.

331.1 hrs on record
Posted: March 20, 2018
After Assassin's Creed Unity, things looked grim for the AC franchise. After an embarrasing launch in an already turbulent year for Ubisoft, I became disinterested in the AC franchise after loyally following it since the first game. In some ways, this was to be expected after 3 games focusing solely on Ezio Auditore da Firenze, the franchise's most memorable character and the shift towards yearly releases.

Then I saw the trailer for Assassin's Creed Origins and my curiosity started. I pre-ordered the game literally the day before it came out. I dreaded the moment it became playable as I was fearing another Unity. And I am glad I was wrong. Assassin's Creed Origins is a true return to form for a franchise that has passed through a VERY rough phase.

The game is set during Ptolemic Egypt, a country with a history stretching back thousands of years. Once a proud kingdom, now a divided region, torn between Ptolemy XIII and his sister/wife Cleopatra fighting for control. At the same time, old tensions are flaring up again while a new emergent power is also taking an interest in Egypt. You play as Bayek of Siwa, a Medjay or a Protector.

The setting is very fascinating as it focuses on a period of civil war in a country that had a long history, a history that is visible all around the map in the game. The story is engaging, albeit at the start there are pacing issues but bear with them as it gets interesting later.

The gameplay is heavily influenced by Witcher 3 and I have to say, it works really well for this. The RPG element is useful and should be further improved in successive games. One element I agree is a tad problematic is the combat system. It takes a short time to learn but a long time to master. The storyline is linear but this has always been the case with AC. What is open is how you tackle objectives or conduct assassinations, allowing you to take on enemies through a variety of ways.

However, for me one feature really stood out. On February 2018, Ubisoft released the Discovery Tour. It allows the player to explore the entire region without any limitations such as combat. To see the setting with complete freedom, to see the details the production crew put in is very impressive. The feature also has tours which focus on particular aspects of the era, from mummification rituals to Egyptian beer to Greek education to Roman crucifiction. As an archaeologist, I find it extremely well-researched and the production crew also explain certain design choices, like the Sphinx having colour even though by Cleopatra's time, it had long lost the colours. This way you appreciate the detail and effort they took to present that history and this could potentially be very useful in educating the public about the wonders of Ancient Egypt so it is a breath of fresh air in this day and age (*cough History Channel *cough).

All in all, I thoroughly recommend this game to everyone, old fans and new people interested in the franchise. You do not have to play the previous games in order to understand what is going on. The modern sections isn't that great but this franchise was always about the past. Full price is worth it but if you're strapped, wait for a sale. The wait would be worth it in the end. It seems that Ubisoft has learnt its lesson and is avoiding yearly releases. The franchise has the potential for a great comeback and can also serve in educating people who are interested in learning more about the setting (which in turn makes you appreciate the effort they took).

Posted: November 9, 2017
Product received for free

I had no intention of getting this game. The previous games had been up and down in terms of story, gameplay and overall technical quality. Unity bored me, I couldn't be bothered with Syndicate. And when I heard of microtransactions in Origins as well, I had no reason whatsoever for getting Origins. But a friend bought it for me and wanted to experience it together with me and I felt I had to give it a go for his sake.

And I must say: I enjoyed it. Quite a lot, even.

It borrows liberally from Witcher III in terms of combat mechanics and world building. And although I don't think it reaches that level of quality, the end result of AC Origins is well worth it. It has a large and for me surprisingly varied map, with a lot of locations, missions and other activities.

The story is fairly standard AC fare: the Assassins (in all but name here) fighting against oppression by killing evil megalomaniacs and hundreds of underpaid soldiers. Ubisoft seems to realize by now that most people don't give a fig about the modern day story anymore (if they ever did). I myself gave up on it after Brotherhood and purely enjoyed the later games for the gameplay and historical setting. All I'll say is that just like in some of the previous games, the modern day alien conspiracy element has very little prominence, and I think it's a better game for it.


The map itself is beautiful. From vibrant and colourful in the Nile Delta to arid and desolate in the rolling desert dunes. It is filled to the brim with locations, quests and side activities. While many of the side missions are fairly unimaginative (get item/npc X from stronghold Y for npc Z), there are a good many too that have a bit more narrative to them. Ubisoft has done a good job of making the world seem alive and believable, even though (I'm no expert) they probably took quite a bit of liberty with historical accuracy. Speaking of which: I quite miss the history blurbs and glossary from previous games. They added a nice layer of depth to the game. Blast it, Shaun, you've been slacking!

The mechanics, while not groundbreaking, are solid and fun. Sneaking and climbing felt very much like Black Flag: fairly simple but solid (though occasionally finicky, especially the parkour. Why didn't they expand on the previous system?). The way strongholds and missions are set up lends itself very well to sneak approaches and for me it was enjoyable. The addition of a bow especially makes sneaking around and combat in general more fun. Melee combat recieved some updates from previous AC games. While it didn't have all of the same fluidity, again it felt quite a bit like Witcher III (and like in Witcher, enemies with shields are a pain in the backside). But the combat system works well and getting into combat doesn't feel like punishment, as was the case in some other AC games. There's a good selection of melee weapons with their own move sets and finishers to match your playstyle. Mounted combat is equally satisfying (although a bit repetitive), and I felt my inner Mount & Blade player assert itself again; run into enemy outposts and make passes on enemy groups while whacking them with spear and sword.

I feel like I need to mention microtransactions. Although I perfectly despise the very notion of putting a cash shop in a $/â‚¬60 predominantly single player experience, and can't condone it in any way, I don't feel like it bothered me at all during gameplay. It just felt so very optional. No obnoxious advertisements, no obvious pay to win rubbish. Earning money and resources in-game is no big hassle (decidedly fun for me, in fact). Legendary gear is not very difficult to get without paying a single real life cent, and I never felt tempted to do so. Skins and time-savers mostly for those that want it, but nothing too insidious.

On the techical side, there were a few (mostly visual) bugs here and there, but nothing game breaking. I don't have the most powerful PC, but the game ran decently well on my system. No major frame dips or anything, but YMMV ofcourse. And I liked how the options menu gives good previews of the graphics options. Really helps well with setting up your game.

In conclusion: nothing spectacular, but a worthy solid AC game. Ubisoft did well skipping a year with AC releases, it paid off handsomely. If I were forced to give it a mark, I'd give 7/10. I could be persuaded into giving an 8 if they cut out the cash shop and fixed the minor glitches.

Recommended
43.1 hrs on record
Posted: June 7, 2018
This was a difficult choice. "Do I recommend it?" and I've gone back and forth between "No, but" and "Yes, if" a lot. This is a stunning looking game, with some of the most amazing environments I've seen. You start in the town of Siwa, decently sized and lovingly detailed, and I thought it would be maybe 10% of the world map. No, it isn't even 1%. The lush Nile delta, the pyramids of Giza, Alexandria with its greek buildings, Memphis with its Egyptian. Mountains, deserts, valleys, villages, temples, monuments, garrisons, fields, breweries, butchers, brickmakers, weavers, slums, palaces. Everywhere you look you can see jawdropping vistas, and weeks and months and years of work put in by some of the best environmental artists in the business. Exploring this world and seeing the inhabitants go about their daily life is the best part of the game. The main plot on the other hand, is the usual drawn out cliched tales of revenge and supernatural conspiracies you would expect from the Assassin's Creed series, punctuated by AAA scenes of action bombast. Lovingly rendered, and very dumb. A bunch of people with nothing in common and no motivation apart from gaining power, being moustashe-twirlingly evil, and being members of the Order of Ancients needs opposing, so around you go supposedly creating a better word by slitting their throats, and the throats of literally thousands of enemy soldiers just doing their job.

The world is filled with quests, a few memorable, most of them forgettable MMO like fare - investigate this, explore that, kill him, find her. In order to finish the game you will have to do a fair few of these side quests, or you won't have a high enough level to stand a chance in later regions that open up. Combat is fairly satisfying, I played on hard and I died a fair number of times until I learned the different enemies and their strengths and weaknesses. When to block, when to dodge, when to shieldsmash and when to sneak around and assassinate.

Despite my complaints about the writing, the exploration and world is just so good that it, together with the non-violent Exploration Module which teach you about the history of Egypt is enough to tip this into a "Yes, you should absolutely get this." Just be aware that it will take a while to play through it, and don't try to force your way through as many MMO quests as possible. Do a few of the most interesting when you feel like it, and climb on top of a rookery or pyramid occasionally and take in the scenery.

Assassinâ€™s Creed Origins
Assassin's Creed Origins is a open world, action, stealth, rpg and a game which changed Assassin's Creed forever.

Origins is the first of its type in this franchise and people are not often too happy about changes. Since Iâ€™m a big fan of the older Assassinâ€™s Creed games I was a bit hesitate at first but after playing it for a bit I started to enjoy the new type of gameplay and its features.

Is Origins a bad game? Simply said: No it really isnt but its something different from what we have seen from this franchise and it made a lot of good changes in my opinion. If you like RPGs, stealth games and fights with quite a bit of action you might also like Assassinâ€™s Creed Origins since this game is a mix out of all of those genres.

Story

The player is controlling Bayek of Siwa who is looking for the people that were responsible for his sons death. His wife Aya of Alexandria is joining Bayek in his path of vengeance. Throughout the story the plot thickens and the player will encounter famous characters like Cleopatra VII and Julius Caesar.

The Story is very Assassinâ€™s Creed like with the usual fair share of actual historical events and made up things that the player discovers throughout the playthrough. The whole events of Origins are set in the ancient egypt which is quite a cool setting for me personally â€“ if you like the setting you should give it a try.

Personal note

When I started playing this game I was quite hesitate as I mentioned earlier. I couldnt imagine how an Assassinâ€™s Creed game could become an RPG. After playing it for maybe 6 hours I started to like the changes and the new possibilities that Origins implemented.

I was a bit disappointed that the focus of Origins wasnt mainly on the stealth gameplay, which older games, in this franchise were so focused on. After a while I learned to like that though, since sometimes you dont feel like sneaking through a whole garrison when you simply can take a fight.

I quickly started to do some side quests instead of following the main quest which kind of boosted me because I was leveling quite fast, which gave me an advantage when I came back to do the main story line. I really fell in love with being able to do whatever I liked to do â€“ when I felt like doing some exploring while following some side quest plots, I was able to do so and it felt so fresh with the RPG elements in the game.

Rating
Pros
The fighting feels pretty good
The RPG elements are well executed
Eagle Vision ability is pretty cool
Freedom that allows you to explore and / or do side quests
The Story is well made and makes sense after a while
There is a lot of stuff to do if you really want to do it
The graphics are pretty good
The cities feel alive
The characters are well developed and have some depth
Photomode â€“ something I really love since I started to take screenshots more often
Cons
The controls on the keyboard are a bit weird (which is nothing new but still an issue at times)
The Photomode controls are not convenient for keyboard users
Sometimes the FPS drops which is weird since my rig isnt the issue
Some areas of the map seem too empty
The voice of Bayek is too loud and there is no option to turn it down
The game can be grindy at times
Conclusion

Is Assassin's Creed Origins a good game? I would say it is. It was a lot of fun to play through the story and the side quests - I also found myself taking lots of screenshots and just admiring the ancient egypt and its cities.

Origins is worth your money if you like the Assassin's Creed franchise and if you're looking for a game which takes you a while to play through. It took me roughly 50 hours to finish the main story - I did a lot of exploring and side questing as well but at the same time I still have so much to do.

8.4 / 10

This is a good game.
I believe it's the best AC to date for a number of reasons.

-Super glad they took this new direction into RPG territory, it was much needed.
It's something I been personally asking and wishing for, and it paid off bigtime.
-The visual are absolutely stunning, at many points throughout the game I asked myself how did that.
I was running at 4K 60fps smooth. The most gorgeous graphics I've seen in any game so far.
And the water, the water is simply revolutionary, never seen water done so perfectly.

My only complaint would be that, as much as this game is better than its predecessors and more into RPG, the side missions are really missing something. For the most part side missions are mediocre, uninspired, except a few, and they are borderline fetch quests that give little incentive to do them. A few incentivize you with gorgeous gear, but for the most part, they are meh.

TLDR: A Good game, with stunning visuals, much better for bringing RPG elements to the table with hopes they bring more RPG into it.

Posted: November 8, 2019
Oh boy...

Assassin's Creed: Origins is the first Assassin's Creed game I've played, in earnest, since ACIII. I've played bits and pieces of Black Flag, Rogue, Syndicate and even less of Unity. Though, I think most people would recite the trilogy with Ezio Auditore da Firenze as some of the best games in the series.

At the time of writing this, I have just finished the main story with considerable but not all side missions/content completed, at roughly 86 hours. I've purchased the Gold Edition and await the Hidden Ones and Curse of the Pharaohs DLC. But, I wanted to express my thoughts and pontificate the main game on its own.

The Last of the Medjay.
In Origins, you'll play as Bayak of Siwa during the last Ptolemaic Dynasty of Egypt with the impending encroachment of the new Roman Empire readily apparent.

Origins is relatively more story focused than previous iterations of Assassin's Creed. However, it's still kind of â€œbloatedâ€ as you've likely heard the series described. And running around and killing captains for loot that's probably not any better than what you've already got isn't going to appeal to everyone. Though, if you're someone that plays Far Cry for instance, and resets the outposts such that you can kill everybody again â€” you'll likely very much enjoy these side location objectives replete throughout the map. I will say that through doing these essentially exploration objectives that I ran into many things I'd not have expected: 

There is almost nothing in common with older Assassin's Creed games here.
Except the parkour and climbing on a lot of things to synchronize with the animus.

Combat is much more direct, no longer can you stand there and press counter when your definitely not spider-sense goes off and subsequently destroy an entire garrison with relative ease. It's still essentially a hack n' slash but the weapon types behave differently and vary the combat in a non-trivial way that I really appreciate. The bows are especially different. Hunter bows are designed for powerful draws, warrior bows are effectively ancient shotguns, light bows â€” repeating rifles. Predator bows... these go into first person to let you aim, once leveled, you'll be able to sixaxis manipulate the arrow in slow motion as it travels.

Origins seems to be heavily inspired by Witcher 3 and Destiny. Which is not a bad thing by any means, it's just... â€œperhaps investigating what happened hereâ€ â€” will lead to a legendary bow. Origins now conflates loot and leveling into the main structure of the game. You can even turn on level scaling. I don't recommend this however.

Assassin's Creed is possibly the most unintentionally meta-game ever made.
You play as Layla Hassan in the modern times, who is inside of a machine, effectively playing the game that you are actually playing. But, it's fine because it's all a part of the lore.

To bring this point further, might you want to avenge player Anubis05841? How about partaking in a timed event such as the Trial of Sekhmet for some rare Anubis gear? Not your cup of tea? Then try your luck with the daily mission from Reda the Nomad Trader for a daily reward â€” whom will also happily oblige you in taking 3000 drachmas in exchange for a lootbox. Due to this technically taking place in a machine â€” in a machine. It actually makes sense. Which I love... and hate.

Yes, there are micro-transactions. Mostly cosmetic. Some â€œtime-saverâ€ ones as well. All completely optional. Though, I hear your argument design wise, some aspects may be more drawn out than usual to encourage you to buy â€œHelix Creditsâ€ â€” the credits you buy with real life money. I understand that argument, and I'm rather nonplussed about it. At the end of the day, if you don't want it, don't buy it.

THE GIST:
Assassin's Creed Origins is absolutely one of my favorite AC games. If only for the setting. Ancient Egypt is rife with mystery and makes a perfect setting for a game of this nature. When you add the new gameplay elements to it that dramatically change what was once an arguably dying IP, you've got yourself a great resurgence of interest.

More here â€” Station Argus

Some technical gumbo:
The graphical presets seem to be completely out of hand. I was able to get the game running at around 40-60fps at 1080p on mostly Very High settings with a few on medium or turned off. Some of the settings seem to have a dramatic effect on performance with virtually no change in visually quality. While others have dramatic effect on visual quality while the performance is virtually unchanged.

Recommended? (AKA tl;dr)

If you somehow like the "Ubisoft-Formula" of map-clearing? Yes! They definately worked on that and made it way better, more rewarding and more enjoyable. The best iteration of their formula so far.
I disliked previous Assasin's Creed titles mostly because they grew boring after a few minutes, yet this one is highly enjoyable, if not only for the incredibly awesome (and refreshing) setting and its sheer beauty. So often
I wandered (well...rode) off the planned path just because of that "omg, wow, what is that?"-factor. I spent 30 hours before I even went a step ahead in the main-quest :-)
Let's just say there's one achievement in the heat of the desert that...well ,-)

I hope that this in-game-shop-â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ from Ubisoft is the maximum we'll see. I can make my peace with the way it currently is. Games like these costs serious bucks, so if they can make it worth their while with people who are fine to cheat with money or buy cosmetic fun-items? Well, fine. Just don't never ever ever try to force anything down my throat in a damn single-player!
The exclusion of the map-coordinates for three collectible-side-quests is...on the edge of acceptable. You can surely look them up in the web or will find them anyway if you're an explorer, but...


The good (what to love):
Cats will follow you curiously and you should not...errr...kill them, because they're sacred. Yesyes, so I've heard, I would never try of course ;-)
Some really refreshing new setting/theme. That ancient Egypt is breathtakingly beautiful.
Insanely beautiful. Scenery, characters, everything is really extremely well done with a passion for detail. Lovely.
Combat has been vastly improved over the previous titles and ranges from fun to challenging.
Wide range of options. Even a very valuable "Dialogue boost" in Audio. Neat!
Vast map, millions of quests, tread one meter and you have another thing to do. A completionists dream or nightmare, whatever :-)
That eagle for reconnaissance is a nice thing. Nearly as much fun as the drone in Wildlands (as it's more passive)
Ubisofts achievements are funnier than Steams. Accumulate points and actually get something in-game (or in another game) for it. I like it. Tip: Get the one quest first, and skip the gear (you'll find plenty and better)!
Side-quest-quality has vastly improved. Though they rarely reach a Witcher III's niveau, they're good enough to keep you going.
World is nicely alive. People work, sleep, talk. Animals hunt, flee, sleep and even fight.
No bugs seen yet, not even some misaligned texture.
Mounts are fun and responsive, felling right. Mounted combat too. Very enjoyable.
You can have your mount "auto-run" (just following the street or navigating to your way-point). While doing that you can call your eagle and watch yourself riding or scout the area or whatever.


The mediocre (neither good nor bad, or simply not objectively either):
Some "multi-player"-elements like in "Shadow of War": Avenge some random people's death. Nice for a lil extra XP, but a real immersion-killer. Why? "Avenge the death of â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥Destroya69". Some people have poetic tags...
Typical Ubisoft-Formula: Map-clearing. BUT not as boring as in their other titles. Quite the contrary actually. They learned.
In-game-Shop. BUT Ubisoft is fair here (for now!). Just cosmetic stuff or "time-saving" stuff for the super-lazy. Back in the day we called them cheats. Now they're a business-model. Smart move.
You can also buy "loot-boxes" with in-game-money and be able to receive the item-store-items. Bought two and got a legendary mount and armor, each for 9,99 in the store. You can even cheat in-game-money instead of buying if you so wish. With such a system I could make my peace. Some extra cash for the dev from the super-lazy but still no feeling of "ugh I really need that item".
Quick item-pickup (means: no animation). Even from a mounts back. Immersion-killer for some, immensely nice thing for me.
It can become a bit "grindy". But only if intend on maxing out your gear and upgrade it all. Then you'll spend a lot of time gathering resources. It doesn't force you into the shop though, as you don't need it all. And if you enjoy the game, a bit of grinding is no grinding at all.


The ugly (what to hate, may kill the fun):
Double DRM. Besides normal ugly Denuvo the whole things actually runs in a VM. Can you believe this? So if you'd wonder why the game constantly uses 100% of all your CPUs cores...that's why. Yet I understand the need for more and more drastic measures to counter piracy, I totally hate it to be the moron who pays with CPU-life for that, while pirates just wait a lil longer and can enjoy it without that crap (not yet so far, so at least it's working).
Too much random chatter from random people in a language most of us don't understand anyway. Can get quite annoying when riding through a city and every â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ NPC talks some stuff to you. Are they all retarded or what's their problem? :-) Actually that's the worst thing in the game, I wonder how no one in QA complained about it...
I have to start the game 2-5x each time to get it finally running. What the bloody hell is that magic?!

At this point there are two main series of Assassin's Creed games...the first ones being the Altair/Ezio & Desmond games (Ac1, Ac2, Brotherhood, Revelations +Ac3) and then all the rest...

There's a definitive line drawn after Ac3 (even if that game wasn't good, it was still with Desmond and the original story... for better or worse!) The truth is after the ending of Assassinâ€™s Creed itself in Ac 3 , Ubisoft departed greatly from the original gameplay and story (except one more game later that sadly didn't go out so well) and so, Assassin's Creed lost its identity to the point of not being recognizable even to the players of the first games, and yet at the same time, Ubisoft kept trying to exploit the success of the "name" and the original series by coming up with a new title (almost) every year because, who knows, maybe they were afraid of starting something new.

To be sincere and less subjective, there were some good attempts here...of course...

The new series started with AC 4 Black Flag which was a good game, but... it didn't have ANYTHING to do with Assassinâ€™s being a sea adventure... and pirates (?!)
Then Ac Unity arrived and it was finally, a return to what was like playing an Assasin's Creed game... it was about parkour, free movement, stealth, big city to climb, and other places to hide, but improved in some ways and the story side of things had potential. But the game had problems.
The main story had the french revolution chronology completely messed up and disorganized, if you didn't knew about the history period it would be impossible to follow what was hapening in game, the side missions being copy paste of each other a hundred times, and incredibly, the voices of the French characters had english accentâ€¦
Then AC Syndicate was announced and after seeing some gameplay i decided just there... i wasn't even going to try that game.

So after all this it's safe to say that i wasn't at all excited about Ac Origins. Of course i like Ancient Egypt as much as the next guy, but that doesn't mean Ubi can take any historical period they want, just throw you in the middle of it with nice looking graphics and expect you to just like it already right ? I mean... that's what they did with the last three games but still :D

Ashraf Ismail was the director of Black Flag and again here in Ac Origins and it shows.
I didn't like Black Flag, just because i wasn't interested in playing a pirates game , but that wasn't a bad game.

With Ac Origins i do like the idea of being lost in the desert with a camel (or a Legendary horse! ;) and this comes from someone who played a lot of Egypt games back in the 90s , i liked them but after so much Egypt i was pretty tired (especially because all the games were similar) but with Ac Origins, to say it goes deep into Egyptian mythology (without being too heavy, if you are just a casual) but deep enough that it does seem to add something more, to show Egypt like you never seen before, like they done a proper investigation and respected the subject (not unlike what they did with the French Revolution) that is saying a lot.

And while the main story of this game... fails to do justice, if you explore the map enough and go deep, very deep in its land, you will be surprised of how many things you can find.

To be honest here, this is possibly the least Assassin's Creed game of all Assassin's Creed... and that's good! when Assassin's Creed Origins forgets everything about Assassin's Creed and it just lets itself be what it is, a game about Ancien Egypt with great historical research a great land to explore and great gaming parts, it just shines and amazes and becomes one of the better games that came out of the Ubisoft factory since Patrice DÃ©silets, the creator of Assassinâ€™s Creed, left the company.

Then at the end, same as Black Flag, when it tries to relate with the firsts games it is too little to late... the connection to those games comes just at the last moment of the last couple of missions, some special objects and symbols here and there over the game...some bad excuses for the origin of some traditions... it seems forced and unnecesary...

In fact, Ashraf Ismail's game could be even better if he just wasn't trying to continue with the impossible task of relaunching again and again the Assassin's Creed saga wich has long ended since 2012.

As for the game itself, Assassin's Creed Origins takes chances, it dares to be quite different from the previous Assassin's creed games, and that's one of the reasons it works so well (as a game) It is fun, it makes sense, it is full of great characters that are full of life and expression (it is indeed a beautiful game to take photographs!) and in the end it does show respect for the Assassin's Creed legacy, (although the main story fails, the game and the exploration works excellent, including the side activities.)

Contrary to previous games in these last years, the side missions are generally good and sometimes pretty good, there are also other sides activities like the circle of stones wich is a nice adition to relax, the gladiator arena and also you have many tombs to explore (and the pyramids of course) which is great although i would've prefered more in depth exploration with them)

As for the main story it has a rough start, there is a short 3 minutes video, and that's it, you don't totally get Bayek at first, who he is, what he wants, why he is doing what he's doing (you start already with one assasination done and you don't know why) and it takes a long time to even finish the prologue (the main titles comes up after playing several hours) But...once the story starts going, and you meet Aya the game finds its rythm and it flows really well (as an Ancient Egypt game where you are a Medjay) and it has nothing to do with anything else really.
Then towards the end, the brotherhood is created...but... it seems unrelated, there's no real origin story thereâ€™s, just the spark, but then nothing happens . You don't get to see how it connects to the future chapters of the series.

Then the bad guys, the so called "The order" are unmasked but you never get to know anything about them really... and whats up with the head these guys worship?

And even before the ending, the main story of this game while it is well represented, and well acted, it does come out as short and doesn't have a lot of development.
The main missions are 20. By comparison the side missions are more than 100!! and that without counting tombs, and other side activities. All that side content, in this game is pretty well done, but i would GLADLY change half of that content, for more main missions to develop more the main characters and the main story. In fact, the game is really too long and at the same time feels too short because of a very weak main campaign. For example, the main character Aya is pretty interesting at first, but finally you don't get to see her too much (aside from being badass wich is cool) ... but in the end she becomes a little shallow) By comparison for example, Elise from Ac Unity even in that mess of a story manages to develop a lot and i still think she's the better female protagonist of any Ac game (yeah, even better than Aveline in Ac Liberation). And it doesn't do any good to just have so much side content if the main story suffers. Because that's all that remains long after the end.

That's really my only main gripe about this game. Because the game itself is really good. And i think it is about time Ubisoft let Ashraf Ismail do his own original game to see what he (and the team of course) are really capable off.
And as for Assassin's Creed ? I really liked this game, it was fun, and showed me a love and respect for Egypt that i truly cared and enjoyed while playing and sure, Ubi can make a dozen more of these games if they want, but i think it's time to finish here and try new things. Isn't that what it's all about?

Introduction:

After 360+ hours in the game I just completed everything there is to do and I can finally give you guys a good (spoiler free) review of Assassinâ€™s Creed Origins. Assassin's Creed Origins is a game set in the beautiful Ancient Egypt and is the origin story of the franchise. You play as Bayek, a retired medjay who seeks revenge because of events that took place before the main game. Assassin's Creed Origins is an RPG, Open World, Stealth, Adventure and Action game developed by Ubisoft Montreal, published Ubisoft, directed by both Jean Guesdon and Ashraf Ismail, written by Alain Mercieca, produced by Martin Schelling and composed by Sarah Schachner. This game runs on the AnvilNext 2.0 engine and it came out October 27, 2017 on both PlayStation 4, Xbox One and PC. This game is perfect for people who like RPG, Open World, Stealth, Adventure and Action games Assassinâ€™s Creed Origins is the latest installment in the franchise.

Story:

The story of Assassin's Creed Origins is amazing and also pretty long. For me it took around 40 hours to complete just the main story and I really liked the conecpt of how the it all started. You play as Bayek who is a retired medjay. Bayek is a very good protagonist and actually my second favorite protagonist after Ezio in the franchise.

Open World:

The open world in this game is amazing and takes place in ancient Egypt. When I played the game I stopped so many times just to appreciate the beautiful environment Ubisoft has created for this title and there is even big cities with amazing detailed architecture to explore. The cities themselves was very alive and filled with people to interact with and each city felt unique in it's own way when you visited them. There is a lot of things to do and see in this game and a few of them is to explore ruins and tombs, climbing pyramids, fighting in the gladiator arenas, join the hippodromes races, visit the Sphinx, explore underwater and so much more.

Combat:

The combat system in Assassin's Creed Origins is greatly improved as well and much harder and not as easy as the other games combat is. But it was hard but in a fair way and you really felt rewarded after defeating the enemy. I also really am happy with the new combat system just because it feels a lot more stable and not as clunky as the previous games from the franchise. But after you play for a while you will get used to the combat system and understand it.

Ability System:

In this game there is also a brand new awesome ability system. When you level you, you gain ability points that you can spend on new abilities and I overall liked the abilites I got and felt so rewarded when I unlocked them.

Gameplay:

This time around Assassin's Creed Origins is not your standard AC game but more like an RPG game and I really like that Ubisoft went down that road because I can honestly say that they nailed that aspect of the game. This game also delivers a lot of mission variety which is a big step forwards compared to the other games in the franchise. I also like that the parkour feels way much smoother and better developed. Another thing I liked as well was the new hunting and crafting system. You can use your eagle called Senu and mark the animals or resources to now where they are. You can either hunt or find resources to upgrade your personal gear but this time it felt important to do it and I felt very motivated to do it as well. For me I didnâ€™t feel like I had to grind to get resources like you did in the previous games. There are parts in this game which make the game feel very realistic and one of them are hallucinations you can get when you are in the desert regions because of the heat. You can also tame animals so they can assist you in battle for example, just like in Far Cry Primal for example. This games loot system was also very good and simple which is awesome and I hope that the other games in the future goes by this loot system.

Graphics:

The graphics and the visuals in this game is simply amazing, I think this game actually is one of the best looking games out there. You can explore environments like deserts, swamps, waters and much more. The details looks so realistic with the AnvilNext 2.0 game engine and people who really like the Ancient Egypt era will not be disappointed at all.

Discovery Tour:

Curse of the Pharaohs:

Photo Mode:

I'll give this game a good 9/10 and I highly recommend it to anyone who likes RPG, Open World and Stealth games. Recommended
463.9 hrs on record
Posted: October 27, 2017
Now that I have 100% the game and have more than 100 hours in it I feel I can write a final review of the game.

I will say now that if you are one of those people that thought Black Flag didn't really feel like an AC game then this game will probably also disappoint you.

Whist its a huge improvement over the last few AC games, and probably the best AC game since Black Flag, it still has problems, and one of them is very big. I will try to keep it as spoiler free as possible, but there is one point I may ruin that happens very early on in the story that I would not consider a spoiler but some people may, so be warned.

I will start with the good things.

-The open world is amazing, huge and fun to explore and has tones of interesting things to do

-The new side quest system is really good with over 100 unique side quests which makes the game feel more fleshed out, and the side content is actually fun for once instead of collecting chests and animus fragments from all over the map

-Almost no collectibles

-The new combat is really fun and much more challenging. Also makes stealth more meaningful

-Interesting main character

-Modern day is back, and whilst its still not as good as it used to its a huge step up over the last 4 games


Now the two small issues I have are:

-Very few historical characters. There is only really 3 major ones.
Cleopatra who is the main one, Caesar who is only in the end of the game, and Ptolemy who is only in 1 main cutscene. None of them are in the game enough and feel like wasted potential.

-Stealth feels more clunky than the last 2 games. You almost never use cover for stealth and social stealth has been removed. The animations are pretty clunky which really ruins the flow.


Now onto that major problem I mentioned.

Well it saddens me to say, but the story in this game is â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥. Seriously. I have never been this let down by a story in a video game in years, and AC games tend to have pretty good stories.


For those who don't yet know, last year Ubisoft announced a new plan of how to approach stories in their video games, going away from narrative storys and focusing more on the world and letting the player make their own storys in the world. To quote them "less storytelling and more players experience." Sadly this new approach may be the death of the franchise, atleast to me and many old AC fans.


The game starts of very messy with 3 different time periods, the main time period that you spend playing most of the game playing in, a flash back period 1 year before the main game where you find out about Bayek's Sons death (which is the main driving force for the story), and the modern day story. This jumping back and forth really confuses things and starts the game of badly. But it gets worse.

Every single assassination target in the game is completely forgettable. I finished the story 2 days ago and cannot remember a single one of their names, and only about 2 of their faces. Since this is a game about killing people, having villains that are so forgettable and giving you no real reason to hate them, except that one of them killed your son (who was only on screen for 5 mins in a flashback) is a really bad idea for a story and gives you no motivation.

The story telling also feels incredibly rushed, with most of your targets being assassinated in the very first mission they are introduced in, giving almost no character development and giving you no idea of what the are actually trying to achieve. The first assassination target is killed in the opening cut scene before you even start playing, the second target is killed in mission 2 and targets 3 and 4 are killed off screen so you don't even find out who they were.

There is another instance late in the story where you are told by one of the side characters that two of the people you were working with have betrayed you, just out of the blue. This is meant to be a major twist in the story, so why the â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ did Ubisoft get some forgettable side character to just walk up and casually say "you have been betrayed". Non of the characters even seem to care, so why the â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ would the player care.

To make it even worse, there are pretty much no interesting side characters, so the main story ends up getting carried by Bayek and his wife Aya's relationship, which is the only part of the story which is actually interesting in any meaningful way. Most of the side quests felt like they had more depth and story to them than the main story.

I hate to say this, but unless Ubisoft change their mind on story telling in their games then the AC franchise is dead. I'm sure it will continue to sell well, but the main reason core fans like me play these games is for the amazing story and lore that this franchise has, and sadly this game completely failed in that regard, and if the next game has a story as bad is this one then I'm afraid alot of the main fans may lose faith in the franchise.

I wish steam had a mixed rating since this is a really good game but the terrible story really lets the whole game down. I will give it a positive review for all the great improvements this game made, but if you are looking for a interesting narrative and emotional story go and buy one of the older AC games or the witcher 3 or something.
