Recommended
117.3 hrs on record
Posted: November 30, 2019
So. . . Assassins Creed Origins. There is some truth to the idea that if you've played one AC game, you've played all of them. This also extends to a certain degree to many other Ubisoft-published titles. They are vast open worlds with a plethora of mission content and objectives. You have a protagonist on a personal quest for revenge for some injustice done to him or her. Said protagonist is a parkour-performing serial killer with superhuman stamina and endurance. The series's most enduring mystery, whether it is "Assassin's Creed", "Assassins' Creed", or "Assassins Creed" is likely to never be answered to the satisfaction of many (okay, just me).

Origins is the somewhat-confusing tale of Bayek, a medjay (sort of an Egyptian sheriff) whose son was murdered by a cabal of conspirators who sought his assistance in opening a vault with, well, it's never terribly clear what was in it, but they figured that child-murder was a good way to get in it. Bayek didn't know how to get into the vault anyway, as is sometimes the way of these things, but he makes good his escape and begins a quest to hunt down the conspirators and forgive them. Just kidding. He wants to murder them.

My last AC game was Assassins Creed II, which I thought was really fun, but I ended up getting stuck on a story mission involving stealthily killing five or six different guys (yeah, the details are pretty fuzzy after all this time). I enjoyed most of the aspects of the gameplay, although the puzzle rooms were my least favorite. I think I'm too old for them--or maybe I never had the requisite patience to start with.

This entry in the series is purportedly intended to reveal the "origins" of the Assassins, hence the clever name. When you finish the game, you may have a vague idea about this, but there will remain things that are fairly unclear to you--unless it's just me and if you've played every AC game since ACII, you'd suddenly experience total enlightenment on this point. This is a possibility, but I feel confident that it is a remote one.

The game looks and sounds terrific. It's clear that Ubisoft Montreal put a massive amount of work into making period locations, details, and backgrounds as authentic as possible. If you don't believe me, check out the Discovery Tour mode. This mode is one of the things I was particularly excited about regarding the game. In it, you select a topic and an avatar from a range of the PCs and NPCs in the game and walk, ride, or punt your way through an area while hitting points of interest associated with behind-the-scenes information on creating the game world, real archaeological information, or real historical information about the setting, the people, and/or the place. It is a substantial amount of museum-tour-quality information at your fingertips, and Ubi sold it separately from the base game (there is no interactivity to speak of beyond the points of interest, so if you want to explore ancient Egypt without even being attacked by annoyed crocodiles, this is your ticket). It's quite good, but mostly what I've discovered is that, after putting approximately 119 hours into the base game and the DLC content, I don't really have the patience for it.

Bayek starts off with five targets to eliminate, one of which he does in the game's prologue. After finishing off the last target, he discovers that his conspiracy is more wide-ranging than he originally believed and gains a new set of targets. In addition to the main story missions, there are numerous side missions that appear in every region. They're not super-original or complex--they're fairly generic fetch, murder or rescue quests, but what they lack in quality they make up for in quantity. As in many modern open-world games, each region contains so much content that it's not difficult for you to "overlevel" the region. Ubi is aware of this and you have the option to have enemies scale to your level no matter what the default level is in the area; you also have the option to simply not do a lot of side missions that will give you so much experience that you overlevel the area. It really just depends on how you feel about the concept of enemy-scaling and content. I fall squarely in the camp of having more content rarely being a bad thing for a game (unless it's just a terrible game, which this is not).

When Bayek levels up he gains some health and damage and is able to unlock part of his prolific skill tree, with three areas of focus--melee combat, ranged combat, and "mystical abilities" (which include a lot of skills involving poisons, sleep toxins, and animal taming). These mean that you can play Bayek in a few different ways. My Bayek build was essentially a brutal combat machine who dealt serious damage with fast edged weapons. You can also rely on a lot of bow mechanics and sic animals on enemies and poison enemies with toxins that "infect" other enemies, leading to chain reactions of death. The variety of weapons available also makes for myriad tactical options (which you will need for some of the more challenging boss fights). For example, light bows fire a rapid succession of arrows, while predator bows have very low quantities of ammunition, but their charged shots can be devastating. Bayek can wield weapons ranging from daggers to several different types of straight and curved swords as well as large and small blunt weapons. Each of these can range from ordinary to rare to legendary in quality, with each step up granting more powerful bonuses (as one might expect). Weapons have levels, and it's possible to pay money to "level up" a weapon to bring it up to your current level, upgrading its stats. This way, if you have a favorite sword, you can ensure that it keeps up with you. Weapon types are, naturally, heavier and slower or lighter and faster, and these call for different strategies in handling single and multiple enemies in combat. All of this makes AC:O's combat system very rich and rewarding.

You will occasionally play as Bayek's semi-estranged wife, Aya, who is on a mission of her own to support Cleopatra's claim to the throne of Egypt against her brother Ptolemy. Her larger goal, of course, mirrors Bayek's, but she sees this as their best option moving forward--to gain powerful friends and ensure their ascendance. Aya's sections were not my favorites because he has a more limited set of abilities relative to her husband--and some of these sequences involve the game's dull and tedious naval combat. Yes, I get that some people like these sequences but I don't; I find them to be a jarring distraction from the elements of gameplay in the rest of the game. Naval combat involves awkwardly maneuvering your trireme to move around enemy vessels, launch fire arrow attacks, block enemy volleys, and avoid pitfalls like being rammed or running over Greek fire. One of these sequences is mandatory as part of the main story, another is part of an optional side mission, and another plays a role in one of the single-player DLCs.


There are some issues with the game. While it was remarkably stable in general, I did experience some crashes. Some of the game's quests require Bayek to use an ability called "Dawn & Dusk" that must be unlocked through the "seer" portion of the skill tree; this should have been an inherent ability. The framing-device story concerning Layla Hassan felt wholly unnecessary. Also the hints about aliens or gods or time-travellers meddling in mankind's development in the pyramids are bizarre and unexplained.

Having said those things, I have Odyssey in my backlog and am looking forward to firing it up in the near future.

32.9 hrs on record
Posted: October 30, 2017
I'll just say it, I love this game. If you've played Assassin's Creed games in the past, you pretty much know what to expect here. It's not doing anything we haven't seen in other games or pushing any boundaries, but it's a ton of fun and well worth your time and money.

Pros
+ Beautiful world set in a truly interesting setting (ancient Egypt). It's a joy to get lost in exploring. I've had many times where, on the way to a quest objective, I've run off to see what's going on over there and suddenly it's an hour later and I'm no closer to my quest objective.
+ Open-world stealth done well, though not quite up to the outstanding MGSV. I love assaulting forts, taking my time in picking off all the guards one by one. Using Senu (your pet hawk) to scout is a neat way to prepare your infiltration.
+ A TON of things to do. Side quests are (mostly) well-written, varied, and fun. The main story so far (I'm 20 hours into the game at the time of writing) is intriguing, and I'm excited to see where it leads.
+ RPG-lite mechanics. XP from kills, loot, ability points for new skills. Again, nothing too complex but it fits the game well.

Cons
- Overall it feels like they played it safe and went for accessibility over complexity. Like I said before, there's not much new here that we haven't seen.
- Melee combat can be clumsy. I appreciate that they went away from the Batman style to a more dodge and position based combat system, but it doesn't feel entirely... finished.
- Occasional graphics glitches. I had to restart the game once, and it went away.
- Uplay.

If you've enjoyed other Assassin's Creed games, and like the idea of exploring ancient Egypt, pick this game up.

100.1 hrs on record
Posted: June 2, 2019
BCE

We got used to playing a new Assassin's Creed game always taking place later in our historical timeline. Origins changes the formula and puts us in Ancient Egypt (around 49-47 BCE, to be specific). It should also be noted that throughout the game I often felt like playing a Prince of Persia game - the last PoP (as in the last AAA game since just last year a mobile game hit mobile stores) was released back in 2010.

The title refers to how the assassins group came to be. It is an interesting story and we even get to see how exactly the good guys came up with the symbol. As usual, while the story is completely fictional it takes place in the "real" world which was recreated as realistically as possible and once again it is nice to see our hero team up with famous figures such as Caesar or Cleopatra.

Egyiptian Police Force

In other words, Bayek The Medjay. We control him who has this very special title. The Medjay were mercenaries, protectors who always looked at the interest of the pharaohs. He is not alone - Bayek often meets up with his wife, Aya. The story is a tale of revenge, intially: Bayek sets out to find and kill those capturing him. This event led to the death of his son, Khemu. These mysterious figures who hide in the shadows and fulfil various roles such as priest or scribe are actually part of the Order. They try to control Egypt by using their puppet, Ptolemy. We team up with Cleopatra who is in a somewhat exiled position.

AnvilNext 2.0

The same engine is used here after Unity and Syndicate and oh boy does Origin look tremendously beautiful. Especially when we ride our horses in the vast desert of Egypt. There's a rich fauna in this world including hyenas, vultures, hippos and even crocodiles. We often encounter mirages while travelling out there - if not attacked by a group of mercenaries. Oh, and our mount can, of course, be camels not just horses. Facial expressions of characters look better than ever and the water effect is the best we've seen so far in the series.

Senu

Forget the special coloration when pressing V. This has been a signature thing in the series, this time, however, we literally have an eagle vision. Senu is Bayek's pet who's constantly above him in the sky. With just the press of a button we quickly move up in the air so that we can use Senu to tag our enemies. Our pet can even harass some of the targets. Holding V can release a pulse which identifies those objects we can interact with. Most of them here are all jugs, baskets or other containers holding valuables. Chests require holding the E for a couple of secs. They are much smaller and forget the animation we had in Unity where our hero opened a huge chest full of all kinds of stuff. What we have here is more practical.

Revamped combat mechanics

The real deal. No counters this time. Fighting with more than one enemy is a challenge. You get killed many times. Bigger weapons are slower, hit harder but Bayek still wields them with one hand. The other is retained for the - mandatory - shield this time. You can pick up a defensive stance and you can counter with your shield if your timing is right. This always gives the opportunity to hit an enemy successfully.

Adrenaline is gained when fighting. This gives us the opportunity to unleash special attacks (these are weapon specific). Then we have bows, lots of them. One makes us become sharpshooters (very high zooming ability), another cannot be charged but can be fired quickly and the warrior bows can fire several arrows at the same time. There you go: your sniper rifle, machine gun and shotgun.

RPG

Lot of weapons are available with different colours. Blue is standard, rare items are purple and yellow weapons are legendary. We have come full circle - this Assassin's Creed game has become an RPG. If we get attached to a weapon very much mercenaries always level them up to match our level (for a price, of course). As for Bayek himself: level cap is 40 but additional skill points we can obtain by exploring tombs or finding other specific locations in Egypt. We have a lot of abilities to choose from and, in general, it can be stated that we can go towards 3 directions: one skill "tree" is melee oriented, another makes us an expert marksman and the 3rd is more about using gadgets and excelling at hunting predators. You do not need to pick one - all skills can be obtained but it requires a lot of skill points so you really have to explore everything if you wish to be the ultimate warrior.

Exploring Egypt

The map is huge. And I mean H.U.G.E.! We have tons of icons and most of the locations have location specific activities. Once these are completed (treasure found, captain killed, predator hunted down) a small tick will indicate this on the map - this system is very good and makes canvassing the map much easier when aiming for 100% completion. We do a lot of hunting, collect skins of animals and other materials to upgrade our armour, health and wrist blade damage. No more naval battles this time, but we can take control of merchants' boats and get on bigger ships to kills soldiers by, let's say, freeing some lions. Oh, and there are underwater scenes!!! Lots of treasures to find in the ruins of temples located in deep water.

Virtual Museum

Remember Shaun's database entries from the previous instalments? There were a lot of information but it was too much and stopped the immersion. Shaun's inserted one-liners and other jokes helped the situation a little bit but overall I always read many entries when I was done with a couple of memory sequences. In Origins forget the database. Instead there is a free roam game mod called Discovery Tour which allows us to roam the world without any conflicts and we can participate in tours where a narrator explains how bodies were mummified or what beer types the Egyptians made or how certain outposts were fortified. This is just brilliant - a lot of content with hours of audio with extra screenshots on paintings or objects that can be found in museums all around the world.

RÃ©sumÃ©

Origins is an exceptionally good game, something that the series desperately needed. Bayek is still not Ezio but being a Medjay gives him a sort of by-the-book kind of guy feeling which made me lower my expectation. Plus, once again we can exit the Animus and get to meet Layla Hassan. Forget about the system of "initiates" and welcome Desmond's successor with open arms.

Posted: September 20, 2021
Assassin's Creed Origins
TLDR: This is a must play game and I highly recommend it due to it's level of detail, crazy number of quests and locations, great combat and progression!

I've finally 100% the game, done all quests, been to all locations, etc and feel like I can give an honest review of this game.

Origins is a lot different from all of the previous AC games, as this was the first in the series that Ubisoft changed up a little. Compared to the older games it has more combat ability and more to progress towards (upgrades, levels, skins, etc), however story-wise it is pretty similar. Here's some pro's and con's to the game!

Pro's
Playing through every location in the game just shows you the level of detail that went into making this game! From tombs, to camps, to castles, they are all amazing to explore if you are interested in Ancient Egypt.
The main story took me a while to complete, adding the DLC's and all the sidequests, exploring this full game has taken me a good 130+ hours. There is a crazy amount of content in this game to keep you entertained!
The combat in this game has improved SO MUCH compared to the previous AC games! You are no longer at a disadvantage if you are caught in the middle of an army of guards, stealth is only an option!
This game gives the player things to work towards. You'll find yourself too low level to take out a camp so you'll need to come back when you are stronger, this gives you a goal to work to which makes the game more interesting.
(Small pro but...)The soundtrack for this game, along with Odyssey is great and makes you feel immersed!

Con's
Like most Ubisoft games, this is quite badly optimised at times! Within a big city I was getting a lot of frame drops on Medium, after I upgraded my CPU I had very little issues on Medium but it is very CPU intensive in areas.
Some of the animations could use a little speed up as I feel Bayek is an old man sometimes with how slow he climbs.
The mounts are a little annoying, within a city they only run about as fast as Bayek runs. So sometimes it is quicker running to an area than using the mount.
Almost every enemy has a bow on hand, this is super annoying when you are trying to fight them and get annihilated with a volley of non-stop arrows


To Conclude!
This game is definitely worth a buy in my opinion! It is full of endless hours of fun and frustration, but after completing it you feel a sense of accomplishment and are more knowledgeable on the origins of the creed. Buy this game already, it is 100% worth the purchase!

78.6 hrs on record
Posted: April 12, 2018
Assassin's Creed Origins is the first Assassin's Creed game I've completed in a while (the last one being Black Flag). I picked it up recently during a sale and I must admit that my primary interest wasn't in playing through another of Ubisoft's entries in the unceasing franchise but rather in exploring a game world set in Classical Antiquity, a relatively untouched setting outside of tactics and strategy games. I wasn't particularly excited about the game in and of itself and, to be honest, my expectations were quite accurate. To begin with, the combat is a large departure from previous installments. It plays a lot more similarly to third-person action games like Dark Souls and while this makes for more interesting and intense large scale encounters, it comes across as a large departure from the traditional "Assassin" fantasy. Stealth is relegated to being largely optional in a similar vein to the many other open world games currently available on the market. The player is also stripped of much of their toolkit from previous Assassin's Creed games though this choice could be attributed to the game being first chronologically and you are given many new tools and abilities as compensation.

While the combat itself is certainly lighter and more fluid than ever before, I wouldn't go so far as to call it complex. The skill tree you're offered to choose from isn't especially interesting or innovative either, but it's definitely a step up. This leads me into another of my big complaints though, perhaps my biggest. The game, like many of its ilk, has an irritating tendency of taking agency away from the player. The amount of time your character's speed is arbitrarily limited for the sake of "immersion" had become infuriating by the time I was nearing the end of the game. Instances like being forced to move at a snail's pace while crouch-walking through a tunnel in a tomb when you can normally crouch-walk much quicker, or being made to literally walk while in the middle of an enemy encampment just because you're inside one of the few buildings. Having to watched the same finishing move you've seen a hundred times on an enemy while another enemy is just about to turn the corner and not being able to transition smoothly into picking up the corpse like some games have allowed you to do for a while now. When exiting one of the curtained hiding spots, the camera will flip around entirely to show the player doing their quick little animation when the only thing you should be looking at is whatever it is you're hiding from. The issue I take is that Ubisoft seems rather quick to discard sensible gameplay practices in favor of cinematic tricks which, while pretty to look at, tend to quickly grow cloying.

Another problem I would like to touch on is the parkour which has always been a staple of the series. As before the player can climb just about anything, it's getting down that tends to be the problem. It's not as bad as it has been in previous games, but in this instance the character seems to have a knack for getting stuck on ledges and railings where he should be able climb down quite easily. It's minor, but you'd think after a decade they'd have worked out the kinks a bit more thoroughly, though I suppose if it were that easy they'd have done it. But with all of the complaining out of the way, this leaves me with the main reason I decided to pick up this game in the first place, and allow me to be blunt; the world is gorgeous. If there's one thing the Assassin's Creed series has always got right it's set pieces, and this game is no exception. It's one thing to hear and read about the fabled streets of Alexandria, one of the most important cities in the classical world, but it's something else entirely to walk them. This is the most impressive display of Ptolemaic era Egypt I've ever seen and, to the extent of my knowledge, one of the most accurate. There isn't really too much else to say in that regard without sounding repetitive, so I'll just let the world speak for itself. In regards to what there actually is to do in that world, it's about what you'd expect from an open world Ubisoft game.

What you'll mostly find are small chests with crafting supplies and capturable outposts scattered around the map. Aside from the occasional maze-like tomb and side quest, much of the open world content is very par for the course. The main plot that takes you through this world is a rather cut and dry story of revenge following Bayek and his wife Aya. As far as interesting characters go, Bayek's certainly better than some we've gotten in the past, though I believe Edward and Ezio are still more enjoyable to play as. The story is servicable and I wouldn't say it does anything you wouldn't expect with it being the first game chronologically.
The only noticable bugs I encountered along the way were mostly audio (missing sound cues, one whole missing line of dialogue) and some janky lighting in certain underground areas. The game as a whole serves as an adequate entry into the franchise, and while I'm not sure I'd recommend it to anyone I know for more than $20 or $30, it certainly has it's merits. If anyone has a desire to explore the game world without the need of story or gameplay, a $20 version of the Discovery Tour exists as a standalone on Steam with audio guides and full access to the map. While the entire experience didn't blow me away, the game met my expectations and I look forward to seeing where they decide to take the next entry in the franchise.

Posted: November 17, 2020
Currently I am playing through all the titles in the AC series, because I want to understand the story behind it and see the progress that is done by Ubisoft from the very first to last games... Let us begin, shall we?

Even though this is not an AC game we're used to blah-blah... People around me were saying that this is the death of the series and I should play the first games, like AC1, AC2 (which is my favourite)... Don't get me wrong, I like the first titles, but frankly speaking the gameplay in the first one is boring as it can get (same in Mafia 3 *wink-wink*). Where was I? Ah, yes, I decided to give Origins a go.
I'm a fan of RPGs and Open-World-games, so this has already proved to be interesting for me. I logged into this game, not expecting much: first missions completed, galloping through picturesque landscapes, seeing pyramids in the distance, enjoying the immersive world with my trusty mount and bird. At some point I got so hooked, that had been playing for 6 hours straight.

In my opinion, Origins is a successor of the AC series, a bit from a different angle. If you're used to the old mambo-jumbo, I get it, but Ubisoft decided to add some new elements to the game, which I find positive.
I don't really want to write a long review, just leaving this here, so that you don't misjudge this game by only looking at its "cover".

Some things notable:
- Mechanics.
- Story (It is superior in comparison to some previous ones).
- Quests (They are unique, no repetitive stuff. Awesome, right?)
- Immersive world (If you ever wanted to slide down a pyramid, then why are you still here?)
- Tours (Has no impact on the game itself , but it is a nice bonus after finishing the game, where you can learn more about history, well-done!).

TL;DR: I rate this game Bayek (out) of Siwa.

Compared with Ramonet, he is not like an assassin at all, but it is precisely such a person who has left the mark of assassins from generation to generation. For this, I would like to understand this: no one is an assassin from the very beginning, walking in the dark and serving the light, everyone wants their own little happiness. I made it... Game Completion = 100%. Did every Mission / Side Mission, Every Achievement whatsoever. This Game is wonderful. TL;DR at the Bottom!

MY PC SPECS:

i7 7700k @ 4.2ghz
GTX 1070 EVGA SC
16GB DDR4 RAM
MSI Z270 GAMING PRO CARBON, Mainboard
Installed on an SSD with 256GB.

Runs Smooth at 80-100 FPS even on Citys with Settings Maxed out to Ultra on a 144hz Monitor @ 1080p

In Alexandria to around 70 FPS.

A game that is nothing short of a masterpiece, with new innovations and mechanics that make this a standout game in the franchise and arguably one of the best of the year. Without a doubt, the world is the most technically and graphically advanced of any open world game ever and that says a lot with Horizon Zero Dawn at one point having that title. Combat and skills work intuitively to carve a unique experience and leaves the choice with the player whether they want to be a jack of all trades or a stealthy assassin.

The story is incredible but has its fair share of flaws that I think could have made it even better but this series is definitely heading in the right direction. In terms of level design, it is no doubt that Ubisoft are masters of that aspect with what is a experience that mixes and matches that best elements of past franchises e.g. tree climbing, underwater exploration and even naval combat.

Ultimately this game is a standout in the series and definitely one of the best games of the last couple of years building on what was the previous two iterations of the series which were wholly disappointing. Nevertheless I think there is a room to improve in terms of the combat and skill tree which can be taken refined in the next instalment as well as developing on this new AC formula.

I know it probably sounds like im just a pure assassins creed fanboy, but im not really... I just like good video games especially rpg's, action games, and stealth. And this game is the perfect blend of all of them. In my opinion it is a masterpiece and a must play. A masterpiece in mechanics and gameplay set a in a world of beauty and intrigue. It doesn't get much better than this.

10/10 GOTY

TL;DR:

Pros:

+Great voice acting
+Excellent use of the ancient Egyptian setting
+Enjoyable new RPG focused combat / gameplay elements
+Memorable characters / engaging story
+Superb soundscape
+Superior graphics esp in ultra
+Excellent variety in missions with excellent side quests

Cons:
-Poorer gpu performance for AMD users
-DRM heats the CPU hard

130 products in account

73 people found this review helpful 1

Recommended
57.6 hrs on record
Posted: January 13, 2018
This game really surprised me.

I have to start this review by saying that I did pre-order this game and I have seen it in its raw state.
Also, I upgraded my specs while playing this game, so I can say a bunch about the performance on different levels.


First of all: The Story.

The story starts off simple: You are Bayak and your son got killed by some cult and you are out to get them. You are a Medjay; please don't ask me what exactly that is since it is only explained once in the beginning (I think, at least) and then never again.
You just hear people remind you that every chance they get.
But, you are out to seek revenge in those that murdered your son. Together with your wife Aya.
You experience this Story in the Animus, like it is common in AC games.

Speaking of Aya, a heads up: You do get to play as her in the Story as well, she even has her own little chapter if you find her DNA in the cave.
It's nice to change between two characters though, even if it only happens 2 or 3 times.

GamePlay:
Finally; finally you get to do what you want. The game narrates you for around an hour in the beginning, showing you some basic things, they differ a little from older AC games, but it's nice to have it. After that; boom, you are free.
At least a little. It took me 5 ingame hours of Main- & Sidequests to get the . And after that you set out to do your thing.
You could basically enter every single disctrict with the lowest level, you just won't get far. But you can.
Player freedom is insane in this game.
You do not get to choose who to kill (obviously, it's still a story) but you do get to decide a lot. Even if you want to show Mercy or not.(Once.)
One thing that really bothers me is the Parkour in this game. It's never regocnized to be something special, you can't understand the comments (unless you speak egyptian, I guess) and most people don't even react to it.
I love that in other AC games people would comment on it or be somewhat impressed.
Bayak can make jumps Ezio would be so damn proud of and he can basically climb anything. Even walls where I am pretty sure he is holding onto nothing.
At first this was really bothering me, but after some time you just accept it and it does get pretty useful to climb all kinds of pyramids or castle to infiltrate them whichever way you want to.

And to move on to the last part of the gameplay: Parkour is no longer the shortest or best way to get somewhere.
Despite the fact that you can climb anything, it won't do much. Cities are build in ways that you are mostly moving on the ground and actually executing parkour moves ends in you breaking your legs most of the time.
And using it as an escape is also no longer an option. Which is quite sad.

So I decided to play the game as stealth as I probably could.
And it pays off soooooo much.

It changed the entire game experience for me. Sneaking up on enemies, whistling to get their attention, tricking them with arrows, putting them to sleep or poisining them. It all works perfectly.
You can combine them, as well. Depends on how you want your character to work.

You can also go full Gladiator and only wear heavy blades, staffs and other heavy armor.
And before you ask: YES! you can fight in two arenas after you finished the mission on them. Side missions, I think.
And the Arena is a lot of fun, I am glad they implemented it. You can see your friends best rounds and beating them is actually a fun thing to do. Especially after you beat the game.

/EDIT: 24.01.2018:
I have played some more after finishing the story and have notice so many more incredible things. Like for example: If you shoot a normal arrow through fire, it will ignite and deal fire damage to enemies or implode barrels. Starting the just released DLC gives new levels, new gear and upgradeables.

Gear:
Oh boy. You can level your armor, pouches, arrows, by finding materials in the word. You can hunt animals for their trophies and materials or you can boycott enemies who transport materials. When people die they mostly drop loot as well. And almost anywhere in the world are container with loot in them. You can't miss it.
You can buy, sell and upgrade weapons and armor at Blacksmiths and buy new armor and clothes.
You can also buy new camels & horses from the Farmer in every city and sometimes even way outside one. It's pretty neat, let me tell you that.
Every weapon, armor and companion is leveled. Depending on the level, they have certain colors. Blue, Purple, Gold, etc.

Skills:
There are plenty, 3 of which you can level infinite amounts of times.. Those 3 are the end of every branch. Arrow, Sword and Tools.
You don't have to level them all to get to the end of the branches, in case there is stuff you don't need.
This adds to Player Freedom since you are not forced to buy random skills you don't want or need to get to other skills you may want. Plus points here, Ubisoft.

The world:
Oh lord. I am impressed. After I finished the game I still had 4 sections still completely unexplored, I didn't even step foot into it.
The world is huge. And there are many different places to visit, explore and just loot. There were times when I just took my trusty golden horse, took on my armor, rode through the desert and explored.
There is a photo-mode included into this game, that let's you take professional screenshots. This way you can see small little photo-icons on the world map of Photos other players took. You can also rate them.
This is a really amazing feature and sometimes even shows you what awaits you at a certain place.
/Edit: I finally managed to get three more sections explored and I am blown away.
But one section, a lonely desert, still creeps me out. You have Satly areas, full on deserts and greenland. Let me put it this way: You won't get bored.

But just riding through the desert, either fast or slow, looking how the sun goes down and the desert starts cooling off, you just relax. I always experienced the AC:Games to be kind of stressfull. You always gotta watch your back.
But not in this one. Sure, there are alot of insane moments and fights, but there are so many ways to escape all of this.
I really enjoyed just being free.

What is also nice to mention is your all-time companion. Your eagle. Senu.
You can take control of it and fly around the world freely. You can fly pretty far away from your character from what I have tested so far and he can help you spot enemies, loot and secret paths.
You can also skill him to distract enemies and everytime you do a leap of faith his perception gets increased. Neat.


Last but not least:
Performance.

On my old setup; AMD Fx 8320; 16GB DDR3 RAM it ran like crap. 20 frames on low in the city, up to 60 outside, but it stuttered.
New setup: AMD Ryzen 5 1600X; 16GB DDR4 3200;Mhz; same GPU as before: 70+ frames wherever I go, whatever I do, no matter how many corpses, AI, it doesn't matter. All on high-Very high.

Overall:

At first you need to be patient with the game. You need to let it grow on you, get used to its ways. But once you got the hidden blade (Took me 5 hours with sidequests), you are good to go. The game doesn't direct you anymore, it just watches you unfold & play. You have so muhc freedom to do what you want. There are no timers, no need to do this and that. You can take your time, get to know the world.
And even after you finished the game; it's all still there for you to explore. It's incredible.
Of course there are parts in this game that annoyed me (repetetive sea missions) but I can see over this for once.

The game is not perfect, but it is a lot of fun and after 40 hours I have finally finished it.
There is still so much for me to explore and do and I will.

If you want to play the origin story of Assassins' creed, with almost complete player freedom, here you go.
This is your chance. Take it.

I recommend it.

9/10.

93.4 hrs on record
Posted: June 8, 2020
Assassin's Creed: Origins is my 7th AC game, and is probably my favorite so far after AC Brotherhood. Origins has all the elements of a great videogame: Amazing graphics, good worldbuilding, interesting story, and fun gameplay. (Long post)

What I love about this game:
- BAYEK OF SIWA. He is such a strong character, and his VA Abubakar Salim did an amazing job in portraying him. . IT WAS A BEAUTIFUL JOURNEY. He's just so full of life, and you can see multiple sides of him as you go through the story: a protector of Egypt, a grieving father, a loving husband, a cold-blooded killer, a concerned citizen, a sassy mf (lol). He's such a multifaceted character, and I think he's my fave AC protagonist, along with Ezio.

- The parkour! You can climb everything ala Breath of the Wild!!! And it's so smooth! I had absolutely no trouble climbing anything, which is a surprise, since AC parkour has always been pretty wonky.

- The story was pretty good. Though most of it is because of Bayek.

- The world is beautiful, and it's an absolute treat to explore. I could roam around Egypt for HOURS. And I felt so immersed.

- The combat is much, MUCH better than any AC game I've played so far.

- YOU CAN FINALLY CROUCH. HALLELUJAH

What I didn't like about this game:
- The leveling system. In general, I'm not a huge fan of separating areas in an open-world game by level (i.e. you need to be a certain level to explore the area or you will die in one hit). I like when it feels organic, like in metroidvania type games where you need a certain item to get through it, or a softer approach where you just need better gear like in AC IV.

- The loot system. There were sooo many items and weapons that it sort of became a chore to sift through them.

- The empty desert areas. Like, why are they even there if you aren't going to put anything in them?? At least put in a few locations.

Overall, a really, really good game. And while it did sort of veer away from the traditional AC format, it's still pretty amazing.

103.2 hrs on record
Posted: June 14
i'm a Hidden One.
I've been constantly postponing playing the Assassin's Creed series for a long time. I'm finally here to share my thoughts on AC: Origins, the first AC game I've finished.

Assassin's Creed: Origins is an open-world action role-playing video game, the 10th installment of the AC series. The story is set in Ancient Egypt during the Ptolemaic Period and deals with the origin of the assassin-templar conflict with the assassin faith. The game processes the story of Bayek, the first Assassin, a former Medjay who fought to protect his people from dangers.

-- In addition to what I said above, I can say that although I haven't played the series fully, I know that the AC series has always taken real events as its starting point. And this time, we witness the spread of Rome's Republic-Monarchy conflict to Ancient Egypt. Cleopatra was removed from the throne she claimed, and her brother Ptolemy ascended the throne. Cleopatra, who defended that Ptolemy was a puppet, also declared war for the pharaohship. At this point, Cleopatra will not hesitate to take advantage of even Rome's civil war. It is right in the middle of this turmoil that we are Bayek of Siwa chasing his own revenge story. --

it's hard to be a medjay, but it's harder to be Cleopatra's medjay. 
A Screenshot of Assassin's Creed Origins
By: sergio

While Bayek is normally expected to be a character who always frowns and sprints along the path of revenge due to his own story, he was created as a character who can find pleasure in the small details of life and has a sense of humor. That's why Bayek of Siwa took his place in the list of my favorite characters in my game life.

Let me tell you about the innovation in the AC series that comes with this game. Unlike previous games in the series, AC: Origins stands out for its role-playing innovation. The game has the must-have features of role-playing games such as a level system, ability system, and item system. It's just not that. There is also a crafting system. By collecting certain resources, you can improve your hidden blade, quiver, armor, and many other features. Also, if your level has increased and the weapon you like is no longer powerful, don't worry, because you can improve your weapon to the same level as you by going to a blacksmith. Here are all these and many other innovations that show us that AC: Origins has taken on the character of a role-playing game.

holaa! 
A Screenshot of Assassin's Creed Origins
By: sergio

Let me also tell you a little about the new combat system. Because I've never really enjoyed fighting so much before. :) In the new combat system, we can no longer counterattack with a single button and knock down the enemy with a single movement. Especially if our enemy is strong, we also need to actively use important movements such as dodging attacks and avoiding attacks. This also increases the enjoyment of the game.

Assassin's Creed Origins has a seriously huge map. The fact that the world is so vast offers us many places to explore. A new place we can explore may contain a new task, item, resource, or something new related to the story. In addition, the fact that small puzzles have been added to the game is also one of the great features. I have completed all the main missions, side missions, events, and question marks in the game in 100+ hours. I have enjoyed every hour of these 100+ hours. The graphics, in a word, look amazing. The specific mood of ancient Egypt is reflected very nicely. The in-game animations are also beautifully crafted. Although artificial intelligence is not perfect, it can perform much more logical movements than old games.(after a certain level of difficulty)

With all this told, I really liked AC: Origins. I had a satisfying gameplay experience with almost non-repetitive missions on such a huge map. I did my best and as much as I believed it was stupid to take revenge, I did my duty. Now I can say that i'm fine with this, i'm not a father anymore, i'm not a husband, i'm not a Medjay. i'm a Hidden One.

"i'm fine with this, i'm not a father anymore, i'm not a husband, i'm not a Medjay. i'm a Hidden One." 
A Screenshot of Assassin's Creed Origins
By: sergio

sergio... signing off.

Consequently, i do recommend the game 8/10.

Not Recommended
117.9 hrs on record
Posted: October 28, 2017
TL;DR -- This game has LOTS of bells and whistles (open world size/depth, graphical prowess) and lots of polish, but the core mechanics (fighting, climbing, and stealth) are actually a step back from Syndicate.

Detail --I have a really hard time choosing between the "Yes" and "No" answer to whether I recommend this game. There are some things it does so well that it's just a joy to play; the environments are stunningly well-crafted and the graphics are gorgeous. But there are also some features it's either completely missing or does so poorly it leaves me wanting to bang my head against the wall because they detract from what could have been such a better game. It also runs very shakily, with regular, ugly frame drops.

If you adore the series like me, then go ahead and pick this up. You'll get enough out of it to make it worth a purchase (as I feel I did). But if you're not a fan then skip Origins unless you love Egyptian history. This game won't convert you. And I'd go even further to say that if you're lukewarm on the series, you probably want to skip this, too. All it really does well is open world and soundtrack. So unless one of those two are something you love in a game, you're probably not going to like Origins enough to spend $60 on it.

I'm pretty stunned that there are a number of things this game actually does worse than its predecessor, Assassin's Creed Syndicate, which is a game that many consider to be one of the poorer entries in the series.

For starters, free climbing is an absolute mess in Assassin's Creed Origins. The reinvention they worked so hard on in Unity with the Free Climb Up and Free Climb Down buttons, and the perfection of that system into what I consider the smoothest free climbing in the series in Syndicate is completely gone from Origins, which instead has reverted to the absolutely terrible "One Button to Free Climb" system that birthed the frustrating moments of the worst game in the series (in my opinion), Assassin's Creed III. Get ready to randomly jump off walls into the middle of 8 enemies in a courtyard when you're trying to stealth, or to begin climbing up the wall next to you when you're just trying to reposition yourself in the middle of a fight. In addition to this, what you can climb is not really indicated visually anymore. Some buildings have clear grooves that are not usable as handles, and there are statues that have no handholds whatsoever that are easily scaleable. Some spaces seem to far to jump but you can with ease, others seem clearly in reach but are not. It's completely arbitrary and leaves you feeling railroaded.

In addition to the poor free climbing, combat is an clusterâ™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥. Ubi has swiped Witcher 3's combat system without shame, except the smoothness of that game is completely gone, leaving you janky, unnatural, strangely timed animations, and dodges that happen inhumanly fast yet still get you hit by enemies because the hitboxes are so inaccurate. And you have no Signs or potions to deepen the experience. It feels weird, it looks bad, and it's shallow. It's not fun. I played through Witcher 3 on Death March and had a lot of fun, so it's not that I'm bad at video games. Origins saw me turn the difficulty to Easy almost immediately so I could just button mash and blast through the enemies and avoid the combat almost completely.

The stealth is not as good as Syndicate, which made great improvements such as using cover and specific designs in the environment to your advantage. It's not even as good as the stealthy side missions (saving child workers, etc) in Syndicate. It's the same stealth gameplay from Black Flag, which was fine... 4 years ago. Really disappointing if you love the stealth genre like I do and were happy with the improvements from Syndicate.

Another puzzling design choice is the complete removal of the Codex and the historical info blurbs that pop up as you're free roaming. One of my favorite things to do in an AC game is to free roam, hitting map markers, while reading the historical blurbs that pop up to provide improtant context. It's absurd that Ubi would completely remove them from this game for the first time. I'm a layman to Egyptian history and they could have provided some great context to some of these characters. It's great knowing that they're based on real, historical people who actually lived. That context is completely gone and the majority of these characters I'm meeting are way too thinly written without it. They're dry as paper and may as well be scarecrows with costumes. The story is mediocre in general. It's a generic revenge tale with some oddly inconsistent tone (Bayek seems awfully cheerful for having a young son who was brutally murdered less than a year ago) and peppered with some awful voice acting. Bayek and Aya's performers are great, but Layla's is awful, and a lot of the minor characters are inexcusably bad, too.

Okay so I'm kind of crapping all over the game here, but it does still do some things amazingly well. The addition of RPG elements, including ranked loot, really help push you towards exploring, too. At its best, Origins will keep you up all night hitting question marks on the map, levelling your character, getting new loot, and generally just progressing and clearing the map. The open world is spellbinding. There's such a variety in terrain -- desert, arid mountains, oases, cities, woods, etc -- That you never get tired of simply hopping on your camel or horse and exploring. There's verticality, water to dive in, tombs to raid, and caves to spelunk. And the variety in cities is excellent as well. Gone are the samey cities from past games, and back is the huge variance in cities such as between Florence and Venice in II. The Greek architecture of Alexandria, the old Egyptian setting of Memphis, and the varied small oasis towns and camps in between them keep everything fresh and you never feel tired of exploring. There was a point for about 50 hours when I was just free roaming, having a blast experiencing these great environments, and I seriously considered changing this review to positive. But roaming an open world can't carry a game by itself. So I eventually grew bored of hitting points of interest and continued Origins' story missions only to be forced into bad mission design, bad combat, badly designed stealth segments, and bad plot writing, and began hating this game all over again. A lot of this game reminds me of Assassin's Creed III, with all its poor mission design and bad story.

To be concise, the problem is that too often the great stuff in Origins is broken up by one of the negatives I mentioned earlier. I'll stealth through two or three bandit camps, hit points of interest, gain levels and hunt loot while progressing my character, taking in the quiet moments and enjoying the great soundtrack... Then I'll run into a free climbing snafu, or get bogged down in its clunky combat for 10 minutes, or play some drearily designed story mission that kills any desire to keep playing.

Despite all my hours logged, I still haven't finished the game. I've cleared most of the map icons from free roaming, but the story, combat, stealth, and general mission design failed to engage me to such an extent that I have no desire to actually complete the game. I've already gotten what I wanted out of it: A great open world experience that I can take in at my own leisure. It's unfortunate that so much other frustration got in the way. And because of that I can't honestly recommend this game to any but the most hardcore Assassin's Creed fans. So I've got to check the "No", despite my inner Assassin's Creed fanboy wanting to click "Yes".

My series ranking: Origins is nowhere near as good as II, Brotherhood, or Black Flag, but still a more enjoyable experience than the putridly awful III and the below average Unity.

Posted: December 28, 2019
Bayek is a cinnamon roll. You can't change my mind.

This was my first Assassin's Creed game. I played a lot on PS4, but it was so enjoyable to me that it was worth the purchase for Steam.

Origins has a lot of pluses, and only 2 downsides.

Pros:
1) Enjoyable loot system. Even bad loot is good as it can be broken down into parts immediately, and gives a lot of parts when you do to later upgrade Bayek.
2) Combat offers many paths while not absolutely forcing you to do anything. Would trinkets help as opposed to direct combat sometimes? Yes. Do bows do OP damage but a stealth approach would be better for avoiding detection? Yes. Is melee smashing the most satisfying? You bet your ass. But are you ever forced to do any one path? Nope. You can finish any mission any way you want, even if certain strats would be better.
3) You actually get bonuses for unlocking locations. Senu can detect objectives and people a lot quicker and at much farther range once you've unlocked a fair amount of locations.

The cons:
1) Bayek's wife Aya is not developed well at all. The player is constantly told by NPCs that she's strong and venerable, but really all you see is her going down the path of bloody vengeance that everyone warns Bayek not to do. In essence, she gets praised by NPCs for doing things off-screen that those same NPCs warn Bayek not to do. This could easily be overlooked if it were in a supporting character, but considering Aya is the main character's wife, and you're forced to play as her in a few places, she just ends up feeling like a really unnecessary burden that the player is always forced to remember right about when they would otherwise forget she exists.
2) The present day story line is so disconnected and unnecessary. The game is really fun and even exciting to play in the Egypt storyline, but every time I'm forced to go back to the present day it feels forced. The game is trying to serve the present-day story line as opposed to having the present-day story line serve the overall game.

Thank you for your time.

I give Assassin's CreedÂ® Origins: 8.8/10

Minor Spoilers: One of the oldest yet best story driven game franchises within the gaming industry. A great franchise with a huge influence over other games and with an original story driven setting; Assassins creed. After the launch and huge success of ACII the game has had a lot of successful title releases however, in recent years Assassin's Creed failed to show gamers that their franchise is still the best story driven series within the respected genre. That is until Assassin's Creed Origins drops and it is insanely good. It almost brings the vibes from what you felt in ACII.

Personally, one of my favourite gaming franchises a long with other several Rockstar and Bethesda games. I can't play single player games since they bore me however, with Assassin's Creed I can always make time for. Assassin's Creed Origins deserves a top 3 in my favourite AC games.

Pros

Graphics: Graphics in this game is mind blowing. Personally, I think Origins has the best graphics as of now. Everything is beautifully detailed. From the stormy sandstorms, to the calm swaps of the Nile. Everything looks so calm and soothing that I take my time to stop and take a screenshot here and there and upload it to the Ubisoft Club.

Immersion: Origins is very immersive. To level up, you don't follow a main quest after main quest but you are forced to level by doing side quests or other various activities. This game is insanely immersive and my reason for this is NPCs have their own minds. They eat, sleep, guard, talk etc. You can wait until night to assassinate people which is easier since there are fewer guards awake and more sleeping. Animals sleep too! The landscape shape shifts around such as spreading oil and dead body's using water tides or the weapons sinking in the sand. This game has so many features of immersion that I simply couldn't list all.

Story: We follow Bayek of Siwa as he ventures through Egypt to find the killer of his son. The story slowly shows us how the creed of Assassins is formed. I try my best not to give to many spoilers but besides that, there are several intriguing side quests with their own interesting story. We learn a lot about the Egyptian gods through the story and side quests and how each god influences the people.

Soundtrack: The soundtrack is simply beautiful. It brings that unique ACII soundtrack with a version of its own using Egyptian soundtrack. I don't think their was any soundtrack in Origins that made me think "What is this?" but instead it make me think "This is really good".

Gameplay: This game provides tons and tons of hours of gameplay. Don't be thrown of by the 25 average completion hour rate. People that completed it within 25 hours probably had the game on the easy difficulty (yes there are difficulties now). This game provides an insane amount with many activities to participate in such as gladiator fights, tomb raiding etc. There is always something to do in Origins, even if it's something simple such as upgrading your gear.

Historical Figures: This game is set around the end of the Egyptian kingdom so it features the historical figures such as Cleopatra and Julius Ceaser. This isn't one of those one scene cameo appearances but full on dialogues with each historical figures. I find this very interesting since people who love history would love this kind of stuff.

Diverse Gear: The gear that you have can be customised to your liking. You can have your own style of play depending on the gear you have and the abilities that you have picked. I find this as a strong point because everyone would want to play their own way and are not forced to play the game wants them to play.

Enemy Scaling and Combat: I know some people may not like the whole NPC enemy levels but trust me, this is a huge leap for the AC franchise. Enemy leveling provides a huge challenge if you are underleveled. As fun as the old combat system was where you'd counter attack and do that without getting hit for once, that doesn't happen in Origins. You have to think what your next moves are going to be and how you approach things which requires more tactics.

Cons

Performance: It wouldn't be Assassin's Creed without a few bugs on release. Do expected bugs within Origins but they aren't hugely game changing. Sometimes you don't notice them but I wouldn't blame someone if it killed their immersion because of it. Regardless of that, this game runs very smoothly at high graphics.

Parkour: A minor change I would ask is for the parkour to be improved. I've had more deaths due to Bayek jumping off where I wasn't facing or losing a lot of health because of it. I do find this frustrating but I dealt with it since it didn't happen always.

Cut scenes: Yet again, this isn't a huge con but some cut scenes felt really bland and boring to me. Like the CG for the face wasn't done right or something, especially the cut scenes in slow motion. But like I said, it's not all cut scenes that had this problem, only the very few.

I hope you enjoyed my quick review of Assassin's CreedÂ® Origins. I highly recommend getting this game as Ubisoft did a great job reviving the series after a few recent flops. This game is very addicted and immersive. It gives an insane insight to how the creed was formed and how Egyptian life was as well a bit of the Roman and greek life within Egypt. It teaches you more than what you history teacher could ever teach you. You will come out with more knowledge as well as hours of gameplay. I can't wait for the next game for the series.

Nothing is true Everything is permitted.

Assassin's Creed Origins is the 1st game in the AC series to go all in on the RPG elements, and I have to say, they succeed in doing so as this change was needed to reboot the series and make it fresh and exciting yet again.

TLDR: This game is a solid 9/10 (base game) and is definitely worth the try if you're an open world/RPG fan. Both the DLCs are also amazing and totally worth it thus the Hidden Ones gets a 8.2/10 and the Curse of the Pharoahs is 8.5/10.

Now for the Pros- The setting of the game being Ptolemic Egypt is a huge win, the place is soo beautiful, wonderfully designed and detailed, and almost serves as a mysterious place and we don't know anything about. This was also the first time AC went extremely in the past and I'd say it helps with the *change* they were going for. The soundtrack too adds to that mysterious feeling as you don't know what to expect. The story of the game is really good, it serves well overall for Bayek although its more of just a revenge story so... Talking about Bayek, he is an amazing protagonist, definitely my favorite of the series after Ezio, the voice acting is really well done and the motion capture is pretty good. Now talking about the world, the side quests here are amazingly well written, each side quest has a proper story attached to it and it feels natural for our character who is a *Medjay* or a police type figure that helps people, these side quests just add to the immersion. Also I have to recommend everyone who's looking to pick up this game to try the Discovery Tour prior to starting the game as this tour is really well detailed and they explain how the whole world was designed and the historical significance of each and every thing that the developers added to this game, so that when you play the game, you'll feel the world to be a lot more alive instead of being a backdrop to your story. The new combat system is also really well done, and i was soo happy Ubisoft got rid of the counter attack styled combat as it was extremely boring, this newer combat system is a lot more engaging, you have different weapon types, each with pros and cons to suit your playstyle, same for the different bows and tools that are available for us to use. The weapons have a weight to them and the enemies don't feel like damage sponges and I wish they keep it that way (*cough Odyssey cough*) The boss fights are also nicely done especially the one with that big snake and the weekly trials of anubis. The gladiator arena, the war elephants and the hippodrome races are also nice additions and are there for all those who'd enjoy them. The naval missions are also great and extremely fun.

Now for the Cons- There are microtransactions, which although aren't forced at you but are an ugly site for any AAA title. Next is that even though the combat is nice, it can get old quickly. The stealth in this game is also not necessary as the combat is a lot quicker and easier. The lip sync is really weird and it really isn't up to the mark for a huge company like Ubisoft. The also doesn't have any social stealth, in the Discovery Tour however you can interact with the environment and it would have been soo cool to include it in the base game for some stealth kills. Now the game has well made cutscenes overall but most of the times it'll be like a free camera in which both the character and the npc just kinda talk, which was okayish and not as good as I'd have wanted.

Now for the Hidden Ones DLC- This continues the story of the brotherhood 4 years after the main game ends, we get a new area to explore in the form of Sinai, it is slightly different to the main game but its kinda more of the same, the story here is really well written and all the side quests only enhance the experience, a very short and sweet content and was enjoyable overall.

Now for The Curse of the Pharoahs DLC- This DLC is awesome, it introduces a new area to explore with 4 afterlife regions which are really well designed, there are new boss fights as well and the story is great too. Its a really good expansion overall and definitely worth it

Posted: November 27, 2020
I'll keep this brief. This game's pretty much focusing on being an RPG and it definitely works. They "borrowed" a surprising amount of mechanics from The Witcher 3 and even more shockingly, some things are just flat out done better.

The world's better in my eyes. Not because it's more varied or even more exciting, but just by making actual sense. No longer do you have small areas that somehow have famines while having rich areas just 3 minutes away. You don't just have insane cultural shifts in the world within minutes of each other. While I liked The Witcher 3's world, it was also very nonsensical. I was worried Origins would be all about deserts, but you'll see a lot of lush vegetation, swamps, sandy deserts, rocky deserts, inhospitable wastelands and so on.

The side quests are also much more interesting. The Witcher 3 already had great side quests and I think Origins managed to take their ideas and expand on them. Quests that are tied into the world much more strongly are commonplace and while mechanically they can boil down to a series of objectives, it's something I think we should be expecting anyways. An action game will have action. Yeah, there's been a lot of action already, but that's what you're here for.

Graphically the game's â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ gorgeous. Occasionally I have games that make me "ooh" and "aah" on a regular basis and this was one of them. Seeing the pyramids of Giza in their full glory was just amazing. Same goes with the background vistas, all of which felt reachable, yet impossibly far at the same time. Just absolutely top notch stuff.

The gameplay loop is what you'd expect though. Clearing out areas, side quests, looting, killing. If you liked clearing out areas in The Witcher 3, then you should be fine with this. If anything, occasionally you'll be having more interesting stuff here than in The Witcher.

There's just one problem in the game... and it's big for me. There's a level cap of 55 when you have the Gold Edition and 40 if you're on the regular version. This takes away the extrinsic motivation from the player during the last DLC, which already suffers from the "lost potential and too generic" syndrome. So because of that my last 5 hours in the game were just boring and unexciting. I am a person who loves overlevelling and overpreparing and the game just doesn't allow for it and that's more than disappointing to me.

Also, check out the Discovery Tour. If you like easy to digest pop history, then this is for you. It's a great addition with a surprising amount of effort having been put into it. I just hope Odyssey has a similar mode with even more put into it.

I personally don't regret getting the Gold Edition, but it's definitely neutered simply through the awful level cap, which kills a good portion of the excitement and fun in RPG games.

Posted: July 17, 2020
AC: O is reportedly last AC game about assassins. It's also a game with the most RPG elements in the series and and it's amazing. Here's why:

Gameplay
The most important factor in this game. It's very enjoyable. Movement is really smooth. You can ride a horse or a boat everywhere, so travelling long distances is not a problem. As an assassin, you can climb everywhere and use stealth in many occaisons. Combat is very exciting. It's classic rpg-style combat (light attack, heavy attack, charged attack, block and dodge) so easy to learn, but harder to master. You fight enemies based on lvl, so you need to earn xp through quests, activities and world exploration to progress. You can fight many types of enemies (humans and animals), there are also mini bosses, arena bosses and very big bosses (elephants, gods). There are many type of weapons you can fight with. You can also use many types of bows, sleeping darts, or fire bombs. On the other hand, weapons of the same type are not very different from each other (except legendary gear). You can also customize your character with many skills and perks through 3 skill trees. There are aslo many outfits that your character can wear. You can find a few graphical and gameplay bugs present, but nothing significant.

Story
It's decent, because it delivers what the title promises: how and where were assassasins founded. You play as Bayek - a medjay of Egypt to achieve justice. It has It's strong and even emotional moments. Also ending is great. Many side quests expand the main story really nicely. Some has very simple and usual story. The good thing is, that there are many of side quests, so it can take a while to complete them all. Modern story is still present, but not very much and it's really poor.

Activities
There are lots of them and they are very enjoyable. Except of main story and side quests, you can complete outposts (berserk mode or stealth mode) hunt for treasures, solve riddles, explore ancient tombs, fight in the arena, race in hypodrome, clear animal dens and fight gods or war elephants. There are ton of these activities through out of whole map, so it will take a while to complete them all (if you want to).

Enviroment
Everybody knows, that one thing that Ubisoft can do right, is enviroment. The Egypt is huge, beautiful, living place. From crowded cities filled with real life buildings/monuments to lovely villages and fields. Because we are in Africa, huge part of the map cover dry deserts (some with oasies) and mountains. From a graphics standpoint, it's really well made. Amazing water effects, lighting effects, textures, particals, shadows and everything else. Sometimes I cought myself wandering around the map, admiring the beauty of the world. Really good job Ubi !

Conclusion
Great RPG set in gorgeous Egypt with many things to do that is still worthy member of the assassin's saga.

Assassin's Creed Origins brought to me some fresh air for this series. The game brings us to the old Egypt and let us play as Bayek of Siwa, a Medjay of the Old Kingdom.
The game is gorgeous to look at, I couldn't exactly play it at maximum details because of the horrible optimization this game has, but even so I loved the graphic and aesthetic the game offered me.
The gameplay received a complete overhaul, the game is now an rpg with equipment to loot and improve, rarity of items, skills to get, etc.
Combat-wise you can't win by counterattacking dumb enemies anymore (thank you), you have different kind of weapons that you can use, each with different properties. To make it short every type of weapon has different attack speed, damage and reach. I played mostly with an halberd, it was slow, it was heavy hitting and had a long reach. I had tons of fun with that.
You also charge adrenaline when fighting that will allow you to perform an "Overpower" move that basically lets you do a lot of damage to an enemy, I usually just one shot them with the Halberd.
As every open world game, you get a lot of little side activities you can do. Aside for the Synchronization points, there are several side quests, tombs to explore, an arena where you can fight for the glory and (if you're into that) a hippodrome where you can race.
There are also some forts you can "conquer" by killing the captain and/or commander of the fort. It's not really conquer since the enemies will remain in the fort, but after looting all the chests in the fort and killing the leaders of the place the game will tell you that the location was completed.
I personally enjoyed the story of the game where you follow the adventures of Bayek until you see how they formed the Assassin's Creed, plus it's always good for me to have a character that is not a clone of Desmond Miles.
Honestly, if they took out the part where you are "this girl" that enters the Animus to check on memories because she's a researcher of some kind that "whatever I don't care let me play Bayek!", I would be even happier.
The reason I say this is because the sessions you play outside the Animus are three if I recall correctly, and neither of them add much to the story. They're just there to let you know that you are X playing in the Animus. In all honesty, I never cared for the guy/girl outside the Animus and I never will, the only thing the game does when they force me to play with them is break the action and the enjoyment I was experiencing while playing inside the Animus.

The only, really bad, thing that I can say about this game is the optimization. I never understood the causes, some say it's because of the triple-layered DRMs that they put in the game, but this game burns your CPU in a horrible way.
I played this game on two rigs and both of them struggled to keep this game over 30 fps in areas like Alexandria. This is not acceptable. Just for the sake of information I post my specific of both PCs:
1Â°: CPU: Intel Core I5-6500 3.20GHz - 8GB Ram - GPU: Nvidia GeForce GTX 1060 6Gb
2Â°: CPU: Intel Core I7-7700HQ 2.80GHz - 8GB Ram - GPU: Nvidia GeForce GTX 1060 6Gb
I tried everything I could to make it run decently, the only thing I could do is set most details to Low hoping the game wouldn't stagger so much in very populated areas. Honestly? I hope Odyssey makes a better job.
I strongly advise to purchase the game outside of Steam in order to have one less DRM. It probably won't solve the problems, but you'll have one less software running in the background while playing.

Aside this problem that I had, the game is awesome and I definitely reccomend it to anyone who's looking for a good open world action Rpg.
