Recommended
31.1 hrs on record
Posted: May 15
In Origins you play (most of the time) as Bayek, Egypt's last medjay (sort of a freelance cop, with a badge and everything), whose grim tale of personal revenge and earnest desire to right wrongs among the locals soon spreads into a quest to rid Egypt of corrupt, powerful, anonymous figures who operate behind the scenes. Bayek isn't just a warrior but also a detective: investigating and stalking his prey, first rooting out the true identities of these shadowy figures, then infiltrating their lairs and sanctums, and finally putting an assassin's blade through their necks. (And then having a lengthy conversation with themâ€”this is Assassin's Creed, after all.) Bayek's quests take him from his small home village of Siwa to the great pantheons of Alexandria to the Nile Delta and beyond, and lets him rub shoulders with figures like Julius Caesar and Cleopatra.
The Egypt of Origins is a stunningly lovely place and I spent a lot of time simply soaking in the sights. Some areas of the map are expansive barren deserts or open seas, and while seemingly desolate of quests they're still well worth exploring to discover their few curiosities and surprises. Towns and villages are bustling with citizens, farmers, workers, and soldiers. There's plenty of dangerous (and eventually tamable) wildlife from vicious crocs and hippos lurking in the Nile to lions and hyenas prowling the sand dunes and rocky hills to flamingos and egrets that take flight when you thunder past on horseback. The simulation in Origins doesn't go below surface level, but if not a living world it's at least a lively one. And wow, it's big. After 35 hours of play, when I'd completed the main quest, tackled tons of side quests, solved puzzles, collected treasures, killed scores of enemies, and done lots of free-form exploring, hunting, and looting, there were still entire darkened regions of the map I hadn't yet set foot in. Origins is a damn big game in an even bigger world.
How the world is divided up isn't my favorite thing ever. It's MMO style, with different regions appropriate for different character levels. If you're level 8, and you cross a border from a region marked for levels 7-9 and into a region marked for level 17-20, well, nice knowing you. No matter your skills and gear, you simply can't take on an enemy too high above your own level: your attacks just won't do enough damage and their attacks will one-hit murderize you. This gives portions of the map a feeling of artificial difficulty, an open world where you're free to go anywhere but not really free to do anything, at least until you've leveled up. When you begin playing you can make a beeline for Giza's pyramids or Krocodilopolis: maybe you'll get there in one piece, or maybe you'll be insta-killed by a hyena that's 15 levels above you.

While I don't care for that particular brand of world creation, I didn't feel stifled by it that often. There were always enough level-appropriate areas to visit, explore, quest, and fight in (plus revisiting a low-level area when you've grown far beyond it can make you feel like a living god, which is pretty satisfying). And for the first time in what feels like a long time for Ubisoft, the world is filled with things to do without going overboard and looking as if someone spilled an overflowing sack of icons on a map. There are plenty of distractions as you ride from quest to quest, and lots of diversions to come across while exploring, but it never feels bloated or over-stuffed with tasks that require you to hop off your camel every few feet or disrupt your progress with the distraction of endless collectibles.

Origins also has gladiator challenges, chariot races, several types of brief radiant quests, and a few arenas in which to fight armored, rampaging elephants, if that's your particular dream. One of my favorite activities is a quieter, calmer one: a series of papyrus scrolls, which act like treasure maps. First you have to find the scrolls themselves, then decipher a riddle which leads you to leveled loot somewhere else on the map. It's a fun activity that promotes exploration, and takes you to areas you may have overlooked otherwise. For those hoping for more Black Flag ship-to-ship combat, there is a bit, but only in a few self-contained sequences.
Combat in Origins is based on dodging, blocking, and attacks of different speeds depending on the type of weapon you're using, complemented with unlockable skills. It can sometimes feel a bit mushy: dodging, in particular, can be finicky when you're locked onto enemies, and later in the game I became so reliant on a shield bash skill and a single charged strike that fights, while fun, became fairly identical. The new system could use some refining, but I wound up preferring its more methodical approach to previous Assassin's Creed animated combo moves.

There's also a great series of enemies called the Phylakes: a handful of imposing and ridiculously powerful warriors who individually prowl the map looking for you. They've got massive health bars and brutally deadly weapons, and I found myself loving how unfairly difficult they are to beat. There I am, an unstoppable badass with magic weapons and improbable skills, riding triumphantly away from a fortress of soldiers I'd just easily slashed and stabbed my way through. Then I'd spot a Phylake approaching on the road ahead, and would be forced to slink off and hide in the bushes quietly until he had passed. The Phylakes are humbling, and being humbled occasionally is a good thing.

At one point, when I was level 32, I encountered a level 20 Phylake. I cockily unequipped all my weapons, thinking how satisfying it would be to exact my revenge on one of these super-powered bastards with my bare fists. Uh, nope. He was still too tough. I had to switch back to blades halfway through the fight to finish him off.
The story has a couple laborious beats, and there are a few brief jumps to see how things are going in the future (I'm not a fan of the Abstergo crap), but Origins' plot is a good one with a few dabs of humor and heart. I only occasionally skipped through cutscenes, and I'm a legendary cut-scene skipper. Even for a cynic like me, witnessing the beginnings of the brotherhood was a bit of a thrill. Yes, the word "creed" is spoken weightily a few too many times (we get it) but I can't say it wasn't genuinely cool to witness the birth of the Assassins. Prequels are tough to pull off without them feeling clunky and overly referential, but the origin story mentioned in the title is handled pretty nicely.

Naturally, once you've beaten the main quests you can continue exploring the world, and the biggest compliment I can give Origins is that I'd much rather be playing it than writing about it. It's a got a dazzling and beautiful setting, lots of enjoyable systems for mischief and mayhem, and has just the right amount of diversions and distractions to keep you busy without ever feeling like busywork. The extra year Ubisoft took with Origins didn't result in a completely new and novel experience, but it did provide one of the best games in the Assassin's Creed series.

Posted: February 16
8.5/10
The historically significant of Assassin's Creed Origins is far more than the gameplay itself, Ubisoft art team ambitiously reconstructed entire Egypt under the Ptolemaic dynasty and polished the world near perfection, but unfortunately, its poor narrative doesn't deserve such a beautiful map.

Pros:
1. WORLD: Ptolemaic Egypt combined both the elegance of Greece and the exoticism of ancient Egypt, from the majestic city of Alexandria to the quaint Egyptian cities of Memphis and Faiyum, from vibrant banks of the Nile to endless desert under golden sunset, each location in the game has its unique beauty.
When I stood atop the Great Pyramid of Giza, the pinnacle of Egyptian civilization, and looked across the entire Nile, there are no words that can describe the spectacular sensation of travelling through history.

2. COMBAT SYSTEM: The combat system has been systematically overhauled from the traditional Assassin's Creed, the blocking attack and dodging attack are thrilling and entertaining. Players can still enjoy the fun of being an assassin with the traditional sneaking and assassination elements perfectly combined.
You can choose your fighting style using various types of weapons, with a wide variety of tools to assist with your combat and assassinations such as sleep darts, berserk darts, smoke grenades and firebombs.

3. SIDE QUEST: Although most of the side quests are about locating, rescuing, or assassinating a target, which is relatively mediocre compared to Witcher III's side quests, one thing I can't deny is that they still offer me the pleasure of exploring the map and experiencing life in ancient Egypt.

4. ANIMALS: A wide variety of animals enriches the player's exploration experience, each predator has its unique preying style.

5. EAGLE VISION: The player can explore the map and find targets with the eagle (More like a drone to be precise), although the repetitive reliance on the eagle dampens the fun of exploration, I think this design is a successful innovation.


Cons:
1. MAIN STORY: The main story of Origins is the biggest failure of the entire game. The entire main story feels more like a kill list than an adventure, Bayek, the protagonist and his wife Aya avenge for their son from start to finish without any transition in character, the villains are as characterless as a ragdolls provided to the player to assassinate, and even the most important historical figures in the game, Cleopatra, and Caesar, are unattractive, devoid of depth and historical accuracy as they are portrayed in children's storybooks.
The story in Assassin's Creed II also consists mainly of a kill list, but the player can experience the growth of the protagonist, Ezio, and there is much more depth to the characters portrayed. The assassination of Caesar by the female protagonist Aya is one of the most disgusting scene in the entire game for me, she assassinated Caesar purely for the sake of assassination, there is no motivation for Ayaâ€™s action.

2. OPEN WORLD FORMULA: The tremendous number of outposts and treasures bored me to the hell, the number of enemy camps alone amounted to nearly two hundred, each with similar objectives, Ubisoft's open-world formula just copy and paste over and over again and destroyed the fun of exploration, although these objectives are not mandatory, the countless repetitive question marks only make players feel sick.

3. WEAPON: Although there is a wide variety of weapons, most of them are scraps, only a handful of golden weapons that can be constantly upgraded are usable, once you got a golden weapon, you can use it forever, collecting and selling those low-level weapons becomes burdensome for players.

Posted: May 27
Assassins creed origins, what I view as the last true assassins creed game.
I'm not sure where to start with this game, I bought it years ago and played it for roughly 9 hours, basically just two to three days, and then dropped it. I reinstalled it over and over opened it then closed it then uninstalled it and repeat for years, and I'm not sure what, but it finally clicked in the last few weeks. I picked it up and just started walking around and finally figured out why I love this game.
1. The World
Ubisoft is a lot of things, almost none of it great, but â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ if they can't make an absolutely gorgeous open world. This game received some criticism saying that this setting was "bland" and "just a desert" and while yes it is a desert, it is a beautiful one. I would often find myself finding the places with the longest spanning dunes and just walking taking in how amazing it looked. Climbing the pyramids was an amazing activity and every city felt like it was unique, I would know what city I was in if someone were to blindfold me and place me inside. Every place in this game is just oozing with great design and although the parkour has fallen from where it once was, exploration has never been more of a joy.
2. The characters
Bayek, oh Bayek, what a great character, genuinely my second favorite character in the franchise behind Ezio. His story and everything about him is awesome and I believe he should've been the focus of the entire RPG trilogy. Every other character is also great, Aya and the love arc between her and Bayek was heartbreaking and beautiful. The only character I felt was underdeveloped was Bayek's best friend but even side characters who were nothing but the subject of sidequests were still memorable and the entire arc of cyrene was unbelievable fun
3. Combat
The gameplay of AC: ORIGINS was a total change from almost every previous game, it's a lot harder (aside from unity) than every previous assassins creed game but it also feels a lot better. Every game before combat was cool, but it was a joke. All I had to do to win was stand and click one button and then click another button, but this game changed that. While still being simple it's a lot more dangerous, and enemies can actually pose a threat, leading into
4. Stealth
The last good stealth in assassins creed. many complained about the level assassination thing, but it never posed an issue for me, as even captains fell to a single stealth attack most of the game because I wanted it to be that way, I spec'd into stealth and the hidden blade. and while less gadgets were also unbelievable useful in stealth unlike the newest additions. The sleep dart became my go to, knocking out guards who could pose an issue or even guards that noticed me, and smoke bombs were the go to for taking out multiple groups of enemies. Stealth was challenging, far more challenging than most of the franchise, but also rewarding. Taking out camps using stealth was amazingly satisfying unlike Valhalla and I never got angry at being spotted, because it didn't feel unfair.

All in all, I love this game, and while there are issues like the mainly alright ending and the fire effects, this game is a high recommend and I think more people need to give it a chance

Posted: May 24, 2021
Franchise Reimagined
Before Origins came out, Assassinâ€™s Creed as a franchise was in trouble. We were getting yearly releases that were rushed, full of bugs and all felt like the same game. Sales and playerbase were getting lower with each new release. Ubisoft had to rethink their approach and bring us something different if they are to keep one of their most successful franchises going. And that is exactly what we got with Origins. They kept the same general feeling of AC but made it more like an RPG with engaging combat and a progression system.

Setting
Ancient Egypt was a perfect setting to bring revamped AC to. Egypt was one of the desired locations even since AC 2 in 2009, and now we are able to experience it in its full graphical potential. AC always had great world and environment design, and with Origins, they just stepped it to another level. All the content in the game was designed by referencing real world information available from museums, libraries and Egyptologists. This helped create as realistic ancient Egypt as possible. There is even a â€œDiscovery Modeâ€ in the game that acts as a guided tour of the history of the time period that can be used as a teaching material in schools. It was an absolute joy exploring different locations and imagining how life could have been back then. It is something that any history buff will appreciate.

Gameplay
The whole gameplay has been given an RPG overhaul. You level up your character and so some missions and enemies are out of reach until you are close to their level, this may be annoying to some. If you do all the side content along the way you will be more than enough level for any engagement, which in turn makes them too easy. So itâ€™s a tough balancing act. The weapons increase in quality as you progress so you are encouraged to swap them out when you find something better. There are also variety of weapon types that offer you different opportunities combat wise. Combat itself is now completely different. You are not just focused on parrying like in previous games. You can string combos with light and heavy attacks, dodging and blocking - overall the combat is much more involved and engaging. Stealth is still an important part of the game and the most viable way to take on big encampments. There are also many different skills to level up along the way. They are split up in 3 paths: melee combat, range and traps. If you do everything, eventually you are able to unlock them all, itâ€™s just a matter of order in which you do it and what you want to focus on first. The skills can be pretty useful and provide for some nice benefits.

Conclusion
Having played all previous ACâ€™s, my favorite part has always been exploration and experience of the given historic time period. The games always had this part nailed down and Origins is no different. Ancient Egypt is perhaps the most beautiful setting yet with historical accuracy, vibrant colors and attention to detail. I am very glad about the gameplay changes that they introduced to the series. Now combat is also a cool component of the games and does not revolve around just stealth and parrying. I will always look forward to see what the next games will bring to the series.

70.0 hrs on record
Posted: January 15
Origins is one of the prettiest games I've probably ever played, especially given that I love Egyptian history. I've easily taken the most screenshots in this game than any other game I've played (even though the quality seems to dip in the screenshots compared to the actual game).

But after the shiny coat of paint, Origins suffers from repetitive gameplay loops that ultimately sour the experience. Running from location to location clearing bandit camps, synchronizing points, and swimming underwater for treasure is the bulk of the game. I will say that the tombs are enjoyable and unnecessarily creepy.

Bayek and the story carried me through the drag the game became. It's a fresh take on a series that sorely needed one. Each character is voiced magnificently and the missions are pretty awe inspiring.

Posted: November 11, 2017
It is the first AC since AC2 which I really liked.

UPD:
Let me try to explain why I don't think AC4 is really good. AC series generally try to create some personality it the character we play. OK, AC1 was a sandbox with parkour before it started to be mainstream, scenario wasn't the main focus. But for AC2 they came up with a character who tries to make things right. I can easily identify myself with. That's why I stormed through AC2, then Brotherhood, then Revelations. It was a little sad to let Ezio go.

In AC3, though Connor's story was tragic, his motivation always felt a little childish. They tried to create drama, but it was too artificial (if such can be said in regards to computer game). Now, AC4. For me it was difficult to sympathize Edward, it was hard to understand what all this suffering is for. Kills, has fun with money, plunders, has fun with money. Repeat if needed. He is very shallow for the most of the game. By the ending they tried to show how good he became, how it all transformed him into a better man, but it was too late to repair all this impression. If this moment happened in the first part of the game, maybe AC4 would have fallen into "really liked" category, but I'm not sure.

In case of Bayek it's easier to see good person in him, to see what he cares for and why he struggles so much with his vendetta. It made me wanting to see what else world has prepared for him. And it is interesting how Bayek's story will continue to unfold in DLCs.

Posted: August 25, 2019
Let me start this with that I absolutely love Assassin's Creed Origins. Almost everything in the game was great, and some stuff was arguably even perfect. The world, the music, the characters, the locations.

I waited to play this game for at least 8 months. I even read the book, Desert Oath. And I was so hyped, and for a reason. The world is incredibly immersive and beautiful. I think AC Odyssey missed much of the stuff that made this one so great.

AC Origins is mostly a serious game. It fits perfectly to the setting and Egypt, which is experiencing huge changes. In my opinion, the game could've been even more serious.
Before I got the game I knew that the graphics were amazing and the world was great. The music was a masterpiece and the characters likeable. The only thing I was skeptical about was the gameplay. Turns out that it was fine. Actually I really liked the combat and riding.
Now the stuff that maybe could be even better.

The story. It was great, but I felt a bit disappointed somehow. The ending was relatively satisfying but I still felt like something was missing. I guess I didn't like how the story evolved from being a personal quest for vengeance, to a power struggle for Egypt and the Apple of Eden. I liked the start though.
The NPCs. The NPCs were fine, but I would've hoped for them to be even more reactive to stuff, and they could've spoken more.

Also the DLCs we're just fine. You won't lose that much if you don't play them, but if you love the game, and just want more of the gameplay and world, play them.

Now, I like to rate stuff with scores so here we go:

Music - 10 ( it fits the game perfectly )
Gameplay - 9
World - 10
Story - 8
Characters - 9
Immersiveness - 9
DLCs - 7

Lastly I want to say that this game requires a quite beefy computer so beware. That's the reason I couldn't play it earlier.
Now go play it already!!!

Recommended
80.5 hrs on record
Posted: January 17, 2018
Overview

Just at the moment I lost all hope with the Assassin's Creed series, Origins happened and I thank Ubisoft for that. For those who are too lazy to read this review, here is a summary: this game is immersive, the map is huge and it is waiting to be explored, every once in a while AC: Origins will make you stop and appreciate the scenery around you. Even if you are not into the AC series, try to give it a shot and decide after you watch a sunrise in the desert!

Graphics

Well, this is no brainer. The game has awesome graphics. However, in order to run the game in Ultra and enjoy it fully, you really need a good rig. I myself run the game on a midtier GPU and get 40-50 FPS with some settings on High, some on Medium. No stutter, no crash, no lag, just fluid gameplay. But I've read people that can't run the game with better rigs than mine, so I guess it is a win or lose situation. If you think getting less than 60 FPS makes the game unplayable, then you might want to wait for a patch in order for Ubisoft to address the issue. From what I've read, their anti-piracy protocols cost us a few precious FPS.

Story

I'm 40-something hours into the game and I'm nowhere near the end, but as far as I've seen, since Altair and Ezio this is the first time an AC game has a good story. We are first introduced to Bayek and learn that he is a Medjay, an Egyptian warrior that protects the people of Egypt and the protector of the pharaoh. Eventually, the story will eventually lead to the foundation of the Brotherhood and how can an AC fan not be intrigued by this? Sure, along the way we get to learn more about Bayek and the story line mainly follows his personal motives, but in my opinion this makes the game much more immersive. Do I need to say he has a very cool wife?

Gameplay and Combat

You have the freedom to go anywhere, climb wherever you want, ride as far as you can, dive underwater, explore, take a boat to cross seas or lakes, get scared the first time you see a crocodile, learn that hippopotamuses have no mercy or get stuck in a tree because you are too scared to face the lions and tigers underneath which are waaaay too overpowered for you... and I can go on. AC Origins has an interactive world and gives you every opportunity to gain experience, loot rare or legendary weapons. Almost every location has codex and if you take your time to read, you understand that you are roaming the Ancient Egypt. You get to discover tombs, you get to see the pyramids inside and out. This is a big plus for me.

As for the combat, all I can say is that it feels more realistic than the other AC games. It is almost impossible not getting hit unless you are too good at dodging and in the early game, it's not really easy. There are places that make me stop and think before attacking. Rather than barging into a camp and stabbing anyone that stands in my way, I make plans so that I don't die. Remember those missions in early AC games that make you stealth kill your enemies but you fail and decide to smash buttons, hit every direction until you succeed? Well, stealth really works in your favor in this game. Oh and using bows is a thing too! They actually work!

To be honest, the leveling system is quite limited. You can easily get all the abilities and eventually you lose interest in the build tree. There really isn't a real building system going on, maybe in the early games but as you push through higher levels you understand that you are not tailoring a build to match your playing style, there is not much to choose between.

Overall

I thought my PC wouldn't be able to run this game so I passed it, eventually I received it as a gift and I was ready to refund. Thank god I didn't make that mistake. If I knew, I would have bought it myself! So I'm giving this game a 10/10 for all the fun and the quality time it offers. I hope this review was helpful and kudos to anyone who made it to the end!

Recommended
86.0 hrs on record
Posted: November 6, 2017
Assassins Creed Origins, the latest game of the AC franchise, the fresh air that we need. This game has potential despite the flaws. Lets start with the review.

Graphic
Man, this is the prettiest AC I've ever player besides Syndicate. The lighting, heat effect, the draw distance and the water, oh god the water, are the most thing I like in ACO's graphic. Didnt know desert could be that pretty, and the water looks natural especially when I was on a boat. I still remember when I was in Siwa and on the way to Giza, I could see the shape of the pyramid from afar, like very far and got excited. When I reached the pyramid I climbed it straight to the top, and the view is amazing. Furthermore, once you progress the story further, you can see the Roman style building, which are also beautiful. Conclusion, ACO's graphic is the biggest improvement of the series.

The World
Well, I am happy that this time Ubisoft did it perfectly regarding the game's world. Egypt is alive gentlemen, when you are walking the road, you can see people minding their own business, from smithing, riding a carriage, children playing on the street, a group of flamingos flying through the air, animals rampage on nearby village, people singing together in group, so many diversities. Not like in other AC games where people just sort of walking and riding a vehicle, and simply talking to each to each other. The world in ACO is full of details, like animals, you can pet cats, dogs, when you walk in the field of flowers, Bayek put down his hands, reaching and feeling the flowers of wheats on his hands, when nightfall villagers will going back to their house, even the guards, and when you put something on fire, either guards of villagers will try to put it off. This makes exploring the world, going from one location to another location more interesting. And Bayek is an interesting man, the protagonist is likeable, he has personalities.

Story
This is my personal opinion, the story is the usual Ubisoft style, good at the beginning, but forced at the end, seriously, the ending is kinda forced to end, but its not a big problem, at least for me.

Combat
ACO is an rpg now, and combat is kinda sloppy. You have 2 attacks, light and strong. Keep pressint the light attack button for a string of combo, and for the strong attack, its used to break enemies's shield or to know them down. You can also guard using your shield, but honeslty, I rarely guard, the game isnt that hard, unless the enemies are gangin up on you. Another one is dodge, this is the one I use the most. Though more often than not, enemies still can hit you when you dodge. Also there are onlyseveral killing animation that you will see over and over on the course of the game, some good some just plain boring. Besides melee combat, there's a range combat, which is the most satisfying combat in ACO. Aiming is done by holding the RMB, and depends on whick type of bow you are using, each bow has different aiming mode, more will be explained in the gameplay section.

Gameplay
This is where I tell you the game's mechanic, combat is for combat only, while this is for everything AC:O has to offer. For starter, the stealth. Stealth is there, but its dumbed down, you cant merge with poeple to hid anymore, even the hiding spot is somewhat lacking, but bushes are abundant. Yeah, stealth is simplified in Origins. Next, the parkour, in Origins, you dont have to hold certain button in order to run/parkour/free run like previous AC games, Bayek is always running, and you can climb by pressing a button, again simplified. This can be bad or good depends on your taste, I am neutral regarding stealth and free run. But, fun thing is, you can climb almost anything in this game, which is nice.

Equipments, for weapons, you can several types of weapons such as, swords, sickle sword, dual sword, mace, axe, staff, predator bow, light bow, warrior bows. For melee weapons each has their own style and finishing animation, they even has different overpower move, some just give you adrenaline to attack and move faster, some will attack enemy and kill the in one hit. For bows, you have predator, light and warriors bow, as I stated before, when you aim down while using bow, the types of bow depends the aim interface. For light bow, its like a normal bow,but you can charge your shot; for warrior bow, its normal aim, but you cant charge your shot, instead it fires several arrows in quick succession (at most 3), and for predator, when you aim, it will give you a zoomed aim, its easier to hit further target with these bow, and with certain skill, you can guide your arrow into the enemy's head.

For armors, you got shield, which is pretty useless for me, outfits, your 5 basic equips brace, quiver, breastplate, tool pouch and hidden blade, each can be upgraded into legendary using materials and will increase their corresponding atributes. Upgrade them based on your playstyle, either full frontal combat or stealth combat. Outfits can be bought from the weaver shops, sometimes you can buy legendary outfit from the shops, other legendaries can be gotten by completing certain events like chariot race, arenas, daily quests from Reda, or by Heka Chests you bought from Reda with 3000 drachmas (contains random loot).Every outfits can be gotten from the Heka chests, but it need tons of drachmas, except for the Isu Armor, you have to get all the zodiak circle, has 50 silicas and enter the Sphinx, you will get the armor there.

Mounts, since Egypt is massive, you will need mounts. There are 3 types of mounts, chariot, horse and camels. Chariot is faster than the other 2, while horses and camles are similar. Mounts also has quality, but even if you get legendary mount, it wont affect anything aside from getting an achievement for it.

Materials can be gotten by exploring the world and looting everything, or by killing the guards whom are transporting the resources you want. You can find the transporters by scouting with Senu and mark them so that they can appear on your screen. Be careful, if you are in the middle of a fight with the transporters, other guards transporting another resources may pass and enjoy your party, so you might end up against 8-12 enemies. The transporting guards only transports resources like metals, drachma and woods, for skins you have to hunt animals, such as hyenas, crocodiles, hippos, and lions.

Skill, AC:O has 3 skills category, warrior, hunter and seer. Warrior is obvious, Hunter is for bow and stealth mainly, and Seer's skills affecting tools damage and unlock, shop unclock, breathing, taming animal etc. I recommend getting the bow or warrior skills first, especially the bow. Guiding arrow through the enemies head never gets old.

The microtransaction is there, but its not lootboxes, but its not as intrusive and the game doesnt constantly reminding you of its presence like in Shadow of War, the store even located on its own section, and Ubisoft sells you an item for a price, not being randomized, its an item, like the mummy outfit, unicorn mount, time saver pack, etc. I am not defending this, I am just stating a fact.

Optimization
Now this is one of the bad of Origins, because the game is plagued by DRM fest, VMProtect, Denuvo, Uplay and Steam, it affects the game's performance. WIth i5-6600k 1070 16GB, I can get Ultra setting with 30-50ish fps, unstable. After I bought i7-7700k, I got 60-80ish fps. I will test the free version once it's released.

Conclusion:
Origins is a good game despite of the flaws, it has moderate to a lot of content (this is purely subjective), pretty graphic, a lively world, ok story, you get your money's worth. But all of those are ruined by performance issue, after the patch it helps a bit, but still freezing sometimes with my i5-6600k, I dont know if its because of the DRM or other things.
Wait until this problem is fixed, if its not fixed then I recommend get this on sale.

Recommended
74.6 hrs on record
Posted: June 11, 2021
(Playing this on a 4k monitor.)

This is probably the most beautiful game I've ever looked at, and that's a huge compliment after I've played Kingdom Come: Deliverance.

I'm NOT saying that everywhere you go you see insane-quality textures. This game is a bit more subtle. It's about the huge amount of great-quality textures coupled with breath-taking lighting, environment smoke/dust effects, immersive water physics, realistic-looking vegetation with vivid colors. The whole composition is impressive.

The scale is larger than KC:D. Kingdom Come hides it's cities with carefully placed treelines and ridges, so you dont see the neighboring town and feel the world is small. Not here. You'll see kilometers on the distance, and many, many small villages on your screen at the same time, if you get to a high place. Even small, random villages are larger than KC:D largest cities as well. There might not be much interaction on them, but they're nice anyway.

Every 10 minutes I get a jaw-dropping scene while doing whatever quest going from A to B... The game has a photomode which pauses time and lets you move the camera around, take a picture and upload it automatically so other players can see it on their map. In my 21 hours of gameplay so far, I've taken a few dozen pictures. It's THAT good.

I haven't used Fast Travel a single time. The game's just to relaxing and wholesome to be in.

With all that in mind. It is a mainstream game. It is easy. Play it on the hardest setting. Death has no consequence anyways.
The pleasure is in the story, the somewhat akin-to-life locations and the sight-seeing.

Icreaka
901 products in account
50
208 people found this review helpful
9 people found this review funny 0

Recommended
99.0 hrs on record
Posted: October 27, 2017
The bottom line would be I do recommend the game. It was in the end an enjoyable experience.

I got beef about some stuff, while loving others. Check it all to make sense of the chaos of this review.
I ended up referencing a few other titles while doing this, whether that is a no no or not.. I guess we'll see.

Okay, disclaimer is done, to the actual reviewing.
+It looks looks wondrous.
+Ran smooth so far ( FX 6300 3.5ghz & GTX 970 ssc, high settings or above)
+Gentle on my GPU. Something like Shadow of War makes my card really run its fans, 65% or higher, to the point I can almost hear it through my headphones. This doesn't do it. Not as much, and I appreciate that.
+The map so far is well designed, very lush and lively. I've enjoyed exploring it so far.
+The RPGness of it. Skills to acquire, gear to craft, all the weapons and equipment. But that's a double edged sword to get to later.
+It's a new AC! No but really, it's nice to have a new one release. The story telling so far has been pretty good and I look forward to doing more.
+Side Quests so far all have dialog. It's a very Witcher styled feeling beyond that though. To really be prepared for story quests, side ones are strongly recommended.
+ REACHING ALEXANDRIA REMINDS ME OF WHAT BROTHERHOOD COULD'VE BEEN. It feels so good. It really does feel so good to walk the city. So much focus about Egypt, and you forget what all you were gonna actually run into here. It's been minorly breathtaking.
+Soundtrack is pleasant. Same person who worked on Ac4 and Unity did this. I really enjoyed Black Flag, and parts of Unity's sound track, so it I'm diggin it.
+Depth. The year off I think gave Ubi the time they needed to ensure everyone felt more alive. Bayek is a fun character to watch develope more. And Aya isn't just a ghost. She has depth too, not such a fling as Elise. And they're oh so lovely together it mades me feel lonely.
+Plenty of cutscenes, voices, and excellent writing for small moment that give you giggles and nods.
+Reality has a third person thing again. I know some hate it for not simply being Desmond, but I like it so far.
+Easter Eggs hinting as franchises in the same universe are pretty cool.

Now, the beef and things I wanted to talk about. These aren't purely negative, but rather the stuff I have ups and downs with, or simply wanna babble about it seems.

-Its RPGness. It adds a new depth to the game you otherwise never had, but it brings in flaws. It reminds me of Division. In this, a headshot with an arrow can not always kill. And I now learned that you don't always get a pure assassination. They can resist it. I do not like that entirely. It's two small details about the whole style, but they're big deals to me.

-Stealth (assassinating) is underwhelming. I've since upgraded a lot of tools, learned the methods, and know how to creep far better, but it still lacks. They put forth so much effort into the combat, they left the stealth lack luster in return it feels. It's still better than any other in terms of creep stealthing though really. I'd enjoy seeing something like Blacklist method and variety for silent murder in future titles. Can really only chalk it up now as Bayek isn't really an Assassin in this one. He's a Warrior, a Guardian. Doesn't have the finesse for it yet. It's why his attacks are only one of a handful. No fancy takedowns. One can hope for the future though for more fluidity.

-Social stealth is absent. No more blending. You hide in bushes, or out of line of sight, but no more. I realize there is a franchise long debate about how it should or shouldn't work. Some tasks now, I kinda wish I could still do so. Being in Alexandria and not being able to upsets me.

-/+Combat. I put this as a mix because it isn't outright bad. You lose situational awareness the rest gave you before, though enough time has alleviated that. It's For Honor, thrusted into AC. It's how I've come to see it so far. Instead of the whole area being seen and having the scope of the whole fight available, it tunnel visions it to your front. That works in FH, seeing how the game was designed with the 1v1 encounters in mind. In this? It's a bit more detrimental to your health. I died a few times consecutively because I'm fighting average guys, and big Brutus here comes barreling from off screen and sticks a club in a place it shouldn't be. The locking system was weird, but eventually got used to it too. A soft version of Dark Souls maybe. Lock, block and strafe. Or don't at all, you don't have to after all.
There's a learning curve. For combat, and stealth. It gets easier. The skills, which I really should have mentioned somewhere, do each improve your gameplay. So it's helpful to pick and choose based on what you want to strengthen, or balance out your weaknesses.

-Parkour got more simplified. At first I had complaints you couldn't drop down right, couldn't decent safely and the such. I've since learned the proper method. A for controller, literally does it all for you. to close gaps up or down, jump straight forward, etc. B to decent is more for dropping to ledges. And you can still roll to avoid damage, you just need to tap A on landing. (A lack of high profile though I believe also limits the stealth capabilities.)

-I can't f&$%ing sprint mang? Dude can move at a healthy pace, but there is no, "Okay, go, NOW." speed. It's annoying. Camels are neat. Horses are nicer. All I need now is a suped up ricer. (Why did I rhyme that?)

-Random audio buzzing in various moment. It's just.. what? As I update this, I get them more and more often. Just a solid second of BRRZZZT and then the game goes on. Happens in cutscene transitions, or after deaths.

-Equipment screen is interesting. Two bows, two melee weapons, and one active tool. So to change dart types or bombs, you need to go into the menu itself and change. Weapons swapping between two isn't bad, but given current strength, I find myself needing to swap out empty bows for other two which are full often. Each bow type has its own ammo type as well, which I guess is nice.

As you level up, you get more power obviously. Bows work better, and having quiver upgrades stretch out time. Ensuring you loot prolongs a bow's use too.

- I CAN'T SPRINT, MY HORSE CAN'T GALLOP. I NEED TO GET OUT IN A HURRY AND I CAN'T. I realize I said no sprinting earlier, but a revisit to dying from lack of speed to escape brings me back here. I know making games isn't easy, but we need something that Ac3 had with horses. Come on Ubi.

Okay the whining is done.

It's fun. Not the same AC. It has For Honor, Witcher and Far Cry vibes. Even a little hint of Wildlands, eagle being the drone, minus exploding. Was also suggested it's a tad bit of Zelda. I never played them though, so I cannot say for certain.

If you don't mind it being a different feel, then for sure get it. If you cling to older AC styles too much, didn't like For Honor or Witcher that much, maybe watching a stream is a better choice, until maybe a sale or something.

However! Don't let me entirely deter you! I am enjoying myself, despite the distinct changes. It's a fresh breathe of air otherwise. Truth be told, AC hasn't really been the same since a blended line of Revelations and 3 anyway. Give it a chance if you want it. I do recommend it after all. The more I play it, the more it does feel like AC. I missed this.

I'm new at reviews, be merciful.

Posted: July 4, 2021
The truth is that talking about the big and small parts of Assassin's Creed: Origins and paying attention to all its content, pros and cons, is beyond the scope of this review and you should experience them yourself during the game.

Origins is another Assassin's Creed similar to the other games in the series, and it should be noted that apart from the story as well as some positive points that I will mention below, it has nothing new to offer players.

To activate Fast Travel, you still have to climb to the tallest buildings, jump from the top into a haystack, raise your level, and improve your skills by receiving a skill point. But the point is that Origins no longer give you different ways to complete the stages, and there is not much variety in side missions.

If you have experienced Ghost Recon: Wildlands in the past and its problems have not bothered you, Origins will probably be interesting for you. But if you can not stand the nerve-wracking camera, repetitive missions, technical glitches and combat difficulties, Assassin's Creed: Origins will not be for you and you can think of other games.

Now I will summarize the positive and negative points of the game:

Positive :
1- Different fighting style with each weapon and game upgrade system.
2- A beautiful story that explains the background of the basics in detail
3- Good characterization.
4- The beauty of historical monuments.
5- Excellent music and great sound.

cons :
1- Repetition of gameplay after a while
2 - Technical problems sometimes unbearable and nerve-wracking
3 - Lack of ability to customize buttons and camera problems
4 - Lack of interaction with the environment and repetition of combat animation in a short time.

With all the problems this game has, it is definitely worth a try. And I'm sure you will enjoy the fascinating scenery and design and the great historical story.

Not Recommended
105.5 hrs on record
Posted: March 11, 2020
Assassin's Creed: Origins has been designed to waste your time.
Unfortunately there is no way to rate this game somewhere in between Good or Bad on Steam; it's not a bad game, but you have to be aware of what you're going in for. This is an extremely good looking game on the surface, that is completely shallow and empty underneath its golden, radiant coat of paint.
The story is completely wasted potential, and it has no cohesive structure as it feels like it's been designed by multiple people at various times. The character models, as usual for Ubisoft, look amazing and the art direction is phenomenal and creative. All characters and villains look distinct and original; it's too bad they're completely shallow, uninteresting, forgettable and, worst of all, wasted. There are hints throughout the game of what it could have been, but it never goes there. The game never separates itself from simply being a sand-box adventure with rpg elements in it.
The developers clearly took inspiration from The Witcher 3, but left out everything that made that game great, and missed the point. For example, the world is big. Too big, really. I got tired after a while, due to it being so uninteresting. It does the game no favour, it's no advantage leaving the player with at least 5 or 6 gigantic areas still to explore by the end of the main quest.
Sidequests are aplenty and a complete waste of time. They are boring writing, incredibly shallow and downright insulting to anyone's intelligence at times. It feels like the game tells you you're stupid and you're only here because of the fancy graphics and the freedom of exploration.
Indeed, I won't deny that what saves AC Origins is the world design, coupled with an extremely well realised lighting system. The view distance is insanely huge and makes the world feel real and beautiful to explore. If that's the only thing you're expecting, then this is the game for you.
Gameplay is repetitive however. Most, if not all sidequests and main quests usually end with the player being required to assassinate some target, usually in a fort, of which there are way too many. They're all different, yes, and there's a moderate amount of effort invested in making sure none of the hundreds of forts scattered around the map look the same. Unfortunately, they are the same, since you will use the same ways of clearing them and doing the checklist of treasures etc to clear and complete.
The music and soundtrack are okay when listened outside of the game, but really badly implemented within the actual cutscenes, exploration or combat.
Everything about this game is lazy and shallow and a disgrace to its legacy of past wonderful titles. However, it is entertaining at times and is a good way of sinking many hours of one's time.

PROS: Incredibly beautiful world, realised through astounding technology in graphics and lighting - mindless entertainment at times.

CONS: Story - Design - Gameplay - Lack of character development/drama - Repetitiveness

Not Recommended
23.2 hrs on record
Posted: December 3, 2017
I'm sad to have to do this, but it's going to be a thumbs down for me.

It's just not Asassin's Creed anymore. With every launch it has been less about the asassinations and more about being transformed to fit into the amorphous blob that is the UBISoft sandbox game.

I'll get the pozitives out of the way quick as there's only two. The graphics (scenerey is absolutely jaw-droppingly gorgeous) and the characters. Bayek is not just a wooden plank with a frowny face drawn on it. He exibits emotion, showing both a sensitive, caring side and a violent, revenge-seeking side.

Everything else is dissapointing, and it all stems from one root cause. It's too "video gamey":

- The redesigned leveling system is awful. Are you telling me that just because some dude's floating number is greater than mine, suddenly a knife directly through his windpipe is not going to kill him? This is ludo-narrative dissonance in its purest form. Just like in The Division where you could pump a guy's skull full of sniper rounds and he wouldn't even flinch because his "level" is higher than yours. This screams in your face "WARNING! THIS IS YOUR HOURLY REMINDER THAT YOU ARE PLAYING A VIDEO GAME"

- The combat is a hot mess; I'm not sure why they changed it. Instead of dancing around the enemies and countering, you just roll around, hoping for an opening. And the "super moves"....oh my god the super moves. Yeah Bayek, slow down time by slamming your shield into the ground while you are moving at normal speed and while you're at it, why don't you also move a WOODEN ARROW through the air like it was a â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ laser guided missle. It's not all bad, this game uses slo-mo properly sometimes like when you jump off a ledge and shoot with a bow, a slo-mo is activated. That's cool af. Makes me think there was one decent guy at the studio and the rest were busy partying like the Wolf on Wall Street.

- Stealth is laughably over simplified and uninteresting. What ever happened to the people that worked on Assassin's Creed 1? Yes, O-N-E. I remember when you showed up to a city with nothing but your hidden blade, the name of your target and a slap on the ass from your handler wishing you good luck. You had to blend in with the croud, research your target to find out where they reside, plan your infiltration and exfiltration. You could fight, but the spotlight was clearly on the stealth and asassinations. Yes it was a bit repetitive, but nothing that couldn't be fixed.

But here? Nah son. Bayek must have been bitten by a radioactive spider because he can just climb clearly flat surfaces. You don't need to plan any routes, see which walls you can climb because you can climb efectively anything. Crowd blending? Hiding in plain sight, right next to your target, just waiting for a chance? Nah son, from now on, you are only going to crouch in chest-high grass.

Stealth gameplay here is a straight flow-chart:

A) If the enemies are 4-5 levels higher than you, then don't even bother, because a blade through the rib cage doesn't matter if a magical floating number says so. Better go and grind some more

B) If there is chest high grass, go into said grass, stealth assassinate anyone who comes close

C) If there is no grass, shoot them from the rooftop with the laser guided missle predator arrow.

D) If there's no grass or buildings, just hack away at them and then finish them with your ...*sigh*... super move

I'm not even going to go into detail about how there's just so many uninteresting side-quests that play out the same because of how basic the stealth is, or how the game takes control away from you every 10 minutes when you are talking to someone to show you cutscenes, because they want to be "cinematic". Remember in AC1, where you could move around during cutscenes, the camera focused on your target and ominous music played? THAT was cinematic...

TL;DR

A massive waste of potential. I was hoping the year-long break they took from the series would help them go back to the series' roots (as the ORIGINS title implied), but we are instead greeted with dumbed down streamlined stealth play, clunky combat and a terrible leveling system that constantly reminds you that you are playing a video game.

PS:

I'm going to finish the game, since I care for the story, but I can't say I'm having a lot of fun. Mainly playing just for the act of finishing it...

Posted: May 23, 2020
I had a great time with this game during the Covid pandemic.

The Positives:
- The World, Egypt is incredible to look at, throughout my time with the game I stopped to look around the vistas, cities, canyons, deserts, and all the other incredible locations showcased in this game.
- The Immersion of the World, every location feels alive thanks to the AI, cats can be scratched and
you never feel as though the world was tailored to you. Egypt has a history and you get to witness this slice of time.
- The Roleplaying, Loads of variety of play styles available, there's an incredible amount of combination possible with the melee and ranged weapons present, I loved the roleplaying potential it had at the start of the game and wasn't disappointed to find my niche was loads of fun to play!
- The Combat - Incredibly satisfying with every weapon type.
- The Side Quests - I found them to be better than some of the Main Quest. It's a lot of fun to just help the people of Egypt with their profound problems. Very little "Bring me x number of y, x number of z,etc", more varied and engaging, character driven mini stories.
- The DLCs - I spent around 15 hours in both DLCs in a completionist play-style. The Hidden Ones DLC is focused of what I thought would present in the main map of Egypt. The problems with the first established Hidden Ones offices could have taken place as a prologue to the Main Quest, but it feels like a welcome addition with the introduction of Sinai. The foundation of the Creed is clear and necessary, mistakes are expected during the first years of a secret society. Old characters from the main game come back to be even more developed. The Curse of the Pharaohs is larger and more fascinating, I won't spoil it. It's worth the buy.
- Bayek - He is a great main character, enraged after the death of his son, the actor really brings it and makes this entry to the series memorable.

The Negative:
- The Main Story is overdeveloped at first and underdeveloped during the latter half. It's a bit rushed, it's noticeable.
- The Difficulty - It's really easy as a stealth game, which was annoying personally. I breezed through the game while completing it, no real puzzle in stealth. I expected legions of Romans in Egypt and ended up with barely 50 in the biggest Forts.

Not Recommended
67.4 hrs on record
Posted: March 3
I'm a newbie in the Assassin's Creed universe, playing only AC3 until now, so I'm not going to compare Origins to the other installments.
There are way more pros than cons for this game, but the latter ruined my experience. Let's start with the pros:

Pros
- Amazing World Details:
This is in my opinion Origins' best feature. I loved every little bit of the map (from the vast deserts in the center and south of the map to the crowded cities of Memphis, Alexandria or Cyrene). Every region is unique, each with its' foreign or local influences in domains like architecture or society: Egyptian, Greek, Roman or combinations of them.
The landmarks are breathtaking: you can climb the Pyramids and the Lighthouse of Alexandria, visit the Tomb of Alexander the Great and the Library of Alexandria, or sail down the Nile (maybe the most fun I had in the game, sailing on the Nile with dozens of other boats alongside me).

- Role-playing and Combat:
A lot of people were deeply disappointed with the decision of adding RPG mechanics into the game, many claiming Origins isn't an Assassin's Creed game anymore. Again, I'll be unbiased and say that I liked the gameplay and I think the role-playing aspects were implemented well. The combat is pretty simple, light attack, heavy attacks against opponents with small shields, parry and dodge, plus the Overpower Attack which is very helpful in many situations.
There are many types of weapons which offer diversity in said combat, you have the long range spears, the short range but fast dual blades, the heavy, but slow blunts etc. You also have four types of bows, but I think everyone just goes for the Predator and Hunter ones. Horse fights and melee fights against animals are clunky and boring, although the naval combat is spectacular and awesome and I loved these fights weren't shoved down my throat, there being about 2 or 3 of them in the whole game.

- Historical personalities:
Again, many people complained here about Cleopatra and Julius Caesar being dull and superficial. Look, I'm a History student myself and I really don't mind this shallowness, it's just a game after all, not a graduation thesis, let them be lighthearted villains. I liked seeing both of them, Pompey, Ptolemy XIII, Brutus etc. in a modern game. It is a good combination between fiction and reality.

As I don't want to turn this into a 2000 words review I'll end the pros here. Other smaller pros would be Bayek's character and customization, Senu and her Eagle Vision and animal hunting, the small details like soldiers going to sleep at night, petting cats if you crouch or getting heatstrokes for staying in the desert for too long etc.

Cons

- Side Quests:
It's now time for the biggest con for Origins, the side quests. They are so so many, repetitive, lame side quests. It's the biggest turn off for me, taking me to an exaggerated 64 hours playtime, spanned across three long months. All of them are the same "bring me back x thing", "kill y general", "escort z", "follow n", the latter two of them being extremely annoying and simply pesky. After something like 20 of these quests I just skipped all lines of dialogue and rushed to the objectives. That's one of my main reasons for not recommending the game.

- Locations

The second main reason I didn't enjoy the game was the locations. I liked the viewpoints (even though there are FIFTY-EIGHT!!! of them in the game) and the Stone Circles, but I completely hated the animals lairs, loot treasure locations and rest places. Also there are so so so many boring level 1 outposts. At some point I grew tired of them and I just executed the captain with my bow and rushed to the treasure, ignoring any kind of strategy and stealth.

These are the main cons I encountered in the game. Other smaller cons are Aya and her boring character development and cringy final speeches, buggy and clunky movement, the horse riding, the irrelevant MD story, weapons getting useless after you get legendary stuff etc.

Conclusion

The best generation in all of Assassin's Creed Collections! I have four reasons to support my view.

Conclusively speaking, the Assassin in Origin should behave like a Assassin, but not a warrior.

I am new to the world of Assassin's creed, not really knowing why I even bought this game (well except for being a history buff)
I finally completed the main storyline and the DLC's and as you can see it took it well over a 100 hours, mostly becuase I often got sidetracked with things to watch, experince and solve.
Since there is a lot to be said about this game, I will simply do a pro/con list maybe with some notes in the end. It does have good things in it

Pros:
- The map is HUGE, there are a ton of things to do and watch.
- The cutscenes are beautiful
- The main story is great (Though at times drawn out)
- I LOVE how I can control an arrow from the predator bow, just wish it had a longer reach
- I never get tired of the leap of faith
- A lot of playable hours in this game, more so that many others (Like Wolfenstein, only took me around 30 to complete)

Cons:

- The leveling system does take a bit getting used to.
- Having to set your keyboard so it fits better, because the way it is set up at start is just insane, how are you to use one hand over the whole keyboard, that is just stupid.
- The DLC Curse of the pharoes is just.... Well a waste of time in my eyes.

On a note

Recommended
219.4 hrs on record
Posted: December 8, 2018
One of the best games I've recently played.

Being an history lover, I really enjoyed the AC games I played before this one, namely the first one and Black Flag, being historical playgrounds (especially Black Flag). But this is something else entirely.
It has ignited a genuine interest in this saga, so much that I definitely want to play all the main entries now.

AC Origins is an action RPG interpretation of the old AC formula, which was functional and interesting indeed, but clunky, slow, and in a desperate need of rejuvenation. So, how did they manage to do that? By simply taking inspiration from one of the best games ever, The Witcher 3.
The gameplay is finally smooth, fast, and more dynamic, and the emphasis on the RPG aspects and PG's skills development leads to different ways of playing the game from the older entries. You are first and foremost a Medjay, a warrior concept coming straight from the Old Kingdom of Egypt, and not an Assassin; the game then explains you the transition from a noble like warrior to the more complex identity of Hidden One, being a beautifully mastercrafted prequel for the AC saga.
The Ptolemaic Egypt setting is the icing on the cake. The environment in this game is absolutely brilliant, and you can really tell the Devs had fun crafting this game (along with the Curse of the Pharaohs DLC which is more focused on the myths and legends side of Egypt history). Bayek is a great and interesting character, especially thanks to Abubakar Salim, who did a flawless job giving him personality and depth.

Everything works 100% fine, except for one thing: the AI, and therefore the balance. AC games have never been difficult, but playing this on Nightmare difficulty was a total piece of cake. AI in general is pretty dumb, especially in the stealth sequences (if you decide to play stealth), and combat is fun but pretty damn easy. The only hard times are with higher level enemies that can kill you with one blow and are absolutely sponges, forcing you to calculate every move in order not to restart the whole sequence again.
Also, the whole microtransaction thing is, well, there, and if on one hand I despise microtransaction in a SP game, on the other hand I've never felt forced to buy exp boosts or anything else, and I bought absolutely nothing in the 204 hours of playthrough. Also, the game can be played by only following the main quest, or by doing all the secondary tasks scattered around the game world; I've never, never had to grind my way through, or do quests and stuff because of level gates in the main quest.

I really enjoyed this iteration of the AC franchise and I'm looking forward to play Odyssey. I want more of this!

"May the Hidden One greet you. The Lord of the Duat awaits."

I'm torn between a positive or negative rating. At the core, there is a great base here. There's a lot to see and do. But the more you play, the more the 'do' part is just copy and pasted content from other parts of the map. I fully understand that open world games have to utilize this aspect to some degree. But in this game, the repetitive content is just a huge bore. Infiltrate this base, kill this dude. That's the majority of missions in Origins.

It was really fun at the beginning exploding the pyramids, climbing them, exploring small towns and large cities, and even the open desert areas are fun too. I also like how you can climb any rock face.

But the game's issues come out to play quite early on, and they build up momentum until they are all you pay attention to. The AC series STILL cannot get down decent pedestrian AI. People do not move normally--they do not react normally nor do they interact with each other normally... or atleast acceptably. lip syncing is horrible, voice acting is mostly trash, and animations are largly unpolished. There is also a lack of weapon/gadget variety, memorable characters, unique weapons, etc.

Poor animations have really been bothering me in Origins recently. Watching a tiger attack another animal is cool in concept, but has never been executed properly in these games. AC games have had animals attacking eachother since AC3. Ubi has never been able to make the animations of these animals fighting eachother look even decent. It's embarassing to watch, especially now a days.

The forceful grinding aspect of this game is a tad insane too.

Story wise, I lost interest halfway through and just started skipping every cut scene because they are a huge bore. I just wanted to finish the story. Maybe, I thought, the ending would be cool. Cutscene wise throughout the game: their production values are weak, lip syncing is really bad, and again: ANIMATIONS are wonky, unstable and unpolished.

I'm ripping on this game hard--I know. There is a lot of good in Origins. I'm just frustrated that Ubi has not improved on pedestrain AI and overall animation quantity and quality. These are TOUGH things to get down-they take a lot of resources, but are so worth it. IMO.

i7 7700k

32 GB or RAM
Playing on a 7200 RPM HDD

So are reading a lot of these reviews and seeing people saying that they are getting poor frame rates and drops I decided to write this. I as well was getting these frame drops in game (45-50 FPS). I found a solution however, becuse I was overclocking my GPU i was keeping an eye on my frequency and I notices that the frame drop would always happen at the same time as a frequency drop. From what I could tell this was an issue with the cards power management. It will drop below base clock to save power when it is not in heavy use.

You can fix this in the nvidia control panel under power management.

So over all I think that this is a really interesting game. It is not at all like the other AC titles. It has many elements from the witcher a game that I love. Overall I would recommend this game if you are a long time AC fan or if you are new to the series.

Posted: October 28, 2017
I don't usually write reviews, but I think this game deserves a lot of praise.

If you disliked the recent Assassins Creed and Far Cry titles for their mindnumbingly dull, "vast as an ocean, deep as a puddle" open worlds, then give this a shot. It's a nice change of pace. There's a lot of emphasis on exploring the environment, thereby making the game less linear. Think Black Flag's sea-exploration, but on land.

The developers of this game seemed to take a lote of inspiration from the Witcher 3, which is fine by me. Some ways they've done this is through meaningful sidequests, a lot of detail to the environment, a pretty fun crafting system, and the previously mentioned quality of exploration.

The combat is fun and engaging; it feels like a mix between Witcher 3 and For Honor. Dark Souls players might not like that, as they would say it's "too easy"--which is fair--but relative to previous Assassins Creed titles, it's a big improvement. Gone are the days of waiting to press one button to counter and kill.

I can't write too much else, as at the time of making this I've only played about ten hours (and spent a large chunk of that time upgrading my character's gear). However, it's been a surprisingly wonderful experience. All in all, the game feels like a proper, spiritual continuation of the original Assassins Creed games--and by that I mean before things started going down hill.

Overview
In Assassinâ€™s Creed Origins, players assume the role of Bayek of Siwa, and discover the origins of the assassinâ€™s brotherhood. Throughout your journey, you meet with several historical figures such as Cleopatra and Julius Caesar. You journey through the country of Egypt in 49BC, crossing many historical landmarks and famous cities such as Alexandria. Egypt comprises of a variety of biomes, ranging from deserts to lush forests. Journey through this fascinating land and change the course of history.

Pros:
Visually stunning.
Easy to learn combat.
Decent exploration with occasional surprises.
Great narrative and protagonist.
Great soundtrack.

Cons:
Points of Interests around the map might feel a little repetitive.
The main story starts off at a good pace but near the end it starts to jump from point A to B.

Rating: Great

In-Depth Breakdown

World and Exploration
The world of AC Origins is filled sprawling towns, forests and long stretches of deserts. There are many points of interests ranging from military encampments to ancient temples. Exploration is mostly done on foot, (water bodies are explored on boats, of course) but you also have your horse/camel that you can call whenever.

Water bodies are filled with hippos and crocodiles to kill while the forests sprawl with animals like hyenas, lions, deer, etc. Deserts are mostly filled with hidden ancient tombs, which almost always contain a small environmental puzzle of some sort. In cities you may find military encampments and temples. There are military encampments in the deserts too.

There are many historical landmarks such as Krokodilopolis, Bent Pyramid, Cyrene, Library of Alexandria, Giza, Memphis, Great Sphinx of Giza, Nitria.

While exploring, look out for loot, which is literally everywhere.

There is fast travel.

Scouting
Scouting is done using your trusty eagle, Senu. Senu can help you spot threats, treasures, hidden entrances, resources, etc.

Side Quests
AC Origins if full of quests all over itâ€™s world. There are the typical fetch quests and kill x amounts of people quests but they donâ€™t come up that often and generally have a small story attached with them. Overall, the side quests in AC Origins are interesting, mostly unique, sometimes funny, sometimes depressing, but only a handful which are actually memorable.

Inventory Management
You carry the following items on you: melee weapons, shields, bows, tools, outfits and mounts.

There are different kinds of melee weapons: regular swords, dual swords, sickle swords, heavy blades, heavy blunts, spears and scepters. You can initially equip one melee weapon but an ability allows you to equip two at a time.

There are four types of bows:
1) Hunter Bows: average speed, strength and range.
2) Warrior Bows: Fires a spread of multiple arrows, kind of like a shotgun, which makes them lethal up close and personal.
3) Light Bows: They can fire multiple arrows before needing to â€œreloadâ€, they are kind of like an SMG.
4) Predator Bows: Slow but the most powerful, deals great amounts of damage if you can land a headshot, they can be compared to sniper rifles.
Just like melee weapons, you can initially equip one bow but an ability allows you to equip two at a time.

There are various kinds of tools like sleep darts, poison darts, firebombs, smokescreens and some more.

Outfits and mounts only differ cosmetically and have no impact on stats in any way.

There are also six basic components (like tools bag, chest plate, quiver) which you can upgrade using various resources found all over the world.

Combat
Combat in AC Origins feels fluid, animations flow nicely, controls donâ€™t feel wonky and the parry and shield block systems work fine. Unlike previous releases, AC Origins uses a hitbox system for itâ€™s combat, so hitting multiples enemies with one swing is possible.

Combat can be hard when playing on harder difficulties and especially so when the level difference between you and the enemy is more than about five levels. There seems to be a soft cap that just doesnâ€™t allow you to do as much damage to an enemy more than 5 levels above you. Enemies also seem to swarm you and act like individuals rather than a group, so they donâ€™t just stand behind while one of them fights you, awaiting their turn.

Stealth
Memorising enemy petrol patterns, positioning yourselves accordingly, and then striking from the shadows is the kind of stealth in this game. You pass through enemy camps while remaining crouched in tall grass, whistle to attract nearby enemies towards you, and then stick you hidden blade through them. Stealth in AC Origins is very forgiving and is very easy to get into.

Abilities
There is really not much to say about abilities. There are abilities relating to increasing the amount of experience earned from performing certain actions, abilities improving your melee and ranged weapons, like allowing you to control the shot of your predator arrow mid-air. Abilities allow you to unlock the various tools, second slots for melee and ranged weapons. There are other kinds of abilities aswell.

Final Thoughts
Overall, Assassins Creed Origins is an excellent open-world RPG that brings new mechanics to the series while remaining true to itâ€™s roots. Gameplay is well thought out and fluid. It took me 101 hours to finish the game on Normal Difficulty, while exploring the whole map thoroughly and completing everything the game has to offer. I also managed to achieve 100% achievements in a single playthrough. I can recommend buying at a discount.

Before I start with the review, I want to share my familiarity with the Assassin's Creed franchise:



The game did not hook me up at the beginning. The combat felt strange especially with the M/KB controls. The characters felt generic and the story did not feel like an AC game, but after about 4 hours I started to warm up for the game.

Bayek of Siwa (the main protagonist) started to grow on me. His quest and passion for justice started to become your own, thanks to the immersive world. The new characters introduced to the world were authentic and Bayek's character development made him more and more relatable. My peak was around the questline, where your own blood starts to boil because of the injust you have been witnessing.
Old Egypt is portrayed quite nicely and authentic with a lot of intresting side quests to do and mysteries to unravel, though I can't tell you how historicaly accurate the game is.

Sadly the game starts to feel rushed towards the end. Another negative is the optimisation: As I said the M/KB controls feel strange but you get used to it, but you do not get used to the constant stuttering and frame drops this game has. I recommend everyone to use the Vulkan based implementation of DirectX (DXVK), thanks to that modification you can run this game with higher frames and better stability, but this is still not an excuse for not delivering an update with proper optimisation.

My progression with the game is at 72%, where I stopped playing after finishing the main quest, which required me to play about 40 hours.

I definitly recommend the game, even for someone who is only familiar with the old gameplay of the Assassin's Creed franchise, but I would not buy the complete edition without trying out the game first.
I have the addons for the game, but I did not touch them yet, because I currently feel exhausted of this game.

Posted: March 10
Good Fried Chicken Recipe:

In a large mixing bowl, whisk together buttermilk, hot sauce (optional, for added flavor), salt, and pepper in a mixing bowl. Add in chicken pieces. Cover the bowl with plastic wrap and refrigerate 4 hours.
When ready to cook, pour the vegetable oil in a skillet until it is about 3/4 inch deep. Heat to 350 degrees.
Prepare the breading by combining the flour, cornstarch, onion powder, garlic powder, oregano, basil, white pepper, cayenne pepper, paprika, and salt in a gallon sized resealable plastic bag or shallow dish. Mix it thoroughly.
Working one at a time, remove chicken pieces from buttermilk mixture. Shake it gently to remove the excess. Place it in the breading mix and coat thoroughly. Tap off the excess.
Place the breaded chicken into the 350 degree oil. Fry 3 or 4 pieces at a time. The chicken will drop the temperature of the oil so keep it as close to 350 degrees as possible. Fry each piece for 14 minutes, turning each piece about half way through, until the chicken reaches an internal temperature of 165 degrees F.
Remove from the oil and place on paper towels. Let them rest for at least 10 minutes before serving.

The not so great:
- Even years later the game will crash on some rare occasion. I'm assuming it's usually because of graphics in fast moving scenes (like fighting)

- Reactions to the controls can often get annoying, like the all too familiar jumping to your death instead of the pillar you wanted.

Recommended
125.4 hrs on record
Posted: December 31, 2018
I just finished 100% completion on the main campaign, and both DLCs and was thoroughly satisfied. I've been playing the AC series since the beginning, only missing a few in the series, and this one is, by far, the best (I have not yet started Odyssey).

Gameplay:
This game has elements of Far Cry with the fortress assaults and Witcher 3 with the various landmarks on the map containing miniature objectives. The quests are all fully scripted and many of them are creative. Combat was much more interesting than past entries and the variety of weapons allows you to play the style of combat that you like. Most of the fortresses are designed to allow you multiple strategies for infiltrating them. You can go in with straight up combat, assassinate from the shadows, or pick off enemies one by one with your bow. The mild level-up "RPG" elements were nice and gave you extra incentive to run around completing the miscellaneous objectives. While many of the entries in the series had a lot of tedious filler (collect 100 hidden crosses, etc.), I never really felt that way about this one, despite a few recurring themes in the miscellaneous objectives.

Setting:
I have always been fascinated with Ancient Egypt and this game makes you feel like you're actually there as you wander around the cities and villages. Discovering the pyramids your first time is really exciting and the graphics provide plenty of breathtaking views. And just when you think you've seen enough of deserts and egyptian masonry, you start to discover other biomes and certain other architectural styles which I won't spoil for you. The first DLC (Hidden Ones) just is more of the same (and rather short), but the Curse of the Pharoahs really strikes out into new territory. If you can get it at a discount, get them both.

Overall, this is one of the best games I've played since Witcher 3. My only gripes are pretty minor. Several of the quests require you to follow someone who walks very slowly. I've gotten stuck following these people as they slowly walk across the city because I decided to launch the quest at the wrong time of the day. It's very annoying, but fortunately rare. Also, inventory management can be a pain. While there is a shortcut to sell all junk, some quests actually require that you collect certain "junk" items, so you generally want to avoid using this. Selling items line by line is tedious and time consuming. But these are very minor complaints in what is otherwise a fantastic game. Highly recommended!
