Recommended
119.2 hrs on record
Posted: July 3, 2021
I love the Assassin's Creed franchise and play it religiously, but after Syndicate I was honestly scared for its future. That game had the most hideous story I had the displeasure of playing in an AC game. Bad writing, bad characters, everything was shallow and uninteresting. It was an all-time low.
But this...

This is insanely good. Story. Characters. Setting. Gameplay.

They revamped the formula of the AC games. It is still the open world parkour game we know and love, but now it has a twist: It's now more gameplay-focused, instead of being cinematic. it also has many new RPG elements.
It's still similar enough that old players of the franchise will still like and different enough so that people who previously didn't enjoy the AC series may like this one.

Now to talk about a few things worth noting:

The map! The world of AC Origins, which is mainly Egypt in the end of the Ptolomaic line, with a few bits of Rome and later on egyptian afterlives, is insanely large, detailed and beautiful. Breathtaking, to say the least.

â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ ton of side quests! They bring depth to the giant world AC Origins offer, but the writing and acting is not always on point. A lot of times they are boring and outright abnoxious. I also don't get how Ubisoft thought it was a good idea to add characters from side quests into the main quest later on without requiring the player to complete them. (Where did Tahira come from if I didn't complete her quest????)

Leveling! We had leveling in the AC series since Unity, but this game takes that beyond. Where we had up to 10 levels in previous games we now have 55 â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ levels (with the CotP DLC) with a lot of skills to earn. I like leveling systems. They make me feel like I'm actually progressing though a game and becoming stronger, but this also amounts to the farming issue.

Difficulty! You can now choose now just how tough the enemies will be, ranging from "slap me and i be dead" to "god himself may smite me and i shall still stand." That being said I played through Nightmare a few times and the only difficulty I had was with the last two bosses, which I was able to handle eventually, and the Curse of the Pharaohs DLC bosses. These â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ suck. I turned down the difficulty for a couple of them cause I was at max level, max damage possible and yet dealt no damage at all while getting hitkilled.

Damage calculation! Yep, you can no longer just insta kill anyone with your hidden blade. That now takes into consideration your level, difficulty and hidden blade upgrade (which is interesting but also means you have to farm for levels which may be boring to some people.

Now, for the cherry on top of all of my cakes: the story:

I love this game's story. Why? Because I love the characters. I love Bayek, I love Aya, I love Phanos... the list continues. The characters bring me back to AC 2 and 4's level of development and depth. Seeing Bayek shedding his scales of vengeance to live by a new creed is excellent and seeing the culmination of that at the Hidden Ones DLC is just...beautiful.

Do I recommend this game to you? If you have a good PC, enjoy open world games with a few dozen hours of content to explore, good gameplay and loveable characters, then YES!

Even if you previously did not like the AC series, try this. Maybe you'll enjoy this one

if you don't no refunds from me >:)

Not Recommended
83.6 hrs on record
Posted: November 29, 2021
Plus:

- Stunning and exceptionally well optimized visuals, you don't have to buy plane tickets to see pyramids. Just buy this game and you will see the whole of Egypt ( ancient, that is ). Land and sea, equally beautiful
- Fast travelling system
- Hunting for crafting to get certain items
- Minimal to none micro transactions
- NPCs are slightly better than average, as you would expect with the reactions/ dialogues
- You get to study Roman Empire and Ancient Egypt without going to school
- Very, very mediocre but heart-warming storyline
- Minimal glitches / bugs, overall decent optimization


Minus:

- Had my friend not mention about this, I wouldn't have realized it sooner. Side quests are so repetitively boring that it made me quit this game. Let me elaborate: You go to different parts of the map, face the same types of enemies, kill them, gain levels, rinse and repeat.
- 'Same types of enemies', ie same human, The only difference with these human enemies ? Levels. The only exception where you face bigger bosses are other animals , refer to: https://acorigins.fanswiki.com/Enemies. Again, the difference between the animals are levels. There are no monsters ( technically ) in this game.
- Which brings me to the levelling system, this is a arguable point, but IMO I don't prefer games where they are level dependent in order to progress. In AC Origins, you have NO ( 0% ) chance to progress other maps of the world or even the story itself without levelling up. You will get a warning by the game saying that you are lower level and not encouraged to clear the area, even if you tried to, you can't 1 shot stealth kill / can't win a combat. It's doable if enemies are 1 or 2 levels higher, but at 5 levels higher, they're just telling you to GTFO.
- Which then brings me to the grind, you're short of level, what do you do ? Oh, let's grind. At the time of writing, my game totals at around 80 hours. I was able to cap my levels by continuously travelling from 1 place to another, same kills, same combats, gain levels. It becomes too repetitive that after I had cap my levels, I did not finish the last 30% of the map and just too bored to even finish the story
- Grinding which then brings about the levelling, once you're max / higher levels, enemies are just punching bags for you, there are minimal skills needed but overall to none in the combat department. You gained levels = you hit faster/ harder to the point that you are just pressing 1 button while your character swings his schlong around automatically dealing fire / poison to whomever comes near
- Mediocre AI just like Hitman. 1 distraction and you could take them down 1 by 1. Peripheral vision by AI is poor and performing kills by lurking around the bushes is just not satisfying enough


What's fun:

- Stealth kills but NO WAY as fun like Batman franchise
- Getting OP weapons
- Different levels of transportation ( from slow to fast )


CPU/ GPU Specs:

- IntelÂ® Coreâ„¢ i9-9900 Processor
- Asus ROG Strix GeForce RTX 2060 SUPER


Buy/ Not buy ?

- It is a grinding game no matter you've checked out other reviews or gameplays, etc. So if you're the kind of person who doesn't mind doing the same â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ over and over again, this game is for you
- Would recommend to buy it during sales unless you're a fanboy of Ubisoft, then go ahead to purchase it full price, otherwise not a buy from me unless this game goes for 4$ or below

The story is good, the gameplay mechanics are decent. The biggest issue I have with this game is the REPETITIVENESS. Majority of the game plays out the same. Go here, climb this, tail this dude, don't get caught, kill this dude, escape the area. in comparison to a game like MGSV where each mission could be played out in 20 different ways. There's very little variety. In the first 12 hours of the game you have already experienced what the game has to offer then it goes on for another 20 or even more. Then there are the side missions, UBISOFT'S idea of mission variety is like this: Hey here's the exact side mission but the enemies have higher health and it's over here on the side of the map. At some point in the story the game just comes to a halt cause your character isn't a high enough level, turns out the side missions aren't just things you can ignore. In this game, you have to complete a ton of them in order to level your guy up, and I have to say, they give you very meager xp for doing a side mission that takes a while. And by the time you finally reached the required level, the story just becomes confusing at times. But, but, but, that is where time savers come in bois! UBISOFT want's you to pay for xp and equipment so you don't have to play the game you just bought for 60$.
But hey if you look over all those flaws then there is a graphically beautiful open world you can explore. 6/10 WAIT FOR SALE.

A Screenshot of Assassin's Creed Origins
By: Rurik


I never played any of Assassins Creed games. Mostly because all of them are action games, but I don't like action games.
I bought it because it has good reviews and I like Ancient Egypt.

In the start it was fun. Cool pictures, nice cutscene, new mechanics for me. I started completing all available stuff (side quests, killing captains). At the day 2 I understood there come more of them, it disappointed me.

I finished the game in 31 hours. I skipped all unnecessary stuff after level 18, I just wanted to finish it. So, basically, it is not a feature of nice game, but I liked visuals and the end of story, so I give the game positive review.

I liked that ancient egyptian drug trip! 
A Screenshot of Assassin's Creed Origins
By: Rurik

Pros
- So beautiful game. Deserts, cities, seas. Days and nights are different. Pyramids and tombs. Temples and shrines. Great villas and poor slum.
- Animations in combat are satisfying. Basically you just click 2 buttons but it is nice to see how Bayek kills enemies
- Animation of face of main hero in cutscene is great. I really feel that man.
- Feel of freedom is good. You can climb almost everywhere.
- A lot of locations and side stuff (quests, tombs, shrines and etc)
- End of story is satisfying

Neutral
- It is too huge. Most of locations have a lot of visual things on them but feel empty. You came in a huge city but there are just 2-3 quests. Complete them and move forward. I would like to see smaller but richer content
- It is 90% Action game and 10% RPG game. Yeah, you get exp, there is a skill tree, but it doesn't affect gameplay significantly
- There are only 3 item of equipment weapon, bow and a shield. No chest, bracers and etc. You get tons of weapons in each kill and they are all similar. It feels pointless. Also I never spend even 1 gold for entire game

Cons
- Devs tell in main screen, it is a fiction of their team. But the story is so silly. Especially the stuff with historical persons like Caesar, Cleopatra and etc. For example, Caesar attack in front line with just a sword and Egyptian fellow which he met 1 day ago. Or a scene, where some random guys get to Caesar palace with a carpet.
- Repetitive. There are a lot of stuff like enemy camp, kill captain, seek for treasure and they are ALL THE SAME. As a true RPG player I started clear all stuff and left that after 20 level, because there are a lot of similar stuff and it got boring


A night!

By: Rurik

Resume
Very very beautiful game with different awesome views, cities, buildings, animations, effects and etc. It is just cool to see it on the screen. Gameplay gets repetitive very fast. You do same stuff. It is only 5% RPG game, so it achieves you with nothing for completion of side content. It is nice to spend 2-3 hours at evening. But it is not engaging enough to keep you playing day after a day like other RPG games. Take it with a discount just to see that graphics.

+ Photo Mode is something new to AC and it's nice to have, you need this because they are so many things that are so beautiful and you want to make a photo of them. You can see what others players photos in the game and on the map sometimes you can see artworks from the Ubisoft that are beautiful.

- Camera positions in fighting sometimes is to close to you and you can't see the enemies and sometimes is fine.

They really need to work on this in the next game. This elephant is just an example, but when you fight in arena or in free-roam with many enemies the camera can â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ you and lose your fight.

I am fascinated with the classical world. This game allows one to visit the Pyramids, the Great Library of Alexandria, the Great Sphinx, Memphis, Alexander the Great's tomb, and so much more. I'm not one that cares too much about the storyline, but what is there is very good. I like how this game ties into the AC universe. The Discovery Tour mode is one of my favourite aspects of this game. This mode allows you to visit many ancient historical sites and explore them as they were in Cleopatra's day. If you're at all interested in this historical time period, I can't recommend this game highly enough!

Recommended
55.1 hrs on record
Posted: May 28, 2020
---{Graphics}---
The graphics are very good for this game. I played on mostly Medium 1440p downscale to 80% and the lighting is absolutely amazing. The textures are also great.
---{Gameplay}---
The gameplay is great. There are many things you can do such as hunting, fighting, and exploring. The combat and sealth is good though as an AC game there isn't much focus on sealth. Still though it is decent, and the combat is pretty nice and different. There are different types of weapons with different benefits and harder enemies show up in more difficult parts of town

---{Audio}---
The audio is pretty good. When you go in caves or some buildings it gives a nice reverb effect. The audio quality is also pretty good. What I dislike about it though is that you can't lower the dialouge volume, which is a bummer
---{Audience}---
Teens and up
---{PC Requirements}---
A fast computer is good for running this game. My rx570 usually ran around 45-55 in the streets with 80% of 1440p Medium (1152p) with textures and details at Very High
---{Difficulity}---
Easy to learn, Hard to Master. I played on hard mode and it was fairly easy until I fought enemies that were 2 or more levels ahead of me, espically the big and more advanced enemies. You can parry attacks, which can gives some buffs such as healing you depending on the shield, but you have to time it right.

---{Grind}---
What makes this game different from the majority of the older AC game is that a good amount of the game is grinding. You'll spend alot of the time doing side missions or maybe even looking for materals instead of the main mission. For me I didn't enjoy doing much of the missions, and I just wanted to do the story quests.
---{Story}---
It was fine ig. Idk it just pretty decent, not something I would remeber. Maybe if there was less grinding and more story it would be better.
---{Game Time}---
I'd say it's pretty long. Took me around 40 hours to finish the story. I did do some tomb exploring and some hunting though, as well as playing the game on hard mode (I did fail a few missions...)

---{Price}---
Honestly I'd wait till it's on sale. I personally wouldn't buy this game for 60$.
---{Bugs}---
Other than some minor visual bugs I'd say it's good

This game has great gameplay and graphics, but I don't like much of the level grinding. I give it a 7/10 (Pretty Good)

10/10

So much better than Syndicate / Unity.

Running a 980Ti, and i7 4770 in a triple 1080p setup (nvidia surround, 5760x1080), consistently achieving 35-45 frames on ultra.

Pros:
Mostly perfect performance (for me at least).
New combat, actually takes some skill if you want to fight someone of equal or higher level, can't always just button mash.
Phylakes are the best, can't just stamp on low level hideouts when one of them rocks up.
New item system is fantastic.
Map is massive, and amazing to look at.
Theres lots to stay for after you complete the story, side quests are interesting, and they finally got rid of boring old chests you have to lock pick and replaced them with bandit hideouts you can loot from.
Steam Achievements, I've actually been spending extra time trying to get them all.
100% sync is actually pretty reasonable (I got it in about 90 hours). I've been motivated to get full sync in Unity / Syndicate, but couldn't because there was just too much grinding (endless amounts of chests etc).

Cons:
On a triple monitor setup (5760x1080) and FOV up high, water doesn't render on the far right and left of the screens.
Can't run the game off a hard drive formatted as a Microsoft Storage Space, had to create a symlink since I didn't have enough space on my none MSS drive.
In deep water I lag a LOT, the ocean is mostly fine, but water in tombs really lags me out, almost unplayable.
Fire looks terrible. Minecraft legit has better fire graphics.
No ability to replay missions or certain events. Other than arena fights or chariot races theres nothing you can replay without creating a whole new save.
No stat / sync tracker, considering this is the first AC game I've been motivated to 100% it would be nice to track progress towards this goal (and see it at 100% once done!!)
No database like previous AC games.

Pros
- Arbitrary access to the real world story arc and a fleshed out Animus user that provides a narrative hook for the player.
- The bleeding effect is back. Useless, but still there. It was probably missing in AC:Unity because they couldn't work it in.
- The original artifacts and no sages or blood drops or lightning swords or teleportation camel saddles (ok I made the last one up, but why not after the AC:Unity sword)
- Eagle sense is a LITERAL EAGLE circling above you, how cool and fresh is that?
- No camelcr*p eagle sense gimmicks like "smell-sense" from AC:Unity
- Completely figurative assassination cut-scenes and farcryesque, hallucinogenic dream sequences that feel more like a visual poem / eagle-sense-fever-dream than an FX-happy intern's post processing assignment.
- Heatstrokes
- "OMG is the Sphinx really that small?"
- Everything from the AC logo to the finger cutting practice get an origin story, which is a nice touch. Also the point of the title of the game. Obviously.
- Animus glitches are Egyptian Gods' personifications.
- No "income system with a lazy backstory because Ezio was a landlord" (I'm still looking at you Unity)
- Brutus

It's as if... It's as if Ubisoft was listening to the reviews. AC:Origins fixes everything I hated with a passion in AC:Unity.
BUT

Cons
- New game plus is a joke (you can practically jump right to the second play-through by turning the auto-level enemies on and playing at hard difficulty.)

- UI is confused about its relationship with Layla. Is it her Animus interface or is it the actual game's interface? Animus hacking and new game plus do not belong to the same narrative level. OR IS LAYLA'S STORY ANOTHER LAYER OF A SIMULATION? (cue in the Inception Bwah)

- Really, really on the nose dialogue along the lines of "we are assassins and our creed will live on... *wink wink*". Only thing missing in certain scenes is Bayek staring right into the camera like Jim Halpert from the Office, along with a snap zoom.

- I guess it was designed to be this fateful saga in the AC universe that sets everything in motion, but I think it was too spread-out in general and too on the nose when it was emphasized.

Well I'm knitpicking.

Story-wise it's still not anywhere near the Desmond story arc, but it's a way more dignified continuation than churning out new things like the sages or whatever the f*ck that stupid sword was in AC:U out of thin air to replace the currently expired elements. It doesn't frustrate like AC:U because AC:O is either taking elements from the previous games by making it obvious (like the artifacts), or trying something new like the Eagle-eagle-sense.

It's self contained. The characters are appealing. It's a specific, personal and fresh little story. Starts violently and ends with a powerful historic scene.

Fair enough Ubisoft, you won me back.

Recommended
86.2 hrs on record
Posted: October 31, 2017
Don't write Assassin's Creed Origins off just with the 'AC Formula' conceptions

Well well, it seems that the game has taken lots of people by surprise. There are so many different and new things in AC Origins that makes it wholly different from the previous iterations.

The game took many ideas from various games like The Witcher 3, Horizon, and even Dark Souls, while still keep the Assassin's Creed identity intact. The game is still mainly revolving around stealth and assassination, but there are also some notable new/improved things such as:
The combat has been revamped so it's now fully action with dodge and lock-on system
There are various weapons with its own moveset, utilities, as well as pros and cons
Weapons and armors have special effects/conditions (bleed, poison, resistance, etc) like what's usually found in RPGs
The map is not just a single city, it's a whole country with lots of villages, towns, and huge cities
The map is also divided into leveled-zones just like in RPGs. You can go to high-level zones but will definitely get wrecked in an instant
Other than the main quests, gameplay loop revolves around exploration for side quests and points of interest
Exploration is well-rewarded as you can get exp, loots, lore, and even MC's characterizations and hidden dungeons/encounters
Side quests are well-written and not just a simple fetch/kill quests, some of them are even chained to the following quest
The stealth is more challenging due to the improved AI, but still satisfying. Scouting the area with the hawk is pretty useful as well
The day/night cycle is not only for show now. NPCs have their routines so you can have an easier attempt at assassination at night
Synchronization doesn't reveal everything on the map, it only shows side quests and the optional points of interest
There are no collectible junks as far as I'm aware, everything is useful whether for crafting materials or making money
I'm liking the direction of the franchise has taken. It made me went from zero interest on the franchise to full anticipation for their next game. Though I'm considerably new to the franchise (only played AC II and Black Flag for a bit) so some things that are listed above might not be a new addition to Origins.

Overall, this seems to be the best game in the Assassinâ€™s Creed series. That extra year of development time has really helped Ubisoft find its creative center again, and craft something that feels both fresh and energized. The game feels fresh, has a new combat system, RPG elements, a great story and looks absolutely stunning. With so much to explore and do in its jaw-dropping setting, Origins is exceptional. All I care about is how utterly engrossed I am with the gameplay loop.

Recommended
74.6 hrs on record
Posted: November 29, 2020
About the Main Game

Beware that Ubisoft changed the development of the series after the weaker titles AC -Unity and AC - Syndicate. This game still has to do with Abstergo, the Animus and assassinating people. However, it shouldn't be looked at as an Assassin's Creed title in comparison to the first three games. The story about Desmond and others couldn't go on forever. So Ubisoft tried something new.

Story
The main story doesn't offer you anything completely new to the series. First of all, the protagonist gets introduced and the story builds up some tension.
Although it starts pretty promising, the storytelling returns to old patterns that have proven to work for Ubsisoft in previous games of the series: Assassinate this or that guy. Oh no, there are others. Assassinate them as well! Still, there are some epic battles though I have to say: the ending of the main questline felt pretty abrupt to me.
Side quests aren't anything special most of the time. Neither the charakters, nor their problems are interesting. Only a few contained memorable stories.

In conclusion, nothing special, but not too bad either.

6/10


Gameplay
The gameplay hasn't been fundamentally changed, really. However, there are a few different types of weapons and bows that allow different playstyles. The three-way-skill-tree allows to invest in further specialties. Controls felt pretty solid, I never jumped any directions I didn't want to go.
The developers did nothing wrong here sticking to patterns that have proven themselves many times.

7/10


Visuals
The highlight of the main game is the open world design. Although the tasks in the non-story-related locations are pretty repetitive, just riding or walking through the world is an amazing experience.
There's so much detail put into most locations, you gotta love it.

9/10


Soundtrack
The soundtrack is memorable but gets very repetitive and boring after a while. Main reason being: There aren't more than about five different tracks. Investing more in the music could have really underlined the beauty of the open world.

2/10


About The Hidden Ones (DLC)
The first and smaller DLC around the Sinai. It takes about five hours to complete all quests.
Storywise, it's a bit stronger than the main game. Sidequests and their charakters were a lot more memorable and interesting. After all, the climax of the main questline felt pretty abrupt to me. The open world remains good-looking. A little bit of new soundtrack here and there.
Get this if you want a little bit more of main game.

6/10


About The Curse Of The Pharaohs (DLC)
The second and bigger DLC. It's not huge, but it offers another major area to the player.
I don't want to spoil anything of the story here, but I can say that the main story and sidequests were a lot stronger than in the main game. Mainly, I guess, because it isn't alike anything you've seen in the AC Series before. You'll find yourself sitting there wondering what the hell is going on a few times (in a good way, trust me). The quality of the open world remains the same, soundtrack is a bit better than in the main game.

8/10


Conclusion
If you like open world games, riding around, Egypt and pyramids, I highly recommend the experience, but you shouldn't be expecting a strong story-game.
Nonetheless, I would recommend buying the DLCs on sale.

Secret information: Don't change the spoken language to anything else but English. Just don't.

137.8 hrs on record
Posted: October 7, 2021
The largest, most detailed, authentic and alive rendition of ancient Egypt ever done.

This is a game that deserves to be played if only for that. The detail, fidelity and scale of the world is truly stunning. You will be fully inmersed in the setting, being able to walk remote deserts, roman streets, egypcian temples and even explore the interior of the pyramids. Or climb them!
You'll also be able to see where the team got every detail from the excellent Discovery Tour, which is leagues better than the old databases and sadly has been discontinued in the saga.

Now, the game itself. This is a very poor Assassin's Creed game. The parkour has been stripped to just press X to climb everything. The movement is floaty and way too fast. The combat is even worse than previous entries, exchanging the Batman - Arkham games style combat for a more generic action rpg one. The equipment system is extremely barebones, featuring random loot composed of too few items with just a random handful of effects. The stealth kinda still works, and cleaning up forts is fun, but gone are double assassinations, gadgets or hiding into crowds or in the scenery.
This is a generic open world rpg clone with a pinch of stealth, and has been stripped of all its identity.

Narratively, the game starts strong, with an interesting protagonist and a cool setup, but passed the halfway point, the story gets rushed, with characters and situations coming and going without much build up or explanation, skipping over extremely important details and effects without solid causes. It is conceptually good, but executed extremely poorly.

Overall, this game is a very mediocre affair, but I fully recommend playing it just because of the incredible game world. It really makes up for everything else and is among the greatest game worlds ever created.

Recommended
118.9 hrs on record
Posted: May 6, 2020
Great game set up in Ancient Egypt with a lot of content.
If you have never played Assassin's Creed game series, this is one of the two best entries to start from, the other being Assassin's Creed 2. It introduces new for the series gameplay style (a simplistic RPG), a new chapter in the modern-day story, and it's just a good game.
I have played every game in the series, and this one is one of my favorites. The only caveat is you might need to upgrade your PC; that aside, the game is definitely worth the money and time spent.

Pros:
- Probably the best thing about this game is the main character - medjay Bayek. Unlike most other protagonists of the series, this guy can really be called a hero: he always tries to do right, is driven by noble motives, faithful to his wife and religion, but at the same time not blind. Sounds too good? Yeah, but at the same time he feels real. This was made possible mostly by terrific voiceacting of Abubakar Salim (honestly, I don't remember any other game character with such range of emotions). The story is a typical vengeance tale, but Bayek makes the journey very real and filled with sense.
- Huge open world spanning the whole map of Ancient Egypt (and not only). Pyramids, Sphinx, Pharos Lighthouse - all of that you can see and touch. The world is full of people doing all kinds of daily routines, which makes it very lively and you can really feel immersed into the history.
- Great music by Sarah Schachner, a combination of Egyptian motives with modern electronic styles.
- Gameplay is a nice refreshment after the low point of AC:Syndicate. For the first time in the series, enemies can attack you together and not just stand there and wait for their turn. In practice, this means that the combat is hit-and-roll style, but the arsenal of tools and a couple of special moves makes it pretty engaging. Even after 100 hours played, I would sometimes discover a new way to fight.
- For the first time in the series (AFAIR), you can set the game difficulty. I played the entire game on the highest possible difficulty, and many encounters were quite challenging. If you just want to know the story, you can always switch to easy.
- For the game of this size, there is surprisingly small amount of bugs. There are more bugs in DLCs than in the main game, but nothing game-breaking.
- As with most Ubisoft games, there is pretty much nothing missable, so you can just enjoy your journey through history without worries.
- We got a first staple modern-day protagonist since Desmond and some modern-day gameplay. Not the best one, but definitely better than what was happening since AC3.

Cons;
- The game is pretty heavy on resources, and not with the best optimization. Denuvo DRM makes it even worse, and Ubisoft is not going to remove it. Oh, and you need to have Uplay ot play this too. So, in your background will be Steam, Uplay and Denuvo - that in the addition to an already demanding game. When people play a cracked version of the game just because it runs better, you know something went wrong...
- At some point at the game, you will inevitably feel overwhelmed with the number of locations. There are just too many question marks on the map! There is a good variety of different activities and assets though, so this point in the game will most likely not come very soon for you.
- People around you talk a lot. The problem with this is that the assortment of their lines is very limited, and they start to annoy pretty soon. The most annoying for me was "Ha! Pessesh en gerrehh" (commonly known as "High precision, Garret!"), which means something like "It's midnight" in the game's version of Ancient Egyptian. Needless to say, you can hear it any time of the day...
- After playing the game, I got the impression that the Roman Empire was the ultimate evil and so are most Romans. Now, I am not a historian, but I am pretty sure that it is not so. Also, the history in the game is a bit disconnected from the story. If you just play the game, you might get lost in the current political situation and such. There is a discovery mode which is a kind of virtual museum, but it is basically a completely separate game. And you probably shouldn't play it before the main game either, as it will show all the major locations and will take away the joy of discovering them yourself. So I ended up reading some wiki articles on ancient history (which is not a bad thing, but I wish there was more explanation in the main game).
- (common for the series) You will kill hundreds (thousands?) of possibly innocent guards and soldiers to get the treasure they are guarding. No way to fix that though, except not playing Assassin's Creed at all.
- As the game is very big and made by many different people, there are some inconsistencies. For example, there are quests where you kill people just because they hunt animals. On the other hand, by that time you would probably have hunted hundreds of animals yourself. Not fair!

P.S. Many people complain about microtransactions. I didn't find it annoying at all. You can play throughout the whole game without even noticing the store button, it's pretty worthless. In single-player games like this, you wouldn't want to get the best weapons upfront, as it will just make it less interesting (and the store doesn't even have the best weapons). Just ignore any real-money stuff and enjoy the game:)

88.8 hrs on record
Posted: November 20, 2017
Better than expected

Ok so I was going to wait until I finished the game for a reveiw but this game is so freaking long. Unfortunately I have a job so I'm not able to play it as much as I would like but in any case I have a played a good amount and feel I can give an honest view point. So let's begin.

GRAPHICS

Holy mother of crap this game is utterly gorgeous! It rivals The Witcher 3 even, except not in performance, which we'll get to. But honestly as far as the graphics go it is fantastic to explore and I have spent a lot of time just looking at it. The detail is insane and it feels pretty authentic scale wise. I love ancient history and this is one of my favorite time periods so seeing it brought to life so beautifully is a real a treat. Tombs are cool, lush areas, big open deserts, lively cities, and a fantastic looking sky box. Another thing is the water. If the The Withcer 3 is considered (jokingly) the candle light simulator than AC Origins is Water simulator 2017. Never seen better water graphics/physics in my life. Over all really good looking and great fun to explore.

PERFORMANCE

Ok so here is the unfortunate problem everyone is dealing with. Performance is pretty bad. I have played 68 hours so far and I haven't had a single crash, so I guess that is something but hitting a stable 60 fps is impossible. I have an i7 3770K processor, GTX 980 ti, 16 GB of RAM, and running on Windows 7 with a 1080p tv and it struggles even though I am above recommended specs. The only way I have hit 60 fps is way out in the desert where there is barely anything to process. Cutscenes are really choppy and stuttering is getting annoying. I have found a decent work around though. After patch 1.03 I decided to cap my frame rate at 45 fps. Now it runs perfectly and this allows me to put the graphics on max settings while still being able to get something smoother than 30 fps. Also my CPU nor my GPU will ever hit 100% usage this way no matter where I'm at so it is a good compramise I suppose. I truly believe all the stupid DRM is the issue so hopefully that will be removed but until then this is a solid work around and is playable.

GAMEPLAY

Ok next is game play. Gameplay is not too bad. Climbing is smooth and accurate. Shooting your bow feels pretty good and animations aren't bad. My one big hangup is the combat. I don't hate it but I don't really care for it either. It's really good for an RPG but bad as an Assassin's Creed game. I miss the old styalized combat. They sacrifice epic style for challenge and strategy. There just aren't very many finishing moves and you only get to do a finishing move on the very last guy in a group and it only works half the time anyway. So you could take on 20 guys but only witness one epic looking kill. I also feel this game could benefit from a counter button. Focusing on one guy at a time is frustrating when archers and others try to sneak up on you. Don't even get me started on the guys who constantly throw smoke bombs at you. If you could counter them for just a second and then go back to the one guy you were focusing on that would be great but no such option is given. Also the hidden blade is very disappointing. You can't fight with it and it is used for stealth only and there is only one animation kill that is used over and over again every time you use it so stealth can get boring and repetative. "But it's more challenging this way and blah blah blah" I don't really care for challenge (I hate Dark Souls) so I was a little worried when I saw the combat but was relieved when I saw a difficulty setting. That's fine if you want a challenge I just wish they could have made it more styalized. Overall though I usually avoid RPGs because combat is always dull, tedious, and boring but in this case the combat is just good enough to keep my interest and keep me going. I just feel a lot of improvements could be made. Also the microtransactions are bull$h!t and are way too expensive.

STORY

Story is good so far, I'm about 75% done or so. Side quests are actually decent and have cutscenes and everything. They give a little more to the main story as a whole much like The Witcher 3. That game definitely had influence on this one. Bayek is also an awesome character. No one will ever top Ezio but Bayek is a close second and is much better than previous titles. (no one can be worse than conner, lol) Over all story seems good and you get to meet a lot of ancient historical figures and it makes the setting that much better.

OVERALL

Overall this is a decent game that is fun enough and interesting enough to see it through to the end, and it is a long one. Great setting, awesome graphics, good characters, decent enough combat and overall a fun time

SCORE

8/10

79.9 hrs on record
Posted: April 9, 2018
The greatest comeback story ever told

Before I start the review, it is safe to say that a lot of people in the gaming community do not like Assassin's Creed. A good chunk of people think of it as repetitive, unoriginal, and uninspiring series in their past few titles. Not to mention, some of their games have been extremely glitchy/buggy.

The thing that Ubisoft centers around in Assassin's Creed is this one element:

If it ain't broke, don't fix it.

Their games were this:
Get mission
Assassinate
Very strict Stealth mission
Reach vantage point
Weird mission
Plot twist that is average
Rinse and Repeat

For some people, this was never a problem and it felt perfectly fine to have this type of gameplay. It oddly scratches the ADD or OCD tendencies that we have and makes you feel like you are going through a meditative experience. As humans, we like to fall in routine so what better way to get in the groove of things with 'fun' repetition.

Hence the "Oh my god, I just played this game for 8 hours in one sitting?" feeling.

Stardew Valley is very guilty of this and who would have known making a farm and seeing crops grow would be satisfying?

If I was Ubisoft and I was making millions off this formula, no freaking wonder I would barely change it and rehash it every year!

This time, they went balls to the wall with getting their games to be more than just tedious.

Back to the drawing board

Assassin's Creed was in hot water because their last few titles were quite simply not selling enough. Unity was glitchy, Syndicate was great but not strong in the sales department, Rogue was also good but just more of Black Flag in every respect.

The last memorable Assassin's Creed is without a doubt Black Flag. Ubisoft needed to get this game back on it's good graces and let everyone know that their cash cow is not going to die out into the sunset. First thing's first, some time off and think:

"How can we make this game stand out from the other games?"

Assassin's Creed follows a more Action RPG approach this time around. For example, instead of a barebones Combat system, it is a meaty and visceral experience; something that could compare to a toned down For Honor combat system that only includes Light Attacks, Heavy Attacks and Dodging with an Overdrive Meter that fills up everytime you land a strike. Each weapon archetype has different functions when it comes to the Overdrive meter. Giving the player the option to test out each category and see what is the one that they favor the most

An example like this shows that Ubisoft understood that they had to do drastic measures to make some noise. This was a great risk on their part. To get away with stealth and go action oriented and boy did it work.

"Out with the old, in with the new."

In my playtime of the game, here is what is better:
Climbing/Freerunning
Combat
Godlike World Details
Looting system w/ Item Levels
Your magical bird that scopes out the area
Stealth and Sneaking (that magical crouch button)
Cutscenes
Story
Minor complaints for me are:
Bugs where the enemies get stuck in walls, floors, along with other NPC's and Mounts.
Story is good but if you dont pay attention, you will get lost. Certain games have a beautiful magnetism in their storytelling that it is almost impossible to not pay attention (Killer is Dead, Uncharted 4, Last of Us, etc.)
Some mechanical mishaps such as your horse derping around terrain and enemies having the innate ability to know where you are when invading.
In game Micro Transactions. I plead guilty. I gave in and bought a set that makes my character look like a pharaoh.

A game that keeps on giving

When you play this game, you will find it hard to compare it to the previous entries in the series. There are so many different aspects and very few same ones that you will actually compare it to other games that it gets influenced by.

This is easily Metal Gear Solid V meets Witcher 3 meets Assassin's Creed. The immense map and activities to do are all fun and barely tedious because of the fantastic progression you feel when leveling up and geting better loot across all of Egypt. Bravo, Ubisoft!

Even though this game has a Fast Travel option, I spend a lot of time cruising around with my horse on the sand dunes from Point A to Point B. That is how much detail there is in the world, that is how much they changed this game, that is how serious they are when it came to being mindful of others playing this.

I look forward everytime to fighting because they no longer want you to stick to sneaking as the viable option. You can get alarmed and duke it out with every poor soul in any camp you take over. It is immensely satisfying when doing so too. Seriously, I do not think you understand how gorgeous this game looks. Even on Medium-High settings it is a serious looker.

Give this game a shot on sale or full price if you are a Assassins Creed fan that is dying to play it.

Assassin's Creed Origins â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜… (4.8)

LONG REVIEW by jSM 2019

tl:dr One of the best AC Games ever! Great 100% factor to it, feels amazing to play, stealth mechanics are almost perfectionated, when ignoring the sometimes wacky AI - can not recommend this game more!

I had a blast, that lasted 200 hours and gave me many happy memories while playing this masterpiece of a game over the course of almost 3 years.

This is by far the best Assassins Creed game out there and for me even AC II and Brotherhood can't compete with this game. Bayek is such a great and sympathic character, the world is beautiful and interesting, there is enough side content to make every little cave and spot valuable to the largest open world of all Assassins Creed games (except maybe Odyssey).

If you are a fan of either the AC franchise or of RPG games in generel and even slightly like what you will read through, grab this game at a sale, play it and make your own opinion on what i consider to be one of the best games out there.

That said, Origins is not only one of my favorite 100% games but also one of my overall favorite games of all time, even with all it's flaws that it might have.

The Good...

Assassin's Creed Origins is what many expected when it first came out: a new try on the slowly repetitive AC franchise. Giving the player a whole new understanding of the series, integrating RPG elements, a huge Open world in ancient egypt, horses, camels, many interesting characters, an outdated, stereotypical but still relatable main plot, a TON of interesting but also fairly simple and fetch-quest kind of side content and quests & with Bayek of Siwa, a medjai (former protectors of the pharao and the folk) one of THE, if not THE best Assassins Creed main characters of all time (sorry Ezio)

The open world is a massive construct, devided in level orientated areas that you'll discover while progressing the main story. From Alexandria, to the big pyramids of Gizeh, to the Fayyum and through endless deserts, this is the most beautiful and authentic open world AC has ever seen and it catched me the first time i ever set foot in it and still does when remembering how the Assassins Creed Origins title appeared after finishing the almost 5h long prologue! - Every of the about 35 different areas offer the player a variety of ? that represent points of interests. From hidden treasures, papyrus-riddles that need to get solved using the given hints, outposts of the local militia or bandits in the open, AC typical lookout towers that allow your eagle "Senu" to spot enemies and quest objects from a further distance, using the eagle vision, animal shelters/camps, where you have to kill a special "alpha animal" that drops you more than the usual ingredients that you need to upgrade Bayek's gear, such as your hidden blade, armor or arrow holster.
-
Overall there is A LOT TO DO, whether your searching for the next phylakes (strong bounty hunters that will be set out in the world (in there respective region) after a certain story point and will hunt you down), fighting war elephants aka. the strongest enemies in the game in their arenas, progressing through the main story, or collecting one of the many crafting materials such as iron, wood, etc, Origins has a lot to offer for any kind of player, while giving you access to RPG typical experience points to aquire all kinds of skills like allowing you to control your arrow mid-air, extra damage, better attacks with one of the multiple swords, spears, staffs, battleaxes & many other skills.

All of the playable weapons have their own playstyle, spears are long and slow, while dealing more damage, battleaxes even more so, while the dual blades deal less damage but are quicker to use and feel more "assassin"-like. Every weapontype has their own moveset, chargeable attack and power attack once you have build you power attack bar up. Normal swords come with a stab and shield bash, heavy axes come with a rage mode, that allows you to deal more damage while having higher armor stats, dual blades let you jump your enemy and with the upgraded skill even stab your enemy multiple times while you sit on top of them and so on.. Overall a nice design concept, the same goes for the bows that all come with their own playstyle.

The world also looks absolutely stunning. Rarely have i seen a world that sucked me in so well, giving me this kind of immersion, while having this kind of graphical finesse. From an artistical viewpoint every landscape seems to be made just to be looked at for hours and hours upon. I could say much more but instead just look at two of the many pictures i took with the ingame camera mode to tell for yourself.


Assassin's Creed Origins 
A Screenshot of Assassin's Creed Origins
By: jSM


Assassin's Creed Origins 
A Screenshot of Assassin's Creed Origins
By: jSM


I dont want to say too much about the story, because this is something everyone should experience for themselfs, but even though it is a "stereotypical" story, i did enjoy the majority of it.. You meet all kinds of historical characters throughout the game, the cutscenes are beautifuly made, designed and animated, aswell as acted. The english, as well as the german voices are all believable and feel true to what they try to tell you, although the english voices are (like in most cases) still a bit better than its counterparts.

The Boss fights are overall well designed and are fun to experience even on the hardest difficulty called "nightmare" - at first this is a experience for very grounded players but after a while playing on nightmare almost feels like second nature and when playing with a stealth/bow build the overall difficulty is so easy that playing on either hard or higher becomes almost a necessity. - Only with the DLC and high end game bosses the difficulty isn't perfectly balanced and ends in pointless hack & slash, without tacticts. You die in one to two blows while your enemy tanks hundreds if not more. This is not good game and enemy design, just lazy and pushed me to turning down the difficulty to the easiest mode after fighting some of the DLC / War elephant enemies for 20 minutes, dealing almost no damage on the highest level and the best available gear.

All of the achievements are a challenge to play this game even more, are nice to finally aquire and (imo) are a perfect example on how to create good achievemnts, grinding them never once felt like a waste of time, was a reason to clear out all the question marks (having slight OCD when it comes to open world maps also helps with it) and all in all Origin is probably one of my favorite games to 100% ever made, even though having to play the DLC's just to finish the game on steam with 100% was a punch in the face at first. Having played both DLC's on 100% now, it feels a lot better and i do not regret having spend all the time and money.

The Bad...

Not much actually, the enemy design regarding boss battles and their insane amount of tank abilities are a slight concern, but the feature to turn down the difficulty at any time solves the issue.

Here and there are some bugs and glitches, the framerate can drop in populated areas and the climbing mechanics can be as clunky as you would expect them to be from an AC game but nitpicking this as a big problem would be ridiculous.

There are lootboxes in the game but they can only (or almost only) be received and opened through the ingame currency. When opening you can receive either purple or golden rarety items that are all capped at your current level (can be leveled up later on for currency) and are all nice to look at and to play with. But since they are practically lootboxes, the received items are pulled at random, so in over 200h of playtime i still havent gotten the dual blades that i always looked for (rip me)

Posted: November 25, 2017
Tl'dr version:

Perhaps the best Assassin's Creed yet. Ubi's 1 year hiatus of the series did it no end of good. The RPG elements turn what would have been a drab action adventure game into a lengthy romp through Egypt. Obviously, hugely influenced by the Witcher 3 in almost every respect.
Additionally, possibly the best interpretation of the ancient world in any game ever made. As an avid classicist, HUGE PROPS to Ubisoft Montreal.

WARNING, CONTAINS MICROTRANSACTIONS

You can follow me, and see the rest of my work here:
http://steamcommunity.com/id/StarSide/myworkshopfiles/?section=guides

Elaborated version:

Ok, first off I'd like to preface that this game has quite a lot of microtransactions - make of that what you will.
Some of you might wonder why I'm giving this game a pass when I ripped into Shadow of War. The answer is I'm not. If I was able, I would be giving this a neutral review purely on the fact it has microtransactions however, in this case they are not as invasive as the ones in SoW where they were literally built into the subsystems of the game in a thoroughly insidious manner.
Make no mistake, they are still bad here, but I can't bring myself to give this a negative review purely on that fact.

Attitudinally, I would also say that this has been my first AC since BlackFlag, since I haven't even bothered playing the rest. That does not mean however, that I have not been keep tabs of Ubi's meddling and taken into account all their little invasive tactics; Unity's buggy microtransaction riddled strore springs to mind.

Onto the core-game, and it's a doozy. You're Bayek, a magi (some kind of Pharonic body guard essentially), and you're out on a quest for vengeance on those who killed your son (Not really spoilers, its on the back of the box). You'll be bouncing across a absolutely insane map that dwarfs almost every other I've seen in a long time, it's absolutely bloody massive; stretching from Siwa, to Alexandria, and through Memphis. That brings me to my favorite part of the game, the settings.

Not gonna lie, I got the game just for the chance to bounce around Hellenic Egypt, and boy do they do it justice. Every little detail of the ancient world has been captured immaculately, from the fresco's on individual buildings, to the slowly crumbling limestone coating on the great pyramids themselves. It's absolutely insane. With that said, you'll need an equally insane rig to experience it at it's fullest, as anything less than 5 year old hardware will be chugging hard, especially in the more densely populated areas.

Luckily, the options menu is fantastic. You'll have every opportunity to tweak every setting to get it running how you want it. I would highly recommend turning on the dynamic resolution option, so you can keep stable frame-rates without sacrificing fidelity. On it's highest settings, the game looks nothing less than fantastic to the extent I have almost no criticisms.

I have heard however, that some users have been experiencing some severe framerate drops due to the nature of the DRM. I kind neither confirm nor deny this as I myself have had no issues.


Microtransactions.

It's an online store, plain and simple. It's avoidable however, not like SoW. I strongly urge everybody to stay away from the virtual currency. Some of the stuff you can buy from the store is designed to break the difficulty gradient to make things so easy, you'd might as well be on Easy. It's a trap!!

Story.

Pretty run of the mill Asssassin's Creed type drama, but suffice to say their are lots of twists and turns, and tons of political intrigue to get your teeth into. Some may not appreciate the heavy emphasis on politics this time around, but for me It absolutely made it better.

Movement and Combat.

Think normal formulae of Assassin's Creed, but mixed with some of the Witcher 3, and a splash of Dark Souls. A strange mix to be sure, but it seems to work to work quite well. Bayek retains all of the agility of his Assassin compatriots from the other games, but you'll find he's a little less OP. Gone are the days when you could mow down a whole battalion of soliders without breaking a sweat. Instead, the combat mechanics focus a lot more on strategy, with a Dark-Souls esche combo system, where every blow counts, especially at the earlier levels. You'll eventually build up your tech tree where you are just as insanely OP as the last games, but you'll still have to think a little harder than before.

Additionally, the RPG mechanics are extend the number of weapons. Now there are multitudes of different weapon types ranging from spears to Khopesh's (the Dothraki curved swords), to warhammers, as well as many types of bows. Each one of these items will have been stated according to its level. Thankfully, you can only use weapons lower or the same as your own character levels, which keeps things balanced.


Sound.
Truly amazing. Swords sound viciously sharp as they whistle through the air, along with the hustle and bustle of ancient life. Some of the more intellectual among you might also notice there is many different languages being spoken across Egypt, ranging from Ancient Greek, to Latin, and some others I didn't recognize. Both are true to life and absurdly close to how they would have spoken in those days. Again, major props to the devs for the accuracy of the setting!


Conclusion
Again, not concentrating on the poor industry behavior, this is a truly phenomenal game. If you have an eye for scenery or like taking screenshots, you'll spend more time gaving at the insane monumental scenery than actually playing the game. There is something to like in almost every aspect of the game, and so I recommend this to almost everyone.

Recommended
128.5 hrs on record
Posted: October 30, 2017
Review in progress:

1. Looting. There's no "hold E" to loot for most of the items. You do have to hold it for the larger items, but that's not a big deal since it's faster than before and it's not all the time. +1 for me.
2. Game is beautiful. Draw distance is superb and adds to the realism. Characters are highly detailed.
3. Performance is really good (Very High settings at 1440p on a 1070 laptop 45-70 fps depending on the area. Desktop is 70-90 fps at very high 1440p 1080ti). There's also a lot of PC specific settings, benchmarking, and in the options menu it'll tell you how the game ran for the past 30 seconds by giving you a graph with fps and frametime for CPU and GPU.
4. In terms of gear, you can obviously gain loot from high ranking captains and such, but you if you find a certain sword or bow that you like, you can go to a blacksmith and upgrade your weapon and it'll scale to your level.
5. No Chromatic abberation, film grain, vignetting, or motion blur. +4 for me.
6.I like that you have a mount.
7. You have a more control over your parkour. In previous games I got annoyed at times because my character would run up a wrong wall or do something that I didn't want them to do. So far, this version seems to be more fluid. While I'm talking about parkour, it doesn't play as significant of a role as previous games. Which is fine by me. It's fun, but it did become monotonous in the other titles.
8. Combat system does take some getting used to
9. There is auto-movement (like using the jeep in FC4), which is nice so you can enjoy the scenery. You can create custom markers to auto travel to; you're not limited to objectives.
10. Side missions are much, much better than before. Granted I haven't played them all and they may end up becoming repetitive, but they feel a lot like the Witcher 3's side quests. Now, they're no where near as good as the Witcher (I mean, the Baron's side quests were some of the best I've ever played), but for Ubisoft to take some time and flesh them out, add variety, fully voice act a lot of them shows they're trying to make a change. In the previous AC games, I rarely did the side missions. They felt so boring, repetitive, and completely forgetable.
11. The world feels alive. Black Flag and Unity were excellent in creating the world that felt alive and bustling. Syndicate felt dead. I think they took another cue from Witcher here.
12. I like the main character a lot. I think the voice actor did a great job. But a lot of times the mocap seems off with his lips...Not ME:A bad, just not as good as it could be.

It feels like they took a few of the better ideas from other successful games while maintaining the AC identity. Glad I bought it. I was skeptical at first because Ubisoft has a way of making games look and play better than they actually are, but I think this one is a good and much needed change for the series. There are a lot of things in the open world that are useless and are simply clutter, but I think the new changes make the game a much better entry to the series than the stagnant yearly release it was in before. I'll be updating the review once I'm finished with the game to discuss story/characters.

Posted: November 1, 2019
If you're a person interested in culture, theology and the history of Ancient Egypt, I cannot recommend this game to you enough. 550 hours later, this game still promises hours and hours of fun, intriguing combat and heartwarming interactions with NPCs, all while you're surrounded by absolutely astonishing graphics. I learned many tactics and found many secrets during my playtime and I keep finding more and more things every week. If you by chance are fond of details, subtle storytelling, atmosphere, aesthetics and interaction with other people in games, this is by far the best personal example of an excellently-made game.
There's something for everyone: unique items for collectors, historically accurate arts & crafts for history fans, interesting gameplay and action for adrenaline junkies, an intriguing story for readers and watchers, and beautiful scenery for artists. The details and world building in this game are both phenomenal, the graphics are breathtaking and the controls are fun and easy to master. If you are looking for a challenge, this game is not for you, but if you are in any way an artistic person and prefer getting immersed in the beautiful ancient world of royalists, merchants and farmers, this game will not disappoint you. There are many paths you can take in this game, despite the story, of course, being linear, but the best part of this game is the freedom it gives you. With intriguing and unique content and stories, each step you take is different, but take my word and please, take your time while playing this game. Do not rush through it, do not skip dialogue, do not run wherever and whenever you can. For gods' sake, that's what Z is for. Get on your mount and walk through the town or go for a stroll through the village. Help out your fellow farmer after they'd dropped a haystack, make a dog happy and pet some cats. Light up some candles, sit down on a bench with your neighbour and enjoy the sunset, or warm up in front of a fire during chilly nights. If you are madly in love with the green waters of the Nile, lush gardens of Athu and the bronze sands of the Desheret, trust me, you will feel like home.
Just don't forget to take some screenshots, camera mode is astounding, especially in 4k.
 

Manslaughter
40 products in account

46 people found this review helpful

Not Recommended
29.6 hrs on record
Posted: January 1, 2021
Assassin's Creed Origins is an interesting point in the series, this is where Assassins Creed was infamously known as the repetitive yearly franchise, bringing a product that barely evolved with each release. Origins is the response to criticisms, they've added in a lot of mechanics from other games here and while I do think some changes have made massive improvements to this formula, there are a lot of poorly implemented ideas that result in Origins becoming a bit of a mess. I still enjoyed my time with Origins, but there were just a few too many pitfalls for me that I can't really recommend it.

By far my favourite thing about the Assassin's Creed franchise is the historical settings each game allows you to explore, and Origins is no exception in delivering an exciting world. Egypt is so unlike anything we've seen in the franchise so far, there's a surprising amount of variety through the map. Most areas feel relatively distinct from one another, you've got the isolated small towns that fit into the desert perfectly, and sharply contrast the more populated cities. I think the difference between the desert and plant filled areas also made for a surprising amount of map variety I wasn't expecting, same with the isolated areas of Egypt lacking in enemies and free for calm traversal, accompanied by some solid music. Unfortunately, the map did feel very empty to me at the same time. Enemy forts & camps were plentiful but they all felt extremely similar, and the few tombs I explored never felt exciting to uncover, especially when there's no incentive to other than money and loot in a game that's already teeming with it. I was especially disappointing that roughly a quarter of the map was gated at max level, incentivising you to stay away when in reality, these parts of the map contain almost no content (which I felt was a really misleading way of portraying how much content was in the game until you've already finished the story). While not the best at serving gameplay, the recreation of Egypt was fascinating to explore and took up the majority of my game time that wasn't directly in service of the story.

The story is unfortunately pretty stock standard for Assassin's Creed. You've got the standard kill a bunch of people throughout the country plot, but I don't think I've ever felt this unmotivated to do so. Origins relies on one extremely weak plot hook throughout the entire campaign, and it just does not deliver. The main campaign is full of uninteresting characters, conflicts that failed to engage me, and a story line that just goes on for way too long that I was completely uninterested by the end. I also cannot believe how little this game has to do with the titular "Origins" of the Creed, its briefly discussed in the last moments of the game, but overall has no focus in the narrative. The one saving grace is Bayek, who is a pretty solid protagonist to play as. He's got this calming mature tone to his actions, but is not afraid to showcase extreme emotions, and overall made for an enjoyable character to experience. However he rarely gets to show this, due to a lack of agency in the main story and far too little interesting side quests that actually involve Bayek as a character. And these side quests really are just run of the mill, I found a few good ones in my play through, but an overwhelming amount are just "kill bandits" or "steal thing from place full of bandits" that they just made the game feel extremely bloated. Origins failed to hook me with it's story, and Bayek really needed more time to shine in this game.

Origins introduced quite a rework to Assassin's Creeds' gameplay systems and it's pretty evident from the get go. Combat has received a significant overhaul for the better, and its actually engaging for I think the first time in the series. Weapons feel different from one another, you have a couple options for attack and defence & it actually requires some level of strategy compared to the standard parry-fest of previous entries. It's still rather basic however and a lack of upgrades that make much impact leave the combat wearing out its welcome fast, but I appreciate the steps taken here to make a huge chunk of the game more enjoyable. Stealth more or less operates the same, but removing a reliance on gadgets in favour of sneaking around enemy bases made for a more exciting gameplay loop for me (although using the bow could make things a bit easy at times). The reworks here definitely work to Origins' favour, but I don't think they quite did enough to give Origins much of an identity, it doesn't excel in any areas, just grabbing the basics from a lot of other games that execute these ideas much better.

The biggest change is the introduction of RPG elements and I think mostly they're fine. I don't care for massive amounts of loot, and I think most of the skill tree was bland, but neither felt detrimental to the experience. But special mention needs to be brought to how much levelling ruins this game. Origins has such a strong reliance on levelling to get through the game, but levelling up never changes combat. Both Bayek and enemies feel the exact same for the entire game aside from a couple upgrades, so I don't think areas needed to be so gated by high level enemies. The worst part is any enemy 3 levels above Bayek will become near invincible and deal a point o ungodly damage, to the point where even assassinations, the franchises staple 1 hit kill, will do maybe 1/10th of their health bar. I think this was an atrocious decision, it limits the player so much in where they want to explore, forced to grind up in order to merely survive. Combine this with the huge jumps in required levels for story content and the disgusting drip feed of xp, and Origins becomes dreadfully inflated, forced to do an awful amount of mandated side content that just drags the game out. I don't understand this decision, the side content should be there for those who want it, making it mandatory just highlights how repetitive the core gameplay is, and drags down the experience as a whole. Origins has no reason to be as long as it is and the poor inclusion of RPG elements just brings more attention to the worst parts of the game.

4/10

I couldn't quite mesh with Origins, although I respect the steps its taken to revitalise Assassins Creed, it created even more problems and needs so much more cleaning up to bring the game to an enjoyable standard. There was still a fun game in here, but it was just dragged down too much for me by its many problems. I'd recommend it to existing fans of Assassins' Creed or anyone who wants to chill out with a simplistic game in a beautiful setting; I spent most of my time in Origins talking with friends at the same time, and it was a good background game to get lost in. But I just don't think it does enough by itself to be a worthwhile experience.

Recommended
117.5 hrs on record
Posted: July 20, 2018
So this is my second review for Assassin's Creed Origins. My first one was a lot more negative than what this one is going to be. I feel that my opinions on some areas of the game have changed quite a bit. Because of that, I felt the need to make a new review.

The Story

Assassin's Creed Origins (ACO), is set in Ancient Egypt during the Ptolemic Era. You play as Bayek, a medjay and protector of Egypt. Bayek's story is tragic. He and his wife Aya seek revenge for the death of their son caused by a group of people called The Order of Ancients. The story sees you enacting their revenge as you travel across Egypt assassinating each member of the group.

Whilst this is happening, Egypt is in turmoil with a weak ruler and a suffering population. Egypt is inhabited by various peoples, each with varying political opinions and luxuries that cause conflicts all across the country. Most of these conflicts are caused by The Order of Ancients, so although what you are doing is personal, your actions are helping the people of Egypt.

So how good is the narrative? In short, it's alright. I enjoyed it more this time around. The characters are decent enough and the quality of the writing is great. Where the narrative fails is in its pacing and significance. The narrative structure for most of the game consists of finding somebody and killing them. To do that, you have to travel and investigate to find out who the target is and where they are.

For the most part, these missions are really good. However, the story begins to rush itself in the later hours of the game. Avoiding spoiler territory, Bayek and Aya are developing an idea that pretty much forms the basis of the entire franchise, but the story doesn't give this idea much showcase. Instead, you are thrown back into doing the same loop of activities you were doing before. It gets too easy at this point. This is present in side quests as well. There are many side quests that are simply too short. They end abruptly and leave you wandering what exactly the point of all of it was.

Despite these problems though, I enjoyed the story. It's memorable and has dozens of iconic moments. Bayek and Aya are great characters and although they could've had more character development, they carried the narrative for me. The way the writers were also able to tie in real historic events into the story in an immersive way is also worth some extra points.

The Gameplay

If you've played previous entries in the franchise, this game will feel very different to you. Pretty much every area of the gameplay has been improved. They completely transformed all of the previous gameplay mechanics into a much more smoother and open experience. This new style of gameplay allows the player to freely approach different scenarios in the way that they want to.

The best way to talk about the gameplay is to split it into three different sections; combat, stealth and exploration. Each of these sections blend together to create the base of ACO. To clarify, this game is not an RPG. It does contain RPG elements, but these do not constitute a role playing game.

The combat is the most in-depth part of the gameplay. It is designed to be a hitbox system allowing room for maneuverability and creativity. The game has a lock-on system that allows you to target specific enemies, though it doesn't force you to use this. You can turn it off with the press of a button.

There are a wide range of weapons you can use ranging from swords, spears, bows and battle axes. Each weapon type is distinct from the other, and overtime you will develop preferences on what to use. As well as these weapons, the player can obtain skill points. These points are mainly earned via levelling up. They can then be invested into areas that broaden the possibilities in combat.

The game has a really smooth and fluid combat system that makes every combat encounter engaging. You are encouraged to play the way you want. Whether you are sniping enemies with a bow from a distance, charging them head on, or sneaking up to them and killing them with your hidden blade, there is a play style that will fit you.

The stealth in this game isn't mandatory, however, it is foolish to ignore it. There are many moments in the game where charging in and killing everyone you see isn't an option. You can be powerful, but you can easily be overwhelmed when soldiers call for reinforcements.

To help with this, a new feature to the franchise was added to ACO. You have an eagle called Senu. With the press of a button, the player takes the perspective of Senu. Senu essentially acts as a drone. You use him to mark targets and plan your way through a tough situation. It creates a layer of strategic depth that adds to the "being an assassin" niche.

Lastly, there is exploration. The eagle plays a big role in exploration. As well as being able to mark enemies, he can also mark treasures and other points of interest. The map is filled with distinct locations that have their own objectives. Completing these locations gives the player XP, which is vital for progressing through the story and obtaining new skills.

Another benefit of exploring is obtaining resources. Using resources, you are able to upgrade various parts of your character. These upgrades are entirely option, but they do have an impact in how well you play.

Each section of the gameplay has something that connects it to the other sections. It's because of this connectivity that the gameplay works so well. It all blends together brilliantly, to the point where I don't really have any complaints.

The Visuals

One of my favourite parts of this game was exploring the ancient world of Egypt. The game world is vast, varied, and beautiful to explore. The game covers the whole of Egypt which is an impressive task to achieve. Each section of the map is distinct from the other. The designers were also able to include various historical sights such as the Great Pyramids and the Library of Alexandria!

There is a high attention to detail in every location on the map. There are times where I got lost wondering through vast canyons or exploring the various tombs. I would've enjoyed exploring even more if the optimisation was better than it is. This isn't the worst optimising I've seen but the rapid FPS drops when exploring cities or towns is annoying. My PC is more than capable to run this game, I shouldn't be having issues.

The design of other things such as characters, weapons and clothing is also really good. It all looks authentic to the time period. The animations for the characters could've been better in some scenes but for the most part they are fine. What bothers me the most is the boring cinematography. This is present in the normal interactions that Bayek has with NPCs. Having the player being able to move the camera around as two characters talk to each other whilst looking like robots isn't interesting in the slightest, and it detracts from the experience.

However, despite these issues, the game is still gorgeous to look at. The level designers and the modellers deserve massive praise for this. Their work is phenomenal. Assassin's Creed is known for having interesting and well designed maps. This one is no exception.

My Final Thoughts

I'm glad I gave this game another go. I can't explain why my thoughts changed after playing it a second time. Perhaps it's because I was more patient and took my time with things. All in all, this is a great game. It's not perfect, but it's beautiful to look at and amazing to play. Definitely a step up in the franchise.

Pros:
-Gorgeous world
-Smooth combat system
-Decent story
-Attention to detail

Cons:
-Inconsistent narrative
-Boring cinematography
-Poor optimisation

Final Rating:
8.5/10

I believe the time I spent on this game is plenty of proof explaining why I recommend this game. For years I delayed playing AC Origins, having doubts over this franchise morphing into an open-world RPG. How wrong I was. This game is worth all your money, even at full price.

Above all else, the world, the landscapes, the ancient cities and settlements are magnificent and the main selling point of this game, at least for me. This is not top-notch graphics quality mind you, but the level of detail, the level of knowledge regarding Ptolemaic Egypt is simply stunning.

In about 130-135 hours I completed most of the stuff this game has to offer. The main story line, the side quests, the DLC's with all of their content, the papyrus scrolls, the myths of the pharaohs, all the landmarks and all of the game achievements. Probably what's left are some discovery tours and those bloody chariot races. At the end of the day, I am completely satisfied with the direction Ubisoft took with this franchise. An open-world RPG of Ancient Egypt is every history geek's wet dream.

My only minor complaint is that they did not provide some more naval battles. The ones that were part of the story quest were good, but too brief. Ptolemaic Egypt was a major naval power, even during its decline period so it is a pity that I could not get more naval battles and incursions. From what I heard though, AC Odyssey provides plenty of these, so I am looking forward to that!
