I can imagine people on lesser systems being seriously frustrated and having to cap framerate to 30 just to get a decent experience.

I wholehearted recommend the game to anyone who loves AC, anyone who loves great stories, and anyone who gets a kick out of huge open worlds.
 

Sabin
1,991 products in account
1
17 people found this review helpful
1 person found this review funny 0

Recommended
64.3 hrs on record
Posted: November 12, 2017
Marking not only the 10th main installment, Assassin's Creed Origins was released just in time to stamp the 10 year anniversary of the much beloved franchise. For a decade now, players have entered the Animus in search of legendary treasure and ancient artifacts; exploring the sprawling city of Rome, sailing the seas of the Caribbean, witnessing the construction of colonial America, fighting in the French Revolution, and so much more in the shoes of classic, fan favorite assassins such as AltaÃ¯r, Ezio, and Edward. Origins has promised to deliver fans the story of how the Assassin Order began, and what better place to weave such a tale than that of ancient Egypt.

The primary story revolves around Bayek of Siwa, the last known Medjay of Egypt, during the Ptolemaic era and the final years of the empire; to put it in laymans terms, 49 B.C.E, and during the time of Cleopatra's rise to Pharaoh over her brother. Without going too in depth, as the story is exceedingly well crafted and should not be spoiled for anyone, Bayek's story is one of personal revenge, and beside him stands his wife, Aya. The vengeance quest sends Bayek to hunt down thirteen members of what is only known as The Order, while both parties help to serve Cleopatra, ensuring her rise to power while the malevolent force of Rome, ruled at the time by the tyrant Julias Ceaser, loom overhead. Though the description may sound a bit bland, trust me when I say that this synopsis is leaving out every single the juicy detail. However, the modern day story arc leaves much to be desired, and it may disappoint long-term fans to know that it does not pick up where Syndicate left off.

The land of ancient Egypt is absolutely awe-inspiring in every way imaginable. While thoughts of the land conjure images of neverending deserts and sand dunes, not even a recognizable fraction of Origin's land is made up of these fictitious imaginings. The map is extremely diverse, and it's filled with beautiful, busy cities, refreshing oases, and startling clashes of Egyptian, Greek, and Roman culture. Above all, the glorious landmarks and jaw-dropping statues are what really make the exploration in this title fun and interesting. Gamers can expect to visit the Great Sphinx, complete with nose and paint, as well as the three Pyramids of Giza which don their original smooth casings. Statues of old Pharaohs and gods stand towering over city streets and inside temples, while the cities and temples themselves are adorned with lavish carvings. Ubisoft really went all out with the intimate details in this game, and it's all incredibly commendable.

With a staggering 34 map sections to explore, over 120 main missions and side quests to complete, 58 synchronization points, and dozens upon dozens of locations with challenges to complete, one would be hard pressed to say that there's nothing to do in Assassin's Creed Origins. From exploring ancient tombs, to looting chests, killing certain enemies and animals, and even discovering secrets hidden by Minerva herself, there is easily over 60 hours of gameplay present for those who want to get their money's worth. Otherwise, the main story can be completed in about 12-15 hours, but the additional content should definitely not be missed. The side quests feel far from generic, and each of them feature dynamic characters that Bayek becomes aquainted with; some of the missions even turn into larger, more in-depth tasks. Origins is truly the first Assassin's Creed title that lacks an abundance of repetitious behavior, and all time constraints have been eliminated, which allows players to roam freely and take their time with any given mission.

Much like Unity and Syndicate, Origins does have a detailed RPG factor to it, complete with a multi-branching skill tree, weapons and shields with stats, many different mounts, and various outfits, all with three rarity qualities; legendary, rare, and common. This time around the outfits do not offer anything further than an aesthetic appeal, and neither do mounts, and there are an incredible amount of both to collect; Ubisoft even have additional ones that players can purchase with the infamous Helix credits, aka in-game currency bought with real-life cash. However, it's worth noting that the best weapons and shields in the game are not bought with microtransactions, so there's no pay wall standing in the way of Bayek being his best. Sadly, a lot of the skills are dismissable, especially the over-hyped animal taming that Ubisoft pushed at E3; in most cases, it's not even worth the effort.

Among the advancements, the entire control scheme has changed. There are no more convoluted parkour buttons, but rather one for ascending and one for descending; there's no longer even a run button, as Bayek moves at full speed at all times unless he's crouching. Being stealthy is a lot easier, even for clumsy fools like myself who can't hide in pitch dark. Ubisoft must've also taken a page from The Witcher 3, since there's now a "follow road" option for when Bayek is on his mount. It's a great option if one needs to get up and stretch, grab a drink, let the dog out, take a poo, whatever it may be, however there are times that this option can lead players straight into danger, and coming back to a random desynchronization is both irritating and disappointing. Eagle Vision also now has a new meaning, as Bayek uses his pet Senu to do all of the scouting and targeting.

With that all said, Assassin's Creed Origins runs on the AnvilNext 2.0 engine, which is also used by Tom Clancy's Ghost Recon Wildlands, Steep, and both Assassin's Creed Unity and Syndicate. Many folks have compared Origins to Wildlands in terms of how it plays, and those people are not far off. Senu, the Eagle, does control with great similarity to the drone in Wildlands, and the overall control scheme and functionality of Origins feels extremely similar. It's also sad to say that both titles have abhorrent optimization, and a plethora of technical problems. On my i7-6700k/GTX 1080 rig, I saw frame rates as low as 45 and as high as 120, with a standard rate of 65-75; mind you, all settings were maxed and I was using 1080p resolution. The biggest clincher is why Origins devours a whopping 70-80% CPU usage while running, however. Twice the game hard-locked on me, as my CPU usage skyrocketed to 95% out of nowhere, and one time it was while I was attempting to shut the game down. A smaller downside to Origins is the lack of soundtrack and the bad quality of of the sound in general. While everyone's voice acting is top tier, especially Bayek's spot-on emotions, the quality of everything from voices to footsteps sounds compressed, especially when using a high quality 7.1 surround sound headset.

Disregarding its downfalls, Assassin's Creed Origins is the best installment in the franchise to date; in fact, it borders on Game of the Year quality. The map is easily 4-5 times bigger than any other entry, and it will take dozens of hours to polish off all of the side quests and location exploring. For once, it's worth paying the huge launch price of $80 CAD, as the hours played to price ratio comes in at about $1.25 per hour for a full completion run. Even the deulxe edition content is worth the extra $10, as the weapons given are the most powerful that gamers will encounter until the very end of the journey. As for performance, if you have a mid or low end rig, and you have a console, definitely consider picking it up on another platform instead; as Ubisoft's track record of fixing optimization is abysmal. PC gamers still rate the lowest of the low on their list, and that doesn't seem to be changing any time soon.

Rating: 5.0/5.0 - An astonishing achievement, this game must be played.
The Horror Network Curator | Group Click for Gore

365 products in account

14 people found this review helpful 0

Recommended
161.3 hrs on record
Posted: April 25, 2019
AC Origins, for the first time in a long while, was a truly new Assassin's Creed experience. For the better. It features a huge immersive world with a fantastic level of detail and so many little details that it does almost feel alive. The world map is probably the largest I have ever seen in a single player game and filled to the brim with things to do. To be honest, too many things to do. Or rather more correctly, too many of the same things to do over and over and over and over and over again. 78 viewpoints to climb upon? That much I can do. Doing lots of quests that send you all over the place all the time? That I can do too, even if it's fetch quests, at least the stories are interesting most of the time.

What I really came to gripe with are the several hundred of locations where you had to "find the treasure", "kill the captain(s)", "free the slaves" or "solve the papyrus puzzle". All of these things are fine and fun, but not several hundred times over and over again. After I had "completed" about a third of the game world, I already had had more than my fair share of those mechanics, but to get to a true completion, I had to spend another 100 hours just repeating the same thing over and over again. In a sense, Origins felt as grindy as a JRPG: It had it's moments, but it was quite annoying more often than I would have liked.

That flaw of mindboggling repetition aside, Origins is hands down one of the best Ubisoft games I have ever played. For reference, I did happen to have played almost all of them within the last somewhat 20 years.

Origins is a fresh start for the series, changing up a lot of the gameplay elements and becoming more of an open world action RPG. It changed so much that the "classical" AC gameplay is mostly only present in spirit, but this is a great thing to revive the series which was starting to get more than just a wad repetitive.

With Odyssey out, which was almost a copy-paste of Origins, it'll take me at least another year or so, before I am willing to go through looking for treasure and several hundred locations yet once more again, but even although I cannot be bothered to do all of that again so soon, I am already looking forward to the time when I will eventually delve into the ancient greek world.

I really did enjoy the Egypt setting, which as a setting in itself was both visually and in regard to the story something really new not only for the series but also a setting which hasn't seen much, if any, attention from triple A gaming.

This game pretty much reignited my faith in the series, which means it'll be the only series next to Final Fantasy which didn't turn into a huge steaming pile of dung or just was scrapped due to being financially unviable.

AC Origins is definitely one of the best large scale productions within the last couple of years and definitely deserves to be played. Especially by people which started to get more and more annoyed by the series or never really could get into it in the past. The series turned a new leaf and succeeded immensely with it.

Now the only two settings that are still missing are Vikings and Ninjas. It's bound to happen and I can't wait for it.

685 products in account

9 people found this review helpful 2

Recommended
39.5 hrs on record
Posted: June 30, 2020
My playtime isn't accurate as I've put in at least several dozen hours on this game before.

Introduction
Originally, I wasn't interested in Origins at all, even though I've been a fan of the Assassin's Creed series since 2012. I was indifferent towards the new direction Origins was taking the series, and since it was a new game (I rarely get games at release) I kind of just ignored Origins for a few years. And even though I had played through the game last year, I forgot pretty much everything about it. So when I got the game again on Steam, it was a unique opportunity to experience it again and to form a proper opinion.

Let me just say this: Origins is fantastic. Both as a game, and as an Assassin's Creed game. This is a bit of a polarizing stance among fans but I don't really care. Sure, it may not have flashy parkour like Unity, it may not have ships like Black Flag, it may not have shops to renovate like Brotherhood. But Origins is such a breath of fresh air, it's hard not to like it.

Gameplay
There are some annoyances in gameplay however. Level-gating is a thing, essentially slowing your progress in the story depending on your level. There's no other way to say this; it's annoying and it's bad game design. I understand wanting the player to spend more time doing things slowly, and making sure they're prepared for whatever is coming. But even though the game tells me the "recommended level is 25", I should still at least have a fighting chance to proceed. But that's just not the case. The game will artificially limit your effectiveness based on your stats, level, gear, etc. High-level enemies will kill you in just one or two hits. And forget about assassinating in one-hit; without upgrading your hidden blade, some enemies will survive assassinations. This is bad for a number of reasons, since the hidden blade and the concept of one-hit assassinations has been a staple of the series since its inception. I really wish that the game could at least make an entire playthrough possible even if you were a low level simply by forcing you into stealth. It would at the very least give the player the freedom to go their own path rather than being manipulated into spending time away doing side quests just to advance another level to do one main story quest.

World/Environment
Its rendition of Ptolemaic Egypt is lavish and beautiful, and the tombs you can explore are mystic and atmospheric. The soundtrack is remarkable. But the thing I love the most about Origins; Bayek! I think I can safely say that he's become my favorite AC protagonist. His voice acting, his attitude, his story, and his dialogue are just awesome. Abubakar Salim did a great job of portraying him.

Characters/Synopsis
As for the main plot itself, it's certainly not the series' best, even with its strongest moments, and game-design wise there are some strange choices. There's also the obvious elephant in the room with Aya. I really wish I could've played as her more often, and her quest of justice as well as her long absences from Egypt almost makes me wonder if Aya should have been the protagonist rather than Bayek. There could have been some interesting moments, perhaps multiple locations, with not just Egypt, but the Aegean Sea (bringing back ship exploration and combat to the open world), Rome, smaller islands, etc. They could have even done something like Syndicate by having two protagonists. But I think it was for the best that there is only one protagonist in Origins, even though it honestly feels like there's two. Bayek is still fantastic, but there are certainly some missed opportunities.

As for the historical plot, it's fine I guess. But history buffs will be quick to find obvious issues, mostly centered around the depictions of Cleopatra and Julius Caesar, as well as Pompey. But those aren't relevant to my review, so I won't discuss them further.

Conclusion
Overall, I highly recommend Origins. It's an imperfect new lease on life for the series, even though it's 3 years old already. I haven't played Odyssey so I can't compare the two, but even though Origins may lack the verticality and crowded cities of games past, it still provides a compelling, fun, and beautiful world to explore with one of the series' best protagonists yet. I would even recommend this game at full price, however getting it on a sale (like I did) is obviously preferable. I've played through the DLC before but haven't included my thoughts on them in this review. If you do decide to get Origins, just make sure your CPU has adequate cooling, since this game is very demanding on the CPU.

TL;DR - Recommended

Assassin's Creed: Origins brings you a similar game to all the previous titles, with almost all of the features added into each installment, combined into a grand masterpiece following the protagonist Bayek in the Ptolemaic dynasty of Egypt. If you've played any previous Assassin's Creed games, the backstory continues to deliver many questions and answers at the same time. You are not required to play previous Assassin's Creed games in order to follow the story and understand it all.
The game was graphically gorgeous to say the least. The combat is fairly fluid, but had some animation problems every now and again, such as assassinating a guard through a wooden wall in very awkward poses. Though overall, I experienced far less glitching in this game than I did in previous titles.
An in-game feature called the "Discovery Tour" is like a history lesson that you wish you had in school. You'll be able to navigate around the game world while hearing various voice-narrated facts all about Egyptian culture. Not only does it offer you bunches of facts, but it also gives you insight about some decisions made by the dev. team.
One HUGE downside is the need to install Uplay due to it being a Ubisoft game. Normally this wouldn't be too big of a deal, however due being forced to launch the game with UPlay left me unable to play AT ALL on certain days. Random server outages and downtime left the whole of Uplay unable to accessed, leaving me unable to launch any Ubisoft titles at all.

7/10- If Uplay launcher weren't required to launch the game, I would most likely give it a 9/10. However the connection issues caused by UPlay Launcher and being unable to play any Ubisoft games because of it leaves me to simply warn you to be weary of Ubisoft titles as a whole due to the aforementioned reasons.

Recommended
20.7 hrs on record
Posted: September 20, 2018
This game continues the best traditions of Assassin's Creed. The player is in the role of a peacekeeper of sorts called the Medjay. He is aided by a trained eagle named Senu. The quest begins when the Medjay's son is murdered by a group of powerful men, each named for an animal (Jackal, Crocodile, etc). The story takes place in ancient Egypt during the time of Cleopatra and she is, in fact, a character in the game. This is a completely open world game with many side missions and places to explore including hidden tombs and pyramids. Each region withiepn the game offers a different set of challenges. Some areas are completely dessert while others are watery oases with abundant wildlife. You can travel by horse, camel and also by boat. One of the missions even includes a battle at sea. There are a myriad of weapon options that can be upgraded throughout the game. They include bow and arrows, swords, axes and shields. The story of the medjay is supposedly the story of the beginning of the League of Assassins. If you are into gameplay for the story and the adventure, as I am, then you should truly enjoy the latest offering from Assassins Creed. The mature rating is because of violence and a few scenes that are sexual in nature.

The only Assassin's Creed game I've ever finished... & I mean finished too(99% completion).

The combat feels excellent, the movement is fluid & very simple, & the story was interesting enough to hold my attention. The deeper story... That has me almost willing to go back & replay the older games to find out more about!

The CPU performance is abysmal, sadly. I have an EXTREMELY fast watercooled quad core with a high overclock & could barely hold 30FPS in some of the cities. GPU trucking along just fine until CPU maxes out.

The item, movement, & combat systems are excellent, & a step forward in my opinion from previous games, but the performance needs some work...

I'm betting this game would benefit hugely from DX12/Vulkan on systems with 4 cores, & I'd like to see Ubisoft start moving in the direction of newer & better APIs if they plan to continue putting this much stress on CPUs in the future, as I've seen improvements of up to 20FPS in games like The Division 2 when going from DX11 to DX12 mode.

You either have to kill soldiers, kill bandits, kill animals, loot treasure or do a combination of the aforementioned things, exciting
- could be on my end but the game ended up crashing quite often during loading screens

Overall I can only give this game a negative review. It could be good but it just goes on and on and on and on... I'd rather have a more compact game that maybe only lasts 30 hours or even less but is actually interesting, than this uninspired mess.

Edit 1: Took me 7 more hours to finish the Discovery Tours, guided tours covering a huge amount of different topics ranging from the pyramids to the daily life of the egyptians. I enjoyed these 7 hours. Very informative and a nice gimmick.

118 hours in I can say this is my most played AC game and probably in my top 2 AC games. The main character Bayek at first seems quite one dimmentional but by the end his growth as a character transforming into an Assassin is amazing. Voice acting for Bayek was spot on. Even the enemy characters were well developed and well put together. Taking down the baddies one by one was really satifying.
While the story is quite predictable it kept me coming back for more. It seemed rushed towards the end and that's where I started to do side missions in order to progress through the harder areas which dragged out the game a little longer for me.
Havent encountered any game breaking bugs but i have experienced frame rate drops at the sync points.
The additions of Discovery Tours and 2 DLC's are really well done are are at least 10 hours each to 100%. I haven't seen a good DLC out of an Assassins Creed game since Freedom Cry so that's refreshing. Highly recommend buying at least the Hidden Ones DLC.

As far as the new combat and new mechanics with "eagle vision" i think the studio nailed it. It is now rewarding to take down a bunch of gaurds in open combat rather than a chore of wait and counter spam. There are so many different tactics to exploit and explore. Spears, swords, dual blades, sceptors, sickle swords, 4 bow types, fire bombs, sleep darts, shields, status effects and perks applied to all of the above... amazing. New is always scary at first but the team that worked on this game really nailed all the changes that were implemented here.
Stealth is more fluid and makes sense being able to crouch.
Parkouring still is a bit janky depending on what surface you're climbing. In the cliffside areas Bayek seems to get stuck then somehow clips through the rocks and gets unstuck. I've managed to get stuck a handful of times finding the perfect spot to air assassinate from and then perma-falling on maybe an object that isnt climbable. Fast traveling will end up saving your assassin. Other than than Bayek is a freak at climbing.
At about 118 hours of gameplay I had gone thorugh the story, both DLC's, discovered all locations and completed them, colected all achievments, done the majority of the side quests, and enjoyed the environment long enough to give this game the review it deserves. Enjoyed every hour of playing this game.
Pick up this game! Egypt is an amazing sandbox that will take the series to new heights. 10/10

Origins is the first Assassin's Creed game that I have enjoyed. The changes to the combat system and open world systems are the key reason for that. It feels like a real RPG now with levels, gear upgrades, skills, and a massive world that contains a ton of quests.

The combat was the biggest plus for me compared to previous AC games. It's a lot more action-orientated instead of the previous Arkham style combat. This change makes the combat more difficult but it also feels a lot more rewarding because you feel like a badass when you pull off good dodges that follow up with killing blows that are displayed as cinematic executions.

The world is absolutely massive and there is a ton of content within it. The map is split into zones, each with a set level range. By the time I completed the main story I still had 14 zones that I hadn't even visited yet. Each zone contains side quests, fast travel points, treasures, and various camps that each have their own objectives.

At the start I was doing every side activity I could find but they get very repetitive so after 25 hours or so I just stuck to following the main quest. That's not to say the side content is bad, it's just too much of the same for my taste. Go to area, kill bad guys, loot treasure, leave. That covers most of the non-quest side activities. If you like that type of thing though, you will probably have a 75-100 hours of gameplay in this game.

Overall, I think it's a solid game and definitely worth a play if you like open world RPGs. If you were like me and didn't like previous AC games then you may want to take another look at this game because it changes everything for the better.

Recommended
102.0 hrs on record
Posted: June 29, 2018
Overview


Just at the moment I lost all hope with the Assassin's Creed series, Origins happened and I thank Ubisoft for that. For those who are too lazy to read this review, here is a summary: this game is immersive, the map is huge and it is waiting to be explored, every once in a while AC: Origins will make you stop and appreciate the scenery around you. Even if you are not into the AC series, try to give it a shot and decide after you watch a sunrise in the desert!

Graphics


Well, this is no brainer. The game has awesome graphics. However, in order to run the game in Ultra and enjoy it fully, you really need a good rig. I myself run the game on a midtier GPU and get 40-50 FPS with some settings on High, some on Medium. No stutter, no crash, no lag, just fluid gameplay. But I've read people that can't run the game with better rigs than mine, so I guess it is a win or lose situation. If you think getting less than 60 FPS makes the game unplayable, then you might want to wait for a patch in order for Ubisoft to address the issue. From what I've read, their anti-piracy protocols cost us a few precious FPS.

Story


I'm 50-something hours into the game and I'm nowhere near the end, but as far as I've seen, since Altair and Ezio this is the first time an AC game has a good story. We are first introduced to Bayek and learn that he is a Medjay, an Egyptian warrior that protects the people of Egypt and the protector of the pharaoh. Eventually, the story will eventually lead to the foundation of the Brotherhood and how can an AC fan not be intrigued by this? Sure, along the way we get to learn more about Bayek and the story line mainly follows his personal motives, but in my opinion this makes the game much more immersive. Do I need to say he has a very cool wife?

Gameplay and Combat


You have the freedom to go anywhere, climb wherever you want, ride as far as you can, dive underwater, explore, take a boat to cross seas or lakes, get scared the first time you see a crocodile, learn that hippopotamuses have no mercy or get stuck in a tree because you are too scared to face the lions and tigers underneath which are waaaay too overpowered for you... and I can go on. AC Origins has an interactive world and gives you every opportunity to gain experience, loot rare or legendary weapons. Almost every location has codex and if you take your time to read, you understand that you are roaming the Ancient Egypt. You get to discover tombs, you get to see the pyramids inside and out. This is a big plus for me.

As for the combat, all I can say is that it feels more realistic than the other AC games. It is almost impossible not getting hit unless you are too good at dodging and in the early game, it's not really easy. There are places that make me stop and think before attacking. Rather than barging into a camp and stabbing anyone that stands in my way, I make plans so that I don't die. Remember those missions in early AC games that make you stealth kill your enemies but you fail and decide to smash buttons, hit every direction until you succeed? Well, stealth really works in your favor in this game. Oh and using bows is a thing too! They actually work!

To be honest, the leveling system is quite limited. You can easily get all the abilities and eventually you lose interest in the build tree. There really isn't a real building system going on, maybe in the early games but as you push through higher levels you understand that you are not tailoring a build to match your playing style, there is not much to choose between.

Overall


I thought my PC wouldn't be able to run this game so I passed it, eventually I received it as a gift and I was ready to refund. Thank god I didn't make that mistake. If I knew, I would have bought it myself! So I'm giving this game a 10/10 for all the fun and the quality time it offers. I hope this review was helpful and kudos to anyone who made it to the end!

Posted: March 28, 2018
This is by far the most fun and amazing Assassin's Creed game I've ever played. And yes, that includes the first ones and Black Flag.

Simply put, the Egyptian world the game puts you in is AMAZING. It's not only full of fun and meaningful things to do, but the Egyptian aesthetic is something you've never seen in any other game before. Exploring the highly detailed Egyptian cities, deserts, and jungles, along with fantastic Greco-Roman cities, is a blast. There's just so much to do, and everything is deeply tied to its rich culture and story. It makes you feel like this ancient world is alive, and you are a big part of it.

Now, you can argue that this is the least "Assassins Creed-ey" game yet. And there's some merit to this in practice: you can indeed stick to assassinations and stealth to progress, but in general the game encourages you to use tools and weapons that encourage full-frontal fighting and aggression. The good news is that there is a deep weapon system with many types of fighting styles, and several skills and other tools you unlock as you level up. It all gives you a reason to explore, fight, look for resources and treasures, and upgrade yourself and your weapons, which is all fun and engrossing.

But even this, along with just about everything else, FEELS like Assassins Creed. The game encourages you to explore the world and uncover many mysteries tying to the lore. And there's of course an Animus story too. This is after all the story of the founding of the Order. And the story makes you care about the characters that are part of it, and you'll want to know what will become of them, for better or worse. Beyond that, all the familiar elements of the series are there, along with many new things to discover, and that's what makes it worthy of being considered a proper AC sequel.

I could go on and on about other things like how it brings Egyptian mythology to life, constellations, the Discovery Tour, etc. but the bottom line is that discovering the many things this game has to offer on your own is most of the fun. So I recommend this to anyone who wants to immerse themselves in a uniquely new, fun, and exciting world to live in for dozens and dozens of hours on end.

Better than I expected but not what I wanted.
Assassin's Creed reboot leading to the birth of the brotherhood in ancent Egypt.

The Good
The game itself is great with improved visuals, movement, and combat. Everything has been improved upon. The story is good getting to meet and kill iconic figures of history. This is the largest map for an AC game yet giving you a huge playground to explore. The down side is that you will run out of missions before seeing it all and there are several areas with next to nothing in them. That is not to say there isn't enough to do because there are a ton of items to hunt down and explore to easily get over a hundred hours into this game. But with the size of the map, there could be more.

The Bad
However, what the game lacks, like Syndicate, is online content for co-op. Had this game launched with the online co-op feature of Watch Dogs 2 where you could play with others or take on assassin contracts to defend or kill targets or other players, it would have easily been "game of the year" for me. As it is, its a great game but not what it could've been had they kept pushing the co-op of AC Unity. And due to the lack of content for the huge open world map, it feels a little empty once you complete the main story.

Recommendation
If you're an AC fan, this is a must play, especially if it is on sale.

When Assassinâ€™s Creed Origins releases in 2017 itâ€™s now been two years since the release of Syndicate. The intention was to take a little more time to renovate and innovate the Assassinâ€™s Creed franchise going forward. Was that a successful strategy?

Yes, it was. Ubisoft has rebuilt the franchise into a(n action) RPG instead of the action adventure game that it used to be. And with that switch come changes. Letâ€™s see if these were worth the extra development time.
Gone is the minimap. It has made room for an Elder Scrolls-like navigation bar and the land is now covered in fog on your map. Only walking through these foggy areas physically will show them on the map. Itâ€™s an excellent fit and it invites to actually explore.
Instead of Eagle Vision you now have an actual eagle. It can attack and distract enemies, or mark specific things. Itâ€™s a so-so addition. Using the bird on enemies is a good idea, but marking things just takes too long in general.
Reintroduced is swimming and diving. So you can now look for treasure on both land and in sea. Just like Black Flag, so another great - if reused - idea.
Optional tombs are introduced. You canâ€™t call yourself a RPG and not have some kind of dungeons. So no question about it: these had to be added in any case.
An experience system like Syndicateâ€™s has been added. And instead of following rather linear missions you can now accept quests all over the world. Also something thatâ€™s just a must in a RPG.
And the last thing to be overhauled is the combat system. You now have to take into account that enemies have levels. Insta-killing an enemy 5 levels above you is therefore not possible and youâ€™ll only damage him for a specific percentage. Also something youâ€™ll see in any self-respecting RPG.
So except for maybe one tiny thing itâ€™s all very positive. And it really is an incredibly big game with over 150 hours of content. I enjoyed it very much, but do admit it got a little repetitive 40 hours in. I think I couldâ€™ve squeezed 10-20 hours more into it maybe, but then I absolutely wouldâ€™ve been done with it.

While still not looking as great as Assassinâ€™s Creed Unity the graphics are very colorful, sharp and detailed. The whole world feels real and it feels alive.
I donâ€™t think Iâ€™ll ever speak ill of the voice acting or music of these games. They are always of the highest quality.
With a world as big as this come some glitches. Fortunately nothing game breaking. Performance issues were (are?) still aplenty when I played it and as far as I know these were never truly fixed.

Ubisoft has once again redeemed itself: Assassinâ€™s Creed Origins brought new life to the franchise when it was needed most. Itâ€™s a fresh take on the genre with more than plenty of content. There are a few innovations, but the time used has mostly been spent on renovations. All in all still a very good step forward for the Assassinâ€™s Creed franchise.

Recommended
80.8 hrs on record
Posted: April 16, 2021
9 out of 10

Assassins Creed Origins (ACO) is an amazing game. It just misses that little something magical that would have made it one of the best games of all time. Unfortunately Ubisoft has gradually diminished the Assassins part of Assassins Creed. Now the series has pretty much become a hack and slash RPG game. It could have been so much more.

The good:
- The game world is the best I ever played in by far. No competition; hands down. Firstly, the historical buildings are stupendous - so much so that it feels fake; but it is real, I have seen it. If that is not enough, the natural environment is mind boggling - witness the transition from the black desert into the white desert - it is not to be missed.
- Finally, Ubisoft made the very good design decision to not have a lot pointless crap for you to collect.
- Finally we get a convincing AC protagonist in Bayek. I am so tired of main characters that look like they hang out in nail bars. They are supposed to be hard assed assassins for crying out loud.
- The gameplay is very smooth.
- I am ambivalent about the swordplay. I can see why they changed from the very scripted style of previous games. But unfortunately the new free flowing style does not convince. It was neither bad nor good. If anything it was way too frequent.

The bad:
- Sadly the second protagonist, Aya, sucks. She is a stupid horrible character and person.
- Bayak and Aya's story of revenge has been done before to death.
- The forced swordplay elements weaved into the main story was annoying.
- The game world is too large and the game too long, with too many pointless locations. Yet, the game world is a weirdly compressed. I mean, you can run from Giza to Alexandria in about 5 minutes. Weird.

The ugly:
- Very generic gameplay. The game lacks memorable moments. This is the big problem with AC games and why I probably won't play another one. I really miss AC1's challenging assassination missions.
- Continued crap optimisation of the AC series. My laptop would overheat after a couple of minutes. The internet explains that this is due to Ubisoft's choice of anti piracy protection. Fortunately I could avoid problems by reducing my max processor state (under power management) to 80%. Unfortunately I had to set this every time I played because the setting would reset on entering the game.

Recommended
103.4 hrs on record
Posted: October 30, 2017
Those early reviews made me very skeptical, but I can assure you , this game is worth the price of admission. The story itself is ok, definitely better than the most recent ACs. However, the character Bayek is extremely well developed, and you will care more about him than the actual overall story. What's most incredible about the game is the open world itself, filled with details to the brim, creating one of the largest and beautiful open worlds I've ever seen. I'm spamming F12 left and right. The sidequests, although not Witcher 3 level, are clearly higher effort, and each have their own little stories and unique gameplay elements.

Most people complain about the combat, but I feel like not only is it really good, its also very challenging and different, depending on the type of weapon you're using. The parkour is extremely smooth too, utilizing everything they've learned from previous ACs and piling it all into one game. The naval combat from Black Flag returns as well. There's just so much stuff to do, and this time, it's not a repetitive grind filling the map. I feel like Ubisoft has really outdone themselves here. 9/10

254 products in account

9 people found this review helpful 0

Recommended
60.7 hrs on record
Posted: March 13, 2018
As a reboot of the AC games, Origins is mostly successful. I love the core gameplay mechanics here, especially when my stealth tactics devolve into me running headlong into waves of enemies and slaughtering them. The melee weapon types on display provide a nice change-up in gameplay, though I found myself sticking with three or four favorite weapons and simply upgrading those instead of using new types I found along the way. I've found some of the bow types to be less fun to play with, but again, there are enough to match my playstyle.

The writing is the best in the series, but it lacks a certain sort of character intimacy. The focus is squarely on the shoulders of Egypt and its troubles, and while the two main characters are fantastic, their story is often shoved to the side in favor of a slightly humdrum political plot involving Cleopatra. The villains in particular are severely lacking in flavor here, as they'll often crop up only for a mission or two at most. The meta plot is still unfortunately circling the drain on the Desmond stuff, which now makes that the... what, fourth game to still be talking about his impact on the AC universe instead of making strides forward? The meta main character barely gets any attention at all, and it feels like they either need to make that more of a priority or drop the Abstergo overarching plot.

What really draws me in though is just how lively the side characters are in this game. Sure, most of them are gone as soon as you've completed a quest or two, but they're nearly all universally well written, with loads of quirks and traits that give this take on Egypt a fantastic bit of charm. It's a bit unfortunate that Origins features a ton of recycled NPC dialogue, especially in confined areas where multiple NPCs will repeat the same dialogue at the same time. It never fails to jerk me out of the experience and remind me that no matter how great this game is, there's still lots of work that needs to be done.

Overall, though, I think this is the finest AC to date. Bayek and Aya are strong characters who deserve more of the focus here, but when they're in their element, this game is absolutely superb.

Posted: February 6, 2018
I think I'm getting bored of this game which is dissapointing. I honestly believe this was a well needed breath of life into a franchise that's been going stale. Yet it's got a couple of issues that honestly ruin it, in my opinion.

The first of these issues is how corny the sidequest writing is, everything feels like a perfect world where there is a perfect Bayek shaped hole in a problem, where he can show up to stab someone or steal something and then everything will fall into place and the people he tried to help will be unquestionably better off for it. It's just so corny and perfect and a fake feeling world.

The second issue, which reinforces the first, is the levelling system. People and creatures a couple of levels above you are near impossible to defeat. At first I thought this would be a benefit to the game as you aren't going to be the baddest baddass all the time. But I'm afraid I was wrong. I found a vulture who I could spend all my arrows on to reduce it's health to 2/3s. If I stood still for long enough for it's simple attacks to hit me, it would takei 90% of my health. It didn't feel very believable. Now the biggest problem with this system is that all the quests have a "recommended level" (it's the level that the enemies in that quest will be set to). So far this is all pretty normal, BUT I'm afraid that the main story quests are spaced too far apart (in level) and require significant grinding to level up to meet the recommended level for each consecutive story quest.

Every time I want to proceed with the main story I have to stop and go looking for side quests for a few hours. It's immersion breaking, it kills the pace, it drags things out artifically and the side quests just aren't strong enough to keep my attention or motivate me to sit through them for the main story. I feel like I'm being punished for wanting to play the main story, or like I'm being tested.

Not Recommended
68.2 hrs on record
Posted: October 5, 2018
A fresh take on series that paid off. (Contains Spoilers, Go to bottom for ratings)

I should start with positives:
1) Art Direction is beautiful. Finest in series.

2) Lighting! Most beautiful utilization of volumetric lighting that works like wonder with atmospheric fog and bleeds inside room or creates a shaft effect through branches of trees.

3) Character details and Animation. It's top notch. Facial animations especially were great!

4) Combat. I love the revamped combat system. It doesn't have parry like in Assassin's Creed Unity which I still prefer more, but it is more challenging and fun in Origins. (BUT SOMETIMES ANNOYING)

5) Loot System. Weapon variety and variable damage.

6) Bayek the protagonist.

7) Cleopatra's sass.

That's it.

OKAY BOI NOW THE CONS:

Everything else. Like literally. The story starts really slow and it feels very disjointed in starting hours.

Their use of characters is not so great. We meet Pompey once to gather forces for war. Next time we see him, his head is in a box which is shown off to Ptolemy by Caesar.

Aya was supposed to be a wise and strong woman. But she's blinded by her ambitions and ignores Bayek's suspicions about Cleopatra's help.

The members of the order don't seem to have any motive behind their deeds. It's just some clichÃ© reason.

The only likeable villain was Septimius.

Pothinus was literally just a wind.

Flavius, the main villain is laughable. His reveal as the leader of the order was supposed to be an exciting turning point but it was stale and disappointing. No character development of him other than 2-3 scenes showing him behaving as a good lieutenant of Caesar.

NOW THE BIGGEST PROBLEM:

The RPG system. In previous assassin's creed games, we were free to go with the continuation of story whenever and however we want.

Here, you gotta be Level 35 to complete the ending mission. Why's that bad? It breaks the experience really badly.

Before the ending mission, when the excitement of the finale was extremely high, they show the level requirement of 35. I was 33.

I had to go do some side missions of stealing herbs from Roman barracks, free prisoners held in random camps and kill some captain who never did anything wrong to me. Probably spent 2 days doing 5-10 missions coz I was playing on Hard difficulty and had to explore a lot.

ALSO WHY DOES A STRONGHOLD OR FORT HAS ALL GUARDS RESPAWNED?? I LITERALLY KILLED THEIR CAPTAINS AND â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥.

The excitement of finale died with tedious side missions just so I can level up and play the final mission otherwise the guards will keep pawning me and I'll keep desynchronizing.

The main story doesn't make use of the whole map of Egypt. But side missions do. Which was pretty much fun but I kept discontinuing because it got boring and repetitive after a while.

The game itself is about origins of the Assassin brotherhood. It pretty much does portray it in an impactful manner. Thanks to Sara Schachner's rendition of Ezio's family theme, the cinematics in final hour felt epic.

So, how it is compared to Ezio Trilogy? Pretty stale. Bayek was a good protagonist, but compared to Ezio who transitioned into being a mature and wise assassin, Bayek stays the way he was at the beginning of the game. Haytham, Connor, Arno, Frye Twins all had some good character development. The writers just didn't do any justice to Bayek's character.

The game is a solid RPG but it can be seen that it's heavily influenced by The Witcher 3.
The series has transitioned from a sci-fi fantasy hybrid action adventure game to a fantasy RPG.

With a lot more addition of ancient Gods and demons and missions designed around it, the charm of Assassin's Creed has completely vanished. I have a sword that has a permanent fire to it, lol. How's that possible? Let's just play it out as Animus feature.

Modern day story is still trash. No connection to Layla. The previous two modern day protagonists are not even mentioned.


So here's my final score.

Graphics: 8
Other than lighting that makes the environment look amazing and facial details nothing stands out. Textures aren't so sharp all the time. But I love the Screen Space Reflections on water surfaces.

Presentation: 7
The world is vast, the art direction is top notch. But missions designed around it aren't that great. Although, love the details like raining insects and storms. Tombs and Audio logs in few locations addressing post Desmond world is interesting.

Audio: 7
Love the soundtrack. But nothing that will stay in my memory for long. Voice acting is great.

Gameplay: 7
Combat is amazing, but oh god I hate it when dodge doesn't work. Hunting and crafting was a cool thing. Character skill tree was very enhanced and feels a lot like Far Cry 4's skill tree, which is a great thing and a significant addition.

Story: 5
Not a big fan of the story in this game. I loved Bayek, but none of the characters is strongly written.

Overall: 6.8/10

It's a good RPG game but doesn't offer anything different than just being another RPG game. Previous entries felt different and had their own identity. Now, it's just like any other RPG set in AC universe. My opinion is with respect to previous AC games.

I don't hate this game. I'm playing it even after completing the main story and that's because it's a solid RPG game to pass the time. It's just not a good Assassin's Creed game in terms of story and if you were ever interested in modern day arc and whereabouts of Juno (the main antagonist of modern day) then you'll be very dissapointed as I am.

Some people might miss the social stealth elements like eavesdropping, stealing and blending in crowd for information about targets but I ignored it since the game doesn't address the existence of assassins till the end of the main story.

Tbh, you may agree or disagree with my concerns about this game, but it would be great if we just discuss it instead of calling out on each other. I wrote this review after completing main story. It took me roughly 50 hours to complete it because I was raiding tombs and caves for loot. I didn't rush it until later stages of main story because I got bored of grinding.

So yeah it's a 50/50 game for me. I had fun but I have lot more questions by the end of the story and salty coz Ubisoft omitted the entire modern day arc assuming that everyone reads the comics.

Anyways, glad if you find this helpful. Happy gaming lads!

Recommended
66.3 hrs on record
Posted: November 23, 2017
Actually not that bad as everyone expected it to be. Granted, i went in with minimal expectations, but was pleasently suprised by this game. Its starts up painfully slow, with nothing Assasiny in sight, and wants to make you familiar with the Egyptian world. This world is very well crafted and looks magnificant. The tombs, the pyramids and just the sheer landmass is a beauty to traverse. Sadly, as with most Ubisoft games, thay fail to make that world feel like its actually livable.

In early production they said they wanted to make a 'Witcher 3' kind of a open world game, but they fail to make it believeble. People just stand and walk around. Don't really act like real human beings and all scream to each other. Every time you encouter a guard somewhere he seems to be angry at you and screams some insults. This is totally gamebreaking because the gaurd in question has no knowledge about you whatsoever. Small irritations like this is Ubisofts hallmark. They create vast world but lack the finesse to really expend on them and make them feel believeble.

When you get past this point the game opens up. The story picks up and really sucks you into it. Bayek, the main character, feels like a real person with strenghts and weaknesses. The main quests feel like they have gravity and are a bunch of fun to play through. If you have a love for old history make that double. Its great to feel involved with real world history and have a hand in shaping it. Very well executed.

Side quests are a mixed bag. Again i will be refering to the Witcher 3. All the people that give you quests feel real and believeble and have awesome dialouge. Not here sadly. A fixed camera angle and a not so interesting sob story dont get me in the mood at all. Turn off.

The open world map is way to crowded with points of interest and side quests. I dont really feel like its soemthing for me but i do understand the appeal. A LOT of hours can be spent and thats a real good investment for your time.

Combat has been revamped and is now somewhat more then jsut pressing 'attack and counter' like the previous AC titles. Its worth to invest some time in it and get good at it, certainly at higher difficulties the combat is sporadicly unforgiving. Something that i enjoyed.

All in all a solid 7/10. Enjoyed it enough to give it a thumps up. If Ubisoft takes the negative points and imrpoves on them the next game could be really good. Lets hope so!

Played few hours so far, absolutely amazed how attractive this game is!

Here is what I see so far:
- Pretty graphics, large word, many details. Playing mostly on high settings and getting constant 80-90 fps with no performance issues whatsoever. There are plenty of options to be configured to match your rig. It calculates required memory vs your VGA memory and shows FPS graph to get an idea.
- The main character, Bayek, despite previous two AC games is very interesting, really eager to see what will happen next.
- Fights are not easy, especially against high level opponents. Need to use different mechanics, use different tactics, etc.
- Side quests so far are not repititive at all and are actually interesting.
- There are different exotic animals roaming the word, dogs barking, cats following you, etc. Creates friendly atmosphere.
- There are micro-transactions, didn't use myself, but checking items from shop and items achieved from some side quests have an impression that quests provide better equipment.
- This game reminds me of Black Flag (very similar areas and models sometimes) and of first AC (the way city feels, the way people talk, the way croud feels alive).

Enjoying the game so far absolutely, time flies faster than i blink. Will add more details after finishing the game.

Recommended
139.6 hrs on record
Posted: March 20, 2019
Assassin's Creed Origins follows a familiar paradigm that will keep you involved and hold your interest level for enough time to at least justify a purchase. The game is set in Ancient Egypt and you're fighting for the rights of those that have been captured and held under the will of ruthless powerful forces. You have a great set of weapons, and there are lots of cool side missions. Moreover, the game has a beautiful landscape and a very large map. The graphics are excellent although even with a powerful computer you can find that the game stutters occasionally. That all being said, after completing about 80 missions, this game got too redundant for me to complete in its entirety. Some of the villains can only be taken down through a series of repetitive and tedious attacks; this greatly retracts from the pace of the game. Other quests require you to find objects located on the map, which at first may not seem like a chore, but on your fifth or tenth such mission--it becomes a pain. All in all, it is worth a buy, but it is not worth $60.

Recommended
129.4 hrs on record
Posted: December 23, 2018
Been an Assassin's Creed fan ever since it started. Sure, it doesn't feel like a true 'Assassin's Creed' game. But it is a damn good game.

Pros:
- Graphics: Everything is beautiful. Look at the flames! The desert. The interiors etc.
- Content: Witcher 3 levels of content.
- Animation: The animations in this game are pretty decent, kinda what i would expect from AC.
- Attention to detail: So many nitty gritty details in the game, like villagers sewing, eating, selling goods and gathering herbs etc.
- Tits: There are topless women npcs in this game. Lots of them.
- Photo Mode: This combined with the above two pros make photo mode godsend.
- Ancient Egypt: The locations in this game are amazing, reaching Alexandria and climbing the Lighthouse of Alexandria is amazing. There are many many more locations such as the Pyramids of Giza, Memphis and Thebes(DLC) etc.

Cons:
- Performance: Not bad, but could have been alot better.
- Story: its Ok at best: though some will disagree with me.
- More of An RPG than a Stealth game: Don't expect this game to play like previous game, is feels more like an action RPG than a traditional stealth game.

The game is slight grindy to some, though i have not faced this issue as i constantly get distracted and do the side quest. There are microtransactions but they can be largely ignored as they are not a game changer.

Verdict: 9/10

Firstly it's really starting to annoy me with people saying it has performance issues, i have been playing the game for over 50 hours now and have had over 80 FPS with ultra settings everything max and it never dips or lags even in big areas like alexandria. Now to the game.

Not Recommended
36.8 hrs on record
Posted: September 30, 2019
As a longtime fan of the series I REALLY wanted to love this game, but I just can't. The three reasons being:

- Absolutely game breaking performance issues on a relatively high end PC (as of playing in 2018).
- A very significant amount of boring content and extremely dull/repetitive side quests (which are necessary in order to reach main quest level requirements).
- Fundamental changes to the combat and formerly fluid assassination/stealth mechanics that made the AC series a unique hack-and-slash staple for over a decade.

While I admire the series for doing something different after a few forgettable releases, this game is just flat out not fun. My biggest issue is that it simply feels like an obviously cheap imitation of games like The Witcher 3 and Dragon Age. It's an incredibly detailed and visually stunning world that feels unfortunately lifeless and empty, completely devoid of any compelling characters or quests whatsoever (and this is after 35 hours of playing). The side quests are among the worst that I've ever seen, completely pointless and repeatedly following the same formula of some useless â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ either getting you to go fetch something or to go help/kill one of his equally useless and forgettable associates. The fact that you're basically forced to explore and endure these "quests" in order to reach a high enough level for the main missions is borderline infuriating. If you can get past these issues there'e also the combat. Replacing Eagle Vision with Senu-the-ancient-drone completely destroys the pacing while you have to scout an area for 15 minutes straight just to ensure that you didn't miss a random guard (it's also incredibly ironic that the series that basically created Eagle Vision no longer has it despite both The Witcher 3 and Red Dead Redemption 2, possibly two of the greatest games of our era, both implementing almost identical systems that were clearly based on it. Does Ubisoft legitimately not know what it had?). The combat, while a good system overall, is much more methodical now. While many might prefer this, it also makes fights very drawn out and slows the pacing down even further. I'm also really disappointed that this game undid the incredible technological pioneering that we saw in Unity in regards to the massive crowds and incredibly realistic movement animations/physics as well as the really neat 4-gear slot customization that it had (I'm not going to argue that Unity is a better game because it just flat out isn't. But I always see just about everyone unfairly ignore the few amazing things that it added and did actually do really well).

Don't get me wrong, the main questline and modern questline are fantastic (one of the best in AC). The main story started out pretty strong and it would be great if I could actually get to play it despite feeling absolutely nothing for any of the supporting characters that I've met so far. Again, the problem is literally everything besides the main story. The changed combat/leveling system, rather dull exploration, and completely â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ side quests all serve only to bog down the overall experience and turn it into a complete slog. It makes me feel as if Ubisoft doesn't really understand that the best and most fundamental part of RPG games in the first place is good side quests and exploration/world building. Combining Assassin's Creed's combat/parkour with it's incredible historical settings should have been lightning in a bottle with their new RPG formula. Hell, the games were already just a few side-quests and dialog choices away from being RPGs to begin with anyway.

Overall, it's neither a great nor terrible game. Would still recommend it if you can pick it up between $15-$25 but it's still far from my first choice. Still objectively a pretty solid 7/10 (how typical of Ubisoft, though they seem to be improving). It's really lost the soul and feel of Assassin's Creed games and has made me a bit apprehensive about future titles.
 
A developer has responded to this review

Posted: October 14, 2020
If you are looking for a continuation of the story of the previous AC games, you wonâ€™t find it here. Then you are looking for the Assassinâ€™s Creed: Uprising comic book series. Yeah, that's how they chose to finish up the story.
If on the other hand you are looking for a big budget open world game set in Ptolemaic Egypt, this might just be the game for you.

This new entry in the series really has more in common with The Witcher 3 than previous AC titles. At least some parkour elements are still here. Everybody wonâ€™t like this change. The new levelgating can be particularly annoying since it more or less forces you to â€œgrindâ€ some side quests in between every main story mission. Sadly, the story on offer here is quite underwhelming. Especially towards the end where all the big historical events take place, everything feels extremely rushed. Ubisoft still seems afraid of having any longer cutscenes interrupt your gameplay and the story really suffers because of this. Considering the almost ridiculous amount of side quests in the game, perhaps some more time should have been spent on the main story instead.

Their recreation of ancient Egypt on the other hand leaves very little to criticize. If you have even a passing interest in ancient Egypt, you owe it to yourself to experience this game. If you feel like doing this without slaughtering half of Egypt the game's new Discovery Tour feature is a great way of doing this. You might even learn something in the process. This really is an amazing feature that should have been a part of the series from the beginning.

All things considered, while I'm not the biggest fan of this new direction the series is taking, no one recreates historical open worlds quite like Ubisoft. Hopefully with the recent shake ups and firings over there we might get a proper story set in one in the future.

AC:O REVIEW

Unul dintre cele mai tari jocuri assassins creed , depasind chiar si Ezio Trilogy
Acum personajul principal este Bayek Of Siwa, ultimul medjay ramas.

PRO
+Gameplay
+Combat ( Mult mai complex si mai dinamic )
+Poveste ( SUPER SUPER nu dau spoilere )
+side quest ( fiecare side-quest are o mini poveste ceea ce nu te va lasa cu ochii in soare)
+HARTA ESTE PLINA DE MISTERE ( Cand te apropii de cele 3 piramide vezi o gramada de miraje)
+FOARTE MULTE Side-questuri si eventuri ( ceea ce te tine in joc muult timp )
+Luptele navale ( nu sunt ele asa multe , dar sunt satisfacatoare )
+Bayek ( Baiatu bun la toate )
+Aya ( Fata buna la toate , mai ales la luptele navale )
+Sountrack-ul ( Return of the medjay sau fight theme , doar ascultati-le si vedeti singuri c.u m este sunetul din joc)
+Senu are un rol important in joc
+Locatiile din joc sunt modelate impecabil !
+NPC-urile ( Pur si simplu lumea din joc este mult mai dinamica )
+Ciclu Noapte- Zi ( Iti poti seta c u m vrei sa fie in joc, ziua lumea e mai dinamica si daca ai o misiune de asasinat nu stiu ce general dintr-un campus, o sa-ti dea de furca pentru ca toti garnienii sunt la posturi si iti va fi mai greu de intrat campus, in schimb daca faci aceasi misiune doar ca de data asta pe noapte , o sa-ti fie mult mai usor pentru ca garnienii si generalii vor dormii si iti va fi mai usor de intrat in campus )
+Photo-Mode ( Daca vreti sa faceti o poza de neuitat si s-o publicati pe Steam , pur si simplu folositi acea unealta si puteti sa faci poze de neuitat )
+Modern-Day ( Este ea foarte saracacioasa, dar sper ca in viitorul joc sa fie mult mai multa actiune si poveste , pentru unii oameni aceasta unealta o sa ii lase cu un gust amar)
+Sistemul De Skill-uri
+Sistemul de iteme ( Pana la urma e un RPG nu? Asa ca te vei bucura cand vei gasii un arc Rar in mijlocul desertului )
+Inlaturarea mini-mapului
+Crafting


-Optimizarea ( bine au mai rezolvat-o ei din ultimul update)
-Buguri ( C u m ar fi ca o femeie sa se plimbe cu o caruta cu boi si dintr-o data sa se invarta ca o balerina)
-Grafica( Uneori grafica este dea dreptul...naspaaa) dar are momente cand grafica este WOW

CONCLUZIE
IN SFARSIT SERIA AC A LUAT-O PE UN DRUM BUN si bine au facut ca au amanat jocul un an ! Ma bucur ca nu am mai vazut un UNITY pe ecranul meu cu o poveste de dute vino de te lasa cu ochii in soare !!

Din cauza optimizarii proaste pe pc si din cauza norilor care zici ca-s din plastilina ( In Brotherhood norii sunt muult mai reali ca aici ) am sa scad din nota finala

PENTRU ASSASSIN'S CREED ORIGINS DAU NOTA 9.5 !

16

Recommended
146.8 hrs on record
Posted: October 27, 2017
Assassin's CreedÂ® Origins Final review . Took over 120h and still didn't finish alot of activities/side quests. I'm a huge AC fanboy but i will give my honest review. I'm gunna start by saying

Assassin's Creed: Origins is a great game with quite good amount of RPG elements in it's gameplay, completely new combat that's way better than last ones, really good main story with a lot story rich side-quests, stunning and one of the best open world out there.

Story
Origins unveils the story of Bayek, a medjay. Medjay's are the protector of the people of Egypt and true to the Pharaoh. Starts with the fall of Egypt and Bayek's people. To avenge his son and the people bayek starts his journey. With friends and family he continues uncovering the truth. As we follow through his jounrney, we come to know how the brotherhood was created. The story starts slow but catches up pretty quickly. It's best best story in recent AC games. Better than Black Flag IMO. The ending was absolutely amazing! I still feel like we needed more. Even tho the story was really big, we are left with wanting more. But that doesn't make it bad in any way. It's a great story overall.

Gameplay
They completely renewed the gameplay. The parkour is same but the fighting, exploring and every other aspect of the gameplay is changed. With RPG elements AC added their own touch, which was needed so that it can make the people happy that loved the old gameplay. The Combat is inspired heavily from Dark Souls. The gameplay is quite smooth and they fixed the bit of animation problems it had at the E3.

Skill Tree is something AC Syndicate had but it wasn't that great. Origins actually makes you wanna upgrade to the maximum skill. The skills are extremely useful and at some point they are must. Different skills gives access to different gameplay style which is really good. I love this skill tree and pretty sure everyone will like it.

Crafting They didn't make it completely RPG so the crafting isn't that hard but the resource needed for crafting is hard to get. For that you can open chests around the world, go after cart raiding or just hunt which is really fun. Overall this is not something huge but it's there.

Customization is good. You can change your outfit and every weapon. It doesn't have that RPG customization but the necessary things are there. You can change to alot of outfits and huge amount of different gears.

Quests
No more missions. Take quests and do them whenever you want. Seriously tho, they did a great job with the quests. Didn't feel like they were repetitive for a second. Side Quests are just too good. Excellent side quests everywhere. Really good story and interection. There's alot of side quests but some are easily better than some main quests. 120h and i still couldn't finish alot of side quests.

Characters
Bayek is one of my favorite protagonist in AC series. The characters in Origins are really well made. Interensting characters with good stories. Each main quest/side quest characters are interesting. Main Characters like Bayek and Aya are perfect. But ACO fails at delivering great Enemies. Some were interesting and you will remember them. But most of them.. i already forgot lol. Don't expect anything like Cesare or Haytham here. When i say you will forget those enemies, i mean their characters.

World Design
Oh my.. i'm in love!! The game world is huge! The entire Egypt and the way they portrayed Ancient Egypt is just magnificent. The citites, deserts, rivers, jungles and lietrally everything about the world is just too damn good. The world looks so alive with great NPC. NPC doing their own thing like harvesting crops and other vegetables, selling things, talking about things with each other, fishing and then going back to home at night. The world just moves on no matter what you do. It has life of it's own. Every part of the world is more than worth exploring thanks to lot of hidden caves and other things that you can find like that. Even underwater is so worth exploring. The animals doing their things, sleeping, resting or hunting. I can't describe how amazing the world is with words..

Graphics
Just beautiful. Before this my favorite graphical game was GR Wildlands but this beats that in every way you can imagine. From the biggest statues to smallest scorpion looks amazing. Ancient Egypt never looked any better. No other game world looks this good IMO. The facial graphics of Bayek to every NPC looks stunning. The beautiful cities, stunning jungles, beautiful water graphics above and underwater and the deserts. The visual in this game is so good that you will keep exploring and taking screenshots instead of playing. Just check some gameplays. Oh and in 4K this game looks "real life" but better.

SoundQuality/OST/VoiceActing
SoundQuality is really good.The weapon sounds, animal sounds to sandstorms and every other part of sound is really good.

OST Beautiful collection of OST. Sarah Schachner did a fantastic job with these ost. Just search some up and listen. And they also modified quite good amount of AC2 OST and put them here, including Ezio's Family.

VoiceActing is also really good. Bayek and other characters voice acting is on point. The NPC and each character has that accent.

Optimization
is really good with this one. Really strong PC port. I get over 90 fps AVG with GTX 1080Ti and I7 6700K Max settings 1080p. Fps dropped to 75-80 in some NPC crowded cities. I tested with GTX 970 and I7 6700K Max settings 1080p and the FPS was average 45. It did drop to 32 in NPC crowded citites. I also tested 4K with GTX 1080Ti and I7 6700k and at max settings i get average 53 FPS. Now i didn't face any bugs in this 120h. No bugs or glitches. After the recent updates i'm getting stable 60 most of the time at 4k with 1080ti. No more drops in cities.

Controls
Controller controls are really good. Just too good. Without any sprint button, you control speed with your analog sticks. Overall controls are fantastic.

KeyboardMouse controls are really good as well. But the controls could be awkward for old AC players. Also without having analog stick on PC, you can't control the speed like you can with controller. Which wasn't that good for me.
I Recommend Controller for ACO, Xbone/PS.

Overall - 9.6

I'm absolutely in love with ACO. Alot of the time the game feels more like completely differnet game rather than another AC. And that is a good thing. The game world and graphics are just stunning. The optimization is really good as well. The gameplay feels great as well. The combat is new and it feels great while stealth is harder but good. The story is really good with a fantastic ending. Overall i think everyones gunna like ACO. Either you're AC fan or new to the series. Overall this is easily the best AC game. The story isn't better than any of the Ezio game. Ezio trilogy is still my favorite but combine everything of ACO, it's nearly a masterpiece.

Having spent enough time into this game I found it boring and repetitive. After reaching level 35 on my first play through, I quit and started fresh, assuming I did not play it right. That I missed a lot of side quests and exploration. I was wrong. This is a very shallow game.

The main quest is short, rushed and incoherent. Also, I do not like being forced to change characters when I have chosen and built one to my liking.

Side quests are horrendous... all similar, assassinate target, fetch item, free prisoner. Zero variety. Bayek is your local delivery boy. All tombs feel the same and so do all garrisons and forts. All that puzzle solving and footwork for meagre XP and useless loot. And of course you can spend a lot at the store if you are gullible enough.

I have not seen in my memory such a shallow game that touts such a large world. And when you do find yourself immersed in exploration, layla hassan wakes up and ruins your momentum, or you have to play as aya. What nonsense.

On a positive note, the world is beautiful. It's a shame they made such a bland game out of it. While important dialogue is in english, villagers and unimportant npcs speak a regional dialect which I do not understand... why? I wish I could eavesdrop on conversations and understand what the ordinary civilians are talking about. Small things like these is what made Dishonored a masterpiece. Also Cleopatra speaks in a British accent. Awesome.

Of the 100 plus hours I spent into this game, about 65% were spent travelling, 15% figuring out puzzles, 10% in cut scenes and another 10% in combat.

Combat system is not that bad as some mention. Overpower attack is terrible though. Bayek acts like a mentally unsound individual while using it. there is no way to direct it where you want to. One time he killed an unmounted horse while ignoring the real enemies around him (poor horse)... On other occasions he takes down the weakest enemy while I wanted to use it against the strongest.. or will simply attack a tree or a wall or an invisible target. It is a shame because that one attack is very important against high level enemies, and it takes a while to build up..

Overall a very ordinary game, Not recommended. I would rate this a 6 out of 10. Play it if you have nothing better to do. I do not understand how this game gets so highly rated here. It has a 6.7 USER rating on metacritic, which seems just about right. I don't trust CRITIC rating (8.4)

I've finished the original AC, AC2, AC2 Brotherhood and Revelations, I could not stand any AC game that came after those.

AC Origins broke that trend. The new fight system is very reminiscent of the Witcher and Dark Souls style, you have to think on your feet to dodge, block and parry, quite enjoyable.

The best part of the game I would say is the ancient tombs exploration and the whole feel of Ptolemaic Egypt, the Nile, crocodiles and hippos, all bring that wild feel to the game.

As usual Ubisoft did an excellent job on graphics, design and aesthetics of the game. I heard of some performance issues but didn't experience anything unusual from a ubisoft game.

In conclusion, if you miss the old AC, this game is for you.

But by all means, please continue.

It seems I was wrong about the CPU usage but since us 'gamer' types take a critical opinion of their favourite games as a personal attack, I'm elaborating upon this a bit.

I â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ up, I thought the bad performance was solely due to the high CPU usage. Patch 1.03 showed that it was not, so clearly I was wrong. Take this and stroke your â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ with it.

That being said, about the game itself, I'm quite enjoying it now that FPS doesn't randomly drop all over the place. The rural areas of the game are running quite well on Ultra, whereas the cities still bring the framerate down, but only to 40-45 - a massive improvement over what it was pre-patch.

The gameplay is, for the first time in a very long time with this franchise, actually fun. Once you get the hang of it and find your favourite weapon (I highly recommend Battleaxes), combat is fun, risky and if you're playing on hard, challenging. Taking on multiple enemies at once can and sometimes will end badly for you, which encourages the use of stealth over an all out full frontal attack.

The graphics are amazing. I've been taking some really fantastic screenshots after I started playing it again post-patch. The lighting, especially in closed areas, is simply amazing, and with the use of photo mode, you can click some amazing pictures all over the place.

It's too early for me to talk about the story, because I've been doing my best to do everything else apart from the main quest. Bayek's personality is well explored in the many side quests he picks, and while it might not be as detailed or as consequential as the ones in The Witcher 3 (which people seem to be comparing it to), they are fun to do and not simplistic, dull collect-a-thons.

As of this moment, if you have a competent CPU cooler that does not push CPU temps over 80-90 degrees Celcius, I highly recommend you pick up this game, Assassin's Creed has return to the fold and it has returned triumphant.

One of the best from AC series! It's like watching a movie, I found it so interesting. The graphics are spectacular, specially the cut-scenes. The scenery of Egypt looks amazing. Unlike on other games I didn't feel like skipping dialogues. The story is great and captivating. Bayek is my favourite Protagonist of all the others from the series, he is a very relatable character. He displays both immense kindness and towering anger, deep sadness and boyish humour. He is incredibly gentle with children, loving to his hawk companion Senu. I found the game to be huge, with loads of side quests. Couldn't recommend it enough. 10/10
