Not Recommended
265.9 hrs on record
Posted: November 9, 2017
I personally like the game but that's not the point. The point is that it's a damn fine game (with understandable flaws). published by Ubisoft That's right, â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥. I don't believe it myself. So why am I writing this review with a "No" recommendation you might ask. Simple, so that those who have not even played the game and have blindly hated on it prior to its release can see this review using the "Negative Reviews" filter. If you wish to truly read an unbiased review, take the time to read this.

_______________________________________________________________________________
OFFICIAL REVIEW

I am 96 hours into the game, finished the entirety of it including the main storyline, sidequests, and all locations on hard mode. I've never actually been an AC fan (In fact I hated them for the most part), though I've played the previous games apart from rogue, unity, and syndicate and all I can honestly say is that the AC Formula prior to Origins is plain straight-out repetitive. Assassin's Creed and the concept known as "CONSISTENTLY FUN", never seemed to have coupled with one another. Until now however, with Origins. To site a few repetitive activites in the original formula:

FLAWS OF THE PREVIOUS AC GAMES
- Trailing missions (Follow this guy for 20-30 mins and if he sees you no matter how close you are to finishing the trailing mission, you get desync'ed)
-Side activities particularly assassination contracts with no substance (There is no compelling backstory to motivate the player. Sometimes, there's no story at all. LMAO)
- Long ass modern day sequences that break the immersion of being an assassin from a specific time period
- Beautiful recreation of historical landscapes though lacking the flavor it needs to captivate the player and by captivate I mean to truly be enticing and not just a mere one-time glance.
- Laughably unchallenging Combat System that only kept me interested for the first 10 mins of experiencing it. After that I realized two buttons only mattered in combat; Counter and Attack (= Counterattack).
- All in all, too linear which always kept the player on a short leash.

With those factors listed, I want to explain briefly how the revamped AC formula of Origins have addressed the past insipid experienceI had with the AC Series:

ADDRESSED FLAWS (OR PRO'S)
- (Bummer for AC fans, I know, but hear me out) No more social stealth BUT THAT MEANS NO MORE BORING-ASS TRAILING MISSIONS THAT ARE BASICALLY UGL's or (Unnecessary game lengtheners). No more blending in with the crowd because you're not trailing anyone anymore. Though it was useful in terms of escaping pursuing guards, I'll admit. But I'll accept that compromise any day so as to completely remove the â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥-faced trailing missions.

- Sidequests (that'rs right they're no longer called missions) now are actually story-driven which makes the experience a whole lot better. Gone are the days when I have to senselessly assassinate someone without even knowing why I had to do it.

- The modern day sequences (Yes there is a modern day story in Origins, not sure if that's spoiler-worthy tho) is actually quite decent tho not as decent as Desmond's I'll say but the point here is that it does not over stay its welcome unlike previous modern day stories, so yeah, immersion-breaking problems are addressed here.

- Not only is recreated ancient Egypt of AC Origins a landmark to behold, it's also alive and breathing. The AI system (tho clunky at times) have specific schedules each tailored to the grand fabric of a truly immersive Open World. Heck, even the animals hunt and eat corpses of guards that are thrown by fellow guards on duty in the river. It's so detailed you can even see the mummification process in Memphis. And of course, it's not just a one-time glance anymore, with the addition of Photo mode, this game has entered my personal list of top 5 Open Worlds.

- Now I know a lot of hatred for this game is due to the new combat system, but it feels and plays better than it looks. If anything, it's way better by a hundredfold than the previous combat system wherein a baby could basically master it in a few seconds. It takes time getting used to it but once you get the hang of it, it's altogether very rewarding.

- This game have finally given the player so much freedom that I'm happily an AC fan now who looks forward to future titles. Black flag did a great job at the Open Seas exploration tho it still lacked the necessary aspects in terms of the freedom from a true sandbox experience derived from an Open World game. I'm just glad AC is no longer linear, the series always had huge potential had it been an open world from the very beginning. Historical landscapes easily explorable anytime without the hindrance of loading screens is what makes this game a truly fine experience.

________________________________________________________________________________
(IF YOU ARE STILL READING THUS FAR, I APPRECIATE IT. BEAR WITH ME AS THIS WOULD ONLY TAKE A FEW POINTS LEFT)

For the last part of my review, let me quickly give you a rundown of the Cons that has really got riled me up to take a piss on this game:

CONS
- U-â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥-PLAY
- Microtransactions (But they are only ever there if you need them. You can get all of them by playing the game tho RNG-dependent that is)
- Annoying FPS drops when exploring cities attributable to the HIGH CPU USAGE (My gtx 1060 3gb drops from 70-80 fps to 40 fps or half of it @ 1080p High Settings)
- Horrendous facial animation during non-cutscene conversations.
- The story plot is not the best although it's interesting enough for players to engage in it. The way I see it, it could have been handled better in terms of story delivery. Where the main storyline falls short is during the later half of the progress. Character development at that point seems rushed and all of a sudden you feel like asking, "Who was this again?". However the ending did justice to the original storyline of the AC Series by simply going back to its roots. In addition to that, if you pay attention closely, the ending reveals a certain assassin whose sepulchre was visited by certain assassin named Ezio.

CONCLUSION
Please don't dismiss the game altogether all because the publisher have had a bad reputation for the past few years. Yes it's true that Assassin's Creed Origins is a long way from reaching the pinnacle of an almost perfect Open World Rpg game like The Witcher 3 though it's definitely on the right track which makes me excited for future titles of the Series. Hopefully, Ubisoft will continue with this formula with significant changes towards the weak aspects of the game so that it can acheive its full potential as a benchmark or golden standard for Open World RPG games in the future.


RECOMMENDED FOR
1.) TRUE AC FANS (NOT THE WHINY ONES WHO SEEM TO COMPLAIN ABOUT NEW INNOVATION) WHO LOVE THE NARRATION ASPECT OF THE WITCHER SERIES COUPLED WITH THE CHALLENGING COMBAT SYSTEM OF DARK SOULS.
2.) GAMERS WHO ARE UNFAMILIAR WITH THE AC SERIES (This is a decent starting point).
3.) PEOPLE WHO HAVE PLAYED PREVIOUS AC TITLES THAT HATED THE AC FORMULA.
4.) CASUALS WHO LOVE OPEN WORLD EXPLORATION.
5.) PEOPLE WHO OBSSESS ABOUT HISTORICAL EGYPT.
6.) EGYPTIANS

Recommended
153.1 hrs on record
Posted: May 11, 2021
TL;DR: GOOD GAME, buy when on sale. 7/10

To preface this review, I have 100% completed the storyline and achievements for this game including DLC, and played over 150 hours.

The Good:
- Great action RPG gameplay
- DLC feels worth the money
- Great storylines among the Main game and the DLC's
- Many hours of content
- Actual variability between playstyles (especially early game), you can be an stealth assassin, an up-lose fighter, or a ranged bowman, and all are viable
- It "feels" like you're in ancient Egypt, if that's a seller for you
- The skill trees give you abilities that are actually useful, and make you want to really plan out your build
- The notorious Assassins creed trailing/following missions have been pretty much removed altogether in this instalment


The Bad:
- There a many missions that include investigations, which involve using searching around a room and interacting with anything out of the ordinary. Really boring, and sometimes even frustrating to find the "clues".
- A lot of the side missions are cut-and-paste, even in the DLC's
- The animus storyline is incomplete, we can infer what happens based off of the other assassin's creed games, but it straight up has no proper ending. The DLC's also missed the opportunity to expand on the animus storyline. Most people don't care that much, and just like the assassin stuff, but it's a little disappointing

The Ugly
- Visual bugs when you are swimming, hard to explain but you will 100% experience the "glowing" crack in the wall during your playthrough
- There is a bug that crashes the game and sometimes even turns my computer off. I've done extensive diagnostics and can 100% confirm that it's only happening with this game. The bug usually happens when you fire and arrow or use Senu while the game is auto saving. You will probably face this bug once every 60 hours of gameplay.
-Online connectivity is require for this single player game, which is a deal breaker for many of those with spotty internet.

Comments:
I liked the Hidden One's DLC better than the Curse of the Pharaohs. The Hidden One's is $10 less but much smaller. I preferred the storyline, and it felt more like an extension of the main game than the Curse of the Pharaohs. The Curse of the Pharaohs adds a huge amount of content, a ton of bosses to fight, and a ton of loot.

I give this game a 7/10, definitely worth a playthrough. At the time of writing this review, this game is almost 4 years old, so I wouldn't go rushing to pay the full price for this game. If you ever see this game for 35% off, or around $50, definitely pick it up along with the Hidden one's DLC, you won't regret it.

102 products in account

Recommended
207.4 hrs on record
Posted: September 12, 2019
Assassin's Creed Origins took me whole 3 months to finish (100% of base game, both DLC's and Discovery tour, all achievements and club challenges) but it was definitely worth it! This game was one hell of a journey and I have to write a review of it (this one will be only base game review, DLC's will have its own reviews).

Story:
The main story quest line is not particularly long but it is interesting enough to keep you entertained. There are many cut scenes, everything is voice acted and there are several good plot twists that you won't be expecting.
There are little over hundred side quests and 24 main story quests. The side quests are pretty good too but after a while they will feel quite similar to each other. Some of them are unique but most are rather similar in content. But every quest is voice acted, they introduce some recurring characters you will meet later - either in base game or in DLC's.


Gameplay:
The world of Ancient Egypt is HUGE in this game and that's not an exageration. If you are completionist like me, you will be probably overwhelmed by sheer size of the map. The time it takes to explore everything is crazy. It took me around 150 hours to finish the base and most of it was spent on exploration. The world is stunningly beautiful. All the vistas, towns, cities, temples, deserts or countryside - all of them has its own charm and in this game, they feel alive with people or animals everywhere.

The tools you have in this game are numerous. You can run, swim, dive, ride a horse, camel, chariot or boat. You can climb every building or mountain or slide down the pyramids. You have your loyal Senu which allows you to see the world from bird's perspective.

The combat is pretty fun too with variety of weapon types. You can be a warrior and fight a melee or sniper with a predator bow, sniping down your enemies undetected or an assassin ambushing enemies from the shadows - the choice is yours to make.

Each weapon has its own atributes and abilities and there are several weapon rarities. You have an option to upgrade some of your gear which permanently increases tool or arrows capacity or increase your damage or health. The gear progression is suprisingly nice.

Character progression is simple but still rewarding. You will get ability poins for each level up and from certain locations which you can spend on enhancing your character and unlocking new combat options. Level cap is at 55 with all DLC's but you can still get experience even after that and keep enhancing your abilities.


Enjoyment:
I still found the game entertaining even after 200 hours. It was kinda hard to find a motivation to keep playing by the end of the base game but DLC's introduced some refreshing changes and the game become enjoyable once again. The issue I had with base game was simply that it was too huge and I was getting really tired of exploring all the regions. There were just too many of them and finishing everything just to get those achievements is very tedious.
Still, it was very enjoyable ride for most of the time and I feel like I will miss the Egypt now, that I'm done with the game.


Graphics:
If you can manage to play the game on ultra high settings @ 1440p then you are in for a treat. The game looks absolutely beautiful. While it is true that draw distance could be higher, or there could be an option to increase it for those, that can afford it, it still looks great. The view distance is insane. You can see all of the Egypt from some places and with the in-game photo mode, you can make some wallpaper materials.
If you pay close attention to the detail, you will notice that some textures has lower quality than other and sometimes, it is rather noticable but thanks to the great use of lightning the game looks just stunning most of the time.


Audio:
Everything is voice acted, even random NPC's are talking in Egyptian, Roman or Greek languages which adds to the whole atmosphere a lot. The voice acting is very good as well.
Sound effects are top-notch with great attention to the detail. The background music is subtle and not intrusive in any way.
Hard to find any flaws when it comes to audio.


Technicals:
The optimalization is not the best for CPU. As soon as you visit one of the large cities like Alexandria, Memphis or Thebes, your frames will most likely plummet. While I was able to have constant 60 FPS everywhere else, in those large cities, I was often down to 50 FPS and the game was stuttering a lot.
Other than that, I had few random crashes while playing and for the last couple of days, crash to the desktop when I tried to load my files. Not sure if this was Uplay issue or what was causing it.
But for the game as huge as this one, the technical aspect is very solid and the game is stable for most parts.

Recommended
28.7 hrs on record
Posted: November 18, 2017
I've only played this game for about 6 hours. It's awesome, honestly. Funnest assassin's creed I've played.

Some people seem to think that I'm rating the game down because my computer's performance. If you read the whole review, that is not the problem. But for clarity, I am editing the review here to say that my specs are in the comments. My PC's performance is definitely not the issue here. I was running the game on Ultra settings with my FPS never dipping below 75, even in the most hectic situations.

The game has optimization issues, clearly. It doesn't run poorly on my system on Ultra settings, but it definitely doesn't run the way I'd expect it to. The gameplay is more than enough to make up for this. And I expect there will be a patch within the next month or two to rectify this.

Finally: the reason I don't recommend this. I can't start the game. I could start it a couple days ago, and that's when I played it for 6 hours in one day. Tried to start it the next day, and it didn't work. I've been chatting with the ubisoft support team since then with no resolution. This is the biggest issue on the Assassin's Creed: Origins support site that I can see with over 450 people engaging in the chat, saying that they have the same problem with no resolution, other than a few outliers who found success in changing the install location to their C Drive, running it in administrator mode, etc. But for the vast majority, this is a problem that has not been solved.

I can't give this game a thumbs up if I can't play it.

Edit: From what I've been able to troubleshoot with the support team and on my own, the failure to launch is most likely caused by A: Having more than one HD/SSD installed in the PC, B: A conflict between Steam and Uplay, or C: (Most Likely) Some weird combination of both. The only troubleshooting option the support team has left is to do a complete windows reset. I'll update when that happens.

Edit: Windows Reset didn't help either. Hopefully Ubisoft finds the issue and releases a patch to fix the issue soon, because at this point, it doesn't look like this is anything I can solve on my side. I'll update if the support team is able to help get the game running.

EDIT: FIXED! The most recent Uplay update fixed it for me! My guess is the Uplay launcher was having difficulty finding the game files for some reason or another, and that fixed it. Like I said at the first part of the review, I think this is a great game, and now I'm finally able to play it.

Not Recommended
2.2 hrs on record
Posted: August 21, 2018
I sincerely appreciate that they tried something new, and took a bit of a risk, but for me this is too far of a step away from the previous titles in the franchise, to the point where it no longer feels like an Assassin's Creed game.

The leveling system feels too much like a classic RPG, and in increasing the difficulty of each area thus making it too treacherous and dangerous for lower level players to enter really takes away from the freedom that fans of the franchise enjoy.

Though my biggest issue with Assassin's Creed Origins is the rework of the combat system. It is PAINFULLY obvious that they tried to emulate Dark Souls. I cant help but feel like during one of the development meetings somebody said "You know what? People love Dark Souls, so lets make the combat system JUST LIKE DARK SOULS" and then everybody in the room cheered. Combat in the previous titles felt very fast and fluid, now it feels clunky and monotonous. *swing weapon* *dodge* *swing weapon again* rinse and repeat. I might have a personal bias, but I do not like Dark Souls, so having a combat system that feels just like Dark Souls does not work for me at all, and it makes combat feel repetative, clunky and slow. I also do not like how when you hit an enemy a number appears overhead to show how much damage/loss of health your attack did to the enemy. Again, it feels far too much like an RPG.

My final gripe is that they seem to have changed the movement (which seems to have been done to accomodate the combat system rework) there is no longer a sprint function, the character just runs at what feels like a pretty slow pace and the button usually associated with sprinting now causes the character to walk at a steady pace. This movement rework also makes climbing a bit more difficult and overall harder to manage. And I am sure we can all agree that the fast paced movement and climbing is one of the seminal components of the Assassin's Creed franchise.

I was really excited to play this game, and what I wanted and expected (and I dont think it was unfair of me to want or expect it) was an Assassin's Creed game set in Ancient Egypt, instead what I got was a game that seems to have abandoned it's predecessors and is trying really hard to be something it isnt and shouldnt be, whilst trying to emulate other games.

And as a quick side note, the game seems pretty poorly optimised, my system is not able to run it very well, and the frame rate is pretty low (but to be fair its not unplayable) in spite of the fact I have a GTX 1080, i7 7700k CPU with 32gb DDR4 RAM

Disappointed is an understatement, I have loved the franchise since the beginning but this game seems to have forgotten where it came from, and unfortunately due to this I doubt I will be checking out Odysee either.

The Witcher I never knew I wanted.

I have encountered a few glitches, at worst, an annoying sound glitch where my sound gets stuck on the heartbeat, and misses/stops dialogue with npc's as a result, but reloading the game fixed that. Egypt is stunning to explore, I wanted Egypt since Revelations. It's a really vast map with so much to do, even just running around using photo mode in cool areas is fun, but obviously there's way more to the game than that. I love the combat, it could be a bit less sluggish, and the AI could be a lot less dumb, but at this point I'd argue it gives the NPC's character and normally their level of dumb works in our favour, so it works. But the revamp of the combat system was completely worth it. Weapon variations are fun, upgrading them is worthwhile and so far I've ended up spending quite a lot of money on weapon upgrades as opposed to just letting it rack up in my inventory as I'd done in the previous games. The game itself is a really solid RPG, the side quests aren't grindy at all and most of them you either want to do the quest for the sake of the NPC or it has a good story line to it, that all lead you into exploring the map at the right pace, all I've done from the start of the game is progress because of this, as opposed to doing drab 'back and forth' quests that feel like you aren't progressing in the story/game at all. They really did take a leaf from Witcher, a little from Souls from the combat, and obviously kept it's own signature. I'd mebbe say wait til sale, but honestly, if you wanna play AC and want something fresh, this is the one.. It's a change of style but keeps the old school enough for you to get your AC cravings fulfilled. Uplay DRM sucks tho, my frames do drop and the game does sometimes stutter and fighting multiple opponents can be annoying. I also feel like they could've done more with the musice, good music makes memorable areas in my opinion, I still remember to this day the music in Brotherhood as I climbed the Colleseum, the music isn't bad, it's just a lot more subtle, but if that was what they were going for they got it, it's also just a matter of opinion. Lastly keep in mind the game has microtransactions, to the point you can unlock all the map secrets with Â£Â£Â£, but to be fair, it's nothing a simple google search can't do anyway. Nothing is completely perfect though, maybe wait on some optimisation updates, but it's still one hell of an experience.

138.3 hrs on record
Posted: January 26, 2018
This game is really enjoyable. It is a massive open world and by far the largest AC world we have seen to date. The devs taking some time out from their usual one-year-pump-churn-repeat style that so many franchises are at fault of, it has really paid off. The game mechanics have had a complete overhaul, there are far less "collectibles" to get, the game is very story driven and focuses on exploration and of course killing and surprisngly, even though the game is basically desert based in terms of setting, you still get a vast variety of regions to explore containing rivers, lakes, swamps, forrests and of couse lots of desert and mountains. The views are amazing and the graphics are as good as any game out to date. The way you level up and what you need to do to level up with gear etc, it is VERY similar to Witcher 3. This game is a mix of Witcher, AC and Tomb Raider all into one is how I would describe it's feel.

However, something was missing from it. I think that when playing Assassin's Creed games, they are much better suited for huge city environments with incredible details. The game flows more as you have much more options. Black Flag could get away with having relatively small "city" or "town" details to explore as it focused a lot on the shipping side of things and sea. In this game, you don't get that option. The shipping side of things (which I find just as fun) are purely story driven only. So what we are left with is a massive open world game to explore, but not a huge amount of detail. The Witcher 3 or Ghost Recon Wildlands can get away with having vastness because the environments are so different and there is always something going on. In between the towns and cities (I don't think there is even a "city" in the game), there isn't a great deal to do aside from loot locations. I am fine with looting, just not having to travel 1000 miles to get from place to place with not much to do in between and very much the same stuff.

In a recent update it has added a first for the AC franchise and that is Tours. You can take guided tours of the entire games historic places, buildings and landmarks which is also backed up by running commentary on it's history and all things educational. Really good idea and there is no combat involved at all.

Overall this game is huge and is excellent. Worth the price. With the DLC, it is on par with Witcher 3 in terms of size!

P.S.I can't be the only person who thinks the main charcters voice (when he is wearing any kind of mask), it sounds exactly like Bain played by Tom Hardy out of Dark Knight!

I was a huge fan of the Assassin's Creed Franchise up to Black Flag; for one reason or another I could not enjoy the titles that came after. This game however got me hooked after only a few hours of gameplay. When i first launched the game I intended to try it out for 3 hours... somehow that session took about 8 hours, this should give you an idea of how hooked i was and how addictive the game is.

Ubisoft seem to have improved a lot of the games interface and mechanics. The most noticeable is the introduction of the Action-RPG system, and they have done it right. There are levels, talent trees, rare drops, Critical hit chance, on-hit effects and much more RPG aspects that make grinding feel more rewarding and worthwhile. They introduced this RPG system while still managing to keep the game ... Well still keeping the game an "assassin's creed game" where stealth, exploration and recon are still important.

Other Positive notes on the game are:
-Amazing environment
-Very large and connective openworld (one that I can compare to the Witcher 3 if not larger)
-Unique and rewarding side quests
-A fun Combat system that is MUCH superior to the games predecessors. (fans of Dark souls, BloodBorne and Nioh like myself, will fall in love with it)
-Graphics are pretty amazing though requires a decent VGA
-Amazing Soundtrack (as we have come to expect from any Assassin's Creed game)

One thing that I enjoy but dislike is this game has partial multiplayer, let me explain. No, you can't invite or join your friends in Origins but you are able to take screenshots in game and share them on the map meaning just about anyone can search on the map where you took your screenshot and see it for themselves. Another thing I really like is when someone dies in the game, you are able to see their death marker and avenge them by killing the enemy that killed them. This is very creative from Ubisoft but I would have preferred co-op or at least a free-roam only mode.

But other than that, definitely get this game if you're a fan of Assassin's Creed and stealthy games, when it comes to it. This is a must buy!

Posted: February 3, 2018
Speechless.

Due to the creed games previously, I was VERY skeptical about getting origins. After seeing some gameplay, and reviews I figured I would take a leap of faith ;) Lets dive in, shall we?

Gameplay

The game is set in Egypt near the end of the Ptolemaic period. The main character you play is named "Bayek". In my few hours of play, I was tasked with helping out a healer, blacksmith, and family in the first area named Siwa. 2 Hours of play later, and im nearing the completion of side and main quests for the area. Ive yet to even begin pursuing collectables! The game allows the player to play in ANY style they choose. Ranged attacks, fire bombs, bows, spears, swords of all types.. The diversity is intense in this game especially, as the open world of egypt is done incredibly well. You will literally feel like you are stepping back in the periods of what, 50 bc? You have MANY ways to complete a mission due to the vast amount of choices you have for say eliminating a captain. Want to climb on the roof and shoot him with the bow? Want to lure his guards to you, kill the guards, then have the captain investigate his troops, only to find theyve been inflicted with poison that will harm the captain himself. You also start off the game with a mount, and the ability to use him any time you desire. Crafting, although handy, is quite basic. Think Far Cry. Disappointed in that lack of depth, but it still allows for some game changing experiences. Just recently I met an old friend, senu? I believe. He is your pet eagle that allows for recon of areas, and tagging of enemies, objectives, and also you can set custom markers with him. Think Wildlands drone style.

Rating 9/10

Performance

Origins looks insanely beautiful on a modern day pc. Cutscenes look directly like the game itself does, and sometimes worse, as if some were ported from the console build. not affecting towards any gameplay, therefore I feel it shouldnt detract any score from the game. I did notice some little choppy/laggy bits in the beginning for some reason?

Now lets talk numbers here..

My PC is a i5 6600k Base clock, with a gtx1070 all run on a 140hz monitor

Ultra/max settings, the frames were at the lowest low 50s, max was around 70
High settings, Frames were a little better at 70-80 FPS
No need to test lower settings

Im not disappointed at the performance, as it is highly playable, but I guess im just SO used to getting frames that match my refresh rate..

Rating 9.5/10

Final Thoughts

The game is done incredibly well so far as im 2 hours into it, my biggest complaint would have to be the lack of a satisfying crafting system, and the very little frame drop from time to time. The gameplay affects are done really nicely, the UI is done really well.. Its a complete package that feels like a nice refresher to the more closed of creed games

Final Rating
9/10

I HIGHLY recommend this game if you new to the creed series as the combat is SO much smoother and seems more fluent. Look out souls, and witcher a new game is on the block ;) I Pray Ubi keeps building and improving upon this formula, and doesnt run it to the ground. Cheers folks :)

72 products in account

6 people found this review helpful 0

Recommended
36.3 hrs on record
Posted: October 28, 2017
I wanna start this off by saying I am huge fan of the AC series and I have played and beaten all of the Assassins creeds games, some of them multiple times. I was worried that they were changing up their bread and butter format for games but all of the changes added into origins make the game much more enjoyable and challenging.

Minimap and Eagle Vision:
In the other Ac games it was very easy to just pop out of cover for a second lure a guy over and then kill him it was generally very forgiveable to being seen by enemies which doesn't really make sense in a lot of situations. There was also a minimap which made it easy to rout all the enemies systematically because you knew where they were at with the minimap and eagle vision.

Assassins creed origins got rid of the minimap feature and replaced it with a typical skyrim and fallout type inidcator bar at the type showing nearby quests and areas. This makes the game much more interesting and challenging for a stealth game because you cannot see all the enemies on your minimap. They also changed eagle vision from a button that shows all enemies through walls and targets to an actual eagle lining up with AC lore. So you can scout out targets and mark enemies using your eagle which feels much more realistic and rewards calculated stealthy movement. They also added a leveling system to the combat making the game more challenging throughout and revitalizes the combat from the tradtional parry kill staleness AC is known for. In the other games I never worried too much about agroing 10 guards for most missions because I knew I could just parry and kill them all if I needed to but for origins you need to minimize the amount of enemies agroed to be successful in the game because of the huge revamp of the combat system in this game.

Combat:
The different melee and bow combat is very rewarding and very fun to use and rewards good mechanics and gameplay. I had always preferred melee weapons in the other AC games other than occassionally using my pistols to instakill enemies in tough spots. but in origins I find myself constantly using the bow to headshot isolated enemies and targets. The different types of bows are very fun to experiment with. The horse combat is very intuitive and realistic and can be very fun to hunt and fight from horseback in the right situation

Map and Exploring:
One of my favorite parts of the Assassin's creed game is the environment and historical world created by ubisoft to take you back in time and explore the cities and culture of that time. AC Origins and egypt is by far the biggest map and area to explore in the entire series and doesn't suffer from some of the reused textures and staleness some of the previous games had with reusing houses, character models, voice lines, and using pointless collectibles to fill the map. All of the map I have explored so far has been fresh, interesting and beatutiful constantly pushing me to explore more. The mounts have differing speeds and uses. The horses are fasters and better for combat and the camels are better for exploring and climbing rougher terrain. There is an amazing follow the road feature where the mount follows the road to your next objective or marker on the map making travel much more enjoyable and fun. While the horse is going to your next objective you can use the "eagle vision" to scout the area ahead and look for loot and mark enemies and targets while your horse brings you to the marker.

Story:
No spoilers but the story is very compelling and sticks to normal AC norms of making you truly feel a part of the character and constantly keeps you on your toes.

TLDR: No minimap, different eagle vision, revitalized combat, amazing map and travel features, stop reading this go buy the game and explore ancient egypt.
Remember:
Nothing is true.
Everything is permitted.

In Origins the story sometimes feels out of order. I kill someone before fully understanding why I have such a rage-fueled desire to do so. Thus, instead of feeing pulled into the game I feel plunked in. It looks and feels so freaking good once Iâ€™m there I nearly forget, but it can be disorienting at times.

â€œEagle visionâ€ (from games past) has sort of been split into two acceptable variants. You have Animus pulse (a name I loathe because you have it in this game before you have backstory for why it is called that), which lets you become aware of loot and hidden doorways in your immediate vicinity. Long-time AC fans may feel like they are no longer able to charge in, hide, locate all enemies instantly, and then charge forth and stab...and thatâ€™s true. Combat is a whole new ball game. Yes, this also means some players can pay to upgrade, but I say let em.

Recommended
129.4 hrs on record
Posted: November 1, 2017
This is the First Assassin's Creed since the Ezio Trilogy that truly blew me away.
The world is large and filled with interesting side activities that, for the first time in any AC game that i played, MEAN SOMETHING! They're not just there to fill out the map.
Also, the game looks absolutely fantastic. From the badass outfits to the Pyramids of Giza i haven't found a single thing that i didn't want to look at.
The story starts out a bit slow but gets better and better all the way to the kicker ending.

other pros:
-a skill tree and RPG-like progression system
-absolutely great combat system, far better than any other AC game. You actually have to work for your parry kills for once
-the game rewards exploring, which is great because there's a million things hidden in this game.
-no limits. the world is yours to explore in its full extent from the moment you finish the mandatory intro quest
-you get pulled away from the main quest line a lot , and getting side tracked is not boring at all.
-no BS stipulations for maximum synchronization. In fact, no stipulations on anything. you are truly free to tackle every challenge as you like.
-diverse choice of weaponry
-diverse boss encounters.
-YOU CAN FIGHT BLOODY WAR ELEPHANTS
-game runs smooth. although i read there can be some performance issues, i had none.
-The Bath towel outfit. nothing funnier than slaughtering some Romans in a towel.
-Those Who Came Before give you a lot of food for thought. If you are willing to listen.
-The game's built in Screenshot feature let's you take and look at breathtaking and hilarious pictures from the whole community. Yup this game has its own Instagram. sort of.

some cons:
-farming your upgrade materials can be a bit time consuming
-occasional small bugs here and there, but definitely nothing major or game breaking.
-even though some bosses can be quite the challenge, overall the game is a bit too easy for my taste. I'd like a difficulty setting higher than "hard"
-the AI can be a bit derpy if you have to follow someone or they follow you. Minor annoyance.
-microtransactions. well, it's Ubisoft, what do you expect. but throwing more money at them certainly doesn't give you acess to easy mode.
-Main character tends to have the vegan syndrome. He tells literally everyone who he is and what he does in the first sentence after they met.


Overall verdict:
definitely worth the 60 bucks i spent on this game. i clocked in almost 46 hours now and I'm far from done with this game. Exploring Ancient Egypt at the turning point of human history has been the best gaming experience i had in a while.

T3TSVO_

3 people found this review funny 0

Recommended
62.9 hrs on record
Posted: July 2, 2018
A true example of Irony!

Assassin's Creed Origins charm is the fact that it doesn't feel like an Assassin's Creed game.
What does it feel and play like? Like a poor man's Witcher 3. An overpriced version of the better game.
Assassin's Creed Origins costs twice as much as The Witcher 3. However when it comes to content and the quality of content then Witcher 3 feels like a triple A title while AC: O feels like a cheap indie title. The sad or a funny part is that it's the complete opposite: The cheaper and better game, The Witcher 3, is an indie game and the more expensive but way worse game, AC: O, is a triple A product.
AC: O is a very good game. However, let us admit that it tries to be Witcher 3 and let it be clear that Witcher 3 is superior in every single aspect.
That said let's get on with the review.

The Story

AC:O has a pretty basic and unoriginal story. It's what I call a "stock story". It's your classic man-on-a-revenge-quest story.
Either the protagonist has lost his wife, girlfriend, kid or an entire family because of the bad guys. In this case it's his son.
You play as Bayek of Siwa. A man who has lost his child. You start to pursue the evil doers and assassinate them one by one. That's pretty much the entire story without couple of spoilers.
You will travel through Egypt to Greece and Rome and then back again. The world is huge and you'll encounter a lot of characters and side quests along the way.

Gameplay

It's pretty basic and some would call it clunky but it does it's job and it does it's job well.
You can equipt different weapons: Shields, swords, dual swords, spiers, axes, maces etc. Each weapon has different attributes but they all work the same: RB - fast attack, RT - slow attack, LB - block. Yes, I used the Xbox 360 controller.
Movement works as you expect in an AC game. You run up a wall and your character starts to climb it. You can leap into haystacks and sneak around your enemies.
You also have 3 different skilltrees: Archery, Melee and Gadgets. That's not what the skilltrees are actually called but I figure these names make more sense. In archery you can upgrade your archery skill (obviously). You can equip 2 different bows, fire more than one arrow at once and even guide your arrows. With melee tree you can execute people faster and the gadget tree unlocks smoke bombs and lets you tame wild animals.

The world is HUGE and there's a lot to explore. You can buy different mounts (camels, horses etc) or fast travel between regions. You can do side quests, treasure hunt, take part in the gladiator tournaments or race in the hippodrome. At first it seems like the game has a lot going for it but in the end you'll realise that it isn't that much different from the other Ubisoft titles and each side quest starts to become a chore rather than a joy. It's definitely better than your average Ubisoft game but that isn't saying much.

Performance

Ubisoft games are infamous for being badly optimised. However AC: O seems to run fine for most of the people. I only encountered couple of graphical glitches myself and just a single bug in one of the side quests.
Graphically the game looks good. However I was a tad dissapointed. At max settings it doesn't look much better than The Witcher 3. The scenery is nice and will fool you but the graphics aren't anything special. I'd Say that Final Fantasy XV on PC looks way better.
Oh and when it comes to voice acting then this game falls into indie category easily. There's only a handful of characters that are voice acted well. Most characters feel emotionless and just fake.
These are my two cents.
I don't usually give out scores but some people are interested in them so...I'd say AC: O is a solid 7/10 for sure...That is if you can get it on a sale because it definitely isn't worth the full price for main game + expansion DLCs.

Finally an AC game made by one of the best teams in ubisoft, The creators of AC IV has released and ever since the day it launched i was sinking not my time, but my entire life in to it. so let me get one thing straight, I will not fill my review with c-r-a-p, so instead i will give my honest opinion about each part without talking too much ! THE GOOD:
Huge open world. This is the biggest AC game of all time.
Map is filled with many superb things both in terms of quest and details.

Recommended
97.5 hrs on record
Posted: January 10, 2019
The game is okay.

I like that they changed the classic Assassin's Creed gameplay elements up a bit. It now resembles open world RPGs such as The Witcher. The revamped combat seems to draw some influence from Dark Souls but is of course much easier (but compared to previous AC games it is more difficult).

That's what irks me about it though: while this is all new for the AC series, it's all been done before and better in other games.

Some thoughts about various aspects of the game, not really a full review:

Main plot is the classic AC revenge plot. The main character (Bayek) is not so interesting. Occasionally you play as his wife (Aya) who is much more likeable and actually gets some kind of arc. They're no Ezio or Kenway.

Quests are mostly forgettable. Almost all of them are fetch quests + an assassination. This is mostly the case with sidequests, the main questline does have a few more memorable ones.

There are many characters, most of them uninteresting, I could only remember 10 or so. Human models and (facial) animations are not great. Sometimes you'll come across NPC's adressing a crowd with wide gestures. Gestures continue to play even after the speech has long ended. A minor problem but stuff like that is noticeable and breaks immersion.

While the game is open exploration is discouraged as quests always have only one entry point and win state. If you're in a location where a McGuffin is supposed to be, but the quest was not given to you yet, the object won't spawn. Find the quest, then return to the location. All of these places have respawning enemies. At one point in the game you'll come across a Roman citadel, 3 separate quests need you to go there, I did them all one by one and had to clear out the place 3 times... It's more efficient then to first chase every quest marker and only complete locations after you've done all quests.

Ubisoft has clearly found their sandbox formula and is sticking to it in this game. Clearing locations feels a lot like Far Cry. A location can be completed by finding all the designated loot and killing all the "special" enemies (captains/commanders) in it.

There are microtransactions but I haven't used them and they don't get in the way of the game. They work in a way somewhat explained in-game which is an okay way of doing this sort of thing if you have to I guess. Like other games they're lootboxes. You can get a lootbox for free each day by doing a quest and it sometimes gives you items that are a bit OP.

This all sounds very negative but there are good parts. This game can look absolutely stunning at times. Seeing Ancient Egypt in motion is quite neat, and the map is interesting enough to explore. I must be a sucker for completing locations on a map cause I've spent 60 hours doing it and also intend to play through the DLCs.

Ultimately seeing as I spent so much time with this game, I would recommend it, but it's not as good as AC2 or Black Flag IMO.

tl;dr
Game is average. Has many problems, but still fun to play. Beautiful open world.
I suspect mostly fans of the franchise will enjoy it but your mileage may vary.

Update:
Played the DLC's by now. The HIdden Ones is alright but Curse of the Pharaohs is really good, and improves upon some flaws of the base games. Sidequests aren't as disconnected from the main storyline, there's more cinematic cutscenes, and it's not as repetitive.

Recommended
365.7 hrs on record
Posted: November 4, 2017
I just finished the game, and it is far and away the best Assassin's Creed Game I have played. As a few of the major review outlets have already pointed out, there is much greater depth to the gameplay than in previous entries, and I'm fairly certain that a significant chunk of that extra year of development time was spent by the devs playing The Witcher 3 to see how an action RPG is done. I'm not saying that ACO is an RPG, but it certainly feels more like one than any of the previous games.

Egypt is gorgeous, Bayek is relatable, and the world is full of lore-enriching secrets that made me excited every time I saw a question mark on the map with a distinct golden tint. The side quests were typically well-designed multi-stage endeavors that made playing the role of Egypt's Medjay feel meaningful, as well as making the world feel very much alive. The main campaign is good, even great at times. Without giving anything away, the ending didn't have the positively hollow feeling that Syndicate's did, and more importantly, it felt earned.

The new gear system was appreciated in that it was fun and balanced, as opposed to the needlessly convoluted system of Unity and the overly-streamlined (but by no means bad) gear system of Syndicate. I actually liked that outfits were purely cosmetic with outfit upgrades existing as a separate crafting system applied to Bayek rather than to individual outfits. My only real gripe about the leveling system is that given the sheer amount of content in the game, the cap should have been higher. That said, you can keep unlocking ability points even after reaching the max level, and based on the number of abilities I never wound up unlocking, it seems like the ability tree was meant to be crafted based on preferred play style instead of being maxed out to the point where Bayek just becomes OP.

Performance-wise, the game runs just fine at high settings on a GTX 1060 with an i7 6700HQ and 16GB of DDR4. By "just fine," I mean that it never quite gets to a stable 60 fps, so I just locked it to 45 and enjoyed the game. I'll note that while 60 is always preferred, I'll take 45 FPS on a 4K screen at 60% resolution scaling. It still looked great, and all frame rates above 30 fps are above the "floor" of remotely enjoyable frame rates in video games as far as I'm concerned. But that's just me.

Might as well just add that this game did not murder my CPU. Optimization could have been a bit better, but I'll wait and see how things are several patches from now before giving a final verdict on that front.

Overall, this was an incredibly ambitious and thoroughly refreshing instance of an Assassin's Creed game, and I hope future entries in the series are more like Origins.

9/10

Recommended
48.6 hrs on record
Posted: November 7, 2017
Good game, finally something different from Assassin's Creed. After 10 years that awful braindead counter spam combat is gone, that alone makes Origins better than any of the previous AC games in my opinion, except maybe 2 or Brotherhood because the story was very good in those games and the story in Origins is by far its weakest point.

The open world and exploration are some of the best I've seen in gaming, especially if you love ancient Egypt. One of the best experiences I had in this game was arriving in Memphis and seeing the Bent Pyramid of Sneferu in the distance and thinking, "hey I know that pyramid", then riding there on my horse and exploring the whole necropolis, turning a 5 minute detour into an hour of exploration. However I find the choice of Ptolemaic Egypt questionable, I was hyped for an Assassin's Creed set in ancient Egypt, but the Egypt depicted in Origins has seen 300 years of Greek occupation, and almost all the towns and cities in the game are dominated by Greek architecture and culture as a result. It often feels like a game set in ancient Greece rather than Egypt.

Bayek is a cool character, he's a religious and honorable man who cares for Egypt and its people, but he also has a good sense of humor. He's a likeable guy. However Aya is a horribly wooden and boring character and for some reason the game forces us to play as her on multiple occasions. The story is awful, and somehow gets even more awful in the 3rd act. I won't spoil any of it here but there's not much to spoil anyway, especially if you know the story of Cleopatra and Caesar in real life.

I want to mention the leveling system, in that I don't like it and it doesn't belong in the game. If you are 1 or 2 levels under an enemy's level, he will kill you in one or two hits, and it takes 10+ hits from you to kill him, playing on Hard difficulty. It's not like an actual RPG where you can be crafty and get around being underleveled, simply if you are underleveled in Origins the enemy will one shot you and he will be a bulletsponge to you. This forces you to grind side quests. I have almost 40 hours played but I'd say it's a 15 hour game if you didn't have to grind so many side quests to level up.

I liked Origins but it's held back by the awful story and soundtrack, which is basically background noise. The only good track in the game is the remix of Ezio's Family at the end which is mostly Jesper Kyd's work. But still the combat is decent for once and the open world and exploration are exceptionally good; overall it's a massive step up for Assassin's Creed as a franchise.

I did have some problems with crashing but it turns out it was a driver error on my part. The game runs alright, 60 FPS @ 1440p on my GTX 1080 Ti and Ryzen 5 1600 @ 3.8 ghz, but I think the performance could be better especially in cities like Alexandria and Memphis where it can drop down to 50 FPS.

I bought this during the Christmas Sale last December, but just haven't had the urge to play it. Now it's hard to put down. Oh well, things come to those that wait.

To start with, the graphics, and music score will blow you away. As of this review, I have approximately 10 hours in, and I'm loving every moment. Catch this on a good sale as it's on the pricey side, and play for just under 2 hours before returning it, but if you like it, keep on gaming!

Recommended
57.5 hrs on record
Posted: September 29, 2018
Overall a good experience, the wait of 2 years without AC was worth it for Ubisoft to re-evaluate their direction.

Story
It feels like the previous AC games (excluding Ezio timeline) where you fight against the Templars, yet you don't know why (except to get to the treasures of previous civilizations before them) which makes the future story lacking. All missions are focused on Egypt at the time of Cleopatra rise to power, with Caeser thrown in the mix.

The main narrative keeps you engaged for more content, with the side stories also having purpose and continuity. The DLCs are great, and I think the Hidden Ones are even better than The Curse of the Pharaohs since it has a continuous story with more relationships and culminations.

Speaking of which, the good guys turning bad in all stories are rather obvious from the start since they try to give you purpose in the game, but their beliefs are vague and mysterious.


Of course, the bad guys such as the Order, have their reasons and do not challenge Bayek to be better since they are short lived in the story. You only notice their beliefs once you have defeated them while everyone is telling you why they are bad. Maybe for the next game, they can switch this so that everyone tells you, but you have back-and-forth quests with the same bad guy similarly to Joker and Batman in Arkham series .

However, there are some copy-paste side quests where you need to go some place and get something, and then return. This is where the developers hit their time constraints when making this game, so they added a different dialog each time to give you a new purpose to finish them.

Scenery
This is where the game shines. Even though it's a desert and it's hard to put content there without looking blant, they have made compact environments (like Memphis, Alexandria and a lot of oasis) that pop out when you see them.

Since it's a desert, there are places where I feel the developers could have added more urban environments instead of leaving it as a desert. For example, there are 3 huge deserts where there are 1-2 treasures and nothing is happening there, so you leave that for last in order to 100% the view points synchronization.

However, you might notice that the Render distance is rather low, which makes the game feel like you are playing on PS4 where objects start rendering at somewhere 150-200m. On the other hand, The Curse of the Pharaohs has the best scenery in the game with all those flares, particle effects and changing environment based on the weather where the distance is so low, you wouldn't notice the rendering issue.

Another great feature is the Photography one, where you can share great sights with the community as they show on the map. Of course, you can also use this for spoilers or hard to find places.

Gameplay
This is not your typical AC game. They have gone in RPG-like direction, where if you previously can one-shot anyone, now you need to be 5+ levels above your enemies to beat them. This gives the game an incentive for players to grind for levels and items to become stronger. The fighting mechanics are good, with each type of weapon having an advantage over the other as well as Legendary weapons having additional perks such as Heal on hit or Instant charging .

Hopefully, they can balance the game more. For example, if you are 2-5 levels lower than your enemy, they kill you in 1-2 shots, while if you are 2-5 levels above them, you need to hit them 7-10 times to kill them. This means if you are lower by 2 levels, you will need at least 100+ hits to kill them, but if you are higher by 2 levels, they can kill you in 10-15 hits. This ruins the experience for players coming from other RPG games such as Dark Souls where by being skillful you can defeat anyone. For this to be a success, they need to add a unique strength/weakness to each enemy, similar to Shadow of Mordor .

Also they can improve the vision of the guards NPCs similarly to Metal Gear Solid: Phantom Pain where they can notice you from your shadow on the ground or while doing parkour on high places. Most of the guards I assassinated was because I was high up on a pillar and they couldn't notice me.

Another thing they can improve are the tracking animations of the opponents. For example, the Phylakes and one of the guards (the ones with big shields and sword) gave you this feeling that they fought as a player would with all the mechanics of the game. But, sometimes they will track on you, and their speed will increase, their animations will lose cooldown and their arm will go through their teammates just so that they can one-shot you when you are low health and even if you dodge, they will track you again without any cooldown of the previous hit.

History
After each story arc, you can enter Discovery Mode where you are narrated the history of the place with facts from historians and books. Of course, the game also tells you that some segments might not be 100% true since history has lost any evidence about some theories. At times I felt that some sceneries could have been added to AC:Origins since there were places in Discovery Mode that were unique to what was narrated like the death of Cleopatra or the rebellion with Ptolomey and Cleopatra.

In-game purchases
Mostly cosmetic and somewhat cheat-like add-ons so you can have more gold, or easier crafting. Some of those can not be unlocked without In-game purchases, but I never felt like I needed them. The only exception was the Nightmare pack with the Ghost Rider horse.

In the game you can get all the Legendary items yourself to look great and be strong while also grind the items to craft your gear. But, some of them are exclusive to the DLCs, so you will need to either buy the DLC or buy the others via the limited 200 Helix coins you earn in the prologue or Uplay currency by doing challenges.

Technical
They could have removed the Denuvo DRM once it was cracked since the additional DRM they added made the game badly optimized. With an 1070 and 7700k, this game never reached over 50% utilization on the GPU while the CPU was 80%+ on all cores because of the double DRMs. And, no matter how much I could OC my GPU, the framerates on 1440p would only go 1 or 2 frames. And speaking of frames, the jumps/drops were 30+ frames (80 -> 45, 49 -> 71, etc) while other games such as Tomb Raider would keep it between 60-70.

Summary
Overall 7/10 experience, where you grind to be stronger, defeat anyone that is not following the protect the innocent dogma while swimming-running-riding in this beautiful scenery called Ancient Egypt blooming with history and characters such as Cleopatra, Caesar, Isidora, Ptolomey and many others.

Posted: November 5, 2017
I would say ignore the negative reviews for this game. I played (and streamed) this game on a 5 year old AMD FX-8320 and 1070, and while the game had some fps dip issues for a few seconds at most and then was fine later, the whole game was completely playable and smooth looking.

The game itself was fun to play. Bayek was a good character, something that was missing from the series for quite a while since most of the previous characters weren't serious about their roll in the Assassin's and were just *there*. His story is more of an internal journey than the typical "I'm an assassin, it's my duty to fight templars".

Gameplay wise, it's a a lot different than the others. It sort of expands on Syndicates leveling system where if you're not in the right level range, you will be killed quickly and do very little damage to enemies. The loot system is pretty underwhelming, since for the majority of the game, you're most likely going to be using the same weapons you get early game and just upgrade them later to your level since you can pay black smiths to do that.

There doesn't seem to be much stealth aspect in this. You can still play it like an Assassin's Creed and bush camp kills or sneak around, but with the open world, there hardly seems to be any stealth routes you can take like in the older games. You can also throw stealth out the window and just run into places killing everybody since it's entirely possible to do that now with very little consequences.

The combat is fair enough. Like I said previously, if you're not within level range with enemies, you will die quickly by them. The majority of combat is mainly hack and slash with the chance to dodge or parry at the once in a great while moments. You can compare it to Breath of the Wild if need be.

The world is very large, and with that, is very disappointing in some places. There are zones on the map where it's just nothing but sand and rocks with no landmarks. It's disappointing since so much can be put into these areas, but there's hardly nothing. Don't worry about that, though, since the content that is in game makes up for it, such as the tombs in Giza or the side quests. Speaking of side quests, it appears that each zone has its own sub story for its area rather than a generic fetch/kill quest.

The leveling system is not really my favourite thing about the game. This is just me, but I'm not really the one who likes being forced to grind in order to do the main story. It may just be that they don't want people to go quickly through the main story or not, but there have been moments where I would spend 3-4 hours a day discovering/completing locations or doing side quests because there was a 3-5 level jump between main quest missions.

In all, I believe this game was great and one of the better Assassin's Creed story and character yet. While I'm indifferent about Black Flag, this game reminds me much about it (It's also made by the same team who did Black Flag, so that's probably why), mainly because it feels like a different game with a little Assassin's Creed elements put into it and got called Assassin's Creed.

ASSASSIN'S CREEDÂ® ORIGINS.

The Assassinâ€™s Creed series has had a tumultuous past. While the initial few titles were all bestsellers, everyone knows the debacle that Unity was. And the series, much like a few other Ubisoft titles, has seen its fair share of repackaging accusations. So, after another average outing in the Victorian UK, when Ubisoft decided to go back deeper in history with Assassinâ€™s Creed Origins, I was definitely excited. But the question remained, was it worth it? Can it deliver on its promises? Let's find out.

STORY :

Just to keep the review as spoiler free as possible, Assassinâ€™s Creed: Origins takes the game back to Ancient Egypt in the Ptolemaic era. The story focuses on Bayek, a medjay(an ancient pararmilitary police), and his journey to avenge his sonâ€™s death and deliver Egypt from its oppression at the same time. Along the way you meet many eminent historical characters like Cleopatra and Julius Caesar, as you travel across famed historical locations like Memphis, Pompei, Alexandria, Giza and more.
One of the strongest things about the story in Assassinâ€™s Creed: Origins is the conviction with which Bayekâ€™s character has been created. He is compassionate and vengeful at the same time, helping those in need while reserving his true rage for the people who have taken his happiness away from him. He comes across as human in his quest for closure, cracking jokes and being affectionate with his loved ones one moment and channelling his rage into his blade the next. Throughout the game, whether on the main quest or on one of the gameâ€™s numerous side quests, you will come across issues like racism, misogyny, classism, imperialism and others that have been depicted as earnestly as possible, while, at the same time, characters have been made to question the same. Overall, Origins weaves an interesting tale, one that could very well have the most character and depth of any Assassin Creed game so far.

GAMEPLAY :

Assassinâ€™s Creed: Origins sets out with one goal â€“ to redeem the AC franchise. It seems, that in a bid to do that, Ubisoft has added heaps of new gameplay mechanics and features. Not that we are complaining, it only makes the game more enjoyable and fresh, as compared to previous instalments which suffered from repetitive experiences across missions. A standard mission is still of the â€˜Reach a place â€“ kill (some) people â€“ free some people/get some object etcâ€™ structure, but certain missions take you into alternatives modes, like the exploration and investigation modes. Both of these are area locked modes, which means that the tasks required of you are to be done only within a certain area on the map, where the investigation of clues or exploration of the area will reveal further clues/objectives as and where applicable. The investigation mode, in particular, is very interesting as it has you looking for clues in your environment that lead you to the conclusions of many a mission.

RPG EDITION :

Assassinâ€™s Creed: Origins goes for an RPG-esque approach on top of the usual Assassinâ€™s Creed fare, with elements like crafting and looting being quite important to your gameplay. You also have an ability tree and level gating thrown into the fray. Each level you gain gives you ability points that you can use to unlock specific abilities, like the predator-bow mid-air control, sleep darts, or even just a half filled adrenaline gauge at the beginning of combat. This way, every person playing the game could be levelling up Bayek in their own way, making their own unique assassin for the game. Level gating does not mean that youâ€™re stopped from playing missions â€“ theyâ€™ll just be insanely difficult â€“ especially when it comes to the combat..

COMBAT :

The fights in Assassinâ€™s Creed: Origins is another area where youâ€™ll notice considerable changes from previous entries in the series. Your armoury is quite diverse with melee weapons ranging from dual swords to power axes and everything in between, and ranged weapons ranging from rapid-fire light bows to the guided predator bows. Even the shield and tools you equip matter quite significantly and will affect how you dispose of your enemies. he lock-on mode that has been seen in quite a few melee combat focused games makes its way to this one too. Although it is quite useful when fighting a boss or a bigger enemy, and certainly a boon for horseback fights, it can be quite a limiting factor when youâ€™re surrounded by enemies and would rather have a broad, tactical view of the battlefield. As mentioned earlier, level matters a lot in combat in this game, with assassinations and shield breaks downright not working against enemies who are stronger than you by more than a level. So itâ€™s a good idea to stick to missions that are of your own level. Ingenuity â€“ like shooting a fire arrow at the hay that your enemy is standing on, pushing an enemy into the water instead of duking it out with them or shooting an arrow through a flame to set your enemy on fire â€“ will help you throughout the game.

GRAPHICS AND SOUND :

Assassinâ€™s Creed: Origins pays a lot of attention to detail. Famous cities and towns are densely populated with people from all stratas of the society, with almost every person you interact with feeling and sounding unique. Each region has its own feel, with the quaint, homely streets of Siwa filled with colour and life in stark contrast to the dying and decaying alleys of Memphis. From people resting on rooftops in Egyptian slums to arguing with scholars in Alexandria to soldiers having lunch together on ramparts, to fishermen hauling in the daily catch cursing at you for blocking their way, the game has been designed to look and sound authentic. Which is why its problems stand out even more. The sheer vastness of this game is new to the series, which makes you feel at times that entire areas and sub-sections within regions have been templatized to speed up development. After a point of time, quite a few bandit caves and soldier camps feel almost exactly the same. And repetitiveness isnâ€™t the only issue. In its bid to be an authentic game, Origins ends up ignoring certain design elements, especially its cutscenes, significantly. During cutscenes, there was clothes flying unnaturally, even going into the body or leading to a couple of virtual wardrobe malfunctions. Lip syncing is often off the mark, which is a shame with the beautiful voice acting that has gone into the game. And once the cutscenes are over, on several occasions thepeople and elements popped out of the ground and continued their normal routine.

FINAL VERDICT :

Assassinâ€™s Creed: Origins bites big, and does a surprisingly good job of chewing it as well. With a few graphical hiccups here and there, the game stays true to the historical approach that the series was originally known for while bringing in a whole new level of depth to the series. Be it the well-designed locations, the immaculate portrayal of Bayek by Abubakar Salim, the numerous gameplay mechanisms that the game throws at you or even the classic assassination missions, thereâ€™ll be something in this game that brings you back to it again and again. Who knows, you might just have a thing for standing atop the Sphinxâ€™s head, gazing into the distance wistfully while an eagle rests on your hand.

OVERALL : 8-8.5/10 (Highly Recommended for both the fans of the series as well as lovers of open world games)

Recommended
179.6 hrs on record
Posted: January 2, 2019
Assassin's Creed Origins is the tenth Assassin's Creed game, developed by Ubisoft Montreal and published by Ubisoft. This game is made by the same team that made Assassin's Creed IV: Black Flag.

Any story must have an origin, and Assassin's Creed origins will provide all the answers to the questions related to the Brotherhood of Assassins: How did they form? Where do their three tenents come from? And many other questions that will be answered during the main story and DLC.

The Modern Day events are occurring in a cave of Qattara Depression, Egypt, where Layla Hassan, an employee of Abstergo Industries, is introduced to us. After four titles of the franchise, the player can again control the protagonist of the Modern Day in Thrid Person View. Although the "free roaming" with this character is limited only in the cave and up to a few meters outside it, the game touches the topic of nostalgia of the first games. Layla with the help of her own Animus, lives the memories of Bayek of Siwa, a Medjay of the pharaohs of Ancient Egypt and for a few moments, the memories of Bayek's wife, Aya Of Alexandria.

The game's story begins near Siwa, Egypt, the year 48 BCE, with Bayek assassinating his first target of the Order of Ancients, a group that killed his only son, Khemu. The death of his son turned Bayek into a killer, thirsty for vengeance. In his mission to make the members of The Order pay for what they did to his son, Bayek interacts with important historical personalities, such as Kleopatra, Queen of Egypt, Caesar, Emperor of Rome and others. Being left on an expedition and later returned to Alexandria, Aya introduces Bayek to the first origins of the Assassins, giving him the Hidden Blade to assassinate his targets. At the end of the story The Brotherhood of Assassins is born under its first name: The Hidden Ones. Bayek is not only a madman who desires revenge and turns his gaze only to death and suffering, but from contrary, he tries how much he can to overcome his son's death by keeping a himself quite happy and hopeful. The carsima and his lines of jokes, when appropriate, can be compared to Ezio's personality, Ubisoft touching the subject of nostalgia again.

Assassin's Creed Origins represents a new direction of the franchise, different from the other titles, through the newly adopted RPG system where you have to work to build your character at a great level. This Medjay of Egypt has a wide range of weapons, melee and ranged, and tools that will help in battle and stealth. Everything in the AC origins has been remade. Combat is acquainted with RPG elements, the player can now shield block, parry, dodge, light attack and heavy attack to eliminate his enemies, in a free and fast movement on the surface of the map. Stealth and parkour have been resimplified, but much more automated; we can even say that they were created specifically for those old times; animations are no longer diversified in climbing, descent and assassination, but reduced to just one aniamtion for each type of action. And it can be understood, because Egypt is not a place for parkour, it is based more on exploration and climbing in the vast majority on cliffs and mountains. The climb control became much more automatic, the player needing to use "free-run-down" only at very high distances of soil and "free-run-up" only when to climb and, preferably, when to jump from a house to the ground at a small distance, giving a feeling that you're a professional free-runner. Stealth has many opportunities due to the various tools available for Bayek: you can be a ninja who puts his enemies to sleep and then sends them to the eternal one, or a serpent that is poisonings those who want to harm him , or a DeadShot that delivers arrows to the soldier's heads. All of this remains at the player's choice. The Skill Tree is much bigger than Syndicate and Unity, featuring three categories that build Bayek in the Assassin desired by the one who controls him: Warrior (an unstoppable Gladiator), Hunter (an Assassin unseen by his enemies) or Seer (a Master of predictibility and strategy). Even Eagle Vision has been changed, saying that Bayek has an eagle view literally, because Senu is his eyes in the air guiding him to his objectives. Inspired by the drone of Ghost Recon: Wildlands, Senu can tag enemies for Bayek and even distract them, while Bayek delivers the Hidden Blade directly in their throats. In an adition of keeping the players however connected, Ubisoft introduces to the game the "Avenge side quest", where the player can avenge others by inspecting their dead body and killing the perpetrators.

The game map is huge. Ubisoft offers the player to explore Egypt at a very detailed level, where he can discover the ancient tombs of the pharaohs or the great palaces where they reigned. The diversity is present, only certain parts being covered in dessert, making the player to walk, with a camel or horse, through the exotic Egypt for hours. Introducing the Photo Mode, Egypt is the perfect location for those who want to take pictures with and exotic or artistic theme, thanks to the climate and shaders that the game has. The people and animals of Egypt are lively present in almost all locations. The side quests are huge and offers the player the opportunity to stay in contact with the game for very much longer after ans between the main story. People are having their own activities: the work in the day like crafting goods, fishing and taking food to their home and sleep at night. The animals are also living their life, every category of animal doing what they do the best. And speaking of side quests, some animals, mostly hippos and crocodiles, are attacking the nearby villages or people and if Bayek is near this conflict, he can save those people by killing the animal for a good reward of XP.

For those eager to learn about ancient Egypt, the game introduces the Discovery Tour mode, where the player can make free roam with a series of characters through the entire map of Egypt, at the same time starting tours about a subject of ancient Egypt.

At the end of the day, Assassin's Creed Origins is the answer to many questions and a new direction that can save the popularity of the Assassin's Creed franchise.

AC Origins Rating: 10/10 Shield and Sword
