Recommended
167.1 hrs on record
Posted: November 8, 2017
If you can bear with some FPS drops ( in cities and during certain events ) and random glitches ( horses can defy gravity and other wacky stuff ) you are up for lots of fun and challenge.

I completed the game on the hardest difficulty with full-legendary gear and mount, all I can say is no grind is needed and there's no need to buy stuff from store. As it clearly states - time savers and special items are there only to help you, their lack in the game doesn't hinder you in any way, in fact, there are much better items than those available by playing the game and completing ( side ) quests every now and then.

There are many interesting side-quests which will keep you busy and entertained, doing those will help you get stronger and richer ( literally ). You won't feel yourself doing stupid chores over and over for some NPC guy, instead you will find yourself being involved in events where your help really does matter.

Lots of hidden locations around the world like Ancient Tombs which hold an Ancient Stone, which rewards a skill point, along with lots of gold and treasures. Hermit places where you can rest will also give you skill points. Beating Elephant Riders ( yep game has those ) also gives you points. Did I mention Chariot Races and Gladiator Arenas? Well, there are certainly enough places for you to go should you get tired of treasure hunting or killing scum of the Egypt.

Many quests involve Egyptian / Roman Mythology ( knowledge of those Gods and Lore is not required in order to complete them ), helping you understand more about how religion and lives of people were entwined. Political situation betweem Egypt, Rome and Greece is well reflected in game - you can see who was prospering and who was suffering from intrigues, contracts and connections with authorities. Secret cults, grave robbers, bandits and other filth, infesting cities or lurking in the ruins - you will meet them all.

Game world is beautiful and full of shapes and colours. Lots of pictures made by other players will reveal sides you couldn't imagine to see. It is quite large and contains cities, forests, deserts, islands and even sea itself! You won't be walking on your two's alone - different mounts will help you travel quickly between areas that you haven't unlocked yet ( fast traveling to cities and observer points help a lot ), you can even use auto-travel option which works on areas with roads or just travel straight line automatically. It's very convenient and time saving. Random events on your way won't let you feel bored - a citizen may be in danger from a wild lion who's hungry or bandits camping poor merchant on his way to the city. Will you stop and change the fate of poor people or just go your way?

There are many other things in game which you can see yourself, as well as an option to avenge fellow assassin players. Should another player of similar level die somewhere near you, his corpse will spawn in your world and allow you to find his killers and punish them. Doing so will award you with sweet 250 XP and sensation of justice, delivered swiftly and righteously.

To sum up : It's a good and interesting game. Few bugs here and there and performance issues may still appear every now and then. Still, nothing stops you from completing it. If you want to play an RPG game in a world of Ancient Egypt, get it, you won't regret buying it.

Edit: I just want to add that the Discovery Tour mode is incredible! Original review below.

Have completed all the AC games (other than Unity and Rogue, and some spinoff Chronicles titles), and thought the franchise was doomed. I am pleased to have been proven wrong. The story is decent, and side quests are no longer fetch this, liberate that, save a fourth, stab a fifth. They can even span multiple regions - I helped out some kids in Giza (might be some other region, I don't remember), and then sent them to Memphis. A few hours later I ventured into Memphis to continue the main quest, and found myself face to face with the kids I helped, and they remembered me (even giving me a nickname)! I just felt obliged to help them again at that point, so I did another side quest. I'm not a completionist, but I have a feeling that I'll be doing a lot more of these side quests, just because they're so memorable and entertaining.

Also, quite a few snobby brats are complaining that this won't run on their insane 7.0GHz, 1024GB RAM, with an SLI setup of a dozen GTX1080s. I can run this on Very High at ~60fps on an i7-6700K, 16GB RAM, XFX RX480; and everything looks amazing. But then again, I'm not gaming on a 4k 144hz 60inch TV, so I might be missing out.

Either way, still worth checking out, in the past 75 hours or so, I have:
[Killed / Gotten killed by / Run away from] a variety of wildlife (you get an achievement for running away from a hippo 3 times).
Tamed a crocodile (guards killed it later).
Tamed a lion, set him up on a date with a crocodile, he defeated the croc, but then a ship sunk my boat. Together with my kitty. RIP my Leo (11/24/2017 2:55 AM - 11/24/2017 3:02 AM).
Saved a few pets.
[Stabbed / Punched / Shot] enemies.

Overall though, it was a lot better than I expected and I can forgive the faults based on the ambition of the game alone.

I'm just a little wary about the expansions they'll be releasing if their current offerings are any indication of quality control.

Recommended
73.9 hrs on record
Posted: April 14, 2019
It's been a long time since Ubisoft produced an AC game of this quality. Where the last three or four installments repeated the same old stuff over and over, Origins is a succesful attempt at revitalising the series as a whole. With new gameplay, a proper story and more quests than you will ever complete in a lifetime.

Origins does away with the traditional progression system and now has an RPG like leveling system. You will find many different weapons with many different stats on your quest, giving you plenty of choice in how to slay your enemies. On occasion this can get annoying as you toss aside your 50th sword for a new one, but overall I'd say it works fairly well.

Luckily most equipment can be broken down into raw materials that can be used to improve Bayek's armor, blade, arrows and more. Getting all these things to their max level is a quest all of its own, and will require much hunting for animals, ambushing cargo transports and infiltrating the many forts dotted on the map for unique material.

Assassin's Creed Origins is by far the largest AC game I've seen to date. The map is enormous, with many towns and cities to explore. Each will have their own side quests, some simple, some complex and lengthy. The main quest will require at least some side quests to be done to raise your level and equipment. Overall the main quest can be completed in about thirty to forty hours, but completing all the other activities on the map and upgrading all your gear will take a multitude of that.

Special shoutout to the story. It's well written, and doesn't focus too much on the founding of the Brotherhood. Instead it tells its own story and weaves the origin story in where it fits. There are many call backs to the older games, which fans can surely appreciate.

If you like Assassin's Creed this is definitely a title worthy of the name and hopefully a taste of where the franchise will go in the future. Highly recommended to get during a sale, but since the game can throw possibly a 100+ hours worth of content at you, it might even be worth it to you at full price.

Not Recommended
79.6 hrs on record
Posted: March 27
Assassin's Creed Origins is fun, more often than it isn't, in fact. However it's not so fun that I can truly recommend buying this game. Note that as of this writing, I have only played the base game.

Firstly, the story. You play as Bayek of Siwa as he seeks revenge for the murder of his son. It's fine for the most part, not great but not that bad, though it feels like the third act takes too long to get here and is too short once it gets here. I feel this may also be a consequence of another part of the game I'll talk about later. For now, though, I can say the plot itself doesn't really waste much of your time with menial nonsense where you get sidetracked, every target you eventually assassinate has a reasonable amount of build up. Any filler the story might have had is relegated to sidequests, making them "optional" as you play through the game.

The sidequests are interesting enough, some are multi-part quests with an overarching plot throughout, others have several unexpected twists and turns within a single quest, while others are as straight forward as they seem on the surface to make sure you don't just start expecting surprises at every turn. Sometimes, once a side characters' quests are done, you can even still see them elsewhere in the world and have a quick chat with them. Unfortunately, at some point, all the side quests just start to blur together and it becomes hard to remember what a quest did unless I did it recently.


Of course, talk of story is all fine and dandy, but what of the game you experience that story through? So let's move on to the parkour.

It outright sucks. High profile, the last remnant of the original Assassin's Creed's marionette controls, has been removed with running now being the default movement. Simply moving Bayek is as functional as you'd expect but parkour is a shadow of its former self. Advanced parkour maneuvers still exist within the game but they're finicky to get working without a lot of practice and are context sensitive like Unity and Syndicate. Here, the only thing I have managed to get working consistently is deciding whether or not to leap off a ledge or drop off gracefully, though even then sometimes the game just wouldn't let me jump off if the angle of my movement input wasn't far enough away from whatever beam I was walking on. While Origins hasn't really removed much more parkour moves that Syndicate didn't already cull (goodbye vaulting, who's animation still exists within the game but is unusable outside of very specific places), what remains has had its utility stripped away with side/back ejects no longer gaining height. If you truly had the will to do so, you can learn the game to the point where you can make something of the parkour here, but it's just not good enough to justify the effort required.


Next to step up to the plate is combat. Firstly, for context, I played this entire game on hard with enemy level scaling on to insure I never benefited from becoming over leveled and I never used the Animus Control Panel. Now, the combat system on paper is fine, you have a light attack, heavy attack, shield, and dodge available without a resource tied to it. You also have smoke bombs, fire bombs, a special attack unlocked when you earn enough meter, and a few ranged options that you can naturally flow into and out of. You're really not starved for options here and moments where your ingenuity becomes the difference between life and death, it's even fun.

But the actual feel of controlling Bayek leaves me wanting. The best way I can describe it is that the man himself feels slippery in a fight. If you're not careful, you can end up wiffing attacks and eating hearts for it. Using your shield to keep Bayek facing where you want seems to be the best way to maintain the most control. The feel of attacks themselves are serviceable, your weapons feel like they hit something when they connect but only to the point where it'd get a passing grade, if you want a visceral feeling, Origins does not deliver.

You are only half of a fight, so what of your duel partners? They also get just a passing grade. They'll shoot arrows at you if you run and sometimes even try to maintain distance to stay safe. Up close, they will use shields if they have one to stay safe and require you break through it or slip around them to get some damage in. Their health generally well balanced when around your level and don't take too long to kill as long as you put in a little bit of effort to keep your gear up to par. Bosses are varied when viewed as a whole but rarely are that interesting of an enemy when viewed individually. There's only one boss that I thought was truly good and it was an optional side boss you can only fight sometimes, and even then it would have been a decent mid boss in another game at best.


This leaves us with the last main gameplay pillar of an Assassin's Creed game for us to take a look at, the stealth. On its own, the stealth is barely functional. Your options for remaining undetected are simply avoiding line of sight, using bushes to mask your presence, making your eagle harass a guard to stun them, whistling to lure guards, and using sleep darts to temporarily stun enemies. The detection system is one I can't truly say I managed to understand by the time the credits rolled. It works as you'd expect most of the time, but there are some instances here or there where you don't expect a guard to see you. With sleep darts, you can use them on guards to save a stealth run and kill them before they wake up. There, sadly, really isn't too much to talk about with stealth, which is the big issue with it, like everything else, it's content being just serviceable. The places you sneak through are generally fine for stealth if unremarkable as only a few (and I really mean a few) places are memorable and they're all late game areas.


Next on the chopping block is the open world itself. It's Egypt. The space between cities isn't filler, but it often feels like it is.. It feels like a real world that's lived in and dangerous but by the end of the game I didn't want to interact with the wilderness outside of necessity. The cities themselves are cities alright. There'll be some parkour routes here or there but it'll be rare that a possible route doesn't seem incidentally there. These don't feel like maps you're supposed to parkour on and the only thing they do to try to convince me otherwise is the fact that some roofs have clotheslines connecting them.


Lastly, the series now being an RPG. I feel the most negatively about this above everything else. It doesn't add anywhere near enough to justify the damage done to the experience as a whole. You now have different weapons and shields you can equip that each have their own traits and stats and the ability to upgrade anything you want to keep using should you favor one weapon over another. These stats just govern the efficacy of its main use, i.e. damage for your weapons. Traits are where any possibility of build variety come into play. I could never really find anything with traits noteworthy enough to justify using over any other.

Where issues really start to arise is with enemy scaling and how I can describe it no better as being outright hostile towards the player. As enemies become too strong, your tools become useless. Sleep darts work but have their functionality stripped as enemies wake up far faster and the game no longer allows you to assassinate them in their sleep, your hidden blade itself can't kill and will trigger open combat if you try, and you do poor damage on top of all of this.

It also affects the pace of the story as you're forced to spend time playing sidequests in order to level up as story quests will not give you enough experience to keep up with the plot, effectively forcing back in the filler the pace of the story otherwise managed to avoid. I have more to say but I can only contest with a character limit for so lo

Not Recommended
79.5 hrs on record
Posted: March 15, 2021
I have such mixed feelings about this game, having not played an AC game between AC Brotherhood and this one. While visually stunning and vast in scope, AC Origins has also been simplified to the point of being little more than an arcade walk through fantasy Egypt.

By contrast, think back to AC 2 or Brotherhood, wandering through the streets of Rome. You felt like you were there. Like every street corner held some new and interesting piece of history. Then, suddenly, you were engaged in a battle which you could not win. So you scaled a wall to escape, and felt the tension as stones or arrows rained down around you. Should you jump from that building? Run? Hide? Turn and fight? That is how it was in the beginning. That is not how it is with AC Origins.

AC Origins is a button mashing fest. Unlike earlier AC games, this one strips away the tension and the feeling of accomplishment when you are finally able to acquire that new piece of coveted gear or build up the villa or hideout with new art or refurbished buildings. In AC Origins, you just run around during a confusing quest (okay, I get it, there is something about your son and some people who you know so little about and have little tie to the main story line and some baddies who we know little about because they took over your country or something like that and so on), killing people and getting revenge for every Tom, Sam and Harry you find. Gear is pretty meaningless. Upgrading is meaningless, other than you cause more damage bubbles to appear above your enemy when you hit them in your arcade-like fashion.
Not much of an origin story if you ask me.

Then there is Aya. Aya is like Pontus. I just don't want to play as Pontus... I mean Aya. She is so unlikable as a character. I mean annoying to a fault. Cold, shallow, even downright mean. She could have been so much better. So much more likable. Why do we not get more of her story in the beginning? Could we see her descent into coldness, if we must go that path? Or are we just to assume "something bad" happened to her and now she is just this caricature of the stereotypical revenge tale? She was absolutely awful.

As for Bayek? He was cool. But again, not fleshed out to his entire potential. By contrast, think of Ezio - we knew Ezio. We knew his family. We knew why he did what he did. He was a true hero and fun to play. Bayek? Well, he would be fun to hang out with, but otherwise he is also kind of a shallow character who we do not know a whole lot about. Except his son. Who we also do not get a lot of backstory on other than... baddies (sorry, don't want to give out any spoilers). And I mean, he does good for the people. But why, other than gods and country? He is almost - almost - a Mary Sue, were it not for the fact that I died so many times before leveling him up. Anyway...

Now for my last point, and this is one that is very important to me because it can really add a lot to the immersion - the music. What gives with this garbage? I mean, there is so much a composer can do with Middle Eastern or even "fantasy" Egyptian music. But we end up with this techno-down tempo-ambient mess, with the occasional duduk thrown into the background for a few notes of Mid-East flair? Really? I know a lot of games are trending that way these days with the music. But come on - what a missed opportunity here. I could go on, but I will just end this here.

TL;DR - Game is visually beautiful but otherwise utterly simplistic in story, game play and character development. Villains are wooden and hollow, to the point of being little more than straw men. Music is forgettable and mismatched. Ubisoft would do well to return to the AC 2/Brotherhood formula of historical immersion and character development, as well as better story writing. Overall - Two out of Five stars, and reluctantly down voted. Only buy this one if you are an AC story completionist.

Edit* Since upgrading Windows 10 to the Fall Creators update and the recent game update I have experienced 0 crashes after playing a solid 4 hours straight.

Good:
-great gameplay and combat

2. The switch to a semi-RPG with a skill tree, loot, and equipment is honestly a great thing in my opinion. It still feels like Assassin's Creed too which is impressive.
-fantastic graphics
-fun missions and quests
1. Even now 18 hours in I am still finding new mission types and engaging side-quests.
-massive world
-above average campaign
1. It wont blow your mind but its better than most campaigns of recent AAA video games. Also I don't think I'm even
halfway done at 18 hours in so its fairly lengthy, but I am taking my time doing everything.
2. As mentioned above, the side quests are fun and really help flesh out the story of the land of Egypt.

Bad:
-graphics settings dont scale well and your CPU can spike randomly
1. On a GTX 1070 and Ryzen 5 1600 overclocked @ 3.7Ghz, I cannot hit 60 fps even on medium. I can hit 55-57 anywhere from medium to very high. 57 was the max FPS I got even after customizing settings for probably an hour (personally I refuse to put anything lower than medium). I literally only saw an increase of 1-2 fps going from very high settings to medium. I havent been monitoring my CPU but many people say that the game does randomly spike their CPU useage way up, so I will make note of that here.

-bugs and glitches
1. I honestly haven't encountered any memorable bugs or glitches, but I do know some people have had bugs that fail their missions and make them re-do them so I will leave this as a bad part of the game.

-crashes
1. I have experienced my fair share of crashes in the game.

-microtransactions
1. They do have a store where you can buy xp boosts and cosmetic items and even weapons. However, you can get weapons of equal value fairly easily in the game so I would not call it pay to win. Still, I do not support full price games having microtransactions so this is bad to me.

I still highly recommend this. I was in a game rut before this where nothing I played interested me. I was bored of playing video games until I decided to give this a try. It grabbed me right away, and I intend to try and 100% it.

Recommended
103.5 hrs on record
Posted: July 2, 2018
As a huge Assassin's Creed fan, I'm one of the few people that not only have played almost every single entry multiple times, but I would even say Syndicate was my #3 or #2 favorite entry, so with that in mind, I'll say I liked this game but with some problems:

-I like that they changed up the gameplay & the combat dramatically, but I do miss having your fighting/attacks lock onto an opponent. This is more free swinging like Skyrim or Dark Souls. I guess there's nothing wrong with it, but I wasn't in the group of people that was clamoring for change to the gameplay.

-The map is too big. If it was only half the size with half the quests, it would still be absolutely huge. It's nice to say "Look at how big of a map we can make" but ultimately, you're doing the same things over & over in each area just with different level of enemies.

-The story started out great, but by the end, it started to feel like fan fiction of previous Assassin's Creed games. I recall at one point the bad guys were reciting Haytham Kenway lines & it was really cheesy. The concept of the targets/bosses being based off of Egyptian gods (The Ram, The Hyena, The Scarab, The Jackal, etc) was cool, but half of them really had no involvement in anything that would really catch anyone's attention or weren't given any real development or purpose (The Crocodile wasn't given a single word of dialogue until their death scene). That being said, while I did enjoy the twists & the overall story, I would say it was one of the weaker entries along side the stories of Revelations or Unity. I probably also got fatigued with the game for how utterly long & big it is. The thing with these Assassins Creed games is the stories usually involve loss of family members (brothers/father, mother, wife, father/father figure, father, son), I'd like to see something different there.

I'm pretty fatigued from the game after 60-70 hours, and it's pretty disappointing that Oddysey looks exactly the same as this game, so much that it's basically an expansion or season pass with more of the same. I'd like to see more innovation, smaller maps, more focused stories, the return of Brotherhood/allies, less story/twists involving family. I'd also like another game from the Templars perspective like Rogue & would rather they go farther into the future than deeper in the past.

cedo

Recommended
95.6 hrs on record
Posted: November 4, 2017
OK, I'm actually in the middle of playing and I had to come post a review.
I'll do a quick pro/con, and then WHY I felt the need to write a review right away.

PROS:
-The graphics...are...AMAZING. I was actually moved a little watching the sun and god-rays rise up above the wind-swept dunes just to the south of Siwa. This is one of those games that makes you truly understand just how far graphics quality has come over the last decade and a half.

-The combat system is new and sometimes frustrating, but only because you really have to develop the skills to manipulate and time it well compared to the relative easy mastery of the other games. No more invincible assassin, but the new challenge is invigorating and interesting. (Also, it's not terrible, like Unity.)

-The world map so far is wonderfully interactive and exploration is rewarding and fun. As has been stated before, there are still plenty of points of interest and enjoyment, but not the wild "icon spam" seen in past games.

-The main character, Bayek, has a deeply interesting personality and a far more genuine personal story than some of the previous assassins we've come across. He harkens back to the depth of feeling and humanity we saw in both Ezio and Edward Kenway.

CONS:

-There are a few pathing issues with some of the AI, and when you need to follow someone they will occassionally get stuck on a wall or something. I found the issue to be correctable with a good ramming with my camel. Also, AI will be reported as being in one place when tracked by Senu, then suddely shoot 300 feet in another direction and stay there.

-AUDIO ISSUES. By far the only truly annoying con so far. Certain aspects of the audio cut out completely when used with my LOGITECH audio equipment on 5.1 surround. Can't hear character footsteps, dialogue (Good thing I had subs enabled when I started it) water or ambient noises. COULD hear combat noises, character "white noise" (when he grunts while climbing etc.) and loot noises. SELECT dialogue would come through. Fine when used with my plug-in speakers, only affected headset.

-CPU usage is VERY high. I have an Intel 4790k at 3.6 with an overclock to 4.1 with a Corsair H105 closed-loop liquid cooling system. Still running at 75-80% non-stop. Kinda nuts. Shouldn't be seeing quite so much CPU usage when I am running a GTX 1080 TI with 11Gb of memory and 32 Gb of RAM, I feel. But the game runs smooth at 75-90 frames per second on 4K with a 160hz refresh rate, so I'm not really complaining.

------------------------------OK, to the meat of why I was SO EAGER to recommend this game---------------------------
It's as simple as this:

Got a poison weapon.
Ran to the middle of the street.
Hacked down some soldiers guarding a transport of Iron.
REALLLLY busy street, lots of people.
Some of the soldiers get poisoned.
Put bodies in a neat circle in the middle of the street. (Because morbid pictures)
The local citizenry start walking over the bodies and getting sick.
Suddenly, sickness is everywhere.
Foot traffic begins puking and dying by the dozens.
More poisoning happens.
Farmers and marketeers closest to the road are dropping like flies.
Vomit everywhere.
10 minutes later, easily over 150 bodies all up and down the road.
MFW it's spreading like a highly virulent disease.
MFW I started the bubonic plague on a street in Siwa.

Get the World Health Organization in here because people are STILL dying all around me, it's spread all along the road and it keeps getting worse. Bodies have dissapeared and people are still sick and dying and making more bodies.

11/10 would poison the entire highway again.

Recommended
94.7 hrs on record
Posted: December 16, 2018
i like this game, i really do. but at this point in time I was considering to not recommend it. Which is really sad for me actually. The gameplay is good. Story is good. Environment and graphics are amazing. But you will see my point in the following paragraph. Here is my full take on Assassin's Creed Origins. Enjoy...

It takes some getting used to the new combat style, and after the frustrating learning curve it gets a lot better, i still prefer to stick to stealth and archery though. I liked the previous combat style. Thats one of my only gripes with this game. the one other being the free running aspect seems to have gotten more buggy and unresponsive. But, My biggest issue though, is the constant crashing. i dont have a monster computer by any means, it was a powerhouse a few years ago and has now fallen into the slightly above average range. I have the EXACT recommended specs of this game, not the required, the recommended. Yet i still have consistent crashing every 20-40 minutes. I have been able to play for up to an hour and a half straight before but it is pretty rare. I believe it has something to do with a memory problem. i am planning to upgrade my graphics card and ram so i will update if the issue still persists. if it does not then they should really change the recommended specs to something higher than 8 gigs of ram. This game and immersion breaking issue is the reason why I wouldnt recommend it, but i am going to due to the other amazing aspects that make up for the big flaws.

Im a big fan of egyptian lore and mythology and have been since i was a child, and ubisoft does a really good job of immersing you in the world. You are sort of forced into partaking in side quests in order to continue in the main questline. Which i found to be tedious at first, but after getting into a few quests I have found that i thoroughly enjoy the stories and characters in the sidequests. the world is well thought out and is very fleshed out as well. The impact Bayek makes is very noticeable and I really appreciate his character. usually the good guy feels cheesy and forced but in this story it is very natural and I really love how Bayek is a very considerate person who doesnt ask for a thing in return and only cares for the people of Egypt above all else. Even the side quests have emotion and make you feel impacted by the world and the suffering or happiness of certain people and events. The main story is compelling and decently detailed, I do care for the characters and plot, but when you are trying to do some very important thing and end up getting side tracked for literal hours to level your character to progress the story it does kind of fragment and derail the story, pulling you out of it a bit.

I actually find the hunting and resource collecting to be rather fun, even if it is a bit repetitive. Upgrading gear for minor aesthetic changes and increased capability is decently rewarding (im big on aesthetics and being able to modify the looks as you upgrade. the little details make the difference for me). Seeing your work pay off with a slightly upgraded look to the wrist guard or quiver really keeps things fresh and motivates you to spend some time upgrading when you begin to have trouble in combat.

The graphics, are wow. Not much needs to be said, its incredible to say the least, I even tried on the lowest setting to see how it looked and it still looks amazing. They have done an excellent job of bringing Egypt to life. The massive great pyramids covered in white stone and adorned with golden points. Surrounded by a vast and desolate desert. Dune after dune with small rocky outcroppings hiding a cave or camp or a lost temple. The beautiful nile and its rivers jutting deep into the land. The way the farms and cities surround the water ways. When you are at a high vantage point and you can see nothing but dead desert in the distance but the nile is extremely lush and fertile and filled with green and life. Walking the egyptian streets of memphis and their clay houses and ancient temples, or riding on horseback through the streets of the roman themed alexandria with the iconic white pillars and roman styled structures. Simply amazing, a lot of time and effort went into making this and it should defintiely be noted.

Overall the game is great, other than my stagnation to the new combat system and the crashing i mentioned, this game is absolutely phenominal. The story and environment are the best in the series. Oddly enough, it wont be one to stay in my library forever. Its fun to play and left a decent impact but im not obsessed with it in any way like i have been with other games (TES series, the witcher seriesl, etc...). So, even with all the good this game offers, its also pretty bummy to have to deal with sometimes. despite the really irritating crashes, I am going to recommend this. even if your game crashes every 40 minutes, you should definitely give it a go just for the experience, endure the annoyance, its worth it. I guess that would be my full breakdown, Thanks for listening!

Im writing this review from around act 2 with 44 Hours clocked in.

First of all, i've been an die hard AC fan since the very fist one, i completed all of the games on multiple platforms on 100%.

The game is filled with things to do, im 44 hours in and i still haven't even completed Act 2 because i get distracted with the amount of stuff you can do in this game. Side missions are broad and actually fun to do instead of them being a drag in other games. They actually make you feel like you're accomplashing something for the people.

Now when you kill the animal, like in previous games you will have some sort of crafting system, though this time you're actually upgrading your gear directly from your gear menu and it tells you how much its going to improve.

The story is great, it really brings back the old AC feel for me, like how i used to feel when i played the second game in the series, the Ezio trilogy were some of my most beloved games period. This game really makes me become addicted to AC once more.

The history in this game is breathtaking, from pyramids to mummies, to sphynx' to gigantic deserts. This game is packed full with it and it all looks just beautiful.

To keep it short: I â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ love this game and i recommend it to anyone who is either an AC fan or just a really big fan of history, as the amount of history in this is amazing.

Recommended
89.2 hrs on record
Posted: November 6, 2017
I was not sure if I want to buy this game or wait for it to be cracked but I went for the purchase eventually.
I am not a big fan of the recent AC games, they got repetitive, the story got a bit confusing, the mechanics were the same and the must frustrating thing, ironically, was the fact that way too many time, my character climbed a wall when I didn't want him to, randomly jumped in a weird way off a building, stuff like that. And the combat got super easy, you just counter and oneshot or smoke bomb and oneshot. There was no real sense of progression.

ABOUT ORIGINS
The simplest way to describe this game: if Witcher, Farcry and AC had a child, this game will be it. And it's a pretty healthy and cute kid.

The game looks gorgeous and I really enjoy the gameplay aswell. I'm not deep into the story but so far I like it. The leveling system gives you a really good sense of progression, the map is big enough, you encounter a lot of different enemy types that require different tacticts and yes, you can still hidden blade one shot people (if your blade is good enough, more about that later).

COMBAT
If you played Witcher or Shadow of Mordor, the combat system will be familiar but with a very big difference. There is no hand holding when it comes to combat. There is not button that flashes when someone is about to hit you, so you can perfectly counter, dodging wont transform you into SSJ3 Goku and you can't hack and slash your way into any base like an invicible god just by smashing the attack button.

You know when you fight groups if enemies and you are attacking a dude in front of you and you want to switch to someone in the back that's a bit farther away and your character would make a mini leap right in front of him and start attacking? Witcher and Shadow of Mordor are perfect examples of that mechanic. That's not happening here though, if you switch targets and the second targer is 0.5 meters away from the edge of your blade, you will hit the air like a dummy.

This may a be a deal breaker for some but I personally like it. It gives another dimension to the combat system. You have to actualy position yourself in a good spot, block arrows with your shield, have priority targets, use specific weapons against specific enemies and so on. It makes the combat a bit harder, with a higher learning curve but when you end up learning how to properly fight it feels good to take down multiply enemies not because you are the main character but because you mechanically outplayed them.

The combat is also pretty smooth and satisfying. One thing I do not like though is the fact that characters seem to move oddly fast when they charge or when you raise your shield and move around. That may take you off of the emersion but it may be a personal thing idk.

Every weapon is different, they have different attack animations, attack speeds, some swords will make your enemies lose balance and expose their back for higher damage while other weapons will straight up hammer them to the ground.

You have power up attack which is different for every weapon type and a sort of "ultimate" ability that charges up when you fight which is also different for every weapon type. This allows you to really make up your own fighting style and it's pretty satisfying.

When it comes to bows, you again, have multiple types for different situation. You got long bows for long distances that have higher damage but fewer arrows, bows that fire multiple arrows in a row or bows that fire 5 arrows in a single shot for massive damage and so on. They are cool to use plus you can ride your horse/cammel while sitting backwards and fight enemies that are chasing you, like your in the next "Fast and Furious: Burnout Sand" movie.

GEAR "Do it for the loot!"

The rpg system really kicks in here and you have a pretty goot looting system. The outfit is cosmetic but you can upgrade your hidding blade for dmg, "bow glove" for dmg, quiver for more arrow, the other glove for meele dmg, chest thing for health and tool pack for more slots. You upgrade them with resources found all over the map, from killing crocodiles for skin to bandits for wood and other â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥. It has a really cool Farcry vibe.

You can upgrade low level weapons to your current level at the blacksmith. Weapons have different qualityes, from uncommon to legendary, each level up having more perks (like a legenday mace witch is alwasy on fire and you end up burning down everything around you, fun but maybe not for every situation).

GAMEPLAY
I wont talk much about the story since I'm not that far into it but so far its good. The sidequests however are way better than expected. They are legit witcher level sidequests. They have multiple parts, with multiple types of gameplay, from rescue to straight up assasinations and you also get plot twists and good mini stories. I found myself doing a lot of these not only to level up but also because they are good.

I'm playin on Hard dificulty and the enemies are actually hard to beat and it's a good challenge.

The movement got redesigned. It's a whooooole lot more responsive. You always run (there is not sprint button which may sound weird but it feels normal) and if you want to climb up you press a button, if you want to climb down, you press another. No more "aaaah no, no, don't climb that door for no reason, noo why would you jump there, no.. no that way.. "

If feels responsive and smooth. It's a similar to syndicate but more polished and way better than Shadow of Mordor. One thing that I never liked is how you can make every single jump and you always land perfectly on every single edge while sometimes your character literally flies in a really spiderman way to the next building. In Origins, if a jump looks a bit shaky then most likely you won't make it and that's a good thing. You feel more in control and aware of your surroundings.

PERFORMANCE
Yes, the 100% cpu thing is real. It happend to me in Alexandria. BUT I dropped to 40 fps while playing on ultra.
I have a 980ti, i7 4790k and 32ram. The game runs smooth 90% of the time and I'm hopping the fps drop will get patched out but for now it's not a deal breaker. I'm not sure how people with way better PC's than mine are experiencing constant 15fps like I saw in the reviews.

OVERALL
If you liked Witcher and previous AC games, you will like this one aswell. I think it's a really good direction, it still has that AC vibe but with a richer experience. I'm glad I bought it.

So I have never written a review on here before, but I feel obligated after listening to all of the bad reviews. I almost didn't buy the game at all because of all of the people who argue that they have elite computers that have to try too hard in order to play the game, or saying they couldn't play at all because of framerate, etc. I'll address some of the issues I have read, and then leave a more positive review at the bottom.

I'm pretty positive most of the people who argue that their computer is overpowered and should be able to easily run the game, have a computer greater than mine and I completed the game with relatively no issue. I did have a couple crashes, but I changed some things to keep my computer cooler and the crash rate plummeted. I rarely, if ever, had a frame rate issue. No, my settings are not maxed, because I don't need to boost my own ego and rate the game based on if my computer can play it on ultimate settings rather than the actual game itself. Most of the comments here that are negative, do say the game is great but they disliked something Ubisoft did. Ubisoft has virtually always screwed the customer somehow, but you knew that before you bought the game and if you really didn't like them you would have stopped buying Assassin's Creed way earlier in the franchise.

The next review I read was about having to rush to complete the community event. After the event became active, the players had a full week to get to the required level and complete the event. At no point at all did I rush through any part of the game, let alone the story, to achieve the level needed and complete the event in time. In fact, I have almost double the hours in the game as one of the posters who made this complain and took my time to complete literally everything. I have all of the achievments for Steam and all of the available ones compelted for the Ubisoft Club. I loved the game, the view, and the experience and I'm not understanding how anyone needed to rush when you were probably a quarter to half of the level requirement before the event came out because I even got the game late.

The last group of reviews I want to counter is the cost and the additional DLC. I did buy the Gold Version for the season pass and I'm not at all put off by the company offering additional resources for more money. Why? Because they are not at all necessary. There are outfits and weapons available, which you can easily get equal to or better versions of by actually playing the game or some of the free options Ubisoft offers. The resources offered are literally called "Time Savers" as in when you are too lazy to grind like in any other RPG and get the things you want, you pay for the easy way out. I admittedly did use one of these items with the free Helix points you start with and so there is no loss to me, only a little boost. I will admit the resources can be short if you don't prioritize what you're spending them on, but without spoiling parts of the gameplay I can't really go further into that. I guess that falls into the "feeling rushed" comment from earlier. If you actually want the items/upgrades it is very easy to simply work for them. Want vs Need. It's basic.

For the actual game, it is extremely large. There is nowhere within the map that you can't go; most buildings are open and you can climb virtually any mountain when walking to a destination. Some battle types were a little frustrating, but that was just a personal thing really and the game itself was great. The kill animations for all of the weapon types were awesome and well though out. You never end a battle just dropping a guy and walking away. There is a bow and weapon combo for everyone.

The story line was very intriuging and after doing a little research I found there was actually a lot of truth to it (as in most of the Assassin's Creed games) and I enjoyed running into a lot of the historical figures and handling the plot twists throughout the game. The game also has a unique way of starting the Brotherhood since this was suppose to preceed the other games.

TL:DR, Game good, reviews bad.

ungeni

Recommended
33.2 hrs on record
Posted: February 17, 2018
Assassin's CreedÂ® Origins, while definitely a must-buy, is not a "revitalization" of the series that everyone claims it is. I've liked all of the Assassin's Creed games to date and this simply furthers the franchise into great environments and time periods.

The game play is essentially the same as every previous entry, with the exception of a new combat system. The new combat was at first unlikable, but once I got used to it, I really liked it. Everyone seems to be praising the "RPG elements" and how this has revitalized the franchise. It appears however, that anyone will call anything an RPG these days.


Let me be clear: There are absolutely no RPG elements found in this game. You can purchase different weapons and different outfits just as any previous entry. The main difference with Origins, is that the mission structure is less linear. The game is open world and you can choose whether to engage in the main quests or side quests. Granted, side quests are better than in previous entries, where you would go around pick-pocketing others or doing small assassinations. Here, the side-quests are a little more involved.

Does that mean this is an improvement? Well no. Side-quests suffer from the Fallout 4 problem. "Go here, kill this. Go there, kill that". There's not a lot of variety and most of the side-quests are boring. The issue with this is that the game has an artificial level system. Once you get enough experience, you level up. But enemies have levels too, and many side-quests and main quests are restricted to you until you level up, simply because the enemies become almost impossible to beat until you reach their level. This means that in order to progress the story, you need to engage in a series of boring side quests to level up. In this regard, the game actually suffers because of its so lauded "RPG elements".

That being said, the story was engaging and the environments fascinating. The contrast between the Egyptian, Greek and Roman cities brings quite a bit visually to the game. Egypt itself also has a number of good looking environments, from rocky desert mountains, to sand dunes, to the marshy delta of the Nile. It's quite fun just to ride your horse from objective to objective, taking in the scenery. The game also does show you the origin of the Assassin's Brotherhood, as well as the Templars, but I found it all a bit rushed. The main focus of the story is the vendetta of Bayek (the main character) and the origin of the brotherhood takes a back-seat. The story itself was great, but it was hindered because of the leveling wall that kept getting put up. I was engaged enough to want to continue the story, and yet I couldn't because I had to do some lackluster side mission or five in order to get where I could progress.

Concerning some minor spoilers, I wasn't a fan of the way Caesar was treated in this game. He was quite out-of-character and was put in a position that he shouldn't belong in. I've also heard rumors of the next entry of the Assassin's Creed franchise going with a Medieval viking setting. While I would be interested, I would hope instead that it goes the route of continuing the evolution of the Assassins in ancient Rome, as this game seems to set up.

Origins has a few other features worth mentioning. Gladiator fights, while limited, are extremely fun, due to the new combat system. You can also engage in chariot races, though I never really got the hang of it. Some might find it fun, but I didn't invest enough time in it to get any good, so I wouldn't know. Origins also returns naval combat to the game, though it is limited to just a few story missions. It was fun to blast other ships with barrages of fire arrows and ram them, as opposed to shooting off cannons. Naval combat isn't nearly as in-depth as Black Flag or Rogue, but it is welcome for short segments and is just present in just the perfect amount.

So is the game worth a purchase? Besides its flaws, I still recommend it. As a fan of the franchise, I liked it just as well as all the previous ones. The so-called 'RPG elements" are annoying and hinder your progress, but overall I found the game enjoyable.

It almost seems like the blag flag team has completely read my mind and addressed almost everything I hated about the old AC games.

- No more 90's collectathon gameplay. Secrets are no longer just stamped on your minimap just waiting for you to pick it up. This game actually expects you to explore and look for these things on your own, with some items giving riddles that lead you on to possible sidequests. FINALLY

- The long awaited move away from the batman counter combat. It feels a little floaty, and it's not quite there yet, but it's such a huge leap in the right direction.

- Sidemissions are FINALLY induvidual and varied. THANK GOD.

There are some fps drops regardless of what settings your on. This game needs a CPU optimization patch, other than that it's still a beautiful open world with a lot to do. Honestly, for the most part, this game is really good mostly because it borrows heavily on the best from other popular games, but it's leaps and bounds better than what has been going on. I can only hope AC continues to go down this path.

This means just to launch it i have to launch steam, Uplay, google and emails, get the code, apply it to Uplay and only then can i even think of launching this game... why is it in 2017-2021 we seem to have lost the mystical art of launching a game the simple way?

As far as the actual game I will admit i have not played assassins creed since black flag and the whiplash of all the collective changes really hurt my view of the game. It feels nothing like the older titles leading me to believe that they abandoned that original vision that started this ohh so long ago.

The game is built in a very arcade simplistic style compared to other games. graphics were better in basically every older AC title with exception of maybe the original and that is perhaps a tie. The combat system got revamped to boost difficulty and, while i like seeing them try they did a very poor job at it. target lock sucks to use and since you don't auto-position for parries it basically forces you to dodge so it feels a lot more like dark souls than anything. As for the good things. I like the callable mount and i wish you could summon a boat. we already have the horse/camel so why not. The leveling system did introduce some interesting skills though some of them blatantly ripped off of shadow of war such as the slo-mo while shooting arrows mid air. the world feels very alive for a AC game and the environment is very immersive. I really enjoy the weekly challenges and other similar things.

All in all its an ok game but, there are some major backtracks for what little we gained in comparison to older AC titles imo. its not worth 60$ by any means. maybe half off its ok.

I got ASSASSIN'S CREED ORIGINS and ODYSSEY at about the same time. These two games are the only ASSASSIN'S CREED games I have ever played so I cannot compare it to previous games of that series.
ORIGINS is a 2017 release while ODYSSEY is a 2018 release and is technically superior, despite using the same engine. I cannot really pick a favorite out of the two - I prefer the setting of ORIGINS (Ancient Egypt) to ODYSSEY (Ancient Greece) but that is just personal preference and does not mean that Greece is boring. I did prefer playing a female character (Kassandra) in ODYSSEY, ORIGINS has no character choice, although the character Bayek is well voice acted and much better than Alexios from ODYSSEY.
I guess ORIGINS is closer to the AC series, as the characters in ODYSSEY are not really assassins but mercenaries. They are over-powered, especially in the later part of the game and you are not required to use the stealth apporach, in the conquest battles you cannot even use stealth at all, while Bayek from ORIGINS is more vulnerable.
Both games allow maximum exploration, which I love, ODYSSEY has the better leveling system, you level faster and get to chose the perks/skills you want directly, while ORIGINS seems a bit slow and requires you to chose skills that you do not want in order to get those that you want.
Storywise ODYSSEY beats ORIGINS as well as in the side show: cultists, nemesis light, decisions(!), etc. the areas are of a specific level but will level up with the player if they exceed that level. All this stuff got me going on, just one more question mark, just one more camp... 50+ hours went by real quick.
ORIGIN's world looks better - again that Ancient Egypt bonus - even though is is mostly a desert, it looks marvelous. Also I felt more like an assassin on a personal quest rather than a mercenary.
There is however one major issue I have with the AC series: the animus and the story bits in the present. They tear you out of the immersive world to do really stupid "quests" (drink coffee, eat something) with a bland, uninteresting character (Layla). It serves absolutely no purpose and is annoying as hell. I wish Ubisoft would just ditch that entire present day garbage.

290.5 hrs on record
Posted: October 30, 2017
Edit: (11/2021) 4 years later, new processor and gfx card (Ryzen 3600 and RTX2070), performance is perfect, technology solves the stuttering problem so the devs don't have to. It could be I used to have an Intel processor and now I have AMD, whatever fixed it the game now runs well.

This is my second go at this review, I really need a middle option because simply recommending AC:Origins or not doesn't cover how the game has performed for me. As far as gameplay and story are concerned everything seems good, unfortunately I can not say the same for performance. I am changing my recommendation to Yes, but I have reservations.

Initially I didn't recommend the game because my i5-6600, GTX 1060 6GB, 16GB system was having severe performance problems related to 100% CPU usage. This is something I consider unacceptable on a system that comes in above the minimum recommended specifications. Eventually after a few hours of trouble shooting I managed to get to an acceptable level of performance by having Environmental Detail on its lowest setting and using Adaptive Sync at 30fps. It is important to note however that this does not solve all problems and the game still freezes for seconds at a time, this is in the opening area, I fear getting to larger cities in case the game performance drops back down to unacceptable levels.

It would seem that now is the time games are going to push CPU's to the limit instead of graphics cards and that is a good thing, but it feels as though the development team have gone too far too fast with this game. i7 processors are nowhere near the norm for the majority of gamers and it feels like they have tried to push gaming forward by ignoring what i5 4 core/4 thread processors are actually capable of.

They have made a good game, this is not in doubt, if they had made a good game that performed well at the minimum specs they published it would be so much better.

AcidPith
109 products in account
0
2 people found this review helpful 0

Recommended
129.0 hrs on record
Posted: December 31, 2017
I really enjoyed Assassin's Creed Origins, but it is not without flaws.

Pros:
The game heavily borrows from The Witcher 3 and that's okay.
The graphics were good, but not as good as AC: Unity. Unity had the best lighting, materials/textures, and character detail/animations of all the AC games.
Huge, highly detailed open world.
I played on Normal difficulty and found it to be a nice casual experience.
There's lots of options on how to approach situations like Roman forts, but I tended to go for the most efficient way of just sniping guards with the Predator bow. It really felt a little too easy, but that may also be because I was playing on Normal difficulty. If you play on Hard or Nightmare, you may need to use all the extra gadgets and techniques to be successful. Otherwise, all the extra stuff just felt like you had to go out of your way to set them up and execute them whereas just stealth sniping with the Predator bow got the job done very quickly.
Lots of different types of weapons to suit your playstyle, but I got the Legendary Mustapha's Blade early which has instant-charging and I pretty much stuck with that throughout the whole game. Instant charged attacks is just really really strong.
I spent a lot of time just enjoying the scenery and a lot of time sailing around the lake south of Alexandria.

Cons:
Bugs. You will encounter them every now and then. Nothing game breaking, just silly.
The world is huge, but the cities and towns felt small. I feel like Alexandria should have been 10x its size in-game. There's a loading screen tip talking about all the stuff in Alexandria and that doesn't compare to what we actually have in-game. Maybe I'm just comparing them to the size of Paris and London from the previous AC games.
Combat can be clunky. If you fight with your back against a wall, the wall will occlude your camera and you can't really see anything. When using your overpower ability, it doesn't target the enemy that you have targeted - it will often go for some random enemy behind your target or even something completely behind you, wasting the ability. You will get stun-locked often when fighting multiple enemies.
The tools were kind of useless. The poison darts didn't always kill the target and took awhile to run its full course. The sleep darts were great although the sleep didn't last very long. I played on Normal difficulty so I didn't really have to use them but maybe they were more necessary on the higher difficulties. The firepots were useless since they did so little damage. I guess you're supposed to throw them on oil pots but by the end of the game you have bows with fire arrows anyway. You can also throw infinite torches to light oil on fire. Berserk is okay but it wasn't in dart form like the previous AC games which made it annoying. It's just easier to assassinate a target than to Berserk them.
Telltale signs of content that was cut from the game. If Bayek catches on fire, one of his voice lines says something like "I should get that repaired", yet there's no repair mechanic in-game despite blacksmiths and tailors everywhere. Repairing was either cut or it's a jab at the repairing mechanic in The Witcher 3. There's another voiceline that I've only encountered once while randomly walking in a Roman fort talking about a "good boy". I didn't catch the name of who he was referring to, but I think it was supposed to be a horse since his eagle is female. However, there's no one horse like Roach in The Witcher 3. I get the impression that the devs were testing different things for horses such as having one horse (Roach approach), not owning horses at all, and the current approach. There's a lot of things that hint that at some point the player didn't have a horse that they could instantly call from anywhere because there are stables everywhere with a horse available to the player, there are horses just laying around the cities and villages that you can hop on, and even one of the abilities lets you hijack a horse that already has a rider. There's no point in any of those when you can just summon your own horse instantly from anywhere. The Bureau doesn't feel complete to the point of why is it even there other than to get buy the 1000 xp tablets.
There needs to be more variation in activities. It gets to the point where the activities are just clear a Roman Fort or loot a treasure chest. They are essentially the same activity since the Roman forts have treasure chests that you need to loot to "clear" them and the loot treasure chest activities usually are guarded by Romans. There's SO many of these activities and they're all the same. It was very grindy to finish them all.
I don't presonally like desert environments in games and there was a lot of that in Egypt.
There's not enough natural xp from cleaing all the activities and doing all the side quests to unlock all of Bayek's abilities. Once you hit level 40, you can keep leveling up to gain another ability point which is nice, but I've done everything so the only xp I get is from killing guards for 10-20 xp each or the daily quest. You can buy 1000 xp items for 1000 drachmas, but getting money isn't easy after clearing everything either.
Some of Bayek's abilities are just kinda meh. Why hijack a horse when you can assassinate the rider and then hop on their horse or just call for your own horse from anywhere?
Hippodrome is so damn annoying. It's basically RNG. Just keep playing it over and over until you win. If you're a masochist, complete it once and then never return.
I was let down by the Hoarde Mode in the arena. It touts being able to use your own weapons to fight, but you can't use your bows. I really wanted to use my bows in the arena. There's only two events in the arena where you can use a provided warrior bow.
I didn't like that enemies could be a higher level than 40 but I was capped at 40. That didn't make sense.
Rules that apply to you don't always apply to enemies. For example, I could be standing in a fire and catch on fire but some of the enemies would be standing in it fighting me and never catch on fire.
The Final Fantasy crossover quest was stupid and jarringly lore-breaking. I say lore-breaking because I didn't know that it was a Final Fantasy crossover when I started the quest and it really threw me off not knowing what the hell that I was witnessing and how it fit in with the Assassin's Creed universe.
The present day story didn't really advance much at all, just like the previous games. I'm kind of bummed about that as I'd like more on the present day stuff.

I give AC: Origins a solid 8/10. It would be a 9/10 if my above cons were addressed. If you like open world third person action RPGs, try it. I recommend the Normal difficulty to give a more casual experience. I can see the higher difficulties being frustrating with the clunky combat.

Recommended
62.0 hrs on record
Posted: January 31, 2021
SUMMARY
"We are the first to see the gods. The first to tame their beasts. The first to guard the soul from evil. We conquered this land and built an Empire. But there are whispers on the wind. A Brotherhood born in the shadows. They are the first to call themselves... The Assassins. The Creed will last forever. From now on, I will be known as the Hidden One. Papo? Jump !" (Bayek and Khemu). Assassin's Creed Origins is a third-person action-adventure RPG stealth game that will make you fall inlove with drama, romance and history in the times of CLeopatra, Caesar and Ptolemy XIII, all while building your Assassin Brotherhood. The title Origins means that beside unveiling dark secrets, you will find how and why the Brotherhood was created. It is without any doubt one of the best games of the Assassin's Creed series and definitely worth playing for its great story and good combat mechanics.

INFO
- This review is a personal opinion. Try the game for yourself.
- Game was played on max graphics setting and ultrawide resolution.
- The team at Ubisoft poured their blood and sweat in this game. It required around 1000 people and four years to develop this extraordinary game. Unfortunately, the game is quite underrated. While not having massive battles like in Odyssey, Origins has one of the best stories in the series, very interesting chain-quests and some awesome mystery puzzles.
- I played this game first time on Uplay when it was released and for the second time now on Steam (unfortunately you cannot link the Uplay games to Steam if they were bought on Uplay). On the second playthrough I did not find any bugs and even if I had already known the story, the feeling was still great. I would dare say I liked Origins even more than Odyssey.
- Plot starts in 49 BC in Egypt following the adventures of Bayek (a Medjay of Egypt) and his wife Aya. It also takes place in the present day following Layla Hassan, a former researcher for Abstergo Industries, uncovering artifacts and the truth about Bayek and Aya.
- The character's max level is 40 for the main game, 45 for the first DLC (The Hidden Ones) and 55 for the second DLC (The Curse of the Pharaohs).
- To get full legendary gear (and mounts) is fairly easy, but upgrading it to max requires a bit of grinding. Doing enough side-quests, frequent road-looting and looting treasures from killed targets and objectives chests should cover the costs. The same recipe of doing side-quests goes if you feel a bit under-leveled for some story main-quests.

PROS
- Full ultrawide support (very few cutscenes are pre-rendered in 16:9 and pillarboxed).
- A beautiful, well written story about the Ancient Egypt and the Assassin Brotherhood, featuring 128 chain story and side quests (the base game alone) plus more in two DLCs.
- A huge open world with a great, vibrant design of Egypt, along with excellent graphics and love for details. Each region has a different beautiful design, feeling unique and authentic. Egypt modeled in this game is a true spectacle, you will find yourself riding a lot without using the teleports or climbing on top of monuments just to see more of the beautiful scenery.
- A great sensation of scale, be it in the cities, or on top of the Giza pyramid or the Lighthouse of Alexandria. The attention to detail, from the outfits, gear, every house, every corner and statue in a city, to the majestic ancient monuments, the Nile Delta and the mountains, the horses, the ships, the chariots and the personality of main characters in the game, even torches or palm-trees, everything is a piece of art and a show of very hard-work.
- The game is trully a masterpiece from all points of view. On top of that, when you finish the game you get a narrated tour of Ancient Egypt with historical accuracy events and data.
- Egyptians AI are not scarce at all in the cities and they all speak real Egyptian. Each AI has a routine every day (such as working during daytime and sleeping at night and traveling on a set path). Most of the quest-givers do not stay in a fixed position. For most chain-quests, players can choose the time of day to assassinate their targets. Factions respond differently to players.
- Beautiful cutscenes, great soundtrack, good voice-acting.
- Very good, fluent, solid mechanics for combat, climbing / parkour, stealth, sailing. Once discovered, the "leap of faith" points can be used for fast-travel (teleport). Naval combat has its own mechanics and beauty. The night-day mechanic (where the character meditates to change it) is a good addition.
- Plenty of chain side-missions, puzzles and collectibles for completionists.

CONS
- The two DLCs (The Hidden Ones and The Curse of the Pharaohs) should have been part of the main game, or at least implemented into a Definitive Edition.
- Only one ending (compared with Odyssey where you have 9 possible endings or with Valhalla where you have 2 endings).
- In-game micro-transactions (drachmas, outfits, horses, gear, ability points and maps for hidden locations).
- As for all Ubisoft games, you must play it using the Uplay client (it is now called Ubisoft Connect).
- If you bought the game on Uplay and want to have it on Steam collection with achievements and all, you can't. You need to buy the game on Steam again for that.

Recommended
214.5 hrs on record
Posted: December 31, 2017
This is everything I ever wanted out of the Assassin's Creed series in terms of gameplay. You no longer simply press counter to auto-kill your enemy, the parkour button no longer makes you sprint so now you don't automatically stick to every surface in the game while trying to navigate tight spaces and quests and items are more meaningful to your character's progression instead of being a mindless collectathon.

Out of the countless things I love about the game, the immersive nature of the world itself is my favorite part. Setting a goal for yourself, such as a quest half way across the map, and navigating your way there based solely on landmarks while getting into exiting adventures lasting several hours or more never got boring. There was always something new and interesting to see and do which is something I never thought I'd say about an Assassin's Creed game. If you're familiar with the series you'll notice a strong conscious effort by the developers to do away with everything people were annoyed with in the previous entries. Among other things it lets you untrack quests so there are no waypoints, you don't desynchronize if you stray too far away from your target and it's almost impossible to get stuck while riding your mount since it can jump over obstacles and down steep cliffs.

The story and characters of the Assassin's Creed games has never been able to live up to the second game's memory and I'm sad to say that still hasn't changed. Origins' effort is certainly an improvement over later entries but it still doesn't reach the same level of character development and mystery that Assassin's Creed 2 had. I think a part of the reason for that is that Ezio was a rich kid playboy turned super cool assassin and as far as living vicariously through a video game character goes it doesn't get much better than that. I also don't like that the present day plot is basically optional at this point. There are a lot of notes with plenty of backstory on present day events and characters if you read through it but it's never presented to the player as a priority. I see this as a blatant compromise by the developers to please both those who like the present day plot and those who don't. I'd prefer it if it was given a more prominent place in the narrative as a whole.

The best thing about the game however is that you can perform fighting animations in the animus loading screen again! That hasn't been a thing since Revelations and I've always missed it. Ironically I'm playing with an SSD now so even though it's back I still don't get to enjoy it. C'est la vie. And I'm not usually a sucker for social features but photo mode is quite ingenious. Now you can spend an embarrassingly large amount of time getting the lighting and framing just right before posting your picture only for it to be completely ignored by the community while a far more mediocre one gets thousands of likes. Just like in real life! The attention to detail is something I never expected to see from an Assassin's Creed game. For example, did you know that if you wiggle the left stick while controlling Senu she'll do a barrel roll? I'm very impressed by the game and remain optimistic about the future of the series.

I haven't finished the game yet, and as far as progress through the main story I haven't gotten all that far yet either, but I can already recommend this game very very emphatially.

ACO is essentially a return to what I loved about the AC franchise from the start. I fell in love with AC2, but unfortunately from that point on it seemed like the series lost its way. It wasn't so much about the basics anymore, and I lost interest because I played AC to, basically, be an assassin, not to rebuild towns or play some weird combination of AC and Civilization.

ACO strips all that other crap away and goes back to what I loved about the games. The setting is gorgeous, the cities feel alive, the plot is just enough to keep the motivation there without being too much. It's basically about just being an assassin again, and while the missions can get a bit repetitive the scenary is more than enough to keep me going.

So if you gave up on the AC franchise kind of like I did, give this one a shot. It might remind you why you liked it in the first place.

Posted: January 7, 2019
Takeaway: A strange but competent entry to the AC series that continues to breakaway from expected franchise norms.

Pros:
-Good graphics
-Massive open world to explore
-Quests have a lot of variation and are reasonably long
-Some built in "cheat"/"game modding" options

Cons:
-Stealth feels more like a gimmick than an actual choice (really weird for an AC entry)
-Tepid revenge plot
-Very limited secondary weapon/tool options (compared to previous AC games, this felt like a big step backwards, & further hurts the game's stealth)
-Gated content (thanks to a new leveling system)
-Loot boxes & the accompanying grind mechanics

Conclusion:
Still good but didn't really feel like an Assassin's Creed game, it could've been called "GTA Ancient Egypt" with it's lackluster stealth experience & bizarre quests.

5,757 products in account

Recommended
193.8 hrs on record
Posted: November 7, 2019
The best AC game since Black Flag. It is a huge change from the established AC formula but the series desperately needed one. This game adds some RPG elements into the game, including a skill tree, and a major focus on level progression. The combat system has been completely reworked. It is well done and precise, but the lack of variation in it can get pretty boring, at least in the beginning. It gets better once you start unlocking more skills, though. The previously mentioned level progression is some of the most extreme I have ever seen. Sometimes it works well, making certain enemies and areas a fun challenge if you choose to try them before you should, but many times it is way too over the top, making enemies literally impossible to beat. The difference between you and a standard grunt that is five levels above you is so drastic that it basically becomes a Dark Souls fight: don't get hit or you die instantly and hack away at him for 10 minutes. This is especially frustrating when it comes to the "Assassinate" ability, since you can't kill someone who is a higher level than you with it, which severally hampers the "stealth" style of gameplay. The best part of the game is by far the Phylakes. The are basically optional bosses in the game that can be found roaming around the map, or will come to you if you "mess up" while clearing the local fort. These are the intentional Dark Souls fights of the game whether you are the same level as them or not and they get intense. They also drop the best loot. The two DLC expansions are also pretty good.

Recommended
92.1 hrs on record
Posted: November 5, 2017
Vivid historiacal characters (Cleopatra, Caesar...) and deities (Amun, Horus...). Stunning scenery. Intense combats. The assassinating system did change somehow (level barriers are really hard to get over...), but think about it: this is 49 B.C., the creed had just formed. Sometimes fightings are necessary instead of just assassinating all the time. You'll see how the first people of the creed gathered and learnt their ways of doing things.

The setting is Ptolemaic Dynasty - almost the end of ancient Egypt, which means that tombs of real pharaohs (or officials) throughout the ancient Egypt calendar, from Djoser to Smenkhkare, remain for you to explore. And these tombs are well-detailed, with hieroglyphic texts (fortunately Bayek knows how to read those lol), grave goods, mummies, and the four pots holding the organs... Have you ever wanted to dig into the three Pyramids in Giza? Or to get inside the Great Sphinx? Or to witness the mummification process? This is the game that can realize your wish. You'll even have the chance to face the deities themselves - Anubis, Sekhmet, Sobek, and so on - and get their theme outfits.

Okay this is not a Tomb Raider review (but again most of these are real tombs existing or existed) so besides that, great protray of famous cities - Alexandria, Memphis, Krokodilopolis... Also great portray of people's struggle in this time period, of Egyptians' anger and complaints about the invading Greek/Roman culture. People's everyday lives are simulated based on the day and night system over this huge open-world map of Egypt.

The Hidden Ones & Rise of the Pharaohs DLCs. The Hidden Ones is simply an extended map and story based on the assassins, which is not too much of a surprise. However the second DLC absolutely is to me. In this DLC, map of the Valley of the Kings is available for players, and a new long exciting story based on the revival of four of the most well-known pharaohs throughout the history - Ahenaten, Nefertiti, Tutankhamun, and Ramesses II. The first two are known for their abolition of the multi-deity god system, replacing which with one single god Aten. Tutankhamun, son of Ahenaten, after claiming his throne, re-established original deity system and is of course, also known for his golden death mask. Ramesses the Great, on the other hand, is not part of this disputation but is known for the great military power he brought to ancient Egypt during his reign. What I cannot expect more of this DLC are the chance players have to enter these pharaoh's afterlives, from their tombs, and the new lengendary outfits & weapons awarded after the afterlife missions.

The new Discovery Tour mode, offers the choice of visiting all important places around Egypt with a vocal guide, and no fights will be elicited. (You will not take damage from no matter how high you jump from.) Great design for people who want to chillax from all the fightings and enjoy their Egyptian vacation. Also, the built-in photo mode is an incredible tool for screenshot lovers. I've never seen anything like this in any games before.

Overall, a must-play for AC fans and for those who are into ancient Egyptian culture/mythology. Thank you so much for bringing these mythical creatures and lengendary sceneries back to life. Absolutely Amazing.
