In the past I have tried to be an AC fan. I could never really bite into the first one, all that Abstergo stuff, and the weird matrix borders in a game seemingly set in the past. It was like you could never really get immersed. But I loved the Prince of Persia style parkour, and the idea. Always loved the idea.

Then I played the fifth one, Black Flag, being a huge fan of nautical games I could not resist. And it was better, it fixed a lot. The world seemed more open, the character had more, well, character. It was highly enjoyable, but I always chalked it up to the fact they had thrown in a pirate theme.

So then Origins came out. And I watched, and I waited. Having played Witcher 3 to the point of breaking, I was looking for something similiar. This seemed right, but, I told myself, it is AC. There will be matrix borders and Abstergo nonsense, and I will probably not dig the character. No pirates.

But I rolled the dice. And I won.

This game is phenomenal.

I am not even done with the main story. I have completed tons of side things and have not even scratched the surface of the amount of side things. I still have I believe 6 or 7 regions I the map is dark on, a couple more the map shows but only because I peeked in and then left, and have not touched DLC. 70 hours of gameplay, and I feel like I am not even near 50%. And that excludes wandering around, taking photos, and just generally enjoying the scenery.

The map is HUGE. The world feels so alive, and just right. I read many reviews, and heard complaints of nothing to do. Nonsense. The map makes perfect sense. By the Nile there are tons of towns and tons of people, lots of activity. Out in the desert and the rocky platues? Not so much. Makes perfect sense to me. But just when you get comfortable with the idea that nothing is out there, boom, bandits ambush you. It is absolutely perfect.

Combat is beatiful, smooth. Weapons are varied, love the different bows for different situations.

Characters are excellent. So many good characters. I have found myself laughing out loud multiple times. Bayek is a really likable character, and yet kind of not. Which I feel is just right. It is like he likes what he does, as far as standing up for the people, but does not like what he must do. And I get that feeling as the player at times in this game. Seen some reviews negatively speaking of quests, and yes, many are essentuilly repeats as far as mechanics. For example you find yourself having to rescue someone from a cage a LOT. However it is the characters and the story surrounding the mechanics that I find wipe away the repetition. They did a wonderful job as far as I am concerned.

I have to say it, this game has made me, after years, and a few tries, an AC fan. It is so gorgeous. At first I wanted a way to turn off the shared screen shots on the map thing, thought it spoiled some views and tombs etc. But now I am actively taking photos and watching for them to show up on the map lol. Even the stupid photo mode gimmick has me hooked. Then there is the hippodrome for chariot racing which is quite entertaining, and the arena.

I really can not say enough about this game. If you are at all on the fence, and if you are looking for your next free roam open world game, this is it. My only regret on this one is not picking it up sooner. Although the sale price is amazing. Picked up gold edition for the price of standard. 150% worth it.

Recommended
210.1 hrs on record
Posted: November 2, 2017
A fresh start

The Assassin's Creed franchise has been around since 2007 and this year mark the 10 year anniversary of the series.

Over the 3 last years Assassin's Creed had some ups and downs but one major complain that most of the players had was that the games were becoming repetitive and stale. Assassin's Creed Origins however feels new, fresh and shows how a franchise can evolve.

Assassin's Creed Origins is an RPG action adventure game that tells the story of Bayek, a Medjay from Siwa that seeks revenge from a group called The Order Of The Ancients, while we get to see how the assassin brotherhood that we know formed from scratch.

In terms of world design, Ancient Egypt is vast, full of colors and the locations feel unique from the barren deserts to the city of Alexandria, all locations have a different feel and ambience. The world is also full of activities for you to keep you busy like outposts to loot, tombs to raid and treasures to find.

The soundtrack differs from calm ambient music that is fitting for exploration to energetic music that pumps you up from for the combat.

Speaking of combat the parry and attack system is gone, now we have a hitbox style of combat that resembles the Dark Souls series. While the animations are rough in the edges, it finally adds some challenge that the series needed.

The side missions or this time around side quests are more open ended and you can tackle them whenever and however you like, also it is a good way for you to gain XP all the while you get to experience different stories and mysteries to solve.

Also it's worth mentioning two large activities : the hippodrome and the gladiator arena where you challenge yourself in tournaments that test your skills in chariot racing and combat respectively.

To sum it up its safe to say that Assassin's Creed Origins it's a solid title that will bring back to the series old players and also bring new players to the series. The game is beautiful from start to finish and that shows how much work the developers put into it.

I give it 9.0/10 and you should definitely give it a try.

P.S. Don't mess with the hippos.

Best game in its' series. Haven't run into any resource issues, runs just fine on highest settings.

Weapons styles are all extremely unique - not just appearance.
Mounted combat is actually decent and viable in many situations.

Story so far is wonderful - love the Egyption atmosphere, and the many places to explore.
The world is HUGE - each one of the 37 (i believe) maps has at least 3-4 hours of playtime before you have done all of the quests and storyline missions. Massive amounts of content that don't seem to repeat, always fresh.
Love the additional content when outside of the animus - characters are new, and well acted.
Spent a couple hours just reading emails and files to catch up on the back story.

Also interesting side content such as ship battles and chariot races that are actually sort of fun.
Crafting system is perfect - nothing is wasted, as everything you upgrade is just.. attached to your character and never replaced.

Well placed boobs, not overdone at all.

Perfect level of tactics and strategy by using your bird.
The hardest difficulty setting makes for a wonderful challenge - anything is Possible, but going head to head against anyone 2+ levels higher than you will be Exremely challenging, and will likely take multiple attempts.

Weapon upgrade system is great - have a favorite weapon? Just spend the money every few levels to keep it at your same level.

Blows my mind how the developers were able to come up with so much unique content in such a short period of time. Well done.

Recommended
241.9 hrs on record
Posted: March 17, 2020
One of the best ACs in my opinion and one of my favourites. Miles better than Odyssey, so if you're going for a recent AC game, buy this.

Egypt is beautifully handcrafted, and incredibly detailed. NPCs all have schedules, the audio design is perfect and it really feels authentic and lived in. This is in no small part to how diverse each biome is: they all feel distinct and provide a new experience, and make exploring really damn fun. Going for 100% completion feels like less of a chore, not just due to the biomes but because every single location you can visit to tick off on the map is enjoyable. This is because each location is individual: no two locations are the same, and that alone just demonstrates how much love was put into this game.

The characters and acting are top notch. Abubakar Salim makes Bayek one of the most relatable and likeable AC protagonists since Ezio. You can hear and feel the rage in the delivery of his lines: two notable examples are the cutscene with Rudjek at the start of the game and later on with one of the targets in the Faiyum. Alix Wilton Regan plays Aya, Bayek's wife, and their chemistry just makes their relationship believable, and more than just a shallow thing. There are other examples, but these two just do such a splendid job.

The gameplay is really fun. The RPG style combat feels fun and satisfying, and can be difficult on the harder difficulties if you don't know what you're doing. But regular enemies don't feel spongey whatsoever, so long as you aren't fighting a level that is miles higher than you. The bosses are of course more spongey - but they're damn good fun. The phylakitai (bounty hunters) you encounter throughout the game are awesome as you can either track them down or they will track you down, sometimes while you're in the middle of a fight or clearing a fort - making you adapt to the situation and making you think as to whether you can afford to face them head or or whether you need to avoid them entirely, and come back to them later. Stealth is also great in this game. It's challenging at times as you can get spotted really easy but it retains it's simplicity and fun, and you really do feel like an assassin clearing an encampment without any detections.

In regards to negatives, the only thing I didn't like was how rushed the story felt for the final few hours. You can tell because of how much effort they put into the rest of the game and the environment, they weren't able to fully polish and refine the final few targets. It feels as if you have no connection to these enemies and one has you wondering as to who the hell they are and where you've seen them before. But I feel this hardly detracts from the rest of the game as a whole, as despite the rushed ending it still delivers a satisfying conclusion.

Should you buy this game? Yes. Absolutely yes.

Recommended
1,559.3 hrs on record
Posted: January 10, 2018
Wow.

Let's start by saying I am a huge fan of the Assassin's Creed series, and Witcher 3 is my favorite game of all time. Considering this game is like the two had an illegitamate love child, it is freaking amazing to me.

Here is my attempt to articulate why.

-Gameplay

Fantastic. Let's get one thing straight, AC origins is a long game. It took me near 80 hours to finish my first playthrough. Even at hour 79 I was still loving it. Zero boredom, even after I beat the main story and was just clearing the leftover areas of interest I had missed. The combat is good. Sword play is pretty standard, but once you learn some more moves it becomes a little more nuanced than just hack and slash. I really enjoyed the addition of real ranged combat. Not the silly auto aim hold a button to shoot from old games. Real, aim down the "sites", third person shooting. (with bows) The quest structure is great, in addition the the main story lines each section is filled with side quests that help flesh out what is going on. For example, an oppresed area may see you kill the head oppressor, but the side quests will have you helping out the various oppressed people in the area. Fun, varied, engrossing, and well designed.

-Graphics

A stunner. This is, in my opinion, the most gorgeous open world game I have ever played. Maybe even the most gorgeous game period. From the incredibly realistic water to the fire that pops off the screen, as vibrant as real life, this game is stunning. The wind sweeps up the dust that was just kicked up into the air by your footsteps, accurately illimunated by the suns rays. Different pieces of cloth bounce up and down individuily as you run, the layers moving independently yet interconnectedly. The smoke from the fires rises up in the air, some of it more visible/illuminated than other parts depending on if it is in direct sunlight or not. Deep green leaves, colorful foliage, even the golden sand is beautiful. Just gorgeous all around.

-Upgrade System

Man is it nice to have an AC with some character progression and perks to choose. Think FF 15 style upgrades. Branching paths of related perks that increase a certain aspect of your characters abilities. There is a ranged path, hand to hand path, and a "tools" path (smoke bombs that can hurt people, sleep darts, fire bombs, etc) Really gives you a reason to get out there and do every mission for that XP. Also, weapons and armor have perks now, and different levels of quality. This style of loot and character building fit into the AC gameplay loop seamlessly.

-Setting

Ancient Egypt is a really cool place to explore and quest through. From the iconic pyramids to the Library of Alexandria, it is incredible to see famous ancient buildings brouight to life in a convincing manner. They sure did their homework when it comes to what life would have been like back then. You meet well known historical figures, help famous Egyptian "Gods" (or animals they worhipped as Gods), aide roman oracles, all kinds of historically interesting activities. There are tombs to explore, war elephants to kill, landmarks to search for "papyrus riddles"in, all while roman/greek/egyption cultures are clashing in the background. They nailed it here. (I will say the game misses the animus database of previous entries. I have hope this will be fixed with Discovery mode, which should come out soon (early 2018))

So, ya, hopefully this helps someone understand what the game is about and what makes it, in my eyes, so great. I have never made a steam review, but this game was so good it compelled me to.

Good job Ubi, this game is a gem.

If you do not care much about the story and tend to skip cut-scenes and dialogues, this is definitely your game.

126.1 hrs on record
Posted: July 27, 2020
Assassin's Creed: Origins


Origins is the first game after Ubisoft's soft-reboot of the franchise


Pros

- A huge and visually stunning map; the best I've seen (Aside from Odyssey)
- Dynamic combat which isn't as ability-focused as in Odyssey
- One of the best main characters in the series
- Parkour is intuitive and fun, especially in the forts
- Lots of stuff to go around and complete in Egypt
- Modern day story is finally back with a protagonist who is not a nameless drone

Cons:

- Can be grindy at times, but you won't have to do too much
- Pacing of the main story is jittery; the final part of the game has a large unspecified time skip
- Social stealth has sadly been removed, although the rest of the stealth is as fun as ever

Is it an RPG?

Yes, the introduction of levels and crafting mean that AC: Origins is very much an RPG; but these are still fun and engaging.


Verdict:
9/10

Peacebringer
181 products in account
0
2 people found this review helpful 0

Recommended
76.8 hrs on record
Posted: July 19, 2020
After having lost interest in Assassin's Creed after Black Flag, this game has renewed my interest in the franchise. I feel like the series had run a bit stale for a while and I think AC: Origins injected some much needed new life into the Assassin games.

I feel like it has gotten increasingly difficult for AAA games to really make a large open world a dense and fulfilling experience to explore. It seems like there has always been a drive to make bigger maps but not as big a drive to actually fill the maps with content. This game does a pretty good job without overwhelming the player either. In fact, large stretches of desert regions are free of side quests and encampments that the player can choose to explore, with varying degrees of reward for doing so. But even if one were to discount these regions, you are still left with an impressively large and diverse landscape.

I was skeptical at first of setting an open world game in a desert environment, but they really went above and beyond in capturing Egypt and making each region of the map feel unique, unlike previous installments where most areas were indistinguishable from one another with all their copy & pasted resources. They really put an extraordinary amount of effort into reconstructing ancient landmarks and wonders as they would have appeared in the decades leading up to the birth of the Roman Empire. Getting to interact with the likes of Cleopatra was certainly a surprise as well.

On a side note, I think its really cool that they added an educational "tour" mode where you can just walk around places like Alexandria and learn about it all. I don't think I've ever really seen AAA game do anything like that before.

Back on the subject of the game itself, I also thoroughly enjoyed the story of Bayek & Aya and their quest for revenge. I think their relationship was handled very well throughout the game without giving in to tropes too much. And it was equally interesting to see the origins of the Assassin's brotherhood to begin with, that basically being the premise of the game. There is a pretty large cast of characters you meet along the way, including many famous characters from that time period.

My only complaint with the story, and this is one of the drawbacks of the current popular open world game format, is that you can get so bogged down with side quests and exploring and a million other things that at times you kind of lose track of what's happening in the main story. It would be nice to have the main story arc be a little bit more involved with the game as a whole, as the bulk of the gameplay is in the side quests and exploration. And as good as some of the side quests are, it does get a little bit repeatitive to go into some encampment, rescue a prisoner, and then find out that they stole some scroll which is being kept in another encampent, and yatta yatta yatta. It's not really story so much as Bayek doing his job as Medjay. And that's all well and good and is enjoyable enough, I just think the game weighed too much of its gameplay on the side stuff compared to the main storyline.

Also, I suppose another complaint I would have is that the modern day story is completely forgettable, but its such a small part of the game, its easily overlooked.

Speaking of gameplay, no complaints what so ever. The combat is fantastic with a wide variety of weapons for different fighting styles but almost all of which very satisfying. If I'm being honest, out of many similar games, I think this has some of the best hack & slash style melee combat mechanics of any open world game I've played. It really puts the old AC games to shame. The closest comparison I would draw is Witcher 3, but this game's system is a little simpler. It still has the tried and true assassinate mechanics with the hidden blade and all that, but sometimes I just stuck to my varies bows, swords and spear. Skill tree was also cool and offered some interesting combo unlocks that added a fun RPG layer of progression to the game.

I told myself going in: "Okay, it's another Assassin's Creed game, which means it's way more content than what can hold your interest, so don't try to 100% complete it." Well, nearly 80 hours later during the unexpected sudden increase in free time during the Covid-19 pandemic, I ended up completing all the quests and locations, the gladiator challenges and the chariot races. And I thoroughly enjoyed it.

By the way, if you don't want to bother with the old AC games, which are probably getting a bit dated now, this is a perfectly good game to start from, since in a sense, this is really starting from the beginning. And the Modern Day story arc is irrelevant enough to previous titles that you aren't missing much plot there either.

Basically, if you are a fan of open world games with melee combat I highly recommend AC: Origins! And on top of that, AC franchise aside, I can't think of another video game that really brings Ancient Egypt to life in the way that this game does.

Recommended
123.7 hrs on record
Posted: January 4, 2020
Came to AC:Origins after a recent completionist run of AC:Odyssey figuring it would just be more of the same, and boy was I wrong! I really liked Odyssey, but for me (this is subjective, of course), AC:Origins was far superior in almost every way, with only a few exceptions. The experience was much more focused, with the story, quests and the environment feeling far more hand crafted and organic overall. The tombs, quests and geography had much more variety and uniqueness when comparing with Odyssey. I also generally preferred the sound design, music, and look of the world in Origins. The more somber tone of the music and environmental color palette were spot on, capturing the atmosphere of ancient Egypt well.

AC:Odyssey was certainly fun, but it suffered somewhat from quantity over quality, where the environment and quests had a bit too much repetitious generic design. However, a few aspects of Odyssey were certainly better, or at least improved over Origins. The combat and character control were much smoother and less janky than Origins. There's a manual save system allowing multiple saves (Origins has an auto-save system). The skill tree and upgrade system in Odyssey were also a lot better and more interesting. And finally, although I found I liked the look & design of the world in Origins better, you have to give Odyssey the edge for overall graphical fidelity, which was just fantastic.

In any case, both are really nice games. Which one you prefer may come down to the kind of game experience you like. Origins is more of a focused "play an existing character's story" approach, whereas Odyssey is more open ended. For me though, the choice is easy, hands down it goes to AC:Origins.

SkilliChilli
106 products in account

3 people found this review helpful 0

Recommended
559.5 hrs on record
Posted: July 27, 2018
Got the Gold Edition on sale for $65, so when reading keep in mind that I definitely would NOT pay full price for this game and its DLCs.

After over 200 hours of active play, I can say that this AC game is like no others in the series. Completely changed equipment system, upgrade system, new abilities, drastically redesigned open combat, and so much more, I've managed to boil it all down to some pros and cons.

Pros

Awesome revamped combat system
Interesting and compelling story
Reasonably done loot/equipment system
Incredible amounts of quests and locations to complete. After having completed both the main story and the dlcs, I'm still at least a couple dozen hours from completing every location in the world.
Truly well done quests and locations. Some are challenging. Others frustrating. Some are emotionally draining gut punches (I'm talking about Hulk-smashing-Loki-like-a-rag-doll kind of hits here). This game has some of the best quests/memories I've seen in the entire franchise.
Thoughtful and believable backstory to the universe that we know and love
New and unique abilities and skills, mostly fitting with the time period
Hacking the Animus! There's a reasonable array of features that you can alter in order to play the game in a different/unique way. Not as extensive or as many features that you can edit as you might wish, but enough that you can have fun with them and get at least another few hours of gameplay out of them.
Fun way of pseudo multiplayer, by way of having pictures be broadcast to the internet, as well as allowing other players to "avenge" and being able to "avenge" your death and the deaths of others respectively.

Cons

Hidden blade does not auto-kill when fully upgraded in main game
Stealth system is poorly done with no skills increasing it, worthwhile incentives rewarding it, or otherwise encouraging stealth and strategy other than not being mobbed by dozens of enemies in enemy laden areas
NO MEMORY REPLAY! You would think that the game franchise whose biggest, most iconic feature is to allow players to replay quests they enjoy as many times as they want, would keep that feature in their newest game. Nope. They added new game plus recently, but still no replaying individual memories/quests that you enjoy. While better than nothing, I don't want to have to grind through the first third of the game again before getting to the really cool/interesting/fun quests.
No way to earn helix credits in game. While in other games the helix credits just made life easier, here they do that and unlock legendary equipment that is impossible to find elsewhere. If you're going to do the second part, at least give us missions/challenges/nigh-impossible goals that will allow the dedicated and/or cheap players to unlock everything without spending ridiculous amounts of money for a game we already bloody bought.

Summary
If you can get it on sale, or the entire game + DLCs for 50% off or more, I would definitely reccomend it. Compared with others in the franchise, it's truly amazing and an improvement in a wide array of areas. The biggest thing for me, is the lack of ability to replay missions/quests/memories over again without grinding through the game again. If they added/fixed that one problem, I'd be willing to bump my reccomendation up to it being worthwhile to buy with just 20-25% off.

Overall, a solid 8.4/10, with points taken off for all of the above reasons. If the biggest issues were fixed (memory replay and helix credits) then I'd give it a 9.5/10 as it really is just that good, and just that much fun.

Recommended
235.8 hrs on record
Posted: January 4, 2018
Assassins creed origins is a great game.

World:
This game is in Egypt while the brother of Cleopatra is farao, it's open world and there is much to do.

Details:
The game is historical accurate, except roman soldiers loadout... But give the devs some artistic freedom.

Gameplay:
It's mechanics are good, far LOS because the rendering is amazingly done. The controls can be a bit difficult at first, but it won't take long to master them. The level up and upgrade system is great in my opinion. While you're getting to the maximum level, you'll need to spend points carefully on upgrades to suit your playstyle.

Lore, quest and story:
The storyline is good, I'm not going to spoil it. The quests can be redundant and boring, but there are enough quests. The lore is just the history of the old Egypt and the background of Bayek, so not much to do wrong there.

Combat:
The combat is really refreshing, normally the assassins creed games are mostly focussed on stealth. This game gives you the choice: stealth or open combat. The weapon selection is great, although the power creep of some weapons kills the diversity.

Minigames:
There are two types of minigames: arena and chariotrace. Arena is quiet funny and challenging to do, but I dislike the chariotraces... The chariotraces are insanely difficult to do and just like arena there is a more difficult challenge to play.

Additional:
The devs try to keep the game alive and I am very thankful for that, but I am a little bit twisted inside about microtransactions... In free to play games I do not mind microtransactions, but when I payed good money for a game and they still ask for more money outside of dlcs I feel my blood starting to boil...

Conclusion:
This game deserves a 9.5/10, but microtransactions and the chariots brought it down to 8.5 in my opinion...
So my final review is 8.5/10 for Assassins creed origins.

Recommended
22.1 hrs on record
Posted: December 31, 2017
I've gone back and forth numerous times on how to review Assassin's Creed: Origins. On one hand, when it works, it's an excellent game, possibly the best in the series. This despite being a drastic deviation from the "classic" Assassin's Creed formula, which had honestly become quite stale in recent years.

Changing the game to be more of an open world light RPG with loot mechanics ended up being a really good idea, because the gameplay feels fresh again, while still maintaining some of that Assassin's Creed feel. There's a buttload of content, both side missions and main missions, and especially the side missions are really imaginative, fun and varied.

The world is also really good. It looks gorgeous and is full of interesting stuff to explore and just look at. Heck, they're patching in a non-combat mode where you can just casually explore the world for historical purposes, and that kinda tells you all you need to know. To me, the world alone is almost worth the purchase.

All that being said, the PC version is not amazing. It's got a ton of different settings and options you can tweak, but none that solve the real problems the version has. I first started playing on a Core I5-4670K system and the game ran like a turd. Every time I got into a city, the framerate would plummet to the low 20s or even below, and frankly that's unacceptable. But hey, you can always upgrade your system, right? Well, now I'm running a Core I7-8700 with a GTX 1080 and the fastest consumer SSD you can buy, and the game STILL runs poorly! Not as poorly as before, because now my CPU doesn't always hit 100% usage, but instead hovers around 91-93% most of the time. The game stutters, the framerate fluctuates wildly and occasionally this will actively impact gameplay, because the combat is fast and reaction based and when your framerate is pogoing between 20 and 60, that's not a great combination.

So, do I give the game a thumbs down because performance this poor (especially performance that's apparently caused by DRM run rampant) is not acceptable and publishers need to learn that they can't dump on paying customers in an effort to protect their bottom lines? Or do I give the game a thumbs up, because hidden under those technical problems and bad management decisions is one of the best games of 2017? I guess I'd rather give a thumbs up to a creative team that did amazing work than a thumbs down to a management team who need to pull their heads out of whatever orifices they're stuck in.

SEOAH
139 products in account

2 people found this review helpful 0

Recommended
44.9 hrs on record
Posted: December 5, 2017
I have an average game completion rate of 17% on Steam. That's actually quite embarrassing, but I mention it only because I just completed Assassin's Creed Origins. It's rare for me to really finish a single player game. For whatever reason, I tend to get into games like this early on, but when the mid-game grind starts rolling in I typically lose interest.

That wasn't so much the case with this game. I played about 37 hours before rolling the credits. That is uncharacteristic of me, which should speak to the quality of this game. Taking a year off in the development cycle seemed to pay dividends to Ubisoft here. I have not experienced such a vibrant open world in a game for some time. In fact, the world they have created here is easily in league with the likes of Skyrim and The Witcher 3, if not better. That's not to say the story or game mechanics are superior, rather it's just a comment on the quality of the open world. Ancient Egypt feels alive, atmospheric, and it begs to be explored. The Assassin's Creed style of traversal, with all its climbing and free running, lends itself well to the setting. Whether you love or hate the franchise, I don't think there is really any denying that the game environment here is a huge win.

As for the combat, I found it almost as satisfying as the exploration. I found myself being tempted to engage entire camps of enemies at times, rather than cautiously picking at the weak spots of an enemy outpost slowly and methodically, as the series namesake would suggest. Taking a stealthy approach was just as satisfying though, which I felt kept the game very fresh from a combat perspective. The combat itself is akin to a faster paced Dark Souls style, though not quite as deep. You'll face enemies with different capabilities and you'll need to be adaptable to succeed. At times, the game will force you to engage various groups of enemies or bosses in combat without a reasonable option of taking a stealthy approach. Other times, you may find yourself pouncing on a major enemy from the shadows, swiftly eliminating the threat while the only danger is being seen. The choice is really yours, and being able to play most of the encounters either way kept things interesting for me.

Then we come to the story. Here's where I have some mixed feelings. Because of the adoption of RPG elements, I found the urgency of some of the major story elements to be rather unbelievable. What I mean is that you'll be hot on the heels of an enemy who has done you an injustice, your character seething for revenge. A near miss, and he escapes. But there's a lead - he's gone to a town somewhere across the map and you'll need to go scout the area to try and find him. Thus one quest is complete, and you're issued the next quest in the chain. However, the next quest is above your suggested level, and suddenly all the baddies in his entourage are a few levels higher. They're firmly out of your reach now, as you can only effectively take out enemies about 2 levels above your current level. You may not even be able to assassinate enemies, rather you'll perform a "stealth attack," which takes a large portion of their health but they'll still react and potentially alert the rest of the camp. Granted, you may not want to rush through the story and perhaps you'll enjoy this pacing. I found myself wanting to know what would happen next, and felt disappointed when I had to open my map and search for adequately leveled quests to take on until I caught up enough in levels. This happened on numerous occasions. With that being said, many of the side quests lead to great rewards, and are great experiences in and of themselves. They tried to take some influence here from The Witcher 3, and it's made the overall experience much better. The stories still aren't nearly as good as The Witcher 3, but that's setting the bar extremely high. Let's just say you won't be bored out of your mind with side quests, and leave it at that.

Now, I purchased this game on the PC rather than console for a higher framerate and some better effects. I knew that the PC version was reported to have issues, and I experienced first hand that it does. It took me quite a while to figure out that the game is completely incompatible with surround sound options enabled on my Logitech G933 headset. By opening the Logitech Gaming Software application and setting it to stereo sound only, the problem was solved. It took me quite a while to find that solution though. I did experience some random bugs throughout my 37 hours, but nothing game breaking. I would expect Ubisoft to fix these issues eventually, but if given the choice again I would still stick with the PC version. I played it with both a Playstation 4 controller and an Xbox One controller, and found both these options to be superior to the keyboard and mouse. The combat was much more satisfying and movement felt more precise.

As an aside, I feel the need to mention the micro-transactions. I am upset to see the gaming industry gravitate so heavily towards liberal use of micro-transactions in fully pay to play titles, especially at the premium price point. I will say that in this particular case, it seems to be a very fair system. The real temptation would be to purchase crafting materials in order to avoid the mindless grinding of "hunting animals" in the game. To max out your gear, you'll spend a considerable amount of time fighting wildlife. It's not the most exciting thing in the world, and the temptation to skip some of that is great. Otherwise, the thing you should know is that there is no actual armor in the game. You'll use crafting materials to give yourself a flat increase to various stats, such as ranged damage, melee damage, health, carrying capacity for arrows, etc. None of these "items" shown on the inventory menu have any in-game appearance. Your weapon will have its own appearance, but your "armor" provides stats and your "outfit" provides an appearance. You don't really earn many outfits through simply questing, and you may get very bored of the way you look when your appearance doesn't change throughout the entire game. There's another temptation to succumb to the micro-transactions. The game balances this somewhat with a daily quest system which has the chance of rewarding random legendary items, though they're usually swords. Other high level quests give you certain outfits which are pretty cool as well, but while you're going through the main story of the game just be aware that you won't be able to access these yet. Just something to think about.

For my final thoughts, I will say that I do highly recommend this game. It's not "the complete package" in the way that games like The Witcher 3 or Breath of the Wild were. By this, I mean this game isn't really changing the industry and it doesn't hit the nail on the head in every category. It has an extremely rich and vibrant open world that feels alive and worth exploring. It has combat and stealth elements that entertain throughout. It has a story that is worth playing through and side quests which are usually pretty enjoyable. The game lacks character development for most characters aside from the main protagonist, who also isn't terribly interesting. I didn't really mind though, because I wasn't expecting this to be truly epic when it came to the story. With all this being considered, I would say it's worth paying full price and you should experience it. Be warned, it gets off to a somewhat slow start. Push through it, give it an honest 6 hours or so to start, and I believe the vast majority of you will find some enjoyment in it.

That's my two cents, I hope it helps someone make the decision. Thanks for reading.

Recommended
157.5 hrs on record
Posted: November 24, 2017
UBisofts decision to take a one year break from the yearly releases of an Assassin's Creed game was a wise decision. The yearly releases were taking a toll on the game making every game seem way too similar and also causing fatique among the fanbase.
Flash forward to 2017 and the release of Assassin's Creed Origins and we see a very different but also very familiar game like its predecessors. Much of the annoying tropes (e.g. infiltrate and eavesdrop or follow a suspect etc) of the game have been removed and new gameplay mechanics have been introduced. But even with these changes it hasn't altered or changed the very distinct 'flavor' of the Assassin's Creed world.

The game is now a huge open world divided up into provinces and you're free to roam anywhere in the world once you finish the initial inroduction of the game. The game for better or worse has become a RPG, introducing experience points and skill points used to access a 'Skill Tree' system to further improve your characters abilities. Hundreds of quests not related to the main story are also a new part of the game helping you to gain experience points but also helping to flesh out ancient Egypt and make it feel more alive.
The fighting system has also been totally overhauled. Gone are the days when you could counter almost every attack and with very little effort instantly kill your opponent. The new fighting system is much more involved making you block or dodge out of the way of your attacker and than counter attack. Although the combat can be more frantic it makes for a heart pumping and rewarding affair.
The beauty of the world is truly something to be seen. This is one of those games you use to show off your new graphics card! The Assassin's Creed series has always been known for the incredible worlds that have been realized and Assassin's Creed Origins has raised that bar. The graphics quality are simply stellar and the level of detail is mind blowing. Especially when many people who play the game may never see half of what is in this world!
The story is done well and the protaganist 'Bayek' is a likable and believable person in the world. Dealing with a personal tragedy only to unearth an incredible conspiracy.,
Assassin's Creed Origins is not only the tellings of the beginnings of the Assassin's Order but also serves as a solid foundation for future games.

Edit January 2018:
It's a decent game. Still laggy af but the beauty of the game kinda makes it worth the purchase on sale.

Gameplay: So-so, a step up from previous AC's lackluster combat and weapon system. Stealth option are much more viable and enjoyable overall. The world is expansive, beautiful, well-crafted. (Almost) Every frame is a picture. Just that there's way too much clutters on UI, but if you turn off UI completely then it lacks specific features needed: For example, there's always a giant "Press () to call Senu" when objective is nearby. It's completely unnecessary and should be optional, considering how quest log gave actual hint on how to find target. Yes, you can turn call senu off by turning hud to minimal, but then the quest log hint will also be gone.

Ubisoft please make UI customizable.

tldr:
6/10 for gameplay+story as is.
8/10 if you want to enjoy the story and the beautifully-crafted world and willing to compromise to use trainers to soften the grind (or skip it completely).

Not Recommended
65.2 hrs on record
Posted: May 19, 2018
EDIT: DO NOT BUY AS OF RIGHT NOW. GAME CRASHING CONSTANTLY FOR SEVERAL PEOPLE. WAIT UNTIL GAME IS FIXED.

ORIGINAL REVIEW BELOW (THUMBS UP):

Great game. Still haven't finished it yet.

That being said, take its historical accuracy with a grain of salt. My only problem is the "historical" marketing pitch.

As in other AC games, there are obviously artistic liberties and fictions to make the story work. Specifically, there are elements of fantasy in the characters, weapons, magic, etc. as in other AC games. And, as in other AC games, many of the historical settings have elements of fantasy/fiction to make the story work.

If someone told you to get this game for your kid or something to learn history, don't. If someone told you you could learn a lot about ancient egypt, wrong. The game is obviously trying to push a present-day political message, and prioritizes this over portraying a more historically accurate egyptian cultural setting. Most notably, the game attempts to make many of the problems about modern notions of race in the following ways:
1) The game portrays pretty much all the Ptolemic Greeks as pasty, pasty white. They sort of white-washed it for lack of a better term. In reality, only Northern Greeks were thought to have light skin. Greeks that would have been living in Egypt at the time would have had a much darker complexion.
2) The first point normally wouldn't have been noticable. But, the game portrays the primary issues as being ones of skin color, where the Greek regime attempts to segregate and oppress the black egyptians (at one point a priest tells you that all the problems are racial, and tells you to "just look at your skin, Siwan"). In reality, historical evidence indicates the ancient Greeks/Romans did not use skin color as a justification for slavery. Additionally, evidence inidicates that Greek/Roman society was not segregated, ever, by skin color. In fact, parts of the empire that were in modern Africa were considered 100% Greek, and black citizens were considered completely Greek, while Northern Gauls from Germany/Russia and Nordic peoples were considered barbarians. The aryan barbarians were likely the largest slave pool for the Ancient Greeks.
3) The game, as stated above, attempts to make skin color an issue when it was not at the time. The term "Ethiopia" roughly translates to sun-burnt. The textual evidence we have indicates that this was not an insult. Thus, "Ethiopians" are thought to have been regarded simply as permanently sun-burnt Greeks.
4) The game has Greeks calling Egyptians "barbarians." The overwhelming majority of Greek textual references to the word "barbarian" were in the context of Eastern Slavs and Norther Gauls, not Egyptians. In fact, Egyptians at the time were regarded as Greek citizens in many parts of Egypt.
5) The game portrays Greece as imposing its culture on Egypt in an attempt to erase Egyptian culture. While the Greeks/Macedonians did conquer Egypt, historians to this day tend to agree that Greek culture was heavily influenced by Egyptian culture. Greek leadership embraced Egyptian culture, many even electing to be mummified, and some worshipping Egyptian gods.
6) Cleopatra is all jacked up.
7) The game appropriated subsaharan African culture and inserted to Egyptian culture. Bayek's Siwan gladiator friend obviously was meant to portray subsaharan African people, as there is little to no evidence indicating that any Egyptians dressed, pierced, or scarred their body like that.
8) Many of these issues are also present in the "museum" mode that was meant as a learning tool. In fact, Ubisoft even disclosed publicly that they changed some things in the learning mode to be more inclusive/politically correct at the expense of history.
As far as the monuments, map, cities, atmosphere, they did a great job. The skin color of the Egyptians was fine in my opinion, as no historian really knows from text what Egyptians looked like skin-wise. All that is largely agreed upon is that they were at least as dark as, and probably much darker than Souther Greeks. Anyway, the Egyptians seem to have a more diverse range of skin tones in the game. Thus, anyone complaining the Egyptians in the game are "too black" should probably do some more research.

I don't care about politics, and the message the game pushes (e.g. white people oppressing black people in the modern sense and it needs to be fought against; The protagonist should always fight to live in harmony and peace) isn't a bad one in my opinion. But, do note that the game sacrifices A LOT of history to push this message. As an Egypt-lover, this was somewhat off putting.

Summary:

Pros:
Awesome game.
Buy it if you love RPG's, Witcher 3, AC, open world games.
It's worth the price for once Ubisoft.
Cons:
Dishonest marketing as a "historical" game when the devs have openly come out about sacrificing historical accuracy for inclusivity.
Don't buy for any historical value.

Assassin's Creed Origins is an open world RPG set in ancient Egypt. Like nearly every AAA game, Origins is being sold for 60 euros, but is it worth it? Let's find out.

The good, the bad, and the mixed

THE GOOD

-Egypt is an interesting setting for an open world game.

-There's lots of stuff to do. Every area has a bunch of side quests, animals to hunt, loot to find, etc. And of course there's the main quest.

-The story is somewhat interesting.

-Gear and abilities work well.

-Mounts are OP. Need to kill a pharaoh? Just run over him with a horse. Who needs assassins?

THE BAD

-The game sometimes crashes for no reason or gets stuck in loading screens. CPU usage is also off the charts. This is what happens when you pile DRM on top of DRM.

-Microtransactions in a 60 â‚¬ singleplayer game. Well, at least the game's true ending isn't locked behind a paywall. (I'm looking at you, Warner Brothers)

THE MIXED

-The combat is a bit messy but not too annoying.

Conclusion

It's best to buy it during a sale. I myself paid the full price of 60â‚¬ for the non-DLC edition and I think it's a bit too high due to the DRM mess and such. This is my first Assassin's Creed though so I don't know how good it is when compared to the earlier titles.

Recommended
63.8 hrs on record
Posted: February 16, 2019
This one is probably the best entry in the Assassin's Creed franchise. The new combat system feels good and so does the new RPG-like system. The open world is simply amazing with many secrets to explore. This entry also shows us the beginning of the Creed.

Story and gameplay
You play as Bayek, a medjay from acient egypt. After a secret cult kills your son, you go on a quest to kill every single one of it's members. To do so, you'll travel through Egypt (yes, all of it, the map is that big) and meet some known names such as Cleopatra and Julius Caesar.

This game also marks the first time that heavy RPG-like elements are introduced. Your character (Bayek) as a level that goes up when you gain XP (duh). Main and side quests have a recommend level for you to complete them, you can try and go underlevel but it will be tougher than normal. There are also various types of weapons to buy and discover. From regular swords, to daggers and spears; from a regular hunting bow, to a super fast light bow; each weapon as it's own benefits and drawbacks.

Weapons of the same type vary between them in rarity, from common to legendary. The higher the rarity the better that weapon will be. Epic weapons and above come with special perks that might set your weapon permanently on fire, or might apply poison to your enemies as you hit them.

Finally, you have abilities that you can equip. There are 8 slots, 4 melee abilities and other 4 ranged. You can unlock abilities with ability points that you will gain as you level up, or when you complete secret locations on the map.

Veredict
Assassin's Creed Origins is, in my opinion, the best of the Assassin's Creed so far (even after Odyssey and Valhalla release). The open world feels alive and it's graphically incredible. The RPG-like elements are done well and the game doesn't feel to grindy.
I definitely recommend buying this game whether you are or not a big fan of the Assassin's Creed franchise.

11/10 game, would get one shot by a random snake again.

Recommended
58.9 hrs on record
Posted: January 9, 2019
I picked up this game during the 2018 Winter Sale for like 20 bucks. So far, it seems to be a pretty great experience overall. The story is interesting, the main characters aren't bland, and the side quests and other things happening in the world tie into the main story quite nicely.

As for the gameplay, it's more like The Witcher than it is like Assassin's Creed. Classic stealth is still an option of course, but combat is more varied and dynamic than ever which I think is a good thing for this series and was a breath of fresh air after 10 previous games struggling to have engrossing combat. The game is a bit grindy as other people have said, and you pretty much have no choice but to do side quests and some of the busywork that Ubisoft is famous for to progress through the main story. Which isn't a terrible thing I suppose as the gameplay, while repetitive, is fun in and of itself.

Graphics are beautiful, especially when the settings are maxed out in 4K HDR, although most people will struggle to maintain a playable framerate under those circumstances. You can really tell the developers had a good time making this world and the extra year of polish really shows. It runs pretty well for me; it doesn't scream of terrible optimization although it could be better. If you have a low end PC you will struggle though as this game is very CPU intensive so keep that in mind.

Overall 8/10
+Good Story and Character Development
+Beautiful visuals
+Immersive world and soundtrack
+Fun combat and RPG mechanics

-Somewhat poor optimization (although I am not affected much by it)
-Repetitive and grindy at times
-Uplay is a requirement

SPECS:
i7 4770k @ 4.2
16GB DDR3 1866
MSI GTX 1080 Gaming X

Recommended
61.9 hrs on record
Posted: January 14, 2018
Following the decline of the Assassin's Creed franchise, I'm glad Ubisoft made the decision to build this game from scratch. The overall gameplay feels fresh yet retains the essence of an Assassin's creed game.

STORY: Storywise, I have no complaints, I won't say it is better than some of the other successful AC titles, but it is good nonetheless.

COMBAT: The combat here is my favourite part of the game so far. Gone are the days of just an attack/parry button, the new combat controls make fights more challenging, yet satisfying.

GAMEPLAY: This game takes on the more RPG, open world game approach, with countless side quest and places to explore. Although the sidequest may be a little tedious to complete sometimes, every one of them is different and unique. There is plenty to do around the map of Egypt, from exploring tombs to hunting animals, to saving villagers from bandits. The developers really added lots of detail to make Egypt lively and immersive. Another thing to add is that events and community challenges such as the Trial of the Gods, offers more content to players who have already completed the main storyline.

GRAPHICS Nothing much to say here, the graphics is amazing. Egypt is vibrant and beautiful.

PERFORMANCE On my setup with a gtx1060 and a 4th Generation i5 cpu, the game runs smooth, averaging at around 60fps. In towns, it drops to around 40fps, which is still playable. However, if you CPU isnt powerful enough, you may encounter an issue where NPCs take awhile to render. Resulting in faceless mannequins, or clay model looking figures in place of the NPCs. There is a picture in this thread [forums.ubi.com] otherwise, there should not be any issue that might make this game unplayable.

Overall, this is a great game, and i would definately recommend it.

Recommended
91.3 hrs on record
Posted: November 5, 2017
It feels like they realized their own mistakes with the latest games before Origins. The itemhunt/collection is severely tuned down and they seem to have put thought behind each collection and area. The fact the game after all these hours reminds me of Zelda: Breath of the Wild and Witcher says a lot about how they taken influences from other games and tried to revamp Assassins Creed a little bit.

The combat is completely different from previous games and it is much better, it's fun and requires more active participation than previous games, less button spamming and more planned attacks. Sometimes a little too easy and sometimes unforgiving. For those looking for a challenge, do play on hard difficulty.

It's a fresh new start to the series and I hope they can continue with future AC games in the Style of Origins, rather than going back to Unity, Liberation or Black Flag games. AC: Origins was a blast to play from first minute to the last achievement and that is coming from someone that isn't a diehard fan of the AC games lately, I did not 100% Unity cause the collection and gameplay simply wasn't that fun. I never fancied Black Flag that much, but I loved liberation.

If you enjoy games like BOTW and Witcher, AC: Origins is right down your ally. There has been claims of poor performance, stuttering and high CPU usage. I cannot comment on that since it ran fine for me from start to finish on a 970 GTX.

This is BOTW with fancier graphics and a more signficiant story. Speaking of the Story it makes sense, it engages and holds quite a few surprises, but it never breaks away from AC logic and honestly it was a great Origin-story. The "Secret of the first pyramid" DLC was however a let down and completed in 15 minutes. It's a nice addition, but it doesn't stand out from any other quest.

My favorite games this year has been BOTW and Hat in Time, but I do believe Assassins Creed Origins is going to have to join them. It is honestly a relief that Origins is what it is. It's a breath of fresh air the series needed.

Recommended
155.0 hrs on record
Posted: November 4, 2017
I've been sitting a while on this one, not knowing if I want to review it or not, I just couldn't settle for a good enough reason or reasons to give this game a proper 'yes' or a strong 'no'. I don't hate it, but I don't love it either, it has it's issues, some things feel good but others don't. This game is like a gray puddle, if you will.

It has a lot of decent content, it definitely isn't a great game, it has some flaws, but I don't dislike it, I think I like it.

The game has a HUGE world map, and it is as diverse as it is beautiful. I found myself wondering around for many hours at the beggining of the game, and I still do it, now and then, I just call my trusted steed, and ride slowly into the sunset.

Taking on the gorgeous surroundings, the deserts, cities, villages, of the ancient Egypt.

Ubisoft did an excellent job making the map, the world, the feel of it is just as good as one could expect. I for one, who loves history, I couldn't but almost find myself with tears in my eyes at the first sight of Alexandria, Memphis and the Pyramids. It shows that extra year of development the game had. It really does.

THE STORY, it is decent, not something that has not been told before in an Assassin's Creed game, it is one of revenge, but stands out from the others, it has a unique feel to it, as it is empowered by Bayek, who is alomst a force of nature, relentless, ruthless, and his anger towards the ones that wronged him may seem madness, yet one could only agree with it, as we all have a bit of madness in there. He is a husband, to a woman as driven and strong willed as he is. Both taking on the same quest to find the one responsible for their loss. Both sharing the same path, as a wife and husband should. Both Bayek and Aya, are in my eyes probably the best main characters in a Assassin's Creed game since Ezio's trilogy.

I'd like to add that I haven't finished the main story yet. I'm close to doing it though, but I take my time with it.

Along with the main quests, I found some of the side quest really well written, some not so much, but they weren't bad.
There are plenty of them, and if that is not enough there are a bunch of question marks on the map that will reveal forts, camps, bandit camps, treasure, tombs and hunting grounds. There are a lot of things to do.

THE COMBAT AND STEALTH, well I feel both good and bad about those two, as they both have good moments and bad ones.

The combat it is If I dare say, like in the Dark Souls games, also taking inspiration from the Witcher. To me it feels more Dark Souls than Witcher, but it is nothing near as good or polished, But you get used to it pretty quick. It may feel like a bad thing for some and that the way it has been till now was perfect, it wasn't. It felt so damn stupid before, as you could clear a whole city of guards just by waiting for one to attack so that you counter and kill all that was there to be killed. This feels much better, even with all the issues it has.

Stealh, is to easy, I play the game on Hard, and it just doesn't feel good enough, I mean, you simply just whistle from a bush and wait for the enemy to approach then you go in for the kill, similar to Black Flag, in many ways it just doesn't have the same think before you act, Syndicate had to a somewhat degree. In Origins, it just feels way to easy.
I got the achivement which required to kill 10 enemies on a row without being detected, in a camp in an area above my level without even breaking a sweet, early in the game. That just felt...wrong, I'm not that good, am I ?

PERFORMANCE, I did not encounter any big FPS drops or STUTTERS in the game, I have around 55-60 outside the big cities, and 30-45 in them, Alexandria just takes a giant crap on my 1070, literally. :).
Though Ubisoft says it's not because of the anti-crack thing the game has, which makes the CPU go nuts, I don't think a great deal about it, I could say I don't care...but I probably do, as I hate MY FPS BEING STUCK AT 30. I just look at that FPS counter and...Ah ! You don't want to know...
I almost didn't address this issue in my review because it didn't make the game unplayble, I expected it to have a bad optimisation...

Overall, Assassin's Creed Origins, It's a good game, I enjoyed playing and I think I will keep on enjoing it.
I recommend it to some people, mostly those that love the Assassin's Creed games, that played since Altair and didn't stop at the mess that was Unity and kept hoping for a good game, this is a decent one.
But to the rest, those that are 'fresh' to it or those that played the most recent ones, if you like the game from watching youtube gameplays or want to try it just because you heard it to be good from friends, buy it, but you would also like to consider buying during a sale.

I have to say the same for those wondering about the DLCs, It is not gonna be The Witcher 3 kinda ones, don't expect any 30hrs content, it's not going to happen, if you don't dream of that, good, I don't either. If it does happen. well, f*** me, I was wrong.

Recommended
42.8 hrs on record
Posted: November 3, 2017
Assassins Creed was never my favorite series. I far favored games like Fallout, Skyrim, and others. It was such a shame too because they had such promise. The idea of assassins in historical times was always one that would excite me, but these were undercut with poor, predictable stories, glitchy mechanics and long swathes of boring missions. Origins changes all of this. The story captures attention immediately, drawing sympathy for Bayek and setting up the game like never before. Like previous Assassins Creeds, it captures all the historical aspects and events from the time period but makes them personal and causes deep reflection. The mechanics are near perfect. Your character can tell when you want to jump off a ledge, climb up a building, or fall from a great height. Unlike previous games where you could get stuck on a 2 foot ledge unable to make your character jump off, Origins delivers the perfect balance between fast running along rooftops without getting stuck and sneaky walking without accidentally falling off ledges. Lastly: the missions. Obviously with a game the size of this, not all missions can be fun and unique, but Origins comes very close. There are small follow missions now, instead of 20 minute long times where you just walk through a town following two people. Pretty much every other mission is unique in some way (except for Assassination missions, but those are more fun and challenging than unique). I also love the connection between magic and science, with curses and gods being mentioned often but then turning out to be something mundane. Overall I would give a 10/10, and it is possibly the best game I have ever played.
